### 1
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/13/financing-energy-infrastructure-from-abroad-opportunities-available-in-belt-and-road-initiative-bri-and-global-gateway-initiative-ggi
TITLE: Financing Energy infrastructure from abroad: opportunities available in Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and Global Gateway Initiative (GGI) â€“ IFA

An apparent mismatch between energy need and the capacity to invest in energy production is requiring Ethiopia to look into alternative finances available from Europe and China. The rapid rise of population accompanied by rapid urbanization and economic growth, Ethiopia needs a rapid growth in energy production proportional to its economy, which by itself hinges on the financial capability of the state.Â The key hindrances of Ethiopia from producing adequate energy include:
Financial gap: according to UNECA data, Africa needs $170 billion annually to satisfy its infrastructure need, one of which being electric grid installation. Ethiopia also share the same challenge and lacks adequate finance to exploit all its potentials.
Technological gap: generating energy either from water, wind, sunlight, nuclear, or fossil fuel required technological endowment. In the past two decades, in fact, Ethiopia has been tapping into the technology of hydropower dam construction and power generation. But diversifying energy sources and improving the pace of the rate of growth in technological endowment is still a challenge to Ethiopia.
Other challenges: though finance and technology are important ingredients, issues related to policy coordination and dealing with instability and maladministration are also critical factors in limiting the nation from investing in energy production and distribution.
The external financial opportunities made available by China and the European Union are worth mentioning here in order to analyze their role in filling the financial gap Ethiopia is now experiencing.
Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
BRI was initiated with the aim to connect Chinese economy with the Eurasia landmass and trans-oceanic maritime space all over the world. Africa also benefitted from BRI though the primary targets of Chinese investment through BRI were Europe and Asia. China financed the construction of the Djibouti-Addis Ababa railway line as well as other projects in Kenya and Nigeria. The promise to finance more projects finally halted after the COVID pandemic, which marked the beginning of the decline in the flow of infrastructure finance from China into Africa.
In the post-COVID era, China announced another package of infrastructure finance to Africa. Xi Jinping made it clear on September 5, 2024 at the FOCAC summit that â€œthe Chinese government will provide RMB 360 billion [$50 billion] of financial support through the next three years.â€
[1]
From out of the total sum of finance, RMB 210 billion will be distributed under a credit line; RMB 80 billion will be an assistance fund for Africa in different forms and at least RMB 70 billion an investment fund for Chinese companies in Africa.
The key challenge in tapping into the Chinese finance include, first, the beneficiary nation has to adhere to the policy imperatives of China. Embracing â€˜one Chinaâ€™ policy is the primary policy expectation if any state aspires to get finance. The second challenge may happen as a result of the source of finance, which is the Chinese state. This implies to the necessity of conducting state-to-state negotiation with little or no space for the private financing enterprises. Third, the issue of debt management is another critical factor in shaping the future of financial interaction between Ethiopia and China. Much of the money gained from China since the beginning of BRI through commercial loan arrangement are either matured or are beyond the capacity of Ethiopia to pay back the accumulated debt. This necessitates the prolonged negotiation for debt restructuring, which tarnish future efforts to request more finance for new projects.
Global Gateway Initiative (GGI)
European Union has a tradition of introducing new budgetary programs, called a Multiannual Indicative Program (MIP), every seven years. For the period 2021 to 2027, EU has allocated â‚¬300 billion for a program called Global Gateway Initiative. It is largely an infrastructure development program intended to be invested in countries close to Europe geographically or in terms of interest. Half of the money, which is â‚¬150 billion, was promised to disburse to infrastructure developments in Africa. The focus of GGI support and investment include infrastructure projects like high speed road and railway line, energy transition, and digital connectivity. It seems that EU stood behind Africaâ€™s interest to connect African capitals through modern infrastructure. The problem, however, is the value attached to the Initiative, which is beyond the reach of most African nations. EU associated the GGI with democracy, good governance, equal partnership, green and clean energy, and security partnership.Â  To benefit from GGI, African nations should have to align themselves with the values set out by EU.
The implementation of the GGI is not free from limitations however. Although a lot has been promised at the inception of the Initiative, like to support more than nine trans-boundary road and railway projects to connect East and West Africa and North and South Africa, there is no significant progress in a matter of five years. The other challenge is the lack of transparency from the side of EU either for its priority lists for the beneficiary project or for the project to be financed by GGI. From the limited investments under the umbrella of GGI in Africa, one can see that the interest of EU goes more to energy transition, whereas connecting African capitals is a top priority for Africa, as clearly stipulated in Agenda 2063 vision of AU. Integrating GGI with the values set by EU is also another challenge for Africa since they are largely beyond reach.
Way forward
Strengthening domestic capacity
:Â  the reliable source of finance for any nation is its own economy. The same is also true for Ethiopia. As it has been observed in the construction of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam by domestic capacity, soliciting fund from within reduces dependency from other nations and reduces the challenges of finance related preconditions. Hence, Ethiopia has to envisage boosting its domestic capability to amass huge finance for energy production.
Neighborly collaboration for energy
: Collaborating with different nations to access finance from foreign sources provides better chance than for a single nation requested for it. The collaboration of Ethiopia and its neighbors for energy production and energy distribution may attract alternative creditors as the beneficiaries are going to be different countries and the risk is also shared among the beneficiaries.
Encouraging the participation of the private sector
: The participation of the private sector in energy production and energy distribution reduces financial stress from the state because the private sector enters into the energy market having its own finance. The private sector may also establish partnership with European and Chinese creditors directly without the involvement of the state. This helps to overpass the debt restructuring challenge that Ethiopia is passing through right now.
[1]
Xi Jinping, Joining Hands to Advance Modernization and Build a Community with a Shared Future, Keynote Address by H.E. Xi Jinping, The Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, Beijing, September 5, 2024,
https://english.www.gov.cn/news/202409/05/content_WS66d964bdc6d0868f4e8eaa07.html
About the author
Dareskedar Taye, PhD,
Lead Researcher and Europe & America Affairs Director General at the Institute of Foreign Affairs

### 2
URL: https://www.mofed.gov.et/blog/ethiopia-china-economic-cooperation
TITLE: Ethiopia- China Economic Cooperation

Ethiopia- China Economic Cooperation
Published:
Dec. 26, 2023
Introduction
Ethiopia and China established the first official diplomatic relations in 1970 and opened embassies in Beijing and in Addis Ababa. After a year, in 1971, the two nations signed the first economic and technical cooperation framework agreements.
At the beginning, the cooperation of the two nations was focused on livelihood support andÂ  Â capacity buildings. However, later it improved into a holistic approach such as financing development projects and programs, foreign direct investment (FDI), trade and construction.
Since October 2023, the cooperation of the two countries further developed from
Comprehensive Strategic Cooperation Partnership
to
all weather Development Cooperation
which People Republic of China (PRC) has such partnership only with few countries.
The cooperation is getting stronger.
The Ethiopian and Chines economic cooperation strategically focused on the development of infrastructures such as railways, highways, telecommunication, airport terminal, industrial development, construction of electric power generating, distributing and substations. In this respect our development priorities have been directly coherence with Chines government development initiatives,
Forum on China Africa Cooperation (FOCAC)
and
Belt and Road Initiative
(BRI).
Since 2006, Ethiopian has undertaken over 70 mega projects with these China initiatives. In order to implement those projects, the Chines government and financial instituted allocated about 14.83 billion USD loans, from 2006 to 2018.
The other focus areas of cooperation are investment in industries and trade. In this respect several Chines companies invested in the industrial sector and other businesses. Among these investments, Â ESTERN industrial zone, Huajian industrial park, Dire Dawa industrial park and others investments generated huge amount of foreign currency and revenues in terms of tax for Ethiopia.Â  Currently Chinas foreign direct investment reached about USD 4 billion, and 1844 Chines projects are operating in Ethiopia.
The construction sector is the other area of involvement that cooperation is strengthened. Â The chines companies played pivotal roles in the construction and built several mega projects of the country. Many railway lines, express roads and highways, suspension bridges, skyline buildings, industrial parks, sugar factories, hydro power dam, wind power plants, substation and transmission line, the Addis Ababa riverside park and many other projects in Ethiopia have been constructed by chines companies.
Conclusion
Ethiopia used all financial resources from china to develop those mega projects. For instance, among the 70 projects 57 of them are infrastructural projects which costed about USD 12.2 billion (82.2 Percent of all loans from China). Â More specifically, 22 projects are transport and communication sector projects, 35 projects are power sector projects, and the remaining 13 projects are sugar factories and urban water supply projects.
Thus, Ethio- China economic cooperation is comprehensive and strategic highly contributed to Ethiopian growth and development. Â In todayâ€™s Ethiopia, the contributions of People Republic China government and people have a paramount value.

### 3
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/02/ethiopias-sea-access-strategy-from-geopolitical-challenge-to-economic-necessity
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Sea Access Strategy: From Geopolitical Challenge to Economic Necessity â€“ IFA

Introduction:
From Silence to Strategy
More than thirty years after becoming landlocked following Eritreaâ€™s independence in 1993, Ethiopia, Africaâ€™s second most populous country, remains without direct access to the sea.Â  While landmark projects like the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) have brought energy security, the absence of a coastline continues to constrain Ethiopiaâ€™s economic potential and strategic autonomy.
For years, the topic of sea access was politically sensitive and largely avoided in public discourse. However, that has changed. The Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Abiy Ahmed, has placed the issue back at the forefront, reframing Ethiopiaâ€™s lack of maritime access not simply as a historical consequence, but as a pressing developmental and geopolitical challenge.
With a population exceeding 126 million and projected to surpass 150 million by 2030 (World Bank, 2024), Ethiopia argues that remaining in what officials describe as a â€œgeographic prisonâ€ is no longer sustainable. This claim is rooted not only in demographic pressures, but also in Ethiopiaâ€™s long maritime history and increasing vulnerability due to dependence on a single foreign port.
This article provides an overview of Ethiopiaâ€™s historical maritime ties, current constraints, and emerging strategies for securing access to the sea. Drawing lessons from other landlocked nations, it outlines diplomatic options grounded in cooperation, regional integration, and international law.
2. A Historical Turning Point
Ethiopiaâ€™s maritime legacy stretches back to ancient times and it is well documented.Â  During the Axumite Empire, ports like Adulis and Massawa provided access to Red Sea trade routes. More recently, until the late 1990s, Ethiopia relied primarily on the port of Assab for its maritime commerce.
The situation changed dramatically in 1993 when Eritrea became independent. Although Ethiopia temporarily maintained access to Eritrean ports through transitional arrangements, the 1998â€“2000 border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea severed these ties completely. Since then, Ethiopia has depended almost entirely on the Port of Djibouti, which now handles over 90% of its maritime trade (World Bank, 2023).
This dependence has renewed interest in Ethiopiaâ€™s historical maritime claims and the 19th century colonial injustice.Â  During the colonial period, the 1884 Hewett Treaty granted Ethiopia access to the sea through a British-Egyptian agreement. Later, in 1952, the UN recognized Ethiopiaâ€™s need for port access when it federated Eritrea under Resolution 390.
Today, these legal and diplomatic precedents are being revisited not to reclaim the past, but to secure a more stable and prosperous future.
3. Why Sea Access Matters for Ethiopia Today?
For Ethiopia, sea access is not merely a symbolic issue, it is vital for sustainable development. As the country expands its industrial base, with export-oriented sectors like textiles, leather goods, and agribusiness growing rapidly, efficient and affordable logistics have become essential.
Ethiopia is also emerging as a regional energy hub, supplying electricity to neighboring countries.Â  This role depends on the steady import of equipment, materials, and technology, almost all of which must pass through Djibouti.
However, this reliance on a single port comes at a steep cost with an estimated $1.5 to $2 billion annual spending on port fees and related services (UNCTAD, 2021). It also presents strategic vulnerabilities from political shifts and economic pressures to supply chain disruptions.
Increasingly, Ethiopiaâ€™s maritime strategy is shifting from aspiration to necessity.Â  Diversifying access to the sea is now central to the countryâ€™s broader goals; such as joining the World Trade Organization (WTO), integrating into the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA), and positioning itself as Â logistics and trade hub in the Horn of Africa.
4. What Does International Law Say About Landlocked Countries
International law strongly supports the rights of landlocked countries to access the sea. The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) guarantees the right of transit through neighboring coastal states though the implementation of these rights depends on bilateral or regional agreements.
In Africa, the 2050 Africaâ€™s Integrated Maritime Strategy (AIMS) reframes the conversation by replacing the term â€œlandlockedâ€ with â€œland-linkedâ€ or â€œlandly-connected.â€Â  This shift in language reflects a more optimistic and cooperative vision one in which countries without coastlines are still actively engaged in maritime affairs through regional partnerships.
Ethiopiaâ€™s current sea access debate has sparked different views.Â  Some critics frame it as a demand for ownership of a port, while others point to the controversial way Assab was transferred to Eritrea during Ethiopiaâ€™s transitional period after the fall of the military regime.Â  They argue that the government at the time lacked the legal authority to make such a concession, suggesting that Ethiopiaâ€™s rights to Assab may never have been formally surrendered.
Regardless of historical claims, international legal frameworks like UNCLOS, grants landlocked states the right of access to and from the sea through transit states. However, the practical application of this right depends on bilateral or regional agreements, allowing the countries involved to determine the â€œhowâ€ of these rights, meaning how they are exercised. This highlights the importance of diplomacy, mutual benefit, and regional cooperation, as legal rights alone are rarely sufficient.
Furthermore, the Vienna Programme of Action for Landlocked Developing Countries (2014â€“2024), and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development all emphasize the importance of cooperation, infrastructure development, and inclusive trade. The UN General Assembly Resolution A/RES/63/17 also supports the creation of transit agreements and infrastructure tailored to landlocked states.Â  Institutions such as UN-OHRLLS, UNECA, and AfCFTA continue to promote cross-border trade, regional integration and harmonized regional infrastructure.
The foregoing underscore while legal rights matter, their effectiveness depends on diplomatic engagement and sustained cooperation.
5. Regional Momentum: A Window of Opportunity
Ethiopiaâ€™s maritime ambitions align well with wider regional trends. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) aims to lower trade barriers, improve infrastructure, and foster intra-African commerce. UNCTAD estimates that AfCFTA could reduce trade costs for landlocked countries by up to 11% and increase freight volumes by nearly 30%.
Ethiopia is also nearing full WTO membership and expanding its presence in global trade.Â  For this, dependable maritime access is essential to attract investment and facilitate exports. Its membership to BRICS further elevates the countryâ€™s strategic profile, offering new allies and platforms for maritime negotiations, infrastructure investment, and trade corridor development.
By framing port diversification as part of a broader African integration agenda, Ethiopia can move the conversation beyond bilateral disputes.Â  Pan-African platforms like AIMS 2050 (Africaâ€™s Integrated Maritime Strategy) provide a shared roadmap for maritime cooperation, legal harmonization, and regional security.
6. What Other Countries Can Teach Ethiopia
Moldova: Diplomacy Over Territory
Moldova, after losing its coastline due to border shifts, negotiated and struck a creative deal with Ukraine in 1999.Â  Moldova gave up a small section of land for a road and in return, Ukraine granted Moldova a 430-meter stretch along the Danube River enabling the creation of its new international free port. This model shows that maritime access can be achieved through diplomacy and this offers a precedent Ethiopia could consider.
Morocco and the Sahel: A Shared Corridor Vision
In 2023, Morocco launched an initiative to provide landlocked Sahel countries like Mali, Niger, and Chad with access to Atlantic ports via Moroccan infrastructure. Through the development of corridors and shared logistics platforms, Morocco has enhanced both economic ties and regional influence.
This cooperative approach offers valuable lessons for the Horn of Africa, where a similar model could ease tensions and promote shared development.Â  In contrast, countries like Ethiopia and Eritrea have yet to build a coordinated port access strategy despite facing similar challenges in a volatile Red Sea region. This also informs that landlocked nations can regain maritime access through infrastructure development. It is a model Ethiopia could study closely.
Somaliland: A Strategic but Controversial Deal
In early 2024, Ethiopia signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Somaliland, leasing a 20-kilometer stretch of coastline for 50 years in exchange for infrastructure investments. This signaled possible recognition of Somalilandâ€™s autonomy. While this sparked outrage in Somalia, Ethiopia views the deal as a pragmatic move to address its maritime needs.Â  Though controversial, the MoU reflects a shift from symbolic politics to strategic pragmatism.
The Belt and Road Initiative
Another opportunity lies in Chinaâ€™s Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), which can provide landlocked countries with greater leverage in international negotiations. By creating alternative transit routes and connecting these countries to multiple coastal or regional gateways, the BRI helps reduce dependence on any single transit country. For instance, Ethiopia now relies on the Ethiopia-Djibouti standard gauge railway built under the BRI to access the Port of Djibouti.Â  This will significantly reduce transit time and cost as compared to road transport and thus lessening the risk of overreliance on a single corridor (Xinhua, 2025).
Similarly, in Central Asia, Kazakhstan has enhanced its rail access to China and Europe via projects like the doubling of the DostykMoyynty crossing and its participation in the TransCaspian or â€œMiddle Corridor,â€ which offers a strategic alternative to Russian routes (RailFreight, 2023).
7. What Should Ethiopia Do Next?
From Isolation to Integration
To secure sustainable sea access, Ethiopia must adopt a multi-pronged strategy rooted in diplomacy, investment, and regional cooperation. Key actions include:
Re-engage with Eritrea- open dialogue to negotiate mutually beneficial access to the port of Assab.
Deepen Ties with Djibouti and improve logistics and seek more favorable trade terms.
Operationalize the Somaliland MoU: Work with regional bodies like the African Union and IGAD to ensure legal and diplomatic backing.
Invest in LAPSSET (Kenya): Increase participation in this strategic corridor linking Ethiopia to the Indian Ocean.
Integrate Ethiopiaâ€™s quest for sea into Pan-African Frameworks: Align maritime strategies with AfCFTA and AIMS 2050 to attract funding and regional support.
In summary, Ethiopiaâ€™s landlocked status is not just a geographical inconvenience; it is a developmental bottleneck. No matter how ambitious its industrial, energy, or economic reforms, the absence of reliable sea access will continue to limit progress.
It is time to treat maritime access not as a nationalist issue, but as a regional development challenge. The path forward lies in cooperation, not confrontation. With a clear, lawful, and diplomatically coordinated maritime strategy, Ethiopia can protect its national interests while contributing to peace and integration across the Horn of Africa.

About the author
Seble Getachew is an Associate Researcher at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA). She is a dedicated advocate for womenâ€™s empowerment and continuous personal growth. Seble has over 18 years of experience working in the UN Offices, Field Services and similar International organizations in Africa, South-East Asia and the Gulf. With her experience working in a post-conflict environment, she has deep understanding of protection of civilians including policy research and administration. Seble has an abundance of multicultural expertise and a passion for diversity. She did her post graduate studies in Global Studies with a emphasis on Peace and Security in Africa from the Leipzig University and International Relations and Development from ISS, the Hague along with Bachelorâ€™s degree in Political Science and International Relations from Addis Ababa University. Seble has been serving the IFA since August 2024 as volunteer in the capacity of Partnership Officer and Researcher in the Multilateral Affairs Research Directorate.

The United Nations at a Critical Juncture: Africaâ€™s Time to Take Active Role

### 4
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/09/the-battle-for-africas-strategic-wealth-leveraging-resource-power-in-the-era-of-critical-mineral-geopolitics
TITLE: The Battle for Africaâ€™s Strategic Wealth: Leveraging Resource Power in the Era of Critical Mineral Geopolitics â€“ IFA

Introduction
The world is rapidly moving to a new wave of technological evolution where Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the way we work, learn things and support innovation efforts; Green technologies reshape production systems and accelerate the transition to sustainable development. These shifts are redefining global competitiveness, reframe labor market modalities and support data driven decision making, bringing new opportunities for individuals, businesses entities and countries. Additionally, this transformation redirects the energy demand as the adoption of environmental friendly technologies such as electric vehicles has become part of our lives and prior preferences.
Modern societies and economies has increasingly rely on critical minerals. Contemporary technological inventions highly demand critical minerals as crucial element, as more industries and economies are transitioning to clean energy sources.
[i]
Apart from critical minerals as inputs of energy production and supporting transition efforts, they play a prominent role in defense technologies and weapons systems, Aerospace components and satellite systems, digital infrastructure and semiconductor manufacturing and Medical equipment and pharmaceutical production sectors
[ii]
.
This technological shift forms critical minerals equally important components in the era of Artificial intelligence and green technology revolution. The demand and extraction of minerals such as lithium, graphite and cobalt
will need to increase by
at least
500
per cent by 2050.
[iii]
According to the 2023 Critical Minerals Market Review by the International Energy Agency, demand for lithium tripled, and that of cobalt and nickel rose by 70% and 40%, respectively, from 2017 to 2022.
[iv]
Similarly, the market size of critical minerals doubled over the past five years, reaching $320 billion in 2022.
[v]
Africa stands at the forefront of this transformative global shift towards sustainable energy sources, as the world increasingly pivots to green technologies. The continentâ€™s mineral reserve is estimated to constitute 30 percent of the worldâ€™s known mineral deposit,
[vi]
including 85% of the worldâ€™s manganese, 80% of platinum and chromium, 47% of cobalt, and significant shares of graphite and copper
[vii]
, positioning the continent as the key player in the emerging global green technology revolution. Â As countries race to secure the critical minerals needed for clean energy technologies such as electric vehicles, battery storage systems and renewable energy Infrastructure, Africa is drawing into the spotlight in global geopolitics. This intersection of global energy demand and continental endowment of resources underscores Africaâ€™s strategic importance in the 21
st
century new technological era and energy transition.
2.
Critical Mineral Geopolitics
The importance of Africa in mineral geopolitics has increased significantly as the continent is a cheap and abundant source of the industrial supply chain in critical mineral markets. It is within this context that major global powers such as China, United States, United Kingdom, and European Union, Japan as well as several middle powers have become increasingly interested to enhance and renew their diplomatic relationship with African countries. They are also investing in infrastructure project and introducing various development initiatives aimed implicitly or explicitly to facilitate the mineral supplies needed by their industries and high tech companies.
As part of a larger strategy to lessen reliance on Chinese-dominated supply chains, the United States has increased its focus on African critical minerals, particularly after China banned the export of Germanium and Gallium to the United States in December 2024
[viii]
, two metals critical to semiconductors and military uses. In particular, the US has established a number of mineral agreements, such as the most recent one with Ukraine, to boost strategic and domestic resource availability right away. The country is also aggressively engaging in Africaâ€™s mineral market. It has committed $553 million investment on the Lobito Atlantic Railway upgrade in Angola; implement the Minerals Security Partnership (MSP) with allies to coordinate investments and establish bilateral critical mineral partnerships with several African nations including Angola, Democratic Republic of Congo and Zambia.
[ix]
All these efforts are manifestations that US severely is in need of competing to possess critical minerals in Africa.
Over the past 20 years, China has maintained a dominant position in African essential minerals by controlling almost 70% of the worldâ€™s processing capacity for 19 out of 20 vital minerals. Furthermore, China has extracted and imported 28% of Africaâ€™s graphite, 58% of its manganese, and 72% of its cobalt.
[x]
China is also a key country investing in infrastructures such as Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) revitalization which will cost over $1.4 billion and leveraging decades of infrastructure development including Belt and road initiative and mining investments to maintain its critical mineral dominance. Japan has become a key player and significant competitor by supporting the Nacala Corridor connecting Zambia and Malawi to the Indian Ocean via Mozambique. The European Union has also developed its Critical Raw Materials Act with specific provisions targeting African partnerships
[xi]
and signing memorandum of understanding with South Africa (2025), Rwanda (2024), DRC and Zambia (2023)
[xii]
to increase its supply of raw materialsÂ  through what they call it â€˜Raw material diplomacyâ€™.
[xiii]
All these infrastructural investmentâ€™s particularly those linking mineral extraction sites to ports along with the rise in bilateral agreements by international powers; reflect their primary goal of securing mineral resources to fuel their competition in global technological race. As a result, Africa is increasingly becoming a battle ground shaped by the pressures of this new technological era. Amid, the growing technological competition, particularly between China and the United States, Africa has emerged as a key battleground for strategic minerals. States such as DRC. Zambia, Burundi, Tanzania in particular has become centers of competition among international actors and directly or indirectly their peace and stability is also linked with these contestation.
3.
LeveragingÂ  Resource power and Projecting strategic influence
As global powers increasingly view Africa as an important player to their economic future and a vital source of supply chain in the race for technological competition, African countries should grab this opportunities for their diplomatic influence, economic development and projecting the continents role in global economy. Africa can leverage its mineral wealth as a strategic tool in diplomacy by negotiating access to critical minerals in exchange for security cooperation and strengthening capacity for strong resource governance. Mineral diplomacy could enable African states to utilize natural resource demand for broader political and security gains. For example as DRC face the advance of M23 rebels in its eastern provinces, theÂ government has made a deal to leverage its minerals in exchange for security assistance from the U.S.Â government.
Additionally, International actors are also highly interested to invest in infrastructures such as railways and ports to ease business operations in mineral sector. The U.S.-backed Lobito Corridor, which links Angolaâ€™s Atlantic coast to copper and cobalt mines in Zambia and the Democratic Republic of the Congo; the China-backed TAZARA Railway, which links Tanzaniaâ€™s Dar es Salaam port to Zambiaâ€™s copper belt; and the Japan-backed Nacala Corridor, which links Zambia and Malawi to Mozambiqueâ€™s Nacala port on the Indian Ocean, are few examples. African nations should aggressively take advantage of these opportunities by negotiating their critical minerals for long-term development results, as more international players will be interested in investing as the role of key minerals in technology grows in the upcoming decades.
Furthermore, African nations could use foreign partners to invest in local manufacturing and refining with the goal of exporting value-added critical mineral goods, as more global and middle-power nations are investing in critical mineral extraction. For example, Zimbabwe banned the export of raw lithium to compel investors to process it domestically; Namibia is positioning itself as a major green hydrogen producer looking to build integrated hydrogen and ammonia production facilities to supply global markets; and the DRC and Zambia have moved to restrict raw cobalt and copper exports, demanding that processing be done locally.
[xiv]
Other nations should follow the same footsteps by balancing national interest and foreign direct investment to boost local economies.
In general, African nations can maximize benefits by negotiating more favorable terms with investors and as the world needs the continents critical minerals, itâ€™s time for Africa to leverage its resource power to be an important player in global political economy. However, African countries should introduce strong resource governance frameworks and monitoring mechanisms since critical minerals could produce negative outcome in peace and stability of those nations
4.
Conclusion
Africa hosts significant deposits of copper, cobalt, lithium, manganese, platinum group metals, rare earth elements, graphite, and bauxite, among others. This puts the continent at the new front in critical minerals power play as the technological shift the world is witnessing needs Africaâ€™s strategic wealth. International actors such as USA, China, Europe, Japan and others are deeply involving in critical geopolitical competition and Africa is becoming a battleground for them to secure sufficient enough resources for their green energy transitions, defense technologies, Â semiconductor manufacturing etc. Realizing the role their strategic wealth plays, Africa should use these opportunities to strength their diplomatic bargaining power, negotiating their critical minerals for long term development outcomes and leverage international partners to invest in local refining and manufacturing aiming to export value added critical mineral products.
5.

This historic setback and economic strain have reignited a fierce national drive for sea access, intensified by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmedâ€™s recent declaration, which stirred deep national pride while provoking swift regional pushback.

### 6
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2024/11/19/ethiopias-strategic-positioning-amidst-possible-rise-in-us-china-rivalry-following-trumps-second-term
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Positioning Amidst Possible Rise in US-China Rivalry Following Trumpâ€™s Second Term. â€“ IFA

By: Anteneh Getachew(PhD)
The world watches with bated breath as the newly elected American presidentâ€™s policy directionsâ€”spanning economic, social, political, and diplomatic realmsâ€”begin to take shape. Regardless of the specific strategies, a profound shift in global and regional geopolitical dynamics across Europe, the Middle East, Asia, and Africa is widely anticipated.
The tenure of outgoing U.S. President Joe Biden has been marked by significant global developments. Key events include the deteriorating relationship with numerous East African States, the cancellation of the AGOA preference for five African States, escalating Ukraine war, the Israel-Palestine war, the expansion of BRICS+, and the civil war as well as worsening humanitarian situation in Sudan. The Horn of Africa, a critical geopolitical hotspot and a focal point of intense competition among global powers, including China, is no exception.
President-elect Donald Trump has signaled plans for a more aggressive stance toward China, building on his hardline approach during his previous term. In pre-election speeches and the â€œProject 2025â€ blueprint, Trump hinted at intensifying economic warfare with China, potentially adopting more confrontational trade policies than those of the Biden administration. These strategies aim to curtail Chinaâ€™s global economic influence through heightened protectionism, significant tariff adjustments, and stringent regulations. Such measures are likely to reshape U.S.-China relations dramatically. For countries in the Horn of Africa-particularly Ethiopia, which has been a major recipient of Chinese financial assistance and investment; this shift could bring complex and far-reaching consequences, compelling recalibration of strategies amidst the evolving geopolitical and economic landscape.
If carefully managed, the shifting dynamics of U.S.-China rivalry in the Horn of Africa could present more opportunities than challenges, particularly for Ethiopia. Analysts highlight that a key shortcoming of Donald Trumpâ€™s previous presidency was its relegation of Africa, and the Horn of Africa in particular, to a secondary priority, with limited focus and engagement. In addition to creating an opening for other global players, notably China, to deepen their influence in the region, his approach was sometimes swayed by actors like Egypt, leading to controversial moments like his widely criticized remarks on the GERD. However, his administrationâ€™s effort to bring Ethiopia and Egypt to the negotiating table on the dam issue remains a notable achievement.
As Donald Trump returns to the presidency, there is hope that his administration will address past policy missteps and recognize the strategic significance of the Horn of Africa for global trade and security. This could pave the way for stronger, more beneficial partnerships with Africa, and particularly the Horn region. For Ethiopia, the challenge lies in its capability in seizing whatever opportunities that arise from the rivalry between the US and China while carefully balancing its relationships with both. How Ethiopia navigates these shifting geopolitical and economic dynamics will also play a crucial role in shaping its future position on the global stage. This article examines the impacts Trumpâ€™s second presidency might have on the geopolitical and economic landscapes of the Horn of Africa specifically addressing how Ethiopia can navigate through the complex web of opportunities and challenges that can arise from heightened U.S.-China rivalry in the region.
A defining aspect of outgoing President Joe Bidenâ€™s administration was its renewed geostrategic and economic engagement with Africa, aiming to counter Chinaâ€™s growing influence, particularly in key strategic areas, while adopting a more measured tone and reduced reliance on military approaches. In contrast, President-elect Donald Trump appears poised to adopt a more aggressive stance toward China. Unlike Biden, Trump favors transactional, bilateral relationships over institutional frameworks that promote multilateral cooperation, signaling a different approach to U.S.-Africa relations.
Donald Trump has consistently framed China as a strategic adversary, yet his â€œAmerica Firstâ€ approach and reduced focus on multilateral engagement signals a shift in the geopolitical landscape that could diminish the U.S.â€™s role in global affairs. Americaâ€™s withdrawal from key global institutions, including the cancellation of agreements like the Paris Climate Accord and the Iran Nuclear Deal, has created space for China to expand its influence over global issues and governance structures. Additionally, the recent growth of opposing blocs like BRICS further weakens U.S. involvement in international forums, potentially giving China an advantage in reshaping the global order and accelerating its pursuit of global leadership.
Trumpâ€™s nationalist, protectionist trade policies threaten to heighten tensions with China, while also calling for substantial tariffs on goods from all trade partners, with especially harsh measures targeting Chinese imports. It appears that Trump is prepared to take strong action to challenge Chinaâ€™s dominance in critical sectors such as green technology, energy production, and electric vehicle manufacturing, potentially reshaping global supply chains and prompting shifts in international alliances.
In such an evolving scenario, Ethiopia, a key regional player and renewable energy hub, will likely find itself caught in the complexities of this rivalry, especially in its pursuit of a transition to green energy and environment-friendly economic development.
China is increasingly influential in the Horn of Africa, significantly shaping the geopolitical and economic landscape following the Trump administration. The Belt and Road Initiative has dramatically transformed the region through substantial investments in vital sectors like infrastructure, energy, and telecommunications. Ethiopia, as one of the BRIâ€™s focal points, has seen massive Chinese investments. Although Chinaâ€™s investments in Ethiopia are fostering economic growth, concerns about debt trap and erosion of sovereignty are not difficult to come by. Such fault lines in Africaâ€“China relations would serve Trumpâ€™s US to recalibrate its geo-economic engagement with Africa, in general, and countries of the Horn region, in particular.
Historically, the U.S. has been a key source of development aid to Ethiopia, but its emphasis on governance and human rights has created a complex diplomatic environment for Ethiopia as it strives to become a regional power amid the U.S.-China rivalry. With China playing a major role in Ethiopiaâ€™s infrastructure development and the U.S. prioritizing democratic reforms and security cooperation, the stakes are high. As Trumpâ€™s incoming administration is expected to focus more on geo-economic engagements, the pressing question remains: how can Ethiopia effectively navigate this complex landscape?
Opportunities and Challenges
Following the recent implementation of macroeconomic policy reforms, Ethiopia is now strategically positioned to diversify its economy and attract foreign direct investment. With a goal of building a more resilient economy, Ethiopia has pledged to expand its international partnerships, moving away from the limited funding sources it previously relied on. Balancing its relationships with both China and the U.S. presents Ethiopia with both opportunities and challenges. In addition to raising concerns about global economic stability, the uncertainty surrounding Trumpâ€™s proposed economic and trade policies poses significant challenges for emerging economies like Ethiopia.
The ongoing tensions over the GERDâ€”a contentious issue with Egypt and Sudanâ€”present another significant concern for Ethiopia as Trump returns to office. Egyptâ€™s involvement in the Middle East â€œmediationâ€ efforts, its role in the Abraham Accord, and its comparative advantage in lobbying U.S. Congress members to influence opinions on the GERD highlight the potential for the new administrationâ€™s stance to be swayed against Ethiopiaâ€™s interests and could intensify pressure on Ethiopia and its developmental needs. As a response, Ethiopia must pursue a more robust diplomatic engagement with the new administration while also strengthening cooperation with riparian countries that have ratified the CFA as a strategic alternative.
As the Horn of Africa region continues to grapple with persistent conflict and instability, the issue is further complicated by the involvement of major powers like the U.S. and China, among other state actors. For Ethiopia, navigating these competing interests is essential to strengthening its security strategy, and calls for enhancing military ties with the U.S. for defense assistance and leveraging Chinaâ€™s investments in security infrastructure are critical steps in addressing terrorist threats and regional instability. By engaging with both powers, Ethiopia can strategically balance its alliances while effectively addressing the pressing security challenges.
Conclusion
With the new phase of U.S.-China relations in the wake of Trumpâ€™s reelection, Ethiopia is at a critical turning point, facing both opportunities and challenges that can be leveraged to enhance its influence in the Horn of Africa. Ethiopia has the potential to strengthen its geopolitical and geo-economic position by diversifying its international partnerships and employing a proactive diplomatic strategy. The choices made by Ethiopia today will significantly impact its internal stability and its future regional diplomatic posture, ultimately affecting the broader dynamics of the Horn of Africa for years to come.
About the Author
Anteneh Getachew (phD), Asia and Pacific Affairs Research Director General at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA).

Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Sea Access: Balancing Between Escalation and D- Escalation
Walking the Talk: Green Modelling Ethiopia in Africa and Beyond

### 7
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/29/%F0%9D%90%93%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8C%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A0-%F0%9D%90%8B%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A4-%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A7
TITLE: ğ“ğ¡ğ ğŒğ¢ğ¬ğ¬ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ‹ğ¢ğ§ğ¤ ğ¢ğ§ ğğ‘ğˆğ‚ğ’ ğˆğ§ğ­ğğ ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§: ğ“ğ¡ğ ğğğğ ğŸğ¨ğ« ğ‘ğ¨ğ›ğ®ğ¬ğ­ ğ’ğğœğ®ğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ² ğŒğğœğ¡ğšğ§ğ¢ğ¬ğ¦ğ¬ â€“ IFA

Introduction
The BRICS groupingâ€”comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africaâ€”was founded on three major tenets: political and security, economic and financial, and cultural and people-to-people cooperation. Despite its vast scope of interests and goals, BRICS is still seen as a forum for economic and developmental partnership, rather than a comprehensive political or security alliance (Mdlokovana, 2025).
In BRICS, the level of cooperation on security is rather
low and tends to be bilateral.
There is no collective mechanism established among the member countries on a formal level and as well the platform lacks shared vision on security threats (Cutrera, 2020). In fact, BRICS countries have different views on security. Whereas some member countries tend to perceive it as a military risk; others as sovereignty, or non-intervention, economic security, or some other threats related to cyberspace. These differences make a unified strategy unlikely.
This means that the BRICS platform lacks the ability to address to common security issues, resolve conflicts, and assure solidarity to its member states in case of external threats. This is even more reinforced by the varied and, at some instances, divergent geopolitical agendas of its member states. This is going to be even more complex considering that there are new BRICS member states including Egypt
,
Ethiopia, Iran, United Arab Emirates, Indonesia, and other nine partner Countries included in the platform (
Makhija
, 2025).
There are many instances wherein
the
BRICS members have taken
contradicting stances within regional conflicts.
A case in point includes Chinaâ€™s strategic partnership with Pakistan which conflicts with Indiaâ€™s national security imperatives (Noor, 2014). This exemplifies that a structural problem may be created within BRICS if a security mechanism is not in place, and hence this may widen gaps in cooperation and hinder deeper integration.
The Need for Security
Mechanisms
Even if the BRICS members share a common vision of transforming global governance and achieving a more multipolar international system, they diverge on their security strategy priorities, threat perceptions, and regional roles which make it challenging to consolidate the bloc (
De Carvalho
, 2025). Every member operates in a different geological setting, thereby entertaining separate security threats, such as regional conflicts, border disputes, terrorism, cyber, and economic coercion, among others, which might hamper coordination of security policies and as a result weaken collective threats actions.
Under such a situation, it is imperative for BRICS to develop appropriate security mechanisms to handle the divergence within the bloc and foster more security among each other, build mutual trust and avoid security deviations that might hamper cooperation in this regard. The key justifications for such mechanisms within BRICS include:
Towards a Strong Security Framework
Of more than 180 BRICS cooperation mechanisms, very few actually operate within the security arena. These include: the BRICS National Security Advisors Meeting (endorsed at the II BRICS Summitâ€”Brasilia Joint Statement, 2010); the BRICS Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism Council (endorsed at the VII BRICS Summitâ€”Ufa Declaration, 2015); the BRICS Working Group on Security in the Use of ICTs (endorsed at the VII BRICS Summitâ€”Ufa Declaration, 2015); and the BRICS Working Group on Counter-Terrorism (endorsed at the VIII BRICS Summitâ€”Goa Declaration, 2016).
Even with the mechanisms above, it can be noted that their scope is dominantly placed within the counter-terrorism and
cyber security, rather than encompassing broader or collective security concerns in real terms.
If BRICS is to emerge as a strategic coalition in its true form, it has to move beyond economic coordination and adopt
a
more comprehensive strategic approach to security. The comprehensive security framework would give rise to an opportunity where conflicts can be dealt with on a collaborative basis and would also facilitate increased transparency among its members. Adopting a collective approach would also increase its stature on the international scene and would give BRICS a much more significant opportunity to play its part in international security.
Preventing Negative
Repercussions
Without binding security cooperation measures in place, member states remain free to support external actors outside the bloc that may be at odds with fellow BRICS members. Such actions set troubling precedents that can be repeated and amplified. In cases where one BRICS member finds itself supporting an ally of an adversary of another, such incidents create
conflicts
of interest between member states, eroding trust and undermining strategic cohesion within the bloc. Ideally, a structured security strategy would help limit these contradictions by establishing
clear
and expectations
reducing the likelihood of members taking actions that harm each otherâ€™s interests.
Avoiding Support for Opponents of Member States
Being such a long-term cooperative framework, BRICS faces threats if its member states support organizations or countries that can potentially threaten other member states. If such patterns continue, there is every possibility that its relevance and credibility can diminish. For development of its security strategies, there should provisions that can deter member states from providing political, financial, or military support to any actor that can threaten other BRICS member countries. In such a way the bloc can better maintain unity and strengthen its collective voice in global affairs by promoting internal solidarity.
Conclusion
Indeed, it can be argued that to date, the BRICS grouping has not yet materialized or can be said â€œfailed toâ€ carve out a comprehensive security strategy, which is partly owing to the divers , sometimes conflicting, geopolitical interests of its member states. that belong to the same alliance umbrella . Thus, it is recommended that in order to overcome these challenges, and strengthen the blocâ€™s strategic relevance, BRICS ought to make efforts to collectively carve out a shared security framework that includes common principles, conflict-prevention, improved intelligence sharing, and informal norms to
desist from taking the side of those who might be considered hostile to any member state could be incorporated. Additionally, it would also be of paramount
importance to include initiatives such as structured security dialogues and
peacekeeping cooperation to deepen trust and help transform trust and help BRICS from a primarily economic partnership to a more coherent and influential global coalition.
References
Cutrera, F. (2020). BRICS Policy Center Centro de Estudos e Pesquisas â€“ BRICS Do the BRICS care about International Security? BPC Policy Brief â€“ V. 9 N. 2
De Carvalho
, G. (2025). BRICS: Rising Tensions and Opportunities in Global Cooperation, THINK BRICS.
https://thinkbrics.substack.com/p/brics-rising-tensions-and-opportunities
Makhija
, H. (2025). BRICS on Multilateral Peace and Security Architecture. Observer Research Foundation (ORF).
https://www.orfonline.org/expert-speak/brics-on-multilateral-peace-and-security-architecture
Noor, S. (2024). BRICS Security Cooperation.
https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/brics-security-cooperation-solayman-noor-5xkqe
Mdlokovana, S. (2025). BRICS+ Series: Beyond NATO, BRICS and the New Global SecurityFramework. IOL.
https://thestar.co.za/business-report/brics/2025-03-04-brics-series-beyond-nato-brics-and-the-new-global-securityframework

Haimanot Eshetu (PhD),
Senior Researcher at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA)

Navigating Autonomy: Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Naval Power in the Red Sea
Ethiopiaâ€™s Digital Sovereignty and the 2030 Economic Horizon: A Policy Analysis of Regulatory Reform and Infrastructure Scaling

### 8
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/13/ethiopias-brics-membership-potential-to-strengthen-ties-with-the-middle-east-and-north-africa-region
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s BRICS Membership: Potential to Strengthen Ties with the Middle East and North Africa Region â€“ IFA

Introduction
The founding members of BRICS assert that the group represents the interests of â€œthe global majority.â€ In this light, undoubtedly, Ethiopiaâ€™s membership in such a group would enhance its posture on the global stage. Among others, its accession helps the country to raise its critical concerns in a multilateral forum, advocate for Africaâ€™s interests, and accelerate the realization of its Sustainable Development Goals (Horn Review, 2023). Prior to the Johannesburg Summit, over 40 countries including Ethiopia expressed their interest in joining the bloc (Reuters, 2023). Yet, the summit adopted the request of only six countries where Ethiopia was one of them. Succeeding membership in such an intense competition, therefore, means a lot for Ethiopiaâ€™s global visibility, particularly after the outbreak of the Northern conflict, which had previously cast a shadow over the countryâ€™s international image.
Traditionally, Ethiopia has been known for its non-aligned movement and supporter of independence struggles in Africa. It has also considered itself as the champion of Pan-Africanism, promoter of African Solutions for African Problems, and to some extent, pioneer of
Afrabia
frameworks. On the top of these achievements, Ethiopiaâ€™s admission to the BRICS bloc provided a platform to show its remarkable potential and engage with major superpowers, including China and Russia. Apart from that, its accession opens a new window of opportunity for the country to approach the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region through the BRICS framework.
While approving the request of several MENA countries, in relative terms, the Johannesburg summit enabled more homogenous countries to join the group. From a geo-economic perspective, the newly joining BRICS members are predominantly Oil Producing Countries with the exception of Ethiopia. Consequently, in statistical terms, following the Johannesburg Summit, the representation of the MENA region in the BRICS BLOC rose from Zero to nearly one-third. In fact, some analysts criticized such BRICS expansion as â€œvery middle East Centricâ€ and â€œOPEC dominatedâ€ while others preferred to call it â€œBRICS plus OPECâ€ (Ismael, 2023). Notwithstanding, Ethiopiaâ€™s entry into the BRICS bloc, together with several MENA countries, is believed to create a strategic opening to engage the MENA region more closely, thereby emboldening its diplomatic relationship with member states.
Ethiopia and the MENA Region
Ethiopia occupies a geopolitically strategic location in the Horn of Africa, located near to the Red Sea Region. According to Professor Brook Hailu, such a geographical position gives BRICS a gateway to project influence in Africa and the Middle East (Ethiopian News Agency, 2024). In particular, the inclusion of Ethiopia in the BRICS club paves the way to cooperate on important matters with MENA countries. It is unfortunate, hitherto institutional-based cooperation between Ethiopia and the MENA region seemed to have been less promising, hindering the country from effectively utilizing those existing geopolitical and geostrategic advantages in the region. Meanwhile, sadly, Ethiopiaâ€™s arch-foe rival in the region, Egypt, has recklessly exploited most of those MENA related organizations to downgrade Ethiopiaâ€™s national interest.
One of the most troubling aspects of Ethiopiaâ€™s exclusion from MENA regional platforms is its denial of opportunity for sharing its views in the MENA regional stage. This marginalization has been demonstrated during the GERD dispute, for instance, when the Arab League expressed its concern over the water security of Egypt. The League passed a resolution against Ethiopia several times. In one of the resolutions, it informed the UN Security Council to take â€œnecessary measuresâ€, claiming the presence of â€œa United Arab Positionâ€ (Aljazeera, 2021). In response, Ethiopia slammed the resolution, blaming the downstream countries for unreasonable politicization of the GERDâ€™s negotiations. In a similar vein, most of the MENA regional organizations expressed their partisan concern. Principally, upon Somaliaâ€™s call, the Arab League and the Organizations of Islamic Cooperation rejected the Memorandum of Understanding, arguing it violates Somaliaâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity though the intention of Ethiopia is totally contradict to such accusations. Importantly, had Ethiopia been a member of MANA based regional organizations, the aforeâ€“stated baseless accusations, and many others, would likely not have been directed at Ethiopia, at least with the tone they have been communicated. Hence, Ethiopiaâ€™s inclusion in the BRICS bloc, which comprises several MENA countries, can provide a valuable platform for articulating its interests and fostering strategic engagement through constructive dialogue.
Conclusion and Policy Recommendations
Ethiopiaâ€™s accession to BRICS together with MENA countries could enhance its connectivity with the MENA region, positioning it as a bridge between Sub-Saharan Africa and the Arab world. Hence, its BRICS membership could create a new diplomatic space, enabling the voice of Ethiopia to be heard equally with others, such as Egypt. It should be noted that Ethiopiaâ€™s exclusion from the MENA dominated regional organizations would hinder any potential cooperation, affecting both parties. Being the only non-MENA country joined BRICS at the Johannesburg Summit, Ethiopia needs to step on the following strategic action. First, it should navigate the Golden-Mean when engaging potentially rival new BRICS members, if any, while remaining mindful of the relative homogeneity among MENA countries. Secondly, Ethiopia should also proactively engage existing MENA affiliated regional organizations, seeking their neutrality or potential mediation role, whenever appropriate.

https://www.ena.et/web

https://www.aljazeera.com/news

Financing Energy infrastructure from abroad: opportunities available in Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and Global Gateway Initiative (GGI)

### 9
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/29/ethiopias-digital-sovereignty-and-the-2030-economic-horizon-a-policy-analysis-of-regulatory-reform-and-infrastructure-scaling
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Digital Sovereignty and the 2030 Economic Horizon: A Policy Analysis of Regulatory Reform and Infrastructure Scaling â€“ IFA

Introduction
The transformation of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia from an agrarian-centered economy into a digitally empowered â€œAfrican Beacon of Prosperityâ€ represents one of the most ambitious socio-economic transitions in the Horn of Africa. This strategic evolution, catalyzed by the completion of the Digital Ethiopia 2025 roadmap and the rollout of the Digital Ethiopia 2030 (DE2030) framework, marks a shift from diagnostic policy planning to institutionalize digital execution. These twin frameworks emphasize scalable Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), telecommunications liberalization, and innovation-oriented legislation. The approach aims to harness the opportunities of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) while mitigating vulnerabilities associated with data dependency and technological inequities (World Bank, 2024).
The Digital Transformation Policy Architecture
Ethiopiaâ€™s digital transformation is grounded in an integrated policy ecosystem that links national planning to regional and global agendas. The Digital Ethiopia 2025 strategy identified four pillars: enabling infrastructure, digital governance, entrepreneurship, and human capital development. Its 2030 successor, DE2030, expands this agenda by embedding digital transformation within Ethiopiaâ€™s Ten-Year Development Plan (2021â€“2030) and the African Unionâ€™s Digital Transformation Strategy for Africa (2020â€“2030) (AUC, 2025).
A central feature of DE2030 is its alignment with the Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI) modelâ€”interoperable platforms for identification, payments, and data exchange. The introduction of the
Fayda Digital ID
system and the expansion of the
EthioPay
digital payments framework symbolize Ethiopiaâ€™s commitment to inclusive financial and digital participation (National Bank of Ethiopia, 2024). These reforms are designed not only to increase efficiency but also to strengthen citizensâ€™ trust in the stateâ€™s ability to deliver digital governance securely and transparently.
Moreover, the Startup Proclamation (No. 1220/2024) and the Data Protection Proclamation (No. 1218/2024) provide the regulatory backbone for innovation and privacy. The Startup Law offers fiscal incentives, incubation programs, and a regulatory sandbox for emerging technology sectors, while the Data Protection Law establishes accountability mechanisms in data usage, processing, and international transfer (MoIP, 2024). Together, these legislative measures mark Ethiopiaâ€™s transition from policy conceptualization to legal codification of digital sovereignty.
2. Telecommunications Liberalization and Infrastructure Scaling
Telecommunication sector liberalization is the fulcrum of Ethiopiaâ€™s DPI expansion. The partial privatization of Ethio Telecom and the licensing of Safaricom Ethiopia, a subsidiary of the Vodacom-led consortium, have fostered a competitive environment conducive to innovation and investment (AfDB, 2024). Broadband penetration increased from below 20 percent in 2020 to nearly 45 percent by 2025, partly due to the national fiber optic backbone project that extends connectivity to rural and industrial zones.
The 2030 roadmap envisions universal broadband access, guided by the principle of â€œdigital equity.â€ Initiatives such as the Woredanet 2.0 and SchoolNet Digital Expansion programs are intended to close regional divides in access to education and e-governance services (MoIP, 2024). Parallel investments in data centersâ€”specifically in the cities of Adama, Hawassa, and Bahir Darâ€”aim to support Ethiopiaâ€™s growing ambitions as a regional data hub, reducing reliance on external cloud infrastructure (Kassa, 2024).
3. Digital Sovereignty, Security, and Global Alignment
At the heart of Ethiopiaâ€™s digital ambitions lies the doctrine of digital sovereigntyâ€”the capacity of states to control their digital ecosystems, including data governance, infrastructure, and algorithmic transparency. The Data Protection Proclamation reflects Ethiopiaâ€™s determination to harmonize domestic regulations with international standards such as the EUâ€™s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) while preserving national autonomy (Agarwal, 2025).
In geopolitical terms, Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of digital sovereignty aligns with the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) e-commerce protocol, which aims to reduce barriers for digital trade and cross-border data flows. By aligning national infrastructure projects with continental frameworks, Ethiopia is positioning itself as a reference point for â€œAfrican data localizationâ€â€”ensuring that data generated within Africa serves African development priorities rather than external profit logics (AUC, 2025).
Furthermore, Ethiopiaâ€™s active participation in multilateral initiatives such as the UN Global Digital Compact underscores its commitment to shaping equitable digital governance at a global level. This approach seeks to avert â€œdigital colonialism,â€ where control over technological supply chains is disproportionately concentrated in advanced economies (United Nations, 2024).
Cybersecurity remains an evolving challenge. The establishment of the National Cyber Security Agency (NCSA) and the adoption of the National Cybersecurity Policy Framework (2025) introduced mechanisms for safeguarding national infrastructure and combating online misinformation, cyber-fraud, and foreign surveillance. The policyâ€™s integration with the African Unionâ€™s regional Convention on Cyber Security and Personal Data Protection (Malabo Convention) further situates Ethiopiaâ€™s digital sovereignty within a cooperative continental defense paradigm.
4. Financing the Digital Economy
The financial underpinnings of Ethiopiaâ€™s DE2030 are built upon hybrid publicâ€“private investment models. The collaboration between the New Development Bank (NDB), World Bank, and Africa50 forms the funding base for infrastructure expansion, with cumulative commitments exceeding USD 4 billion by 2025 (NDB, 2025).
Ethiopiaâ€™s approach emphasizes leveraging Special Economic Zones (SEZs) and ICT Innovation Hubs as investment catalysts. These zonesâ€”particularly in Hawassa, Dire Dawa, and Bole Lemiâ€”function as platforms for digital startups and transnational technology partnerships. Financing mechanisms such as
Digital Infrastructure Bonds
and performance-linked financing are also being explored to sustain long-term infrastructure projects (Kassa, 2024).
5. Outlook and Challenges
While Ethiopiaâ€™s digital transformation is remarkable, implementation risks persist. Challenges include uneven connectivity in peripheral regions, limited private capital absorption, and insufficient skills development for an increasingly digital workforce. The governmentâ€™s Digital Skills Initiative (DSI) aims to upskill five million Ethiopians by 2030, targeting gender parity and youth inclusion in STEM disciplines (MoLSA, 2025).
Another developmental concern lies in maintaining data ethics while capitalizing on AI applications in governance and agriculture. As Ethiopia scales AI-enabled systems, continuous monitoring of algorithmic transparency, human rights, and accessibility will be critical to ensuring technology enhances public welfare rather than exacerbating inequality.
6. Conclusion
Ethiopiaâ€™s DE2030 strategy represents a bold endeavor to redefine the intersection between technology, governance, and development. With institutional reforms, infrastructure expansion, and regional leadership, Ethiopia is redefining what digital sovereignty looks like in Africa: innovation-driven yet sovereignty-conscious, globally integrated yet locally anchored.
If implemented effectively, the Digital Ethiopia 2030 framework could propel Ethiopiaâ€™s transformation into a mid-income, knowledge-based economy while securing its role as a technological hub within the Horn of Africa and beyond.

Ethiopiaâ€™s Posture and Policy Architecture for the 2025 G20 Johannesburg Summit

### 10
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2024/12/18/ethiopias-vision-for-regional-integration-a-policy-dialogue-at-ifa
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Vision for Regional Integration: A Policy Dialogue at IFA â€“ IFA

On December 17, 2024, the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA) hosted a crucial policy dialogue titled â€œ#Ethiopiaâ€™s #Regional Integration Efforts and #BRIâ€™s Evolving Dynamics.â€
The event featured a keynote address by Mr. Adam Tesfaye, chief of staff from #@MoFA who emphasized the importance of a united Africa where goods, services, ideas, and people flow freely across borders.
The dialogue also examined the #Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), initiated by #China in 2013, which seeks to enhance global trade through infrastructure development. #Ethiopiaâ€™s involvement presents both opportunities and challenges that necessitate careful #strategic #alignment.
The event concluded with a panel discussion featuring distinguished scholars. Dr. Abdi Zenebe, Deputy Executive Director of #IFA, emphasized the need for enhanced #interagency coordination, #green development initiatives, and #strategic partnerships.
Key presentations included insights from H.E Ambassador Teshome Toga & Amba, Negus Kebede from #MoFA, who discussed Ethiopiaâ€™s regional integration efforts and the transition to a #green economy. Scholars assessed the alignment of Ethiopiaâ€™s policies with #BRI programs, focusing on modernization in the #Horn of Africa.

### 11
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/28/%F0%9D%90%88%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%88%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%93%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A6%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AB-%F0%9D%90%80%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%AB
TITLE: ğˆğ¬ğ§â€™ğ­ ğˆğ­ ğ“ğ¢ğ¦ğ ğŸğ¨ğ« ğ€ğŸğ«ğ¢ğœğš ğ­ğ¨ ğ’ğ©ğğšğ¤ ğ–ğ¢ğ­ğ¡ ğğ§ğ ğ•ğ¨ğ¢ğœğ ğ¨ğ§ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ–ğ¨ğ«ğ¥ğ ğ’ğ­ğšğ ğ? â€“ IFA

Foreign policy is a set of principles of governments that defines their external relations with other countries. It also serves as an instrument to achieve the national interests of a nation. In implementing their foreign policy, governments manage their relations worldwide through their foreign ministries, embassies and consulates.
In general terms, the foreign policy of governments are targeting in promoting national interests, mainly economic, political, and security interests. In achieving their foreign policy governments use several ways that range from peaceful negotiation and diplomacy to the use of military power.
Some countries have developed their foreign policy towards continents. For instance, the US and the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China have designed their foreign policy towards Africa. In their policy they mention what kind of relationships they want to establish with the continent. On the other hand, the European Union, which is not a sovereign state, has also developed its own foreign policy for dealing with international affairs.
Having said this much about the general foreign policy, I will focus on Africaâ€™s relations with other countries and continents. In the foreign policy document of China towards Africa, it is stated that China has an interest to â€œestablish and develop a new type of strategic partnership with Africa, featuring political equality and mutual trust, economic win-win cooperation and cultural exchangeâ€. Moreover, the policy also underlines that China will support Africa in the field of agriculture, economic aid, culture, environment, human resource development, medical assistance, debt relief and cancellation, increase cooperation in science and technology and the like.
Similarly the US has stated its foreign policy towards Africa by saying â€œâ€¦support for democracy and the strengthening of democratic institutions on the continent, including free, fair, and transparent elections; supporting African economic growth and development; conflict prevention, mitigation, and resolution; supporting presidential initiatives;â€¦working with African nations on transnational issues such as drug smuggling, money laundering, illicit arms, and trafficking in personsâ€.
In order to translate their foreign policy towards Africa into practice some countries have established forums and partnerships with the African Union. African countries are also trying to utilize these forums for their own political and economic benefits. My argument on this issue is that the African Union should also have its own foreign policy in dealing with the rest of the world. Otherwise, there will be policy incoherence between Africa and other countries of the world.
Africa has 54 independent countries which have their own foreign policies. Taking this crude fact into consideration, one can argue that it is difficult to establish one foreign
policy for all African countries. But my argument is that Africa has common interests and issues that can be translated into foreign policy by which the continent can undertake joint actions.
Some of the common interests of African countries are the security and stability of the continent, sustainable economic development, good governance, democracy and human rights, technology transfer, development of culture, environment and the like. These common interests can be translated into foreign policy document of the continent. Such foreign policy would help Africa to be proactive than to be reactive to the policies and interests of other countries.
When we see the current trends and interaction of the African Union with other big countries it is possible to say that the latter develop their own foreign policies towards the former and either a forum or a partnership will be established. This means that Africa is fulfilling the agenda of the great countries. But this doesnâ€™t mean that Africa is not getting some benefit from such interaction. Through such forums Africa could get political and economic benefits as well as a chance of experience-sharing in various fields. Just to mention one example, China built the new conference building of the African Union based on the partnership which has been established between them.
So far Africa as a continent has established strategic partnerships at various levels. These partnerships are at the level of continent-to-continent, continent-to-country and institution-to-institution. These partnerships are Africa-Turkey Partnership, Africa- Europe Partnership, Africa-South America partnership, Africa-India Forum Summit, Forum on Chinaâ€“Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) and the Tokyo International Conference on African Development (TICAD) with Japan. I would like to argue that developing an African policy should get priority than establishing partnership or any other multilateral forums with big countries, continents and institutions.
The European Union, which comprises 28 member states, has its own foreign policy in interacting with others. The 1992 Treaty on European Union was a base for establishing the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) of the Union. Regarding the implementation of the foreign policy â€œmost foreign and security policy decisions are taken by unanimity â€“ all EU countries have to agree on a decisionâ€. This decision-making process is a guarantee for member states in protecting the sovereignty of the country.
The foreign policy of the European Union deals with â€œinternational issues of a political or diplomatic nature, including issues with a security or military orientationâ€. The Union has established a broad set of principles that would help them in guiding the external relations and actions. But this doesnâ€™t mean that member countries of the Union have stopped in exercising their own national foreign ministries and their own national foreign policies.
Similar to European countries, African counties have also a common ground that can be developed into a kind of â€œAfrican Policy or African Engagementâ€ with other countries
and entities. Such a policy would help Africa to have common positions on various international issues as well as to speak and act as one. Unlike the European Union, the establishment of African Standby Force under the African Union is a leap forward in maintaining peace and security in the continent. The basic principles of establishing the Standby Force can also be formulated into the security policy of the African Union.
The vision of the African Union is to have â€œan integrated, prosperous and peaceful Africa, driven by its own citizens and representing a dynamic force in the global arenaâ€. From this vision it is clear that the African Union should not be driven by the agenda of other countries. In the absence of such foreign policy towards other countries, Africa will establish relationships based on the agenda and policy of other countries.
The presence of a common foreign policy will help Africa to have a clearly defined strategic partnership and approach to external relations. In designing the common foreign policy there is a need to have unanimous consensus among the member states of the African Union. However, the policy of the continent should not go down to specific policy details.
Africa should develop its own foreign policy which is a mechanism for adopting common principles and guidelines in interacting with other countries. Currently, the African Union is promoting the active participation and contribution of African peoples in the development and integration of the continent. To meet this objective the AU Commission has disclosed the fact that it will receive â€œinputs informing Agenda 2063 until November 2013.â€ I believe that the organization will give attention to the issue of common foreign policy of the African Union. I hope that my recommendation on the subject will be considered by the organization.
Melaku Mulualem
is a Stakeholder Foreign Affairs Training and Policy Consultancy Director General at the Institute of Foreign
Affairs
.
