The Golden Jubilee of Diplomatic Relationships: 50 Years of Ethio-Cuba Friendship

### 12
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/03/does-the-expansion-of-brics-catalyze-the-shifting-of-the-world-order
TITLE: Does the Expansion of BRICS Catalyze the Shifting of the World Order? â€“ IFA

Introduction
There is a commonly heard Victor Hugoâ€™s saying: â€œNo one can resist an idea whose time has comeâ€. The genesis of BRICS was one of such thoughts when the term was coined by Jim Oâ€™Neil in 2001. Originally, the term ascribed to the emerging economies of Brazil, Russia, India and China which could dominate the world economy by the year 2050 (The Economist, 2023). Some years later, under the initiation of Russia, those four countries announced the formation of a global economic giant dubbed as BRICs on June 16, 2009, at Yekaterinburg, Russia. At the midst, the absence of an African representative from the Global South forced the group to expand its footprint into Africa, resulting South Africa to become the first beneficiary of the BRICS expansion in the history of the bloc.
From the outset, BRICS founding members had conflicting positions on the expansion of BRICS. In particular, their negotiations for expansion faced significant pressure from China and Russia who advocated for the inclusion of more countries. In contrast, Brazil and India resisted, at least, Chinaâ€™s version of expansion (Daldegan, 2023). Setting aside their differences at the Johannesburg Summit, however, the bloc approved the integration of six new members, mainly from Middle East and North Africa region. These include Argentina, Ethiopia, Egypt, Iran, Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates. The inclusion of these countries embolden the blocâ€™s long serving principle of consensus based approach (East Asia Forum, 2024), thereby structurally increasing their leverage in the global system â€“ such as enabling to adjust the shifting world order in their favor.
It seems there is a growing consensus on the issue the contemporary world order is shifting toward a multipolar system. Alfred Mccony, the Nation Magazine Newsletter columnist, underscored, â€œThe end of our world order is imminentâ€, predicting the inevitable dawn fall of the â€œAmerican designed global orderâ€. In this context, the recent expansion of the BRICS alliance system could further catalyze this shift in a meaningful manner. Several MENA countries which have been traditionally US strong allies now joined the BRICS group. That means, in principle, those MENA countries share the groupâ€™s core values and goals, such as the establishment of a multipolar international order without hegemony and the formation of a fairer global governance system (Haibin, 2013). Beyond that the expansion could promote the notion of South-South cooperation, as leverage when time permits.
The Expansion of BRICS and South-South Cooperation
The BRICS group endorsed the principle of South-South Cooperation (SSC) since its inception. SSC refers to â€œ
a process whereby two or more developing countries pursue their individual and/or shared national capacity development objectives throughÂ exchanges of knowledge and skills.
â€
Perhaps relying on this definition, Zhu Jiejin (2015) distinguished between traditional and new SSC models. He characterized the new SSC model in light of substantive elements like mutual respect, equal treatment, mutual benefit based on win-win approaches. Consequently, the new SSC model seeks to the establishment of new international platforms or fundamental transformation in major global institutions. On the other hand, the traditional SSC model insisted on reasonable rights for developing countries in the international system. The impetus of this model is, therefore, reforming existing international systems.
The distinct categories of SSC models offer the esteemed reader to pose: Does the expanded BRICS vow the reformation of the existing international order or advocate for its fundamental transformation. At the moment, the preference of MENA-dominated BRICS seemed to incline towards the traditional SSC model. For instance, the position of Saudi Arabia and UAE could be cited as a best fit to the traditional SSC model â€“ they might not seek a fundamental change in the US liberal world order. This is because for years â€œthe Gulf was firmly in the USâ€™s orbit with relationships founded on the unwritten compact that Washington would be their security guarantor while Arab oil producers ensured stable global energy suppliesâ€ (Financial Times, 2023).Â  The position of Ethiopia is apparently concurrent with this traditional model. Ethiopiaâ€™s Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed, reiterated that his countries motive behind joining BRICS is not to support, oppose, or harm any group (Xinhua, 2023).
On the contrary, BRICS dominant founding countries, such as China and Russiaâ€™s perspective appears to coincide with the new SSC model. Chinese president, Xi Jinping, for instance, called for a new form of international relations where hegemony is over (United States Institute of Peace, 2023). In general, though the Johannesburg BRICS expansion may show the direction that the BRICS motive in the future is resorting to the traditional SSC model
,
the preference of the BRICS bloc pertaining to seeking a reformation or a fundamental transformation in the international order needs further investigation
Conclusion and Policy Recommendation
It is hoped that the expansion of BRICS catalyzes the shifting of the world order in favor of the Global South. Against all odds, BRICS could play a vital role in enhancing the South-South cooperation, as the bloc endorsed the principle since its inception. Besides, the formation of the New Development Bank epitomizes the desire of BRICS countries to play a bigger role in the global financial governance, serving as an alternative source of financial system. In this perspective, Ethiopiaâ€™s entry into BRICS can be considered as a â€œgolden opportunityâ€, enhancing its existing relations with Global Powers such as Russia and China. Indeed, the country should insist on the â€œgolden meanâ€ in its foreign relations to escape any hit back from the Western countries. The golden mean would balance Ethiopiaâ€™s relation with its traditional Western allies on one hand and members of the expanded BRICS, on the other hand. In general, Ethiopia needs to navigate vigilantly in such a way that BRICSâ€™ membership yields more benefits than costs.
References
Daldegan, W. (2023). Opinion â€“ The Expansion of BRICS: Challenges and Uncertainties. E â€“international.

https://eastasiaforum.org
/
Jeiji, Z. (2015). New Southâ€“South Co-Operation and the BRICS New Development Bank available at
https://saiia.org.za/

Xinhua. (2023). Ethiopiaâ€™s entry into BRICS mechanism to boost economic growth, political cooperation: experts

### 13
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/13/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%9D-%F0%9D%90%96%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9D
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğšğ§ğ ğ–ğ¨ğ«ğ¥ğ ğğšğ§ğ¤ ğ’ğ­ğ«ğğ§ğ ğ­ğ¡ğğ§ ğğšğ«ğ­ğ§ğğ«ğ¬ğ¡ğ¢ğ© ğ¨ğ§ ğ‡ğ®ğ¦ğšğ§ ğ‚ğšğ©ğ¢ğ­ğšğ¥ ğƒğğ¯ğğ¥ğ¨ğ©ğ¦ğğ§ğ­ â€“ IFA

H.E. Ahmed Shide, Minister of Finance of Ethiopia, held discussions
with H.E. Mamta Murthi, World Bank Vice President for the Peopleâ€™s Vice Presidency, reaffirming shared commitment to advancing Ethiopiaâ€™s human capital agenda.
The Minister underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic focus on enhancing quality education, improving healthcare delivery, and expanding social protection systems to safeguard the well-being of citizens. He expressed appreciation for the World Bankâ€™s longstanding support in promoting skills development, inclusive growth, and resilience.
Vice President Murthi commended Ethiopiaâ€™s efforts and reiterated the Bankâ€™s commitment to Ethiopiaâ€™s Health Compact, the expansion of safety nets, and progress toward Universal Health Coverage.

### 14
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/01/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%B1%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%82%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%A5-%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AB-%F0%9D%90%81%F0%9D%90%A8
TITLE: ğ„ğ±ğ©ğğ«ğ­ğ¬ ğ‚ğšğ¥ğ¥ ğŸğ¨ğ« ğğ¨ğ¥ğ ğ…ğ®ğ§ğğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ‘ğğŸğ¨ğ«ğ¦ğ¬ ğšğ§ğ ğ“ğğœğ¡-ğƒğ«ğ¢ğ¯ğğ§ ğğğšğœğğ¤ğğğ©ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğšğ­ ğ‡ğ¨ğ«ğ§ ğƒğ¢ğšğ¥ğ¨ğ ğ®ğ ğ’ğğ«ğ¢ğğ¬ ğˆğ• â€“ IFA

The Horn Dialogue Series IV continued on Monday with a dynamic third panel titled â€œInnovation, Financing, and Emerging Challenges in Future Peacekeeping,â€ bringing together leading experts to explore how Africa can secure sustainable financing and harness technology for more effective peace operations.
The session, moderated by Henok Getachew, featured Prof. Kasaija Phillip Apuuli, Bitania Tadesse, Abdirahman Aynte, and Dr. Dawit Yohannes.
Panelists tackled pressing questions: How will hybrid funding models such as UNSCR 2719 reshape African peace support operations? What alternative mechanisms can ensure predictable and sustainable financing for African-led missions? And how can innovationâ€”from AI and digital tools to drones and data systemsâ€”strengthen the future of peacekeeping while guarding against disinformation and cyber threats?
Prof. Kasaija Phillip Apuuli emphasized that real transformation begins with strengthening homegrown approaches. â€œAfrican solutions to African problems must be backed by African initiatives, African financing, and African leadership,â€ he said. He urged AU member states to contribute to peace operations according to their GDP or level of economic development, ensuring both ownership and accountability.
Discussions also underscored the need for smarter partnerships, institutional adaptation, and tech-enabled systems to modernize peacekeeping across the Horn of Africa and beyond.
The panel forms part of the two-day Horn Dialogue Series IV, organized to chart pathways for peacekeeping â€œwith an African realityâ€ beyond 2025.

### 15
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/13/understanding-ethiopias-quest-to-sea-access-the-strategic-cost-of-being-landlocked
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğšâ€™ğ¬ ğ‹ğ¨ğ§ğ  ğŒğšğ«ğœğ¡ ğ­ğ¨ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ’ğğš: ğ‘ğğ¤ğ¢ğ§ğğ¥ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğš ğ‹ğ¨ğ¬ğ­ ğŒğšğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ¢ğ¦ğ ğƒğğ¬ğ­ğ¢ğ§ğ² â€“ IFA

This excerpt is an extension of an article published on IFAâ€™s
website
in April. The previous article provided a general introduction to Ethiopiaâ€™s recent quest for sea access and the mechanisms it intends to employ to achieve this goal. However, it did not explore in-depth the strategic costs it endured being landlocked for the past four decades, despite its geographic proximity to one of the busiest maritime routes in the world, the Red Sea. This policy brief, therefore, assesses what Ethiopia has lost due to its landlocked status from a variety of angles. By examining these issues, one can better understand Ethiopiaâ€™s recent intentions to sea access in the Red Sea region while keeping intact the interests of its littoral neighbors.
Summary of Key Points
Ethiopiaâ€™s lack of sea access reduced its trade efficiency, incurs high transportation costs, limited or lower foreign direct investment, high rate of unemployment, and a 20-30% reduced economic growth compared to its littoral neighbors.
Keeping other factors constant, the transit costs for goods that Ethiopia pays to transit port have increased from USD 500,000 per day in the early 2000s to USD 2 million in 2013, and recently to USD 5 million per day.
As a regional security anchor in the Horn of Africa and the eastern half of the Southern Red Sea gate, Ethiopiaâ€™s role in regional security has been hindered by its lack of direct access to the sea.
Economic Development Perspectives
For a secure economic future, states engage in
economic exchanges
, often through trade with other nations(Lie, 2017; Oh, 2017). This exchange is facilitated by the export and import of goods and services to and from the international market. Ports play a significant role in facilitating these international trade transactions. One
major determinant
of economic development, therefore, is access to the sea. Access to the sea enhances trade efficiency, reduces transportation costs (both to and from the ports and the mainland), attracts foreign direct investment (FDI) due to geographic advantages, creates additional jobs, and stimulates economic growth. Therefore, direct access to the sea is considered a crucial engine for a nationâ€™s economic development.
Studies show that a 10% increase in port efficiency results in a
2-3% increase
in a countryâ€™s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per year. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) has also highlighted that landlocked countries, depending on their distance from the sea, experience an
average of 20-30%
lower economic development compared to those with coastal access. The farther a country is from the coast, the lower its economic development tends to be, primarily because a significant portion of its revenues is spent on transit costs â€“ payable to those providing access. As the largest landlocked country with one of the fastest-growing economies in the world (IMF, 2024), Ethiopia is potentially losing 20-30% of its economic growth each year compared to the global average. Furthermore, when compared to its coastal neighbors, Ethiopia shows a
43% lower annual
economic growth rate. This disparity is largely attributable to the high transaction costs it incurs when relying on transit states in the Horn of Africa. Specifically, the transit costs Ethiopia currently pays to Djibouti Port for a 20-foot or 40-foot equivalent container is among the highest in the world.
In the same vein, the exports of landlocked countries tend to be
less diversified
, and their export structures are generally narrower compared to those of coastal states. This results in significantly lower and more expensive international trade. For example, transportation costs from Djibouti port to and from Addis Ababa
consume 16% of the value
of goods on the international market. Keeping other factors constant, Ethiopiaâ€™s transit costs to the Djibouti port rose from half a million USD per day in the early
2000s to two million
in 2013 and have now surpassed
five million
USD per day.
Similarly, landlocked countries face increased
vulnerability to external shocks
that can undermine their prospects for sustained economic development. Much of their exports consist of primary products, such as agricultural goods, which are often seasonal and depend on favorable weather conditions. This leads to inconsistencies in their supply to external markets, and they sometimes experience low prices. Additionally, since their import-export activities rely on transit through other states, landlocked countries are often
forced to prioritize
certain items. The cost of diversifying their trade is more than twice that of transit countries.
The import-export diversification costs for non-littoral states is
50% higher
than those of their counterparts. This is particularly severe for states that rely solely on one transit access point â€“ impose additional costs whenever they needed. More importantly, their remoteness from the sea hampers the competitiveness of their firms and products in the global market. Although Ethiopia is a State without Access (SWA), it is not an enclave, which allows for the possibility of diversifying its transit access points by negotiating with coastal states. However, for decades, over 90% of Ethiopiaâ€™s import-export volume has depended exclusively on one transit access point, the Djibouti port. As a result, its import-export volume is less diversified, incurring substantial transit costs and suffering from poor service quality. Therefore, diversifying access to the sea could help mitigate transit-related costs and enhance competitiveness, ultimately increasing import-export volumes and contributing to sustained economic growth and development. Recently, there has been an initiative to import-export of a few non-containerized items through Berbera and Tadjourah. This initiative should be expanded to include other similar ports in the Horn of Africa by building corridors and trade connectivity, providing Ethiopia with the opportunity to diversify both its import-export items and access points.
Strategic Security Perspectives
Ethiopia is located in the Horn of Africa (HoA), a region that is both one of the
most strategic
locations on Earth and one of the most conflict-ridden. As a result, Ethiopia is
highly vulnerable
to increasing national and regional security threats. These threats are dynamic and rapidly evolving. To effectively address these growing security concerns, access to the sea is crucial, as naval and military facilities can serve as
docking points
and launching pads to combat issues such as organized piracy, arms trafficking, and terrorism.
In light of the complex and ambiguous maritime threats in the Red Sea region, a comprehensive counterstrategy is necessary, emphasizing access to maritime domains. Ethiopiaâ€™s role as a regional security anchor in the Horn of Africa and the eastern part of the southern Red Sea is hindered by its lack of direct sea access. Establishing transit access would not only reduce vulnerability to regional and national security threats but also
enhance the stateâ€™s ability
to respond to various threats through land, air, and naval means. Being landlocked and reliant on a single transit point provided by a neighboring country has exposed Ethiopia to multiple challenges, including terrorism, piracy, cross-border crime, and espionage.
Given the transnational nature of security threats and the fragile state of countries in the Horn of Africa, along with the proliferation of threats in the region, it is crucial for Ethiopia to secure direct sea access and maintain a
naval and military presence
along the Red Sea coasts. This strategy enhances Ethiopiaâ€™s maritime interests and secures its borders. Some studies suggest that certain African states became landlocked
due to colonialism
, which involved the drawing of artificial borders that caused them to lose their former sea access. As a result, these states may be reluctant to provide access to their landlocked neighbors, even at contractual basis, driven by unfounded suspicions that their neighbors may claim permanent access based on historical or ancestral narratives while they are wide open for foreign naval basis and military facilities.
As a regional anchor in the Horn of Africa, Ethiopia possesses modern and versatile
military power
that could significantly enhance both regional and national security if granted direct sea access. Following the Ethiopia-Eritrean rapprochement in mid-2018, for instance, geopolitical and security analysts noted a
new wave of hope
in the Horn of Africa. This positive shift also led to negotiations regarding the Eritrea-Djibouti conflict and the signing of a tripartite
peace and friendship
agreement among Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Somalia. Although these developments were short-lived, they contributed to an improved regional peace and security landscape. Consequently, Ethiopiaâ€™s direct access to maritime routes in the Red Sea not only mitigates national security vulnerabilities but also bolsters regional security cooperation.
Regional Security Perspectives
On the other hand, sea access enhances a stateâ€™s geopolitical and regional influence, allowing it to play a more prominent role in regional affairs and to establish stronger ties with its neighbors. As a civilizational state in the region, Ethiopia has been significantly involved in regional affairs. It helped establish various regional mechanisms including the Intergovernmental Authority for Development (IGAD) and its functional agencies, to facilitate regional economic integration and security cooperation. The regionâ€™s peace and security heavily depend on
Ethiopiaâ€™s unwavering
contribution to regional peacekeeping. Additionally, Ethiopia is a founding member of the
Djibouti Code of Conduct
, signed by Red Sea member states to combat piracy and armed robbery against ships in the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, and Indian Ocean. It has also played significant roles in the fight against terrorism in the horn of Africa. However, Ethiopia was excluded from the recently established Red Sea Council due to narrow criterion of lacking direct sea access. Gaining sea access could have strengthened Ethiopiaâ€™s efforts toward regional integration and security, positioning it as a hegemon capable of summoning others in the region. Unfortunately, its lack of sea access has contributed to weak regional integration and diminished regional security, hindering Ethiopiaâ€™s role and influence in both regional and global affairs.
Concluding Remarks
Sea access is a critical engine for a nationâ€™s long-term development because it facilitates trade transactions, lowers import-export transit costs, limits strategic security vulnerabilities, and strengthens regional security integration and cooperation. In contrast, landlocked countries frequently face significant challenges, such as high transit costs and limited trade transactions. Their lack of naval and military presence along coastlines makes them vulnerable to increasing national and regional security threats, restricting their maneuverability, detection, and response capabilities.
Ethiopia, despite its historical ties to the Red Sea, has faced limited economic development due to its recent landlocked status, resulting in economic unrest and increased vulnerability to escalating national and regional security threats. The recent push for sea access in the Red Sea region is a response to these growing vulnerabilities. However, Ethiopiaâ€™s efforts have been met with challenges from its littoral neighbors, owing to a misunderstanding of Ethiopiaâ€™s genuine intentions to address these economic and security concerns. As a major economic and military power in the region, Ethiopiaâ€™s access to the sea may benefit the region more than Ethiopia itself by facilitating trade connectivity and regional security cooperation. Allowing sea access to Ethiopia, therefore, not only helps the country address its national challenges but also enhances regional security in the Red Sea area. Hence, Ethiopiaâ€™s sea access should be approached from such perspectives instead of an ambition to evade sovereignty of littoral neighbors.
About the author
Amare Kenaw (Ph.D.)
, Lead researcher, and Middle East Research Affairs Director General, Institute of Foreign Affairs

Does the Expansion of BRICS Catalyze the Shifting of the World Order?
Ethiopiaâ€™s BRICS Membership: Potential to Strengthen Ties with the Middle East and North Africa Region

### 16
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/07/30/geopolitics-of-trade-why-ethiopia-must-balance-sovereignty-and-global-market-access
TITLE: Geopolitics of Trade: Why Ethiopia Must Balance Sovereignty and Global Market Access â€“ IFA

There is an African Proverb often quoted in trade diplomacy circles,
â€œIf you are not at the table, you are probably on the menu.â€
And I expound it as â€˜if you show up without a plan, you might just be the appetizerâ€™. Hereâ€™s what that really means in Ethiopiaâ€™s trade context. Letâ€™s break it down; Trade has never been purely about economics. Especially in the Horn of Africa, it is deeply entangled with political positioning, foreign influence and the enduring pursuit of sovereignty. Ethiopiaâ€™s long-stalled accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO)
[1]
, its participation in the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) and its shifting alliances with China, the West and Gulf actors reflect a country caught between competing imperatives: to protect national autonomy while also securing access to global markets.
As someone engaged in the stream of diplomacy, youth empowerment and education reform, I believe Ethiopia must reject the false binary of sovereignty vs. trade liberalization. The way forward lies in a strategic balancing act anchoring trade policy in national priorities while leveraging regional and global partnerships with clarity, skill and foresight.
Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Dilemma: Trade as a Political Choice
Ethiopia applied for WTO membership in 2003 and, after thirteen Working-Party sessions, now targets accession by the 14th WTO Ministerial in 2026 on the back of bold reforms that have pried open telecoms, finance and logistics to competition.
[2]
However, the finishing line remains contentious at home: skeptics warn premature liberalization could swamp small farmers and fledgling banks, while advocates counter that staying outside the rules-based system will keep investor confidence low and leave Ethiopia voiceless when trade disputes arise.
At the same time, Addis Ababa is a founding signatory of the AfCFTA, theoretically entitled to tariff-free entry into a continental market of 1.4â€¯billion people. In practice, customs delays, thin transport corridors and stubborn non-tariff barriers still choke that promise.
To hedge the gap, Ethiopia has turned to a patchwork of bilateral deals: Chinese Belt-and-Road rail finance, Gulf logistics capital and Western preference schemes such as AGOA each partner arriving with its own (sometimes unspoken) expectations on access and influence.
The strategic choice therefore is not
whether
to liberalize but how to choreograph the opening on Ethiopiaâ€™s terms. A phased WTO deal leveraging special-and-differential treatment, ring-fencing sensitive sectors and insisting on capacity-building from partners would let Ethiopia enjoy global market access without surrendering sovereignty. In short, Ethiopia must own both the timetable and the terms of its trade future.
The Hidden Cost of Overdependence
Trade can be wielded like a tool or a weapon. When the United States suspended Ethiopiaâ€™s African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) benefits in 2021, thousands of mostly female textile workers in Hawassa Industrial Park saw orders vanish overnight.
[3]
At the other end of the spectrum, Beijingâ€™s concessional lending instrumental in delivering the Addis-Djibouti Railway; now prompts legitimate scrutiny over long-term debt sustainability and operational sovereignty.
[4]
Ethiopia must not be seen as a passive casualty of global trade politics, but as a sovereign actor capable of turning pressure into strategy. The suspension of AGOA and the debt entanglements from projects like the Addis-Djibouti Railway reveal an uncomfortable truth: trade partnerships are rarely neutral.
Nevertheless these events also offer a crucial lesson, dependency is not destiny. Rather than accept the terms handed down by more powerful actors, Ethiopia should view every shock be it a suspended trade privilege or a conditional loan as a strategic signal to diversify its export base, strengthen its regional linkages under AfCFTA, and refine its debt governance mechanisms. Geopolitical friction, when approached with clarity and intent, can serve as a catalyst for smarter diplomacy and more resilient economic planning. Trade is not merely a channel for growth, it is a mirror reflecting the countryâ€™s bargaining posture and capacity to innovate under pressure.
The slow pace of Ethiopiaâ€™s WTO accession does not indicate reluctance, but rather the gravity of the reforms required to meet the bar. These arenâ€™t cosmetic adjustments instead they are systemic overhauls enhancing monetary and fiscal policy alignment, improving the transparency of State-Owned Enterprises, liberalizing trading rights and replacing administrative discretion with rule-based customs protocols. Each task demands not only legal reform but also institutional strength, data infrastructure and inter-agency coordination. But hereâ€™s the opportunity: Ethiopia does not have to replicate models from more developed economies. Instead, it can craft a trade architecture that aligns with its own development realities one that liberalizes at a measured pace, protects emerging industries and maintains policy flexibility. The goal should not be blind integration, but intelligent engagement trade policy as an extension of national will. In doing so, Ethiopia can ensure that its entry into the global market is not an act of surrender, but a declaration of sovereignty on its own terms.
Reframing Sovereignty: From Protectionism to Strategy
True sovereignty is not isolation; it is the ability to make informed, autonomous decisions in a complex international system. Ethiopiaâ€™s decision-makers must resist both extremes:
Blind liberalization, which risks undermining domestic industries and
Overprotection, which discourages innovation and foreign investment.
Instead, a graduated approach to global market integration is needed one that:
Prioritizes strategic sectors (like agriculture, logistics and digital trade),
Implements smart safeguards to protect vulnerable populations,
And builds negotiation capacity within Ethiopiaâ€™s ministries, trade missions and youth leadership pipelines.
Diplomacy Is the Missing Piece
Trade and diplomacy cannot be separated. Ethiopia must actively shape the rules of trade engagement, not simply react to them. This means,
Re-engaging WTO Accession with Clear Red Lines:
Ethiopia must fully harness its status as a Least Developed Country (LDC) at the WTO, not as a plea for charity, but as a strategic right grounded in global development justice. Special and Differential Treatment (SDT) provisions offer more than transition periods and technical support; they are a lifeline for countries charting their own development paths amid global asymmetries. Ethiopia should push boldly for sector-specific safeguards and policy space while it still qualifies, using the LDC window to lock in favorable terms that reflect its economic structure and social priorities. However graduation from LDC status must not be viewed as the end of leverage; it should signal a shift in posture, from cautious negotiation to confident agenda-setting. As a country on the rise with regional influence and an energetic youth population, Ethiopia has every reason to approach WTO accession not with submissiveness but with vision. Through smart alliances under AfCFTA and COMESA, it can defend vital sectors like agriculture and digital trade, while crafting a post-LDC trade policy rooted in resilience, flexibility and long-term national interest. Ethiopiaâ€™s engagement with the global trading system must reflect the country it aspires to be not just today, but in the decade ahead sovereign, strategic and unapologetically self-defined.
Using AfCFTA as a Leverage Tool:
Through embracing and deepening its integration within AfCFTA, Ethiopia gains a strengthened regional voice that demands fairer and more balanced terms in global arenas like the WTO. This continental partnership aligns perfectly with Ethiopiaâ€™s ongoing reforms, helping to break down non-tariff barriers and build resilient value chains that reduce reliance on a narrow set of external markets. AfCFTA offers Ethiopia not only economic diversification but also the political leverage to negotiate from a position of strength, anchored in a collective African agenda that truly reflects the continentâ€™s development needs. In this light, Ethiopia is no longer a lone player reacting to global trade pressures, it is a proud and purposeful contributor to shaping the rules of the game.
Training the Next Generation of Economic Diplomats:
I have never failed to state this agenda wherever I engage, since building a strong foundation for Ethiopiaâ€™s future begins at the root. Ethiopia must cultivate youth trade diplomats who understand geopolitics, economics, science and negotiation. Programs like a â€œYoung Trade Envoys Fellowshipâ€ can equip future negotiators with the tools to defend national interests in global trade forums.
Recap: The Path Ahead-Trade as a Sovereign Act
The real challenge for Ethiopia is not whether to engage in global trade, but how to do so with clear strategy, national purpose and dignity. Trade is more than tariffs and quotas. It is a political decision deeply linked to our foreign policy, education and economic vision. When Ethiopia shapes trade policy through the lens of national interest and informed diplomacy; it sends a clear message to the worldâ€¦
â€œWe are open for business, but not at any cost. We are ready to lead, but not to be led blindly. We value global access, but not at the expense of national dignity!â€
Ethiopia must move from being a passive rule-taker to an active rule-shaper, leveraging regional alliances, industrial growth and the energy of a new generation. Bold leadership must align trade with job creation, climate resilience, innovation and regional unity. Trade should empower Ethiopia, strengthening its sovereignty and peaceÂ  rather than compromising it. By choosing strategic engagement over passive adaptation, Ethiopia can write its own economic story on its own terms.
For Ethiopia, the choice is not between sovereignty and markets. It is between passive adaptation and strategic engagement. The future of Ethiopian trade will not be built in Geneva or Washington alone, it will be shaped in Addis Ababa, in regional forums and in the minds of the countryâ€™s emerging generation of diplomats, economists and entrepreneurs. Trade must serve the people, protect national resilience and unlock prosperity not just for a few exporters, but for a nation ready to rise.
[1]

. Addis Ababa: MoTRI, 2024.
[3]

Africa in Focus
, February 2022.
https://www.brookings.edu/articles/ethiopia-agoa-removal/
[4]

. Ministry of Commerce of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China, 2023.

About the Author
Kidus Tesfaye is a PhD candidate at Addis Ababa University with a multidisciplinary understanding of sustainable development, including infrastructure, water systems and public services. He previously worked on technical systems such as energy and water, exploring their roles in fostering inclusive and resilient growth across the continent. Currently focuses on exploring the intersection of education, youth empowerment and regional cooperation, particularly how curriculum development, higher education and vocational training can drive inclusive economic growth and soft power in Africa. He also brings experience in project management, business consulting and diplomacy-related initiatives that contribute to Ethiopiaâ€™s development agenda.

UNFSS+4 in Ethiopia: Forging the Link between Food Sovereignty and Global Food Systems
Remembering the Journey: The GERD Dispute and the Promise of Diplomacy

### 17
URL: https://www.gadasez.gov.et/joint-statement-of-the-peoples-republic-of-china-and-the-federal-democratic-republic-of-ethiopia-on-the-establishment-of-an-all-weather-strategic-partnership
TITLE: Joint Statement of the People's Republic of China and the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia on the Establishment of an All-weather Strategic Partnership - Gada Special Economic Zone

Joint Statement of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China and the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia on the Establishment of an All-weather Strategic Partnership
At the invitation of President Xi Jinping, Abi Ahmed Ali, Prime Minister of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, attended the third Belt and Road International Cooperation Summit Forum held in Beijing from October 15 to 21, 2023. During this period, Prime Minister Abi paid an official visit to the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China.
â€¦..
â€¦During the visit, President Xi Jinping of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China met with Prime Minister Abi of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, and Premier Li Qiang of the State Council of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China held talks with Prime Minister Abi. In an atmosphere of friendship, honesty and mutual trust, the two sides exchanged in-depth views on bilateral relations and international and regional issues of common concern, and reached a broad consensus. The two countries also signed a number of agreements aimed at deepening China-Egypt friendly cooperation.
â€¦I. The two sides spoke highly of the comprehensive strategic cooperative partnership established by the two countries in 2017, and expressed satisfaction with the fruitful results of practical and friendly cooperation between the two countries. The two sides agreed to maintain high-level exchanges, enhance political mutual trust, deepen mutually beneficial cooperation, and better benefit the two peoples. The two sides announced that the existing partnership will be upgraded to an all-weather strategic partnership.
IX. The two sides agree that Chinese-style modernisation will bring new opportunities for cooperation between the two countries, and strengthening pragmatic cooperation and close economic ties is in the fundamental interests of the two peoples. The two sides agreed to further strengthen the balanced and mutually beneficial trade partnership. China is willing to continue to encourage and support the export of Ethiopian products to China, including agricultural and food products, and welcomes the Ethiopian side to use African agricultural products to export to China through the â€œgreen channelâ€.
â€¦X. Both sides agree that industrialisation, agricultural modernisation and talent training are the keys to promoting independent development. The Ethiopian side appreciates the â€œSupporting African Industrialisation Initiativeâ€, â€œChinaâ€™s Plan for Africaâ€™s Agricultural Modernisation Planâ€ and â€œChina-Africa Talent Training Cooperation Planâ€ put forward by President Xi Jinping at the China-Africa Leaders Dialogue. China appreciates Ethiopiaâ€™s vigourous development of manufacturing industry, investment and development of industrial parks and special economic zones. It is willing to continue to promote investment in Ethiopia, explore cooperation projects such as Yaji Railway Danon, and provide support for the construction of industrial parks and special economic zones in Ethiopia.
Source: Xinhua News Agency, Beijing, October 17

### 18
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/24/%F0%9D%90%85%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A6-%F0%9D%90%87%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A0%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A6%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A7-%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A8-%F0%9D%90%82%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A7
TITLE: ğ…ğ«ğ¨ğ¦ ğ‡ğğ ğğ¦ğ¨ğ§ ğ­ğ¨ ğ‚ğ¨ğ§ğ§ğğœğ­ğ¨ğ«â€”ğ¨ğ« ğ’ğ¨ğ¦ğğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ¢ğ§ ğğğ­ğ°ğğğ§? ğ–ğ¡ğšğ­ ğ‘ğğšğ¥ğ¥ğ² ğƒğ«ğ¢ğ¯ğğ¬ ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğšâ€™ğ¬ ğğ¨ğ¬ğ­-ğŸğŸğŸğŸ– ğ…ğ¨ğ«ğğ¢ğ ğ§ ğğ¨ğ¥ğ¢ğœğ²? â€“ IFA

Background: Reform, Rupture, and Continuity
Since 2018, Ethiopia has undergone a profound foreign policy recalibration shaped by domestic political transition, ideological reorientation, and changing regional geopolitics. The ascent of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed marked the end of an era dominated by security-first diplomacy and highly centralized coalition governance. At the same time, the Horn of Africa experienced escalating instability Sudanâ€™s political crisis, Somaliaâ€™s fragile state-building trajectory, Eritreaâ€™s shifting alignments, and intensifying competition over the Red Sea corridor. Against this backdrop, Ethiopiaâ€™s foreign policy evolved through a hybrid approach that combines reformist and economic diplomacy with the understanding of the definition of interest as national and common which shift from the predominant definition of national interest as a guiding policy of state. This briefing examines the structural drivers of Ethiopiaâ€™s post-2018 foreign policy, the contradictions emerging from this transition, and key implications for regional engagement.
Ethiopiaâ€™s foreign policy shift cannot be understood without considering the broader political reconfiguration after 2018. Abiyâ€™s early outreach particularly the normalization of relations with Eritrea signaled a departure from the EPRDFâ€™s threat-driven security doctrine (Abbink, 2019). His government framed this transformation through the philosophy of
Medemer
, which emphasizes synergy, reconciliation, and interdependence (Abiy, 2019). High-profile state visits to Djibouti, Eritrea, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan, and Sudan embodied a diplomatic offensive grounded in soft-power engagement and regional integration.
Yet, these openings unfolded alongside deep domestic turbulence, including the 2020â€“2022 war in northern Ethiopia, rising ethno-nationalist contestation, and widening political fragmentation. These internal dynamics frequently undermined external commitments, revealing the limits of early optimism (Clapham, 2021). Thus, Ethiopiaâ€™s post-2018 foreign policy reflects both reformist aspirations and structural continuities rooted in domestic instability.
Key drivers of Ethiopiaâ€™s evolving Horn policy
Ethiopiaâ€™s evolving Horn of Africa policy is shaped by several interrelated drivers. First, the ideological influence of Medemer (Abiy, 2019) introduced a vision of cooperative regional engagement built on partnership, connectivity, and economic interdependence. This orientation informed Ethiopiaâ€™s renewed commitment to IGAD, its push for cross-border infrastructure, and its â€œneighborhood firstâ€ diplomatic posture. Although this framework aimed to shift Ethiopiaâ€™s image from security hegemon to regional integration champion, limitations in institutional capacity have reduced its transformative potential.
Second, Ethiopiaâ€™s foreign policy has been increasingly driven by economic imperatives, particularly market liberalization, infrastructure expansion, and the structural challenge of landlockedness. Diversifying sea access, reducing overreliance on Djibouti, and strengthening transport and energy linkages with Kenya, Sudan, and South Sudan have become core priorities (World Bank, 2020). The renewed maritime access debates of 2023â€“2024 underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s need to secure cost-effective and politically sustainable trade routes, elevating economic diplomacy as a central tool of external engagement.
Third, intensifying geopolitical competition in the Red Sea has significantly shaped Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic environment. Egyptian activism over the GERD, rivalry among Gulf States, Turkeyâ€™s expanding footprint, and the growing presence of both the United States and China have created a more complex regional landscape (International Crisis Group, 2023). These dynamics constrain Ethiopiaâ€™s choices but also provide opportunities for selective alignment. Ethiopiaâ€™s revived naval ambitions and renewed maritime focus reflects its effort to maintain strategic relevance in an increasingly militarized Red Sea corridor.
Fourth, evolving alliances and regional mistrust have further complicated Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomatic trajectory. Relations with Eritrea deteriorated following the Pretoria Agreement, with Asmaraâ€™s continued use of internal proxies as part of its foreign policy; the 2024 MoU with Somaliland triggered a diplomatic rupture with Somalia; and tensions with Sudan over al-Fashaga remain unresolved (Lefort, 2022). Many of these tensions arise from the intersection of Ethiopiaâ€™s domestic political dynamics and regional concerns about its long-term strategic intentions.
Challenges Undermining the Neighborhood First Policy
Ethiopiaâ€™s â€œneighborhood firstâ€ policy, despite its cooperative ambitions, continues to be undermined by deep-rooted structural and political challenges across the Horn of Africa. The region remains characterized by a persistent trust deficit shaped by decades of historical grievances, unresolved border disputes, and divergent security priorities among neighboring states. These long-standing tensions have made it difficult for Ethiopiaâ€™s recent diplomatic overtures to gain full credibility, as states continue to interpret its actions through the lens of past rivalries and asymmetrical power relations. Differences in political worldviews and governance models further complicate regional engagement, creating ideological distance between Ethiopia and some of its neighbors.
The debate over sea access has intensified these anxieties. While Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of reliable maritime outlets reflects a fundamental economic necessity and concerns related to state survival, many neighboring countries perceive this quest with suspicion due to historical reasons, unworthy reasoning, and purposive misunderstanding. Nationalist political narratives across the region especially in Somalia and Eritrea frame Ethiopiaâ€™s maritime aspirations as potential precursors to renewed hegemonic behavior or territorial encroachment which will not help actually for integration and cooperation and mislead the rationality. These fears, often amplified by domestic politics and media discourse, have constrained opportunities for constructive negotiation, making even economically rational proposals vulnerable to political backlash. The result is a regional environment where cooperative intent is easily overshadowed by entrenched mistrust and competing strategic narratives.
Conclusion
Ethiopiaâ€™s foreign policy trajectory since 2018 has evolved into a hybrid model ambitious in its strategic vision, increasingly institutionalized and consistently challenged by internal vulnerabilities and regional pressures. The shift toward cooperation, regional connectivity, and economic diplomacy represents a marked departure from the historically security-centered and militarized approach that dominated Ethiopiaâ€™s engagement with its neighbors for decades. This reorientation reflects a recognition that long-term stability and growth depend on mutually beneficial partnerships, integrated markets, and reduced geopolitical frictions within the Horn of Africa.
Bridging the gap between the aspirational ideals of
Medemer
and the complex realities of Horn of Africa politics therefore requires deliberate and sustained efforts. Ethiopia must further re-institutionalize its foreign policy apparatus, build predictable diplomatic channels, and invest in long-term trust-building with its neighbors. Only through such a coherent and confidence-enhancing approach can Ethiopia secure its strategic interests such as diversified sea access, regional stability, and economic integration while contributing meaningfully to a more peaceful and cooperative Horn of Africa.

### 20
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/10/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%80%F0%9D%90%9D%F0%9D%90%AF%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğ€ğğ¯ğšğ§ğœğğ¬ ğ†ğ¥ğ¨ğ›ğšğ¥ ğšğ§ğ ğ‘ğğ ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ ğ“ğ«ğšğğ ğˆğ§ğ­ğğ ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ â€“ IFA

H.E. Kassahun Gofe (PhD), Minister of Trade and
Regional Integration, announced Ethiopiaâ€™s dual progress in international trade diplomacy with the launch of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) implementation next week and significant advancement in the WTO accession process.
He confirmed that Ethiopiaâ€™s 6th WTO Working Party meeting in Geneva marked a milestone, with Ethiopiaâ€™s negotiating documents formally accepted and wide support expressed by member states. The 7th Working Party meeting is scheduled for January.
At the same time, Ethiopiaâ€™s launch of AfCFTA implementation represents a decisive step toward deeper African economic integration, contributing to food security, poverty reduction, and sustainable development in line with Agenda 2063 and the UN SDGs.
Minister Kassahun emphasized that these twin tracks of AfCFTA and WTO accession reflect Ethiopiaâ€™s steadfast commitment to expanding its role in both regional and global markets, fostering sustainable growth, and opening new opportunities for trade and investment.

### 21
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/30/ethiopias-posture-and-policy-architecture-for-the-2025-g20-johannesburg-summit
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Posture and Policy Architecture for the 2025 G20 Johannesburg Summit â€“ IFA

Introduction
The 20th Summit of the Group of Twenty (G20), convened in Johannesburg, South Africa, marked a historic moment for Africa within global economic governance. For the first time, African voicesâ€”represented by the African Union as a permanent G20 memberâ€”held a decisive role in shaping the agenda for sustainable growth, digital equity, and climate resilience. For Ethiopia, a leading diplomatic power in the Horn of Africa and a champion of continental integration, the summit provided both a diplomatic opportunity and a developmental imperative. It demonstrated Ethiopiaâ€™s evolving statecraft: positioning itself as a bridge between developing economies and major economic powers while advancing an African-led policy consensus around equitable growth, the energy transition, and innovation governance (African Union Commission [AUC], 2025; Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ethiopia [MoFA], 2025).
Strategic Anchors: From National Vision to Global Advocacy
Ethiopiaâ€™s engagement at the 2025 G20 Summit is underpinned by its domestic policy frameworks, particularly the
Digital Ethiopia 2025
strategy and its successor,
Digital Ethiopia 2030 (DE2030)
. These frameworks seek to transform Ethiopia into a digitally driven economy with equitable access to technology and opportunities (World Bank, 2024). DE2030 expands the original digital strategy by placing greater emphasis on ethical artificial intelligence (AI) development, cybersecurity, and cross-border data governance. This domestic focus aligns with the global G20 agenda on shaping safe and inclusive digital economies.
At the same time, Ethiopiaâ€™s
Climate-Resilient Green Economy (CRGE)
strategy serves as a foundation for its energy diplomacy within the G20. The nationâ€™s messaging at the Johannesburg summit centered around advancing a
Just Energy Transition
â€”promoting clean energy access without compromising growth trajectories. Ethiopiaâ€™s argument is framed through the normative lens of
Common but Differentiated Responsibilities and Respective Capabilities (CBDR-RC)
, which posits that industrialized nations must bear a greater burden for financing Africaâ€™s transition to renewable energy (African Development Bank [AfDB], 2024).
Leveraging its vast potential for hydropower, solar, and geothermal energy, Ethiopia called for multilateral support in scaling renewable infrastructure through debt-for-climate swaps, concessional financing, and technology sharing. This position resonated with continental initiatives such as the AUâ€™s
Addis Ababa Declaration on Climate Change and Call to Action
(AUC, 2025), reinforcing Ethiopiaâ€™s leadership in the global Southâ€™s collective demand for climate justice.
Digital Sovereignty and the Fight against â€œDigital Colonialismâ€
A major dimension of Ethiopiaâ€™s strategy at the G20 was the advocacy for equitable digital governance. The emergence of an AI-driven global economy presents both opportunities and risks for developing states. Ethiopiaâ€™s intervention on
Artificial Intelligence Governance
emphasized closing the digital divide while preventing what its delegation termed â€œdigital colonialismâ€â€”a situation where technological dependency perpetuates structural inequities between the Global North and South (Kassa, 2024).
Under the DE2030 framework, Ethiopia promotes principles of
digital sovereignty
, advocating for open data ecosystems, localized innovation ecosystems, and regional cloud infrastructure built on African regulatory frameworks. By aligning these proposals with the African Unionâ€™s ongoing work to establish a
Continental Artificial Intelligence Strategy
, Ethiopia positioned itself as a policy entrepreneur within the G20 digital inclusion agenda (Agarwal, 2025). These advocacy efforts drew inspiration from the UNâ€™s
Global Digital Compact
, highlighting the countryâ€™s commitment to a digital order that upholds ethical standards, inclusivity, and transparency (United Nations, 2024).
Finance, Fairness, and Reforming Global Economic Institutions
Beyond sectoral initiatives, Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomacy at the Johannesburg Summit was guided by the principle of structural reform within international financial governance. As a member state closely tied to the
BRICS+
architecture, Ethiopia endorsed calls for a more representative global financial system focused on sustainable development financing and debt relief for developing economies (BRICS Secretariat, 2024).
Ethiopiaâ€™s delegation underscored the mismatch between Africaâ€™s demographic and resource endowments and its limited representation in global decision-making bodies. Its proposals included the expansion of the International Monetary Fundâ€™s Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) for low-income countries and the redirection of climate finance through multilateral development banks such as the African Development Bank and the New Development Bank (NDB, 2025). These mechanisms, Ethiopia argued, could bolster Africaâ€™s fiscal space without deepening debt distress.
The Ethiopian Prime Ministerâ€™s address also echoed themes of
developmental multilateralism
, calling for an integrated approach to trade, climate adaptation, and digital infrastructure. Such positions were critical in reinforcing Ethiopiaâ€™s identity as both a reformist and a bridge-builder between the Global South and established economic powers (Ahmed, 2025).
Pan-African Coordination and Leadership
Ethiopiaâ€™s participation in the Johannesburg Summit illustrated the convergence between its domestic reforms and its continental diplomacy. As host of the African Union Headquarters and a permanent voice within Africaâ€™s G20 delegation, Ethiopia coordinated closely with South Africa, Nigeria, and Egypt to articulate a common African position on global equity, technology transfer, and sustainable industrialization.
By linking national strategies to Agenda 2063â€™s flagship projectsâ€”including the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) and the Pan-African Payment and Settlement Systemâ€”Ethiopia reinforced the message that Africaâ€™s integration is indispensable to global prosperity (AUC, 2025). This cooperative posture underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s transformation from a largely aid-dependent economy into a diplomatic actor advocating for fairness, autonomy, and shared advancement.
Conclusion: A Catalyst for African Voice and Vision
Ethiopiaâ€™s policy architecture at the 2025 G20 Summit embodies the countryâ€™s broader transition from inward development planning to proactive global engagement. Grounded in its technological modernization agenda and commitment to green growth, its diplomacy in Johannesburg provided a template for how African economies can negotiate a seat at the table of global governanceâ€”on their own terms.
By promoting
Just Energy Transition
,
Digital Sovereignty
, and
Global Institutional Reform
, Ethiopia positioned itself not as a peripheral observer but as a key player in the reconfiguration of economic power. In doing so, it reaffirmed its status as a continental thought leader navigating a rapidly transforming global landscape.

### 22
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/23/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A6
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğ‘ğğšğŸğŸğ¢ğ«ğ¦ğ¬ ğ‹ğğšğğğ«ğ¬ğ¡ğ¢ğ© ğ¢ğ§ ğğğšğœğ ğšğ§ğ ğ’ğ­ğšğ›ğ¢ğ¥ğ¢ğ­ğ² ğ€ğœğ«ğ¨ğ¬ğ¬ ğ€ğŸğ«ğ¢ğœğš â€“ IFA

Ethiopia continues to strengthen its position as a leading advocate for peace, stability, and reconstruction across Africa. The opening of the 17th International Training on Post-Conflict Stabilization and Reconstruction in Addis Ababa highlighted the countryâ€™s growing influence in shaping dialogue on conflict recovery and sustainable development.
Organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Romania in partnership with Ethiopiaâ€™s Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA), the program reflects a shared understanding that building lasting peace requires cooperation between local, regional, and global actors. It also demonstrates Ethiopiaâ€™s readiness to transform its own experiences in peacebuilding into lessons and inspiration for the continent.
H.E. Jafar Bedru, Executive Director of IFA, emphasized that African nations are working diligently to move from instability toward sustainable peace and stronger institutions. He noted that the diversity of participants from across Africa, representing a wide range of experiences and perspectives, stands as one of the programâ€™s greatest strengths. This diversity, he said, reflects Africaâ€™s collective will to lead its own path toward stability.
â€œYour presence here demonstrates our shared belief that post-conflict reconstruction must be led by local actors, strengthened through regional cooperation, and supported by global partnerships,â€ he stated.
H.E. Jafar also underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s National Dialogue and Transitional Justice process as a central pillar of its peacebuilding journey. These initiatives are designed to heal divisions, rebuild trust, and strengthen national unity. They also serve as examples of Ethiopiaâ€™s homegrown approach to resolving internal challenges through dialogue rather than confrontation.
IFA, he added, continues to serve as a bridge between diplomacy and peacebuilding, equipping diplomats, policymakers, and regional actors with the tools and knowledge needed to promote peace and cooperation.
H.E. Lulia Pataki, Ambassador of Romania to Ethiopia, described the training as a cornerstone of Romaniaâ€™s Africa strategy. She highlighted that the programâ€™s focus on combating disinformation is particularly timely, as misinformation continues to threaten peace, stability, and development across the world. She noted that this forum creates valuable opportunities for connection, learning, and the exchange of expertise on how to prevent instability and rebuild societies.
H.E. Daniela Dobre, Director General of the Romanian Agency for International Development, added that the training has evolved from a technical initiative into a genuine platform for dialogue and collaboration. Bringing together civilian and military experts, policymakers, and practitioners from across Africa and beyond, the program underscores the power of cooperation in shaping shared solutions.
â€œThe last three editions have shown us that collaboration and knowledge sharing are among the most powerful tools for building peace and stability,â€ she observed.
Ethiopiaâ€™s active engagement in this initiative once again highlights its role as both a participant and a leader in continental peacebuilding. By sharing its experiences and promoting African-led solutions, the country continues to demonstrate that stability, dialogue, and institutional resilience are essential foundations for the continentâ€™s collective progress.
The five-day program combines theoretical and practical sessions aimed at strengthening regional capacity, encouraging collaboration, and empowering African nations to turn shared challenges into opportunities for peace, growth, and sustainable reconstruction.

Romania Promotes African-Led Solutions, Strategic Cooperation for Development

### 23
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/09/08/%F0%9D%90%93%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%82%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%81%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%86
TITLE: â€œğ“ğ¡ğ ğğ¢ğ¥ğ ğ‚ğšğ§ğ§ğ¨ğ­ ğğ ğ†ğ¨ğ¯ğğ«ğ§ğğ ğ›ğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¥ğ¨ğ§ğ¢ğšğ¥-ğ„ğ«ğš ğ“ğ«ğğšğ­ğ¢ğğ¬,â€ â€“ IFA

In his recent article, â€œğ“ğ¡ğ ğğ¢ğ¥ğ ğ‚ğšğ§ğ§ğ¨ğ­ ğğ ğ†ğ¨ğ¯ğğ«ğ§ğğ ğ›ğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¥ğ¨ğ§ğ¢ğšğ¥-ğ„ğ«ğš ğ“ğ«ğğšğ­ğ¢ğğ¬,â€ H.E. Jafar Bedru, Executive Director of @ifa_ethiopia, highlights the importance of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) as a testament to Ethiopiaâ€™s commitment to utilizing the Blue Nile (Abay) for national development.

Ethiopia is set to unveil the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in September 2025
From Suez Canal to Bab al-Mandab Strait: Navigating Maritime Security in the Worldâ€™s Busiest Maritime Trade Corridor

### 24
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/04/19/beyond-the-fray-africas-agency-amidst-a-contentious-global-trade-order
TITLE: Beyond the Fray: Africaâ€™s Agency Amidst a Contentious Global Trade Order â€“ IFA

As the global order teeters on the precipice of transformation, two intersecting conflicts, one geopolitical and the other economic, are reshaping the contours of international relations. In both of these unfolding dramas, Africa finds itself conspicuously marginalized, left to navigate the shifting tides of global power without a seat at the table. The first is a maritime security crisis in the Red Sea region, precipitated by the United Statesâ€™ military intervention against the Houthis in Yemen. While this conflict appears to have minimal direct impact on U.S. interests, especially when measured against the broader context of the Gaza-Israel war following the October 7 attacks, Washington has elected to intervene unilaterally. This decision has been made without securing the explicit endorsement of critical regional stakeholders such as Eritrea, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, or even China, all of whom possess a vested interest in the security of one of the worldâ€™s most vital maritime trade routes.
[1]
Africa, despite its geographical proximity, remains peripheral to this critical conversation, as its influence over the outcome is negligible.
The second conflict, of a distinctly economic nature, pertains to the ongoing and intensifying trade war between the United States, China, and a host of other economic powers. What began as a series of punitive tariffs imposed by the U.S. on China, Mexico, and Canada has since spiraled into an all-encompassing trade confrontation that includes major global economies, including the European Union. The imposition of tariffs on China, initiated on February 1, 2025, at a modest 10%, quickly escalated to 20% after reciprocal measures by China.
[2]
By mid-April, tariffs had surged to unprecedented levels, with the U.S. imposing a staggering 145% tariff on Chinese imports, which amounted to $438.95 billion in 2024, and China retaliating with a 125% tariff on $143.55 billion worth of U.S. goods.
[3]
These moves were followed by the U.S.â€™s imposition of tariffs on all nations other than China, further deepening the divide.
The ramifications of this trade war are nothing short of seismic, as it has catalyzed a realignment of the global economic order. According to the International Monetary Fundâ€™s 2024 Economic Outlook, the U.S., the EU, and China collectively represent the lionâ€™s share of the global economy, with respective GDPs of $30.3 trillion, $20.29 trillion, and $19.53 trillion.
[4]
Their trade war is not merely a bilateral dispute between two nations, but rather an economic confrontation that could destabilize the broader global economic system, with profound implications for all economies, including those of Africa.
The U.S. Trade Representativesâ€™ Foreign Trade Barrier Report, released on March 1, 2025, provides a detailed examination of the principal sources of contention. The report highlights Chinaâ€™s protectionist policies, which have systematically impeded U.S. companiesâ€™ access to key sectors of the Chinese market, while also emphasizing the European Unionâ€™s regulatory approach, which, according to the U.S., has created significant obstacles for American businesses. The EUâ€™s deforestation regulation, if fully implemented, could impose an additional $8 billion annually in compliance costs for U.S. companies, further exacerbating trade frictions.
For Africa, the question remains: where does the continent find itself within the broader context of this evolving global economic landscape? What are the potential consequences for African economies amidst this turbulence, and how can they effectively navigate the volatile currents of international trade to capitalize on emerging opportunities? As the worldâ€™s major economic powers engage in a struggle for dominance, Africaâ€™s role, though often overlooked, is crucial and warrants careful examination. Several potential scenarios merit attention as Africa contemplates its position in this complex and shifting global order.
The first possibility is that the U.S., EU, and China remain locked in a prolonged trade conflict. The 90-day tariff suspension announced on April 11, 2025, offers a fleeting window for negotiations between the U.S. and the EU, as well as other key players such as Japan and South Korea. However, the prospects for a comprehensive deal are fraught with complexity. The U.S. has raised serious concerns about its trade deficit with the EU, and there are growing frustrations with the regulatory environment in Europe, which U.S. officials argue hinders American firmsâ€™ competitiveness. The EU, for its part, is confronted with internal divisions regarding the most effective strategy to confront U.S. tariffs. Whether the EU can maintain a unified front or whether individual member states will strike separate deals with the U.S. will be a key determinant of the future trajectory of this trade war.
Should the EU manage to maintain its cohesion, it could emerge as a formidable counterweight to both the U.S. and China, positioning itself as a third pole in the global economic order. However, this dynamic carries significant implications for Africa. While the competition among the U.S., EU, and China might drive increased investment flows to the continent as these powers vie for influence, the reality is that Africa risks being relegated to the status of a peripheral player in the broader geopolitical struggle. Africaâ€™s role in this new world order may be determined more by external competition than by internal agency, as the continentâ€™s vast economic potential remains untapped, subject to the whims of foreign powers.
The second scenario is one where the U.S. and the EU forge a strategic alliance in opposition to China. This could emerge if the EU yields to U.S. demands in trade negotiations or if the U.S. prioritizes its transatlantic relationship over its economic engagements with Asia. In this case, the world could witness the emergence of a new â€œeconomic Cold War,â€ with the U.S. and EU aligning against China. For Africa, this would present a highly disadvantageous situation. A deepening U.S.-EU economic bloc would likely exclude the continent from the economic considerations of both powers. Their trade and investment relations would become more insular, focused on deepening transatlantic ties at the expense of African markets. Furthermore, the combined economic weight of the U.S. and the EU could pressure African countries to curtail or sever their economic relationships with China, further marginalizing Africa in the global trade network.
The third, and perhaps most concerning, scenario is the emergence of the U.S. as the sole dominant economic power. Should the EU and China fail to reconcile their differences and respond cohesively to U.S. demands, the U.S. could leverage its economic strength to secure a commanding position on the global stage. This would signal a dramatic shift in the balance of power, with far-reaching consequences for Africa. The continentâ€™s reliance on both the EU and China as key trading partners would place it in a vulnerable position, particularly if both of these economic giants experience stagnation or decline in the face of U.S. dominance. The result would likely be a reduction in African trade and investment flows, further exacerbating the continentâ€™s economic marginalization.
In each of these scenarios, Africa faces an existential challenge. The ongoing trade war between the U.S., EU, and China is one in which the continent has little direct influence, given the limited size and power of its economies. Unlike during the Cold War, when Africa could occasionally leverage its strategic position to secure economic and political gains, the current trade conflict is predominantly an economic struggle, offering little opportunity for Africa to claim neutrality or capitalize on external tensions.
The implications of this trade war are not only economic but also political. Africaâ€™s exclusion from the heart of this global contest highlights the continentâ€™s ongoing marginalization in the international arena. The absence of meaningful African participation in global trade governance underscores a stark reality: Africaâ€™s future cannot be shaped solely by external forces. Rather, the key to Africaâ€™s future lies in its own hands, within its own borders.
Thus, the most prudent course of action for Africa is to invest in its own economic development. Intra-continental trade must become the focal point of Africaâ€™s strategy moving forward. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) presents a unique opportunity to foster regional integration, dismantle internal trade barriers, and create a single, unified market capable of competing on the global stage. In parallel, African nations must focus on developing business-friendly policies, improving infrastructure, and diversifying their economies to reduce reliance on external powers. By nurturing its own economic capabilities, Africa can begin to carve out a more assertive role in the global economic order, shifting from a position of dependency to one of leadership.
In conclusion, Africaâ€™s future does not need to be defined by the trade wars of external powers. While it currently faces marginalization in the context of the ongoing geopolitical and economic disputes between the U.S., EU, and China, the continent has both the potential and the agency to redefine its place in the global system. Africaâ€™s path to economic prosperity lies not in relying on the shifting fortunes of foreign powers but in its own ability to innovate, integrate, and lead. By leveraging its vast resources, talent, and growing markets, Africa has the opportunity to emerge as a dominant force on the world stage. The time to act decisively is now, Africa must seize control of its economic destiny and become the architect of its own future.
[1]

[2]

[3]

[4]
