Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Sea Access: Navigating Peaceful Diplomatic Strategies
Precarious Peace: South Sudanâ€™s Fragile Transition and the Emerging Regional Security Crisis

### 25
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/25/navigating-autonomy-ethiopias-quest-for-naval-power-in-the-red-sea
TITLE: Navigating Autonomy: Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Naval Power in the Red SeaÂ Â  â€“ IFA

1 Conceptualizing Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Autonomy in the Red Sea
Ethiopia â€˜s conception of strategic autonomy in the Red Sea Region is clearly and boldlyÂ indicatedÂ in Prime MinisterÂ Abiyâ€™s recentÂ parliamentary speechÂ inÂ 2025. HeÂ stated, â€œ
Raising the question of access to the sea is no longer a taboo â€¦ Nor could Ethiopia remain in geographic prisonâ€¦
.â€ Of course, the Prime Minister reminded the presence of the generic version of this notion and the need to reorient Ethiopiaâ€™s strategy to the Red Sea Region in his book entitled
â€œ
Medemer
â€
.Â  He also underlined Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of direct access to the Sea is not a tactical engagement which has happened byÂ accident;Â rather it has been strategically designed to overcome the labyrinth geopolitical challenges in the Red SeaÂ Region. This reflects Ethiopiaâ€™s transition from a strategy of adaptable survival in the Red Sea region to, at the very least, a form of ideational autonomyâ€”allowing it to question existing maritime arrangements and negotiate for mutual benefits in the Red Sea governance. This can beÂ evidencedÂ by three importantÂ subsequentÂ developments. Firstly, the agenda of accessing to the sea which has been a taboo for the last three decades in the hitherto regime is now a public agenda following the 2018 political transition in Ethiopia.Â Accordingly, exchanges of ideas and knowledge production on Ethiopiaâ€™s access to the sea among theÂ public, scholars and politiciansÂ have becomeÂ dayÂ to day activities. Secondly, Ethiopian government through its foreign diplomatic engagement has started negotiation with littoral states and other non-regional actors on how to get access to the sea. Thirdly, Ethiopia has reestablished naval institution under the ministry of defense. In this regard, Ethiopiaâ€™s navalÂ diplomacyÂ and port agreements in 2024, rebuilding naval capabilities andÂ activeÂ involvement in multilateral organizations are indicators of transition from strategic survival towards autonomy
Diplomatic Pathways to Access to Naval power
2.1 Securitization of the Red Sea: Agenda Framing and Mobilization
Cognizant of the looming threats in the Red Sea region, the Ethiopian government has securitized the region since 2018. In this regard, three key securitization measures have been taken by the government. First, Prime MinisterÂ AbiyÂ Ahmed has delivered a series of speeches in parliament highlighting the strategic importance of the Red Sea, associated threats, and the need for maritime diplomacy to secure access to the sea. Second, the issue has been extensively articulated by key securitizing actors, including theÂ Office of the PrimeÂ Minister, theÂ Ministry of ForeignÂ Affairs,Â andÂ the MinistryÂ of Defense. Third, the government has taken extraordinary steps such as engaging in naval port diplomacy and undertaking institutional rebuilding. While Ethiopia has not yet achieved full naval autonomy, it hasÂ attainedÂ a notable degree of institutional and ideational autonomy. To this effect, Ethiopian government hasÂ initiatedÂ diplomatic talks with the
neighboring coastal states
such asÂ Djibouti, Somalia, Somaliland,Â KenyaÂ and Eritrea to negotiate on port access for both commercial and military purposes. Below are some of the diplomatic efforts that underscore Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of naval access in the Red Sea.
2.2Â Â  Ethiopia-Somaliland Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)
The first Ethiopian diplomatic move to get access to naval power was exclusively linked with the Ethiopia and Somaliland
Memorandum of Understanding
(MoU) signed in Addis Ababa on January 1, 2024. Although the full content of theÂ MoUÂ was notÂ disclosed, the publicly communicated
agreement
provides a 20 km (12 miles) coastline access to Ethiopia for both naval and commercial uses over a period of 50 years. However, the agreement makes Ethiopian access conditional upon its political recognition of
Somalilandâ€™s statehood
. Beyond the port fee, Somaliland was promised to have a share from the profitable Ethiopian Air Lines. Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomatic leverage as the political center of Africa and the seat of the African Union appears to be one of the key factors that motivated Somaliland to sign the deal. The respect of the colonial boundary outlined in the African Union CharterÂ remainsÂ a major challenge for the independence of Somaliland. As a result, approaching Ethiopia has been considered by Somaliland as a pathway for achieving formal independence. Additionally, among others, a scholar such as Farah argues that
Ethiopiaâ€™s military strength
and its potential to deter any forceful reunification with Somalia was another driving factor behind Somalilandâ€™s decision toÂ enter intoÂ theÂ MoU.
Although Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of access to a naval base presents considerable challenges, its political leverage as the center of African diplomacy and its status as a military heavyweight in the Horn of Africa could support its efforts to achieve negotiating autonomy for a naval presence. To this effect, soft power diplomacy throughÂ maintainingÂ the principle of neutrality on the Somalia politics and by acting as a reliable security partner to both Somalia and Somaliland, Ethiopia can achieve its presence as a naval power in the Red Sea region. In other words, striking a balance between the interests of Somaliland and Somalia mightÂ thriveÂ Ethiopia to advance its strategic naval autonomy in the Red Sea.
2.3 The Ankara Declaration
The Ankara declaration is the upshot of theÂ Ethio-SomalilandÂ MoU. The way theÂ MoUÂ was signed and communicated caused frustration on the neighboring Somalia. The
government of Somalia
denounced theÂ MoUÂ as a â€œclear violation of Somaliaâ€™s sovereignty, unity, and territorial integrityâ€. It also unequivocally declared theÂ MoUÂ â€˜null and voidâ€™ and expressed its readiness to defend its sovereignty. Additionally, the Somali government wentÂ so far asÂ to threaten the expulsion of Ethiopian troops from the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) and to ban Ethiopiaâ€™s participation in the new African Union Support and Stabilization Mission in Somalia (AUSSOM). Furthermore, the government of Somalia requested diplomatic support from regional countries like Egypt,Â EritreaÂ andÂ TÃ¼rkiye. Similarly, regional organizations like the African Union (AU), Arab League and
Organization of Islamic Cooperation
(OIC) offered solidarity to Somalia. Both statements from Ethiopian rival states and regional organizations stressed the need to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Somalia, and its implication for regional peace and security.
The mounting tension between Ethiopia and SomaliaÂ as a result ofÂ theÂ MoUÂ was averted by the Ankara declaration. The agreement signedÂ onÂ December 11,Â 2024,Â at Ankara through the mediation ofÂ TÃ¼rkiye. Based on the Ankara declaration, Ethiopia recognized the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Somalia while Somalia acknowledges Ethiopiaâ€™s interest to get access to the sea through lease and contract under the Sovereignty of the Federal Government ofÂ Somalia. Both Ethiopia and Somalia agreed on the continuation ofÂ TÃ¼rkiyeÂ as mediator for the implementation of the accord. Overall, the Ankara Declaration achieved a delicate balance between Somaliaâ€™s territorial integrity and Ethiopiaâ€™s access to the sea. It ensured a win-win outcome, giving the sea access agenda broader international recognition and greater significance than theÂ previousÂ MoU. Therefore, it is plausible to argue that EthiopiaÂ demonstratedÂ remarkable ideational autonomyâ€”from setting regional agenda to securingÂ TÃ¼rkiyeÂ as the guarantor for the implementation of the agreement.
3 RebuildingÂ Institutional Capability
For the last three decades, the EPRDF government suppressed the agenda of access to the sea, as it was widely held responsible for Ethiopiaâ€™s landlocked status. However, this simmering public concern re-emerged during the 2005 political contest, in which the oppositionâ€”particularly the Coalition for Unity and Democracyâ€”openly supported the issue. The EPRDF government dismissed this stance as warmongering. After the election, the issue of sea accessÂ remainedÂ an undercurrent in Ethiopian politics. Following the 2018 political transition, the agenda once again resurfaced in public discourse. Currently, the Ethiopian government isÂ leveragingÂ the issue of sea access as a strategic tool in regional geopolitics, with broader ideational influence. EthiopiaÂ now appears to beÂ setting the agenda of access to the sea, rather than merely responding to it. Regional actors are increasingly reacting to Ethiopiaâ€™s initiatives, asÂ evidencedÂ by the responses to theÂ Ethioâ€“Somaliland port deal and the Ankara Declaration of 2024. This marks a shift in Ethiopiaâ€™s foreign policyâ€”from a subservient geopolitical posture centered on strategic survival to one characterized by
ideational autonomy
.
Among other factors, the growing number of military bases in the Red Sea region, the expanding economy and human population, the increasing competition and influence of Gulf countries in the Horn region, the rise of maritime terrorism in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, Ethiopiaâ€™s heavy dependence on the region for foreign trade, and its exclusion from theÂ Red Sea CouncilÂ were key drivers behind the securitization of the Red Sea and the subsequent establishment of the Ethiopian Navy under the Ministry of Defense in 2019. The Navy was initially launched with a
single commander
and gradually expanded with the recruitment ofÂ additionalÂ military personnel. It began with a simple structure, consisting of one head and two deputies overseeingÂ logisticsÂ and training. Currently, the navy has started practical operations in protecting the Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) and involved in rescue operations in times of flooding atÂ different partsÂ of the country.
To enhance the institutional and human capacity of the Navy, the government has begun constructing the Navyâ€™s headquarters in Addis Ababa. Currently, the NavyÂ operatesÂ within the GroundÂ ForcesÂ headquarters. The completion of the new building complex is expected to significantly strengthen the institutional capacity of the Ethiopian Navy. To address the shortage of skilled personnel, the government has alsoÂ establishedÂ a naval academy for Ethiopian cadets. In addition, many Navy personnel have received short- and long-term training in various countries with which Ethiopia hasÂ establishedÂ defense partnerships.
4.4Â Multilateral Engagement
as Autonomy Multiplier
In line with the decision of the 46th Ordinary Session of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), the Committee of Ambassadors from IGAD established the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden Task Force (RGATF) on April 4, 2019. The primaryÂ objectiveÂ behind the establishment of the Task Force was to develop a common position and strategy to address the growing challenges and opportunities in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden region. Notably, the Red SeaÂ CouncilÂ (RSC) had beenÂ establishedÂ a year earlier, with membership limited exclusively to littoral states of the Red Sea. As a result, countries such as Ethiopia, Kenya, and South Sudan were excluded. IGAD member states thatÂ borderingÂ the Red SeaÂ wasÂ granted dual membershipÂ onÂ both platforms. IGADâ€™s Task Force has twenty-one members, three representatives from each member states including Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, and Uganda. The task forceÂ convenedÂ on a quarterly basis and co-chaired by
IGAD
â€™sÂ specialÂ envoy for the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden Task force, Ambassador Mohamed AliÂ Guyo.Â Ethiopia was prosing and pushing for the establishment of RGATFâ€“the ideational power â€“at least for three strategic reasons.Â First, to counter its exclusion from theÂ RSC,Â Red SeaÂ littoralityÂ was the sole criterion for membership.Â Second, to mobilize non-littoral IGAD members as a counter-bloc in shaping Red Sea security governance.Â And third, to address the emerging geopolitical dynamics in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden region, particularlyÂ in light ofÂ the increasing frequency and scale of
RSCÂ military drills
.
4. Conclusion
Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of naval power signifies a fundamental shift from reactive survival to proactive strategic autonomy, moving sea access towards the center of its national security agenda. Through the reconstruction of its navy and high-level diplomacyâ€”exemplified by the evolution from the controversial Somaliland MoU to the more balanced Ankara Declarationâ€”Ethiopia has successfully secured â€œnegotiating autonomyâ€ within the Red Sea region. To ensure this ambition and long-term stability, Ethiopia should now prioritize two key actions: securing maritime access through legally binding international frameworks to mitigate regional sensitivities, and launching confidence-building measures with neighboring coastal states. By integrating joint maritime security and port co-management into its strategy, Ethiopia can transform its naval aspirations into a framework for cooperative regional governance.

Ethiopia Today on the Global Climate Stage : Insights from COP30 and G20
ğ“ğ¡ğ ğŒğ¢ğ¬ğ¬ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ‹ğ¢ğ§ğ¤ ğ¢ğ§ ğğ‘ğˆğ‚ğ’ ğˆğ§ğ­ğğ ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§: ğ“ğ¡ğ ğğğğ ğŸğ¨ğ« ğ‘ğ¨ğ›ğ®ğ¬ğ­ ğ’ğğœğ®ğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ² ğŒğğœğ¡ğšğ§ğ¢ğ¬ğ¦ğ¬

### 26
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/08/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A6-2
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğ‘ğğšğŸğŸğ¢ğ«ğ¦ğ¬ ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ¢ğ­ğ¦ğğ§ğ­ ğ­ğ¨ ğ€ğŸğ«ğ¢ğœğšğ§ ğ“ğ«ğšğğ ğˆğ§ğ­ğğ ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ ğ®ğ§ğğğ« #ğ€ğŸğ‚ğ…ğ“ğ€ â€“ IFA

Ethiopia continues to assert its pivotal role in advancing African trade integration through the African Continental Free Trade Area (#AfCFTA). A key session on AfCFTA Implementation and Readiness took place at Kuriftu Resort, Bishoftu, bringing together regional and international experts to discuss strategies for deepening continental trade and economic cooperation.
ğ‡.ğ„. ğŒğ«. ğ“ğšğ ğğ¬ ğŒğ®ğ¥ğ®ğ ğğ­ğš, Head of International and Regional Trade Integration at Motri, provided a comprehensive overview linking AfCFTAâ€™s foundation to the 1963 vision of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), emphasizing its focus on decolonization, African unity, and regional economic integration. He highlighted the Abuja Treaty as a cornerstone roadmap toward establishing a continental economic community.
H.E. Mr. Tages underscored AfCFTAâ€™s transformative objectives: creating a single African market for goods and services, eliminating tariff and non-tariff barriers, and promoting the free movement of capital and people. He also stressed the agreementâ€™s role in driving industrialization, economic diversification, and shared prosperity across the continent.
Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic position as a founding member was highlighted, with emphasis on its market size, growing economy, and pursuit of equitable access to the Red Sea, crucial for trade efficiency, economic sovereignty, and regional stability.
The session brought together ambassadors and diplomats from Ghana, Kenya, Algeria, and Morocco, reflecting Africaâ€™s strong commitment to collaboration and shared prosperity. H.E. Ambassador General Bacha Debele and H.E. Ambassador Legesse . joined virtually, offering valuable insights on Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomatic engagement and its proactive role in advancing AfCFTA objectives through economic diplomacy. This diverse representation not only underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s influence in continental trade but also highlighted the importance of shared dialogue and partnership in achieving Africa-wide economic integration. The discussions emphasized that economic diplomacy and strategic coordination among member states are essential to fully realize AfCFTAâ€™s potential.
H.E Mr. Mulugeta Getu, Lead Researcher at the FDRE Policy Studies Institute (PSI), highlighted the background and objectives of the AfCFTA, explaining that Africa, though a vast market, remains fragmented. The Agreement aims to create a single African market uniting 1.5 billion people across 55 countries with a combined GDP of 3.4 trillion USD, promoting transparency, accountability, and good governance in trade while potentially increasing intra-African trade by 45%.
He noted that Ethiopia identified priority export sectors through stakeholder consultations, focusing on business and service industries. To enhance trade readiness and awareness, the Ethiopian Mission has organized forums and workshops with the diaspora, investors, and partners, promoting the national trade agenda and strengthening the competitiveness of Ethiopian products in the continental market.
Speaking from Accra, H.E. Mr. Million Habtamu, Coordinator of Implementation at the AfCFTA Secretariat, elaborated on coordination and legal frameworks necessary for effective AfCFTA implementation. He highlighted key objectives, including deepening continental integration, promoting industrialization and participation in value chains, reducing intra-African trade costs and barriers, and strengthening regulatory frameworks to support industrial growth.
These measures collectively aim to enhance Ethiopiaâ€™s regulatory, operational, and productive capacities, positioning the country as a hub for trade intelligence, local industry promotion, and continental economic transformation. By championing AfCFTA objectives, Ethiopia continues to demonstrate leadership in advancing African trade, industrialization, and sustainable economic development.

### 27
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/10/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%94%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%86%F0%9D%90%80%F0%9D%9F%96%F0%9D%9F%8E
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğšğ­ ğ”ğğ†ğ€ğŸ–ğŸ: ğ’ğ­ğ«ğğ§ğ ğ­ğ¡ğğ§ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğğ¢ğ¥ğšğ­ğğ«ğšğ¥ & ğŒğ®ğ¥ğ­ğ¢ğ¥ğšğ­ğğ«ğšğ¥ ğğšğ«ğ­ğ§ğğ«ğ¬ğ¡ğ¢ğ©ğ¬ â€“ IFA

On the sidelines of the 80th UN General Assembly in New York,
H.E. Amb. Hadera Abera Admassu, State Minister of Foreign Affairs of Ethiopia, engaged in a series of high-level meetings and discussions:
BRICS Foreign Ministers Meeting â€“ He underscored the need for stronger collective action to address global challenges, emphasizing BRICSâ€™ historic responsibility in advancing peace, reforming global institutions, and shaping a fairer, more secure world for the Global South.
Meetings with Portugal & Germany â€“ He held productive discussions with H.E. Paulo Rangel, Foreign Minister of Portugal, and H.E. Dr. Bernhard Kotsch, State Secretary of Germany, focusing on deepening longstanding ties, expanding economic cooperation, and supporting UN reform efforts.
Meetings with Sudan & Burundi â€“ He met with H.E. Muhi al-Din Salem Ahmed, Foreign Minister of Sudan, and H.E. Ã‰douard Bizimana, Foreign Minister of Burundi, to strengthen bilateral relations and advance dialogue on shared regional priorities.
Through these engagements, Ethiopia reaffirmed its commitment to multilateralism, regional cooperation, and building stronger partnerships for peace and development.

### 28
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/29/ethiopias-strategic-survival-economic-drivers-for-sea-access
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Survival: Economic Drivers for Sea Access â€“ IFA

Ethiopiaâ€™s departure from the Red Sea in 1993 and the new maritime statusâ€”being a landlocked country, has caused significant impacts on its economy in the horn and the Red Sea Region. As some writers argue Ethiopia has been trapped in â€œgeographic prisonâ€ for decades with little hope of regaining direct access to the sea. Owing to the landlocked status, Ethiopia became dependent on the ports of neighboring countries for its foreign trade and strategic relations. Consequently, its regional influence diminished, undermining its ability to pursue an assertive foreign policy (Dagnew & Megento, 2024; Mohammed, 2024). This shift marked a transition from strategic autonomy to survival. A country that once had direct access to the sea suddenly became landlocked after three decades of civil war. This development exposed Ethiopia to economic vulnerabilities. Below are some of the economic showcase discussions on how Ethiopia has securitized access to the sea.
1. Context: Ethiopiaâ€™s Transition to Landlocked Status
Ethiopia, which had direct access to the sea and used the ports of Massawa and Assab before 1993, became dependent on the ports of newly independent Eritrea. Due to the initially friendly relations between the leaders of the two countries, Ethiopia was allowed to use the Port of Assab for its foreign trade, enjoying a 75% exemption from port fees during the first five years. However, following the outbreak of the Ethio-Eritrean war (1998â€“2000), Ethiopia lost access to Eritrean ports. Among others asymmetrical trade relations between the two countries (more favored Eritrea) and the demonetization of Ethiopian currency were the main causes for the eventual outbreak of the War. As it was evidenced by Amare and Mohammed (2023), the war was more of economic than anything else:
Although independent nations are expected to trade with hard currencies, Eritrea used the advantage of the currency union to use birr to purchase Ethiopian commodities, includ ing coffee, and export for USD. This negatively affected the Ethiopian trade balance with Eritrea and inevitably produced political repercussions. This means that Ethiopia, as a sov ereign state, did not benefit from the Eritrean trade as there was no monetary value in terms of hard currencyâ€¦. Although not the immediate cause, the sudden shift in currency eventually led the two countries into full-scale war in the year that followed.
2. Economic Drivers behind the Securitization of Sea Access
2.1Â Â  Costs of being land-locked
According to some studies, landlocked countries incur twice the trade costs of their littoral neighbors. Moreover, the economic growth of landlocked countries is, on average, 6% lower than that of their coastal counterparts. Additionally, landlocked countries like Ethiopia have a low Human Development Index (HDI), extreme poverty index and lower Per capita Gross Domestic Product (PCGDP). At the worst cases, least developed landlocked countries have low economic growth as they are dependent on raw material exports, low volume of export products and low competitive trade because of high logistic cost (Begashaw, 2013). Â If we compare the HDI for example, Ethiopiaâ€™s
HDI(0.497)
is significantly lower than
Kenyaâ€™s(0.602)
which aligns with the preposition that landlocked status is lower human development.
2.2 Dependence on Djibouti and Rising Costs
Since the outbreak of the Ethio-Eritrean War in 1998, Ethiopia has conducted 95% of its foreign trade through the Port of Djibouti. Although Port Sudan and Lamu (Kenya) are occasionally used, the Port of Djibouti remains the most viable option for Ethiopiaâ€™s external trade due to its proximity to the countryâ€™s center and the presence of the Ethio-Djibouti railway line. However, scholars argue that the lack of diversified port access has negative implications for Ethiopiaâ€™s economic development. Djibouti has generated substantial revenue from port services, which account for 80% of its total national income. The volume of Ethiopian foreign trade cargo increased to
9.5 million tons in 2025
. To accommodate Ethiopiaâ€™s growing demand for port services, the Government of Djibouti offered the Port of Doraleh for Ethiopiaâ€™s exclusive use. Nevertheless, it is undeniable that the cost of port services will continue to rise as Ethiopia deepens its reliance on Djiboutiâ€™s port infrastructure (Erico, 2023; Begashaw, 2013). According to various sources, Ethiopia pays between $1.5 and $2 billion annually in port fees to Djiboutiâ€”nearly one-third of its estimated 2025 export revenue of $5.3 billion (Terefe, 2025).The cost comparison is best expressed by the recent speech of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed â€œ
the amount of money spent on these charges could be used to build the Renaissance Dam every three years.
â€Â  This dependency undermines Ethiopiaâ€™s competitive export capacity due to high logistics costs. For example, Ethiopian agricultural exports to the Middle East are more expensive than those from Sudan and other coastal
African countries.
2
.3 Logistical and Infrastructural Challenges
Djiboutiâ€™s reluctance to develop port infrastructures like improving connectivity to and from the railway terminal and the under capacity of the Horizon Oil Terminal to address the growing oil need of Ethiopia threatened the economic security of the country. Beyond this, Djiboutiâ€™s insufficient commitment to develop or maintain roads on its side risked the timely arrival of Ethiopian export and import commodities to the port. Furthermore, Ethiopiaâ€™s liberalization attempt around Ethiopian Logistic draws tension between Ethiopia and Djiboutian. One of the driving factors for this tension was Ethiopiaâ€™s government attempt to privatize the logistics sector owing to inefficiency and monopolistic practices of Ethiopian Shipping and Logistic Service Enterprise (ESLSE). This reform seems to have dissatisfied Djiboutian authorities who had been comfortable with ESLSE for many decades. Unless this grievance cannot be addressed, it poses threats to Ethiopian logistics operators in Djibouti (Terefe, 2025).
Conclusion and recommendation
Ethiopiaâ€™s transition from a littoral to a landlocked state witnessed a fundamental shift from strategic autonomy to survival. This has left the country to economic vulnerability, structural dependency and national security risk. Ethiopiaâ€™s dependency on the neighboring ports, particularly on Djibouti has caused substantial economic lossâ€”costing $1.5-$ 2 billion port fees and logistics, consuming nearly one-third of its export earnings. Ethiopiaâ€™s structural dependency on the port of Djibouti exposed the country to rising costs and undermines its export competitiveness.Â  To the extreme, Ethiopiaâ€™s dependency on a single port might cause security risks like port shutdown that could disrupt commercial and strategic imports. This policy brief recommends that Ethiopiaâ€™s long-term economic stability and strategic survival requires moving beyond dependence by achieving secure, diversified, and affordable maritime access.
References
Amare K. Aweke & Mohammed Seid (2023) The Ethiopiaâ€“Eritrea rapprochement: highly personalized and less-institutionalised initiative, Third World Quarterly, 44:4, 762-775, DOI: 10.1080/01436597.2022.2158079
Begashaw, G. (2013). Landlockedness as an impediment to economic development in Ethiopia: a framework for a durable solution. Ethiopian e-Journal for Research and Innovation Foresight (Ee-JRIF), 5(1).
Dagnew, S., & Megento, T. L. (2024). Effects of Ethiopiaâ€™s landlocked status on ties with its neighbours. African Journal of Political Science, 12(1), 19-30.
Erko, H. G. (2023). Analysing Opportunities and Obstacles in Ethio-Djibouti Relations: Post-Cold War Era Historical Analysis. Current Res. J. Soc. Sci. & Human., 6, 219.
Mohammed Seid Mohammed (20 Apr 2024): The Red Sea Regional Security Complex: The Implications of the Red Sea Forum for Ethiopian National Security, Asian Journal of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, DOI: 10.1080/25765949.2024.2343232
Terrefe, B. (2025). Ethiopiaâ€™s Red Sea Politics: Corridors, Ports and Security in the Horn of Africa.

### 29
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/04/07/geneva-peace-week-meets-addis-ababa-initiative-a-high-level-plenary-titled-geopolitical-challenges-for-peace-and-security-in-africa
TITLE: â€œGeneva Peace Week Meets Addis Ababaâ€ initiative, a High-Level Plenary titled â€œGeopolitical Challenges for Peace and Security in Africaâ€ â€“ IFA

As part of the â€œGeneva Peace Week Meets Addis Ababaâ€ initiative, a High-Level Plenary titled â€œGeopolitical Challenges for Peace and Security in Africaâ€ convened at the Hyatt Regency Addis Ababa on April 7, 2025.
H.E. Jafar Bedru  Execeutive Director of the Institute of Foreign Affairs delivered remarks on behalf of Minister of
@mfaethiopia
, Dr. Gedion Timothewos, underscoring the role of @GenevaPeaceDE in nurturing multilateral collaboration. He highlights the value of this timely partnership, noting that in an era of global uncertainty, platforms like Geneva Peace Week offer more than clarityâ€”they foster connection, inspire hope, and help build lasting solutions for peace.
The session brought together senior policymakers, diplomats, and experts to deliberate on enhancing Africaâ€™s leadership in peacebuilding and conflict resolution amid evolving global dynamics. Discussions centered on Africaâ€™s positioning within major global alliances, its role in multilateral peace and security efforts, and strategies to promote stability and self-reliance in addressing emerging threats. Key themes included strengthening multilateral cooperation, the impact of international alliances on stability, and the significance of locally led peace initiatives. The plenary underscored the importance of collaborative approaches to ensure Africaâ€™s priorities are effectively represented in international decision-making forums.

### 30
URL: https://www.mofed.gov.et/blog/ethiopia-and-china-sign-an-mou-to-establish-a-working-group-to-boost-investment-and-economic-cooperation
TITLE: Ethiopia and China sign an MOU to establish a Working Group to boost investment and economic cooperation

Ethiopia and China sign an MOU to establish a Working Group to boost investment and economic cooperation
Published:
Feb. 21, 2023
During the Joint Economic and Trade Commission meeting held on February 21, 2023, Ethiopia and China signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to establish an investment and economic cooperation working group aimed at jointly boosting bilateral economic and trade relations in strategic fields.
The MOU was co-signed by H.E. Ahmed Shide, Ethiopiaâ€™s Minister of Finance, representing the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and H.E. Li Fei, Assistant Minister of Commerce of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China, on behalf of Chinaâ€™s Government.
Speaking at the signing ceremony H.E. Ahmed Shide highlighted the two countriesâ€™ long-standing relationship of more than half a century and indicated Chinaâ€™s significant role in Ethiopiaâ€™s economy as its top trade and investment partner. The Minister added that Chinese enterprises have significantly invested in Ethiopia in diverse sectors, including industrial parks, processing, manufacturing, construction and so forth.
Mr Li Fei on his side expressed Chinaâ€™s commitment to encouraging Chinese enterprises to increase imports of Ethiopiaâ€™s competitive products. He indicated that Chinaâ€™s new preferential policy for zero-tariff treatment on 98% of taxable items that Ethiopia will enjoy from 1st March, will lead to tangible benefits from the two countriesâ€™ strengthened economic ties.
The two sides discussed common goals of boosting growth, trade, and investment, and indicated that the new Working Group under the signed MoU will help both nations to accomplish their commitment to efficiently implement the development strategies of the â€œNine Programsâ€ of the eighth Ministerial Conference of Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) and the Belt and Road initiative.

President Taye Atske Selassie Highlights Ethiopiaâ€™s Commitment to Sustainable Growth at Second Global Gateway Forum
H.E. President Taye Atske Selassie addressed the opening of the Second Global Gateway Forum in Brussels, reaffirming Ethiopiaâ€™s readiness to actively engage in the Global Gateway Initiative.
The President emphasized that Ethiopiaâ€™s ambitions in renewable energy development form the foundation of its prosperity, supported by a progressive investment ecosystem and a strategic approach to connectivity that enhances international cooperation.
He underlined Ethiopiaâ€™s commitment to advancing sustainable and inclusive growth through strengthened global partnerships under the Global Gateway framework, aimed at promoting green transformation, resilient infrastructure, and shared prosperity across Africa.

### 33
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/09/03/the-blue-green-deal-introduced-by-dr-gashaw-ayferam-and-dr-gizachew-asrat
TITLE: The Blue-Green Deal, introduced by Dr. Gashaw Ayferam and Dr. Gizachew Asrat. â€“ IFA

The Blue-Green Deal, introduced by Dr. Gashaw Ayferam and Dr. Gizachew Asrat, offers a visionary blueprint for Northeast Africaâ€™s future. This initiative harnesses the potential of freshwater and seawater resources, especially with the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (#GERD) and access to the #RedSea.
Ethiopia can transform historical tensions into cooperation through its rivers and strategic waterways. By focusing on sustainable development in hydropower, fisheries, and maritime trade, the Blue-Green Deal aims to foster peace and prosperity in a resource-rich, yet conflict-prone, region.
This framework highlights interdependence, promoting collaboration between landlocked Ethiopia and its coastal neighbors.

### 34
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/02/from-suez-canal-to-bab-al-mandab-strait-navigating-maritime-security-in-the-worlds-busiest-maritime-trade-corridor
TITLE: From Suez Canal to Bab al-Mandab Strait: Navigating Maritime Security in the Worldâ€™s Busiest Maritime Trade Corridor â€“ IFA

The article â€œFrom Suez Canal to Bab al-Mandab Strait: Navigating Maritime Security in the Worldâ€™s Busiest Maritime Trade Corridorâ€ by Abebe Yirga and Gashaw Ayferam examines the growing maritime insecurities and geopolitical rivalries affecting one of the worldâ€™s most vital trade corridors.
Using a sustainable maritime security framework, the authors argue that the Red Sea regionâ€”from the Suez Canal to the Bab al-Mandab Straitâ€”has become a contested space for military presence and power projection among global and regional actors.
The article contends that post-pandemic maritime insecurity has worsened due to military buildups, port competition, piracy, terrorism, and Houthi attacks. These interrelated threats span political, economic, environmental, and social sectors, each reinforcing the other.
Politically and economically, the authors note that rival maritime strategies, infrastructural vulnerabilities, and vessel attacks have disrupted global trade, raised shipping costs, and destabilized supply chains.
Environmentally and socially, the study highlights pollution from oil spills, human and arms trafficking, and seafarer casualties as major security challenges. Such issues, the article argues, exacerbate climate risks and feed back into political and economic instability.
The authors conclude that achieving sustainable maritime security requires enhanced cooperation among littoral states, stronger regional institutions, and diplomatic efforts to resolve broader conflictsâ€”particularly the Israel-Gaza and Iran-Israel crisesâ€”whose spillover effects threaten Red Sea stability.
Find the complete article here:
https://doi.org/10.47932/ortetut.1744422

The Red Sea: The Imperative of Pragmatic Cooperation between Ethiopia and Eritrea

### 35
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/02/27/dialogue-on-building-long-lasting-partnerships-between-ethiopia-and-its-partners
TITLE: Dialogue on: Building Long-Lasting Partnerships Between Ethiopia and its Partners: Towards its Strategic Engagement â€“ IFA

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
â€“ The Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA), in partnership with the British Embassy in Ethiopia, hosted a significant conference focused on strengthening strategic engagements between Ethiopia and its international partners. The event highlighted the essential role that these partnerships play in Ethiopiaâ€™s ongoing development efforts.
H.E. Jafar Bedru, Executive Director of IFA, emphasized the importance of collaboration, stating that the nations involved are critical partners in Ethiopiaâ€™s socio-economic progress. He noted that the support provided over the decades has been instrumental in advancing the countryâ€™s development, characterized by resilience, mutual respect, and a shared commitment to progress.
As Ethiopia continues its development journey, the conference served as a platform to enhance ties with international partners, fostering an environment conducive to shared growth and collaboration for the future.
In closing, H.E. Dr. Abdi Zenebe, Deputy Executive Director of IFA, stressed the importance of evolving Ethiopiaâ€™s partnerships with countries in Europe and America. He stated, â€œEthiopiaâ€™s long-standing partnerships, along with its commitment to regional leadership, will continue to play a pivotal role in shaping a future defined by peace, democracy, and development.â€ He urged that these partnerships must transform into more strategic and dynamic engagements, prioritizing regional integration, self-reliance, and the aspirations of the Ethiopian people, moving beyond aid and dependency towards relationships founded on mutual respect and collective action.
This conference marks a significant step in Ethiopiaâ€™s ongoing efforts to build meaningful and sustainable partnerships that will benefit its development trajectory and regional stability.

PM Abiy Engages in Bilateral Talks with his Chinese Counterpart ____________________
Prime Minister H.E. Abiy Ahmed (PhD) met with Chinese Premier H.E. Li Qiang during the Fourth Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) in China. Their discussions aimed at enhancing the Ethiopia-China All-Weather Strategic Partnership and exploring new cooperation avenues.
The leaders reaffirmed their commitment to peace and development, leveraging the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and FOCAC frameworks. Prime Minister Abiy expressed gratitude for Chinaâ€™s support and reaffirmed Ethiopiaâ€™s adherence to the One-China policy.
Key cooperation areas included industrialization, infrastructure development, and the digital economy. Agreements were made to establish Special Economic Zones and Free Trade Zones in Ethiopia, boosting industrial capacity and technology transfer. Both countries also committed to partnerships in the digital economy and agricultural modernization.
Financial cooperation was discussed, with Ethiopia appreciating Chinaâ€™s debt re-profiling support under the G-20 Common Framework. The leaders emphasized joint efforts to promote peace and security in the Horn of Africa.
Premier Li Qiang reiterated Chinaâ€™s commitment to supporting Ethiopiaâ€™s talent development through educational programs and scholarships, aiming to equip Ethiopian youth with essential skills for socio-economic transformation.

TITLE: IFA and IGAD Partner on Key Regional Initiatives â€“ IFA

A delegation from the Institute for Foreign Affairs (IFA), led by H.E. Mr. Jafar Bedru, met with H.E. Mr. Abebaw Bihonegn, IGADâ€™s Head of Mission to Ethiopia, and Mr. Camilus Omogo, Director of IGADâ€™s Early Warning and Response Mechanism (CEWARN), along with other senior delegates at IGADâ€™s headquarters.
The meeting focused on fostering collaboration between IFA and IGADâ€™s CEWARN unit in key strategic areas. Both organizations agreed to work together on initiatives such as developing a conflict data set project, conducting research on transnational issues and climate change, co-organizing policy dialogues and forums, and providing diplomatic training programs.
This partnership aims to enhance regional stability, improve conflict prevention mechanisms, and support evidence-based policymaking. Both sides reaffirmed their commitment to strengthening cooperation for the benefit of the region.

### 44
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/03/19/ifa-hosts-online-meeting-on-ethiopias-role-in-brics
TITLE: IFA Hosts Online Meeting on Ethiopiaâ€™s Role in BRICS â€“ IFA

The Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA) hosted an online meeting on March 19, 2025, to discuss Ethiopiaâ€™s preparations for the upcoming 2nd BRICS Dialogue, scheduled for April 4, 2025. The session, chaired by H.E. Jafar Bedru, Executive Director of IFA, brought together key stakeholders to assess Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic direction within BRICS and explore opportunities for deeper engagement.
A key focus of the meeting was Ethiopiaâ€™s growing partnership with BRICS nations, as part of its broader effort to strengthen economic ties, attract investment, and enhance its role in global governance. Dr. Haminot Eshetu presented insights on the BTTC Document Enrichment and key takeaways from last yearâ€™s BRICS Dialogue, highlighting Ethiopiaâ€™s progress in economic and diplomatic engagement within the bloc.
In concluding the session, H.E. Jafar Bedru outlined several strategic initiatives to reinforce Ethiopiaâ€™s role in BRICS. These include organizing local institutions to streamline BRICS engagement, hosting consultative forums for policy dialogue, establishing strategic partnerships to attract investment, and launching engagement initiatives to enhance Ethiopiaâ€™s presence in BRICS discussions.
As Ethiopia prepares for the 2nd BRICS Dialogue, these initiatives reflect its commitment to strengthening ties within BRICS and expanding its global influence. With Brazil set to assume the BRICS presidency in 2025, Ethiopia aims to capitalize on this momentum to deepen its economic and political participation. Beyond economic cooperation, Ethiopia continues to advocate for global governance reforms and regional stability.

### 46

On March 13, 2025, ARDA Talk held a public lecture on â€œThe benefits of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea for landlocked countriesâ€. The lecture explored the UNCLOS legal frameworks that address the affairs of landlocked countries, and discussed potential legal and practical techniques that can be used by landlocked countries to gain access to seaports. ### 47
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/04/02/hon-dr-tesfaye-bejigu-and-h-e-jafar-bedru-engaged-with-young-diplomats-in-a-dynamic-training-session
TITLE: Hon. Dr. Tesfaye Bejigu and H.E. Jafar Bedru engaged with young diplomats in a dynamic training session, â€“ IFA

Hon. Dr. Tesfaye Bejigu and H.E. Jafar Bedru engaged with young diplomats in a dynamic training session, fostering insightful discussions on diplomacy, the philosophy of Medemer, and the challenges ahead. A thought-provoking exchange shaping the future of Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomacy.
H.E. Jafar Bedru delivered a profound lecture on the philosophy of Medemer at the Pre-Service Diplomatic Training Program, Civil Service University. At its core, Medemer is a philosophy of synthesisâ€”uniting Ethiopiaâ€™s diverse society by focusing on commonalities rather than divisions.
It serves as both a diagnosis and a remedy for the fragmentation within the state, addressing governance challenges and legitimacy crises.
Medemer promotes the reintegration of political, economic, and social structuresâ€”offering a systematic approach to nation-building.
By fostering unity in diversity, Medemer envisions an Ethiopia strengthened by collaboration, shared history, and collective aspirations.
This philosophy is more than an idea; itâ€™s a blueprint for sustainable governance and inclusive progress.

TITLE: PM Abiy arrives in Kazan, to participate in BRICS summit in Russia â€“ IFA

PM Abiy arrives in Kazan, to participate in BRICS summit in Russia
Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed arrived in Kazan, Russia, today to participate in the 16th BRICS Summit. He was received at the Kazan International Airport by the President of Tatarstan, Rustam Minnikhanov, according to a statement from the Tatarstan presidentâ€™s office.
Ethiopia became a member of BRICS on January 1, 2024, following a decision at the 15th BRICS Summit in Johannesburg in August 2023. This yearâ€™s summit in Kazan is the first that will include Ethiopia, along with other new members such as Egypt, Iran, Saudi_Arabia, and the UAE.
Scheduled from 22 October to 24, the summit is part of Russiaâ€™s chairmanship of the group. Leaders from over 30 countries, including India, Iran, and the UAE, are expected to attend.

### 52
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/05/22/h-e-mr-jafar-bedru-delivered-a-welcoming-speech-2
TITLE: H.E. Mr. Jafar Bedru delivered a welcoming speech â€“ IFA

H.E. Mr. Jafar Bedru delivered a welcoming speech emphasizing the implications of â€œNavigating Gulf-Horn Economic and Security Cooperation: Opportunities, Challenges, and Future Directions.â€
This conference focuses on addressing key issues surrounding economic and security cooperation between Gulf countries and the Horn of Africa. It will explore the opportunities and challenges that arise from these interactions, as well as future directions for collaboration.
Post navigation
The Institute of Foreign Affairs is currently hosting a regional conference titled â€œNavigating Gulf-Horn Economic and Security Cooperation: Opportunities, Challenges, and Future Directions.â€
Panel One Summary â€“ The 3rd Red Sea and Gulf of Aden Dialogue Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Panel One of the 3rd Red Sea and Gulf of Aden Dialogue convened regional experts, policymakers, and scholars to explore avenues for strengthening cooperation between the Horn of Africa and Gulf states.

### 54
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/sample-page
TITLE: About â€“ IFA

Mission
The institute conducts research and analysis on foreign affairs issues, forwards alternative policy directions to policymakers, trains and capacitates foreign relations personnel, and acts as a center of excellence for the countryâ€™s diplomacy.
Vision
Institute of Foreign Affairs has the vision to be one of the five leading think tanks in foreign affairs research, training, and consulting in Africa by the year 2032.
Values
The institute accepts and practices all global ethical principles and values, and it has also its organizational values.
Patriotism
Professional Excellence
Proactive-ness
Confidentiality
Collaboration
Problem-solving
New perspective
Trustworthy

Virtual Reception of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan
Through the official website of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, you are given the opportunity to send appeals in electronic form directly to the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan without using an electronic digital signature. You can also track the status of a sent request using the code for checking the status of a request issued when sending a request.

TITLE: Belt and Road forum starts in Beijing

President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

Belt and Road forum starts in Beijing
26.04.2019
The official opening ceremony of the second â€œOne Belt, One Roadâ€ International Forum took place in Chinaâ€™s capital city today, April 26.
President of the Republic of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev has attended the event.
Opening the forum, President of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China Xi Jinping expressed gratitude to the heads of all the participating delegations and to numerous representatives of expert and analytical circles.
The Chinese leader said the Belt and Road project, implemented jointly with international and regional institutions such as the UN, SCO, the European Union, the Eurasian Economic Union, corresponds to the development strategies of various countries and therefore opens up a broad opportunities for economic progress of the world in general.
There was a talk also on the projects to be implemented to boost international trade and investment relations, to stimulate the creation of new transport and logistics corridors. It was noted that the number of nations participating in the project has been growing; this indicates a mounting aspiration for sustainable development in the world.
It is worth reminding that the international forum â€œOne Belt, One Roadâ€ was first held in 2017. The initiative voiced by China is designed to buttress mechanisms of interstate cooperation through the advancement of land and sea routes. The scheme currently covers 65 countries across Asia, Europe and Africa. In the future, given potential accession of other countries, it will turn into a global economic platform.
The current forum participants will focus on the enhancement of economic cooperation, enlargement of interaction in finding new sources for long-term growth, promotion of green economy and innovation, and the realization of priority infrastructure projects.
The forum will last two days. Uzbekistanâ€™s President is set to deliver a speech.
President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

### 58

TITLE: President of Uzbekistan puts forward initiatives for expanding multifaceted cooperation with China

President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

President of Uzbekistan puts forward initiatives for expanding multifaceted cooperation with China
17.06.2025
On June 17 President of the Republic of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev took part in the second â€œCentral Asia â€“ Chinaâ€ summit in the city of Astana.
An event chaired by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, was also attended by the President of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China Xi Jinping, President of the Kyrgyz Republic Sadyr Japarov, President of the Republic of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon and President of Turkmenistan Serdar Berdimuhamedov.
According to the agenda prospects of expanding mutually beneficial cooperation between the countries of Central Asia and China in priority areas, topical international and regional issues were reviewed.
In the beginning of his speech President of Uzbekistan particularly noted the role of the President of China Xi Jinping in strengthening friendship and cooperation with Central Asian states, supporting sustainable development of the region through implementing concrete projects and programs.
The major progress in interaction in the â€œCentral Asia â€“ Chinaâ€ format after the first summit in the city of Xi'an in 2023 was noted with satisfaction.
Particularly, a secretariat was established, effective meeting mechanisms of ministers and experts are in force, regulatory base of full-scale cooperation is being formed.
Trade turnover of Central Asian states with China is growing, which will reach $100 billion this year according to estimations.
-
In our view, the development of cooperation in this format is facilitated, on the one hand, by the processes of profound transformation in Central Asia itself, which has turned into a space of trust, good-neighborliness and partnership. On the other hand, it is the unwavering commitment of the Chinese leadership to the development of friendly relations with neighboring states and the promotion of the global concept of the â€œBelt and Roadâ€
, - said the Head of our state.
Afterwards the Leader of Uzbekistan presented his vision of further development of regional cooperation.
Firstly, it was mentioned that the current meeting is being held in the conditions of worsening of the international situation.
The increasing competition leads to escalation of tensions, arising of new challenges and obstacles to security and sustainable development.
-
We consider unjustified and inadmissible the use of forceful methods to resolve controversial international issues and conflict problems,
- emphasized the President. -
I am convinced that all disputes and disagreements should be resolved exclusively through diplomatic efforts - at the negotiating table, on the basis of the principle of respect for sovereignty, norms of international law and the Charter of the United Nations
.
In this regard itâ€™s been pointed to the historical significance of adopting in the course of the summit a Treaty on eternal good neighborliness, friendship and cooperation, which will become a joint contribution to ensuring regional stability. To develop this Treaty it was proposed to work out a Concept of long-term partnership with specific mechanisms and projects.
As mentioned the Head of our state, trade, investment and technological partnership with China is a major locomotive in implementing strategies of socio-economic development of all Central Asian countries.
It was highlighted that convergence of the increasing potential of the regionâ€™s countries and the industrial leadership of China will enable the establishment of Common space of huge opportunities with effective mechanisms of knowledge exchange and technology transfer.
The soonest adoption of the Program of new economic partnership and establishing an Interregional council for trade and investments at the level of deputy Prime ministers could become practical steps in this direction. Readiness of the Uzbek side was expressed to hold the first meeting of the Council by the end of the current year.
In order to stimulate trade ties President of Uzbekistan advocated for organizing a multilateral trade platform â€œElectronic Silk roadâ€ in the framework of â€œDigital Belt and Roadâ€.
The demand for creating a Regional center of industrial standardization and certification in Tashkent for interfacing standards and frameworks, certification of export products by Chinese requirements, was mentioned.
It was proposed to adopt a separate â€œroad mapâ€ for technology transfer, involving business, leading research institutes and engineering centers.
The Leader of Uzbekistan separately noted the necessity to intensify industrial and infrastructure interconnectedness to effectively utilize economic potential. In this regard, it was proposed to develop a long-term strategy â€œIndustrial and infrastructure belt â€œCentral Asia â€“ Chinaâ€.
It involves creation of a system of interconnected industrial clusters, techno-parks and logistic hubs with attraction of Chinese investments, technological and scientific solutions.
The issues of interfacing the energy systems of Central Asian countries and China, including the implementation of the megaproject for the construction of a high-voltage power transmission line, also require careful study.
The issue of introducing effective financial instruments capable of supporting major projects of regional significance is of particular relevance.
-
The current international mechanisms undoubtedly play an important role, but they do not fully cover the region's investment needs. According to experts, the deficit of capital investments in the infrastructural development of Central Asia amounts to hundreds of billions of dollars
, - said the Uzbek leader.
In this respect, it was proposed to consider the possibility of establishing the â€œCentral Asia-Chinaâ€ Development Fund, which could become an effective platform for promoting infrastructure initiatives.
The development of transport interconnectivity between Central Asia and China has been identified as another priority.
It was noted that the launch of construction of the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan railroad is an important element of the new system of transport and transit communications in the Eurasian space. At the same time, the implementation of the Trans-Afghan railway project will open up even wider opportunities.
-
In the interest of developing a common vision of prospects in this strategic area, I believe it is necessary to instruct our transport agencies to form expert groups to conduct field studies, explore opportunities for modernizing logistics infrastructure and implement pilot projects of cargo transportation along alternative corridors
, - suggested the Leader of Uzbekistan.
Based on the results of the work of these groups, specific and substantiated proposals for the formation of a unified map of transport corridors and modern transit infrastructure should be developed by the next summit.
Pointing to the serious challenges of climate change for sustainable development, the Head of our state urged to accelerate the adoption of the Green Development Program until 2030, as well as establish the Ecological Alliance for dialogue and partnership in combating desertification, restoring degraded lands, enhancing bio-ecological sustainability in arid and desert zones.
-
I would like to emphasize the opportunities for cooperation in the field of artificial intelligence and digital technologies. It is these areas that today act as drivers of long-term growth, determining the competitiveness of national economies
, - said the President of our country.
In order to form a sustainable digital infrastructure of economic interaction it was proposed to create a Network of mutually integrated big data banks and processing centers, as well as construct a Digital track of fiber optic connection line "Central Asia â€“ Chinaâ€ along the main energy and transport routes.
-
Our invaluable asset is the mutual commitment to enrichment of cultures and bringing our people together. It is for these means that the Mutual Travel Facilitation Initiative and the Cultural and Humanitarian Action Program, currently under way, are directed
, - mentioned the President.
To further strengthen cooperation in this area, it was proposed to create a single digital portal â€œCultural Heritage of the Silk Roadâ€, uniting historical and cultural resources of Central Asian countries and China, with its access to researchers, students, tourists and representatives of the creative industry.
The relevance of forming a common scientific and educational platform through the development of a program of cooperation in the field of professional education, holding forums of university rectors, meetings of heads of academies of sciences and research centers, was also pointed.
Cooperation in the field of security remains among the key priorities. In this regard, the President advocated the establishment of multilateral mechanisms for the exchange of information through special services and security councils in the fight against terrorism, extremism, radicalism, drug trafficking, illegal migration and cybercrime.
-
The decline in the international community's attention to the problems of Afghanistan, which for us is not just a neighbor, but an integral part of the common historical, cultural and economic space, is of serious concern
, - said the Uzbek leader.
Noting the rich experience of interaction between China and Central Asian states with Afghanistan, the President of Uzbekistan proposed to establish within the current format a High-level group to consider issues of assistance to the reconstruction and involvement of this country in regional integration processes.
The readiness was affirmed to hold its meeting in the city of Termez with participation of Afghanistanâ€™s representatives.
Concluding the speech it was underlined that Uzbekistan is committed to an open dialogue, expanding pragmatic and mutually beneficial cooperation in the â€œCentral Asia â€“ Chinaâ€ format.
As a result of the summit, the heads of state signed Astana declaration and a Treaty on eternal good neighborliness, friendship and cooperation.
A solid package of intergovernmental and interagency documents was also adopted.
In the end of the summit, a ceremony of launching centers for combating poverty, diversification, interaction in the field of education, as well as cooperation platforms for uninterrupted trade, took place.
President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

Belt and Road Forum kicks off in Beijing
13.05.2017
The Â«One Belt, One RoadÂ» international forum kicked off in Beijing.Â â€‹
President of the Republic of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev took part in the official opening ceremony of the forum.
The Â«One Belt, One RoadÂ» project, the main initiator of which has been China, envisages forming and promoting new models of international cooperation and development, as well as further strengthening the existing mechanisms of bilateral and multilateral cooperation.
Uzbekistanâ€™s participation has a very important significance for the project. Our country, located in the centre of the Great Silk Road, since ancient times has had an important place in consolidating international trade-economic and cultural ties.
The main goal of the ongoing forum is to promote and continue the development trends on the route of the Great Silk Road, to develop new mechanisms of economic cooperation, to stimulate economic progress of the involved states, to reinforce cultural ties among different civilisations as well as to promote peace and sustainable development.
Today our country attaches a special attention to mutually beneficial cooperation with all countries. A partnership within the frameworks of the â€œOne Belt, One Roadâ€ project plays an important role.
The competitiveness of the products, manufactured in our country and the demand for them in the world markets have been increasing as a result of the ongoing initiatives of President Shavkat Mirziyoyev on consistent reforms on modernization and diversification of industrial spheres, development of small business and private entrepreneurship, supporting exports. The â€œOne Belt, One Roadâ€ project, aimed at further developing trade-economic cooperation between the countries of the Great Silk Road, has an important significance in developing and demonstrating economic capabilities of Uzbekistan.
The Heads of State and governments of around 30 countries, as well as representatives of almost 130 nations are taking part in the forum. The UN Secretary General, the President of the World Bank, representatives of other authoritative international organizations are also participating.
President of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping opened the forum. He conveyed a gratitude to all Heads of State, taking part in the forum, spoke about the significance, goals and tasks of this project.
The Â«One Belt, One RoadÂ» initiative will allow the involved states to fully utilise their capacities, mutually enrich their economies, stimulate trade and investments, create wide conditions for further development of cooperation.
President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

President of Uzbekistan identifies priorities of deepening multifaceted cooperation in the framework of SCO
01.09.2025
On September 1, President of the Republic of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev took part in a regular meeting of the Council of heads of member states of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization held in Tianjin.
The event, chaired by President of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping, was also attended by President of the Republic of Belarus Aleksandr Lukashenko, Prime Minister of the Republic of India Narendra Modi, President of the Islamic Republic of Iran Masoud Pezeshkian, President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, President of the Kyrgyz Republic Sadyr Japarov, Prime Minister of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan Shehbaz Sharif, President of the Russian Federation Vladimir Putin, President of the Republic of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, as well as SCO secretary general Nurlan Yermekbayev and director of the Executive Committee of the Regional Anti-Terrorist Structure of the Organization Ularbek Sharsheyev.
In accordance with the agenda, the prospects for further deepening multilateral cooperation within the SCO and improving the organization's activities were discussed, and an open exchange of views on topical issues on the regional and international agenda took place.
Giving the floor to the Head of our state, President of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping congratulated President Shavkat Mirziyoyev and the people of Uzbekistan on Independence Day.
He particularly emphasized that under the leadership of the President, Uzbekistan is developing at a rapid pace, the life of the people has improved, and the Chinese side sincerely rejoices in these successes.
Welcoming the participants of the meeting, the leader of Uzbekistan highly appreciated China's chairmanship of the SCO and congratulated those present on the 80th anniversary of the Great Victory in World War II, as well as thanked the heads of delegations of SCO member states for their warm congratulations and sincere wishes on the occasion of the Independence Day of the Republic of Uzbekistan.
The leader of our country stressed that the current summit is taking place in conditions of global uncertainty.
A systemic crisis of trust, the escalation of conflicts, the weakening of multilateral institutions, and the fragmentation of the world trade system are undermining the foundations of the international architecture of security and stability.
-
In such conditions, mutual understanding and solidarity among SCO member states is not just a valuable asset, but the key to preserving peace in our vast region
, - said the leader of Uzbekistan.
With a view to further enhance multilateral cooperation within the SCO, the leader of Uzbekistan drew attention to the following.
First of all, the importance of improving the organization's efficiency, its institutions, and mechanisms for implementing decisions was emphasized. Confidence was expressed that the process of transforming the organization launched at the Samarkand summit would contribute to solving these tasks.
The Head of State spoke in favor of the consistent expansion of the SCO, the inclusion of new states in its membership, including countries from other regions, which will contribute to the transformation of the organization into a platform for cooperation with the states of the Global South.
Cooperation in the field of security was identified as one of the key priorities of the SCO.
-
Today, there is a growing need for coordinated approaches and new mechanisms to build trust and ensure security
, - underlined the President of Uzbekistan.
In this context, the head of Uzbekistan called for the adoption of the SCO Declaration on strengthening multilateral partnership for nuclear security, which will become a solid foundation for the development of peaceful nuclear energy and response to emergencies, as well as an important contribution to the global non-proliferation regime under the auspices of the United Nations.
To effectively counter cross-border threats, it was proposed to resume the work of the Meeting of ministers of internal affairs and public security, revise the provisions of the Agreement on cooperation in combating crime, and develop a Program to combat drug addiction until 2030.
The leader of Uzbekistan supported the resumption of the work of the â€œSCO-Afghanistanâ€ Contact group, one of whose main tasks could be to develop proposals for the development of constructive dialogue and support for socio-economic projects in Afghanistan.
Against the backdrop of current trends in the global economy, priority is given to expanding trade and economic cooperation.
-
We stand for the formation of a sustainable model of economic cooperation in our vast region
, - said the Head of our state.
In this context, the importance of signing the Agreement on trade procedures simplification and the early implementation of effective financial support instruments for regional industrial and infrastructure projects was noted.
In order to develop reliable production and logistics chains and stimulate mutual investment, it was proposed to create a number of new multilateral platforms and instruments to support cooperation within the SCO, such as a Regional center for critical materials, an Energy consortium, a Network of venture companies and funds to support start-ups and innovative projects, and a Special electronic portal for establishing business contacts and promoting investment, with the involvement of the regions.
The Head of our state paid special attention to unlocking the transport and transit potential of the North-South and East-West lines, developing corridors in the southern direction, running through Central Asia, with access to the ports of the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean.
Considerable opportunities were identified for coordinating efforts to form a â€œSCO common transport spaceâ€ and link it to the Belt and Road strategic initiative. It was proposed to develop a concept providing for the creation of new multimodal networks, digital platforms, and â€œgreenâ€ corridors.
In the context of expanding the SCO partnership in the field of green transformation, the need to launch a regional platform on climate change adaptation, decarbonisation and the introduction of artificial intelligence technologies for forecasting environmental risks was noted.
-
The key factor in long-term partnership within the SCO is the further deepening of cultural ties and the strengthening of the institution of "people's diplomacy"
, - emphasized the President of Uzbekistan.
He noted that the International Festival of Folk Art, creation of an online campus for the SCO University partner network, and organization of annual competitions and Olympiads among students and young professionals in innovative fields could give a powerful impetus to the development of humanitarian exchanges and further rapprochement between our peoples.
It was also proposed to work on such promising projects as the launch of the â€œTourism Corridorâ€ and the SCO Medical Tourism Alliance.
In conclusion, the Head of our state congratulated the President of the Kyrgyz Republic Sadyr Japarov on assuming the chairmanship of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.
The President of the People's Republic of China, Xi Jinping, expressed his gratitude to the Head of our state for the important initiatives put forward in his speech and stressed the importance of their joint implementation.
Following the meeting, a document signing ceremony was held. In particular, the Tianjin Declaration, the SCO development strategy until 2035, and a package of important multilateral documents aimed at further strengthening partnership in various areas of cooperation were adopted.
President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan
When using materials reference to www.president.uz is required

President of China Congratulates the President of Uzbekistan on a Decisive Victory at the Elections
27.10.2021
On October 27, President of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev held a telephone conversation with President of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China Xi Jinping.
At the beginning of the conversation, President of China has warmly congratulated our President on the successful conduct and resounding victory at the presidential elections in Uzbekistan.
It was emphasized that the results of the vote have once again demonstrated the broad support of the countryâ€™s population for the ongoing development strategy of the new Uzbekistan and the foreign policy course to strengthen the mutually beneficial cooperation with foreign partners.
The President of China sincerely wished a good luck and new successes to the President of Uzbekistan, along with well-being and prosperity to the friendly Uzbek people.
The heads of states considered the topical issues of further strengthening the Uzbek-Chinese relations of comprehensive strategic partnership.
The current level of trust-based dialogue, the progressive development of bilateral relations and the intensification of mutual exchanges in accordance with the agreements reached during the summit contacts in April this year are noted with great satisfaction.
In the political sphere, the President of Uzbekistan has expressed consistent support for the Â«One China policyÂ» and resolute combat against the Â«three forces of evilÂ» â€“ terrorism, extremism and separatism.
In addition, a gratitude was expressed to the Chinese side for a big practical assistance in countering the coronavirus pandemic, including the timely deliveries and joint production of vaccines.
In turn, President Xi Jinping has stressed that China firmly supports the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Uzbekistan, as well as the ongoing program of socio-economic transformation in the country.
In the trade and economic sphere, the leaders noted a tangible increase in trade indicators. To promote the supply of in-demand products to the Chinese market, primarily agricultural goods, an agreement was reached on the active participation of Uzbekistan in the Fourth International Exhibition of Imported Goods to be be held in Shanghai in November this year.
A special attention is paid to the preparation of the five-year Program of Trade and Economic Cooperation, with inclusion of strategic projects, including in innovation, artificial intelligence, digital technologies and electronic commerce.
The exchange of experiences and knowledge in poverty reduction is identified as a key area of â€‹ â€‹ interaction. An important attention is paid to the practical implementation of the provisions of the Memorandum signed by the authorized departments of the two countries this month.
The heads of Uzbekistan and China advocated the development of a system of effective transport routes connecting China with our region and forming the Eurasian Transcontinental Transit Corridor as a part of the Â«Belt and RoadÂ» initiative.
The opportunities for expanding cooperation in science and education, healthcare and vaccination of the population, sports, tourism, culture and other areas were marked.
President Shavkat Mirziyoyev has sincerely wished his colleague and friendly people of China successful holding of the Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022.
It was agreed to hold the next meeting of the Uzbek-Chinese Intergovernmental Committee until the end of this year, as well as to draft a joint program to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations.
The President of Uzbekistan and the President of China also exchanged views on the international agenda and issues of regional cooperation.
President Shavkat Mirziyoyev supported the Global Development Initiative put forward by the leader of China at the United Nations General Assembly.
In addition, the parties agreed to continue a close dialogue within the framework of the World Health Organization and other UN institutions.
The Chinese leader expressed full support for the chairmanship of our country in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.
The Presidents also considered the establishment of lasting peace and economic development in Afghanistan. They have agreed to continue the dialogue as a part of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and other formats in order to assist the Afghan people.
At the end of the conversation, President Shavkat Mirziyoyev and President Xi Jinping warmly exchanged wishes for peace, prosperity and progress between the two friendly peoples and countries.
The conversation was held in a traditionally open, trusting and friendly atmosphere.
President
of the Republic of Uzbekistan

A solid package of documents adopted with China
02.09.2025
As a result of the talks in Beijing between the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan Shavkat Mirziyoyev and President of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China Xi Jinping, a ceremony of documents signing was held. Among them:
- Cooperation program on aligning Strategy â€œUzbekistan 2030â€ and â€œBelt and Road Initiativeâ€;
- Agreement on mutual organization of cultural centers;
- Agreement on cooperation in the sphere of medical services.
Moreover, in the framework of the visit the following agreements were signed:
- on the design of the second stage of the project for providing Uzbekistan with dredgers;
- on technical and economic cooperation;
- on cooperation in the field of conformity assessment;
- on phytosanitary requirements for the export of fresh melons and almonds from Uzbekistan to China;
- on cooperation in the peaceful use of space science, technologies and the results of space activities;
- on cooperation in the field of competition policy;
- on strengthening cooperation in the field of human resource development;
- on strengthening cooperation in the field of the digital economy;
- on establishing partnership relations between Samarkand region and the city of Tianjin;
- on cooperation between the Chamber of commerce and industry of Uzbekistan and the China council for the promotion of international trade.

of the Republic of Uzbekistan
