TITLE: IMF Deputy Managing Director Meets with Senior Ethiopian Officials

IMF Deputy Managing Director Meets with Senior Ethiopian Officials
Published:
Dec. 5, 2025
The Deputy Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Mr. Nigel Clarke, and his delegation held discussions with senior officials of the Government of Ethiopia. Mr. Clarke arrived in Addis Ababa yesterday for an official visit.
This morning, the delegation met with Minister of finance H.E Ato Ahmed Shide, governor of National Bank of Ethiopia, H.E Dr Eyob Tekalign, Minister of Plannign & Devleopment, H.E Dr Fitsum Assefa, and other officials. The discussions focused on Ethiopiaâ€™s ongoing economic reforms, IMF support to the reform agenda, and opportunities for continued collaboration.
The Minister of Finance, H.E. Ato Ahmed Shide, provided an overview of Ethiopiaâ€™s economic reform efforts and emphasized the governmentâ€™s commitment to consolidating progress and building on recent gains. He underscored Ethiopiaâ€™s interest in maintaining strong partnership with the IMF.
Mr. Clarke commended the countryâ€™s notable progress under the Homegrown Economic Reform Program, highlighting that several challenging reforms are already delivering visible results. He also recognized the high level of preparation, coordination, and determination required to advance fiscal, monetary, and structural reforms simultaneously. Looking ahead, he encouraged Ethiopia to maintain the reform momentum.
During his visit, Mr. Clarke will continue to meet with senior government officials and visit key development projects.

### 94
URL: https://www.mofed.gov.et/blog/20%E1%8A%9B%E1%8B%8D-%E1%8B%A8%E1%8A%A2%E1%89%B5%E1%8B%AE%E1%8C%B5%E1%8B%AB-%E1%89%A5%E1%88%94%E1%88%AD-%E1%89%A5%E1%88%94%E1%88%A8%E1%88%B0%E1%89%A6%E1%89%BD%E1%8A%93-%E1%88%85%E1%8B%9D%E1%89%A6%E1%89%BD-%E1%89%80%E1%8A%95-%E1%89%A0%E1%8C%88%E1%8A%95%E1%8B%98%E1%89%A5-%E1%88%9A%E1%8A%92%E1%88%B5%E1%89%B4%E1%88%AD-%E1%89%B0%E1%8A%A8%E1%89%A0%E1%88%A8
TITLE: 20áŠ›á‹ á‹¨áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‰¥áˆ”áˆ­á£ á‰¥áˆ”áˆ¨áˆ°á‰¦á‰½áŠ“ áˆ…á‹á‰¦á‰½ á‰€áŠ• á‰ áŒˆáŠ•á‹˜á‰¥ áˆšáŠ’áˆµá‰´áˆ­ á‰°áŠ¨á‰ áˆ¨

20áŠ›á‹ á‹¨áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‰¥áˆ”áˆ­á£ á‰¥áˆ”áˆ¨áˆ°á‰¦á‰½áŠ“ áˆ…á‹á‰¦á‰½ á‰€áŠ• á‰ áŒˆáŠ•á‹˜á‰¥ áˆšáŠ’áˆµá‰´áˆ­ á‰°áŠ¨á‰ áˆ¨
Published:
Dec. 1, 2025
áˆ•á‹³áˆ­ 22 / 2018 á‹“.áˆ - á‹¨áŒˆáŠ•á‹˜á‰¥ áˆšáŠ’áˆµá‰´áˆ­áŠ“ á‰°áŒ áˆª á‰°á‰‹áˆ›á‰µ 20áŠ›á‹áŠ• á‹¨áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‰¥áˆ”áˆ­á£ á‰¥áˆ”áˆ¨áˆ°á‰¦á‰½áŠ“ áˆ…á‹á‰¦á‰½ á‰€áŠ•áŠ• á‹´áˆáŠ­áˆ«á‹²á‹«á‹Š áˆ˜áŒá‰£á‰£á‰µ áˆˆáˆ…á‰¥áˆ¨á‰¥áˆ„áˆ«á‹Š áŠ áŠ•á‹µáŠá‰µ á‰ áˆšáˆ áˆ˜áˆª á‰ƒáˆ á‰ áˆšáŠ’áˆµá‰´áˆ© á‹¨áˆ˜áˆ°á‰¥áˆ°á‰¢á‹« áŠ á‹³áˆ«áˆ½ áŠ áŠ¨á‰ áˆ©á¡á¡
á‰ á‰ áŠ áˆ áŠ áŠ¨á‰£á‰ áˆ© áˆ‹á‹­ á‹¨á‰°áŒˆáŠ™á‰µ á‹¨áŒˆáŠ•á‹˜á‰¥ áˆšáŠ’áˆµá‰°áˆ­ áŠ­á‰¡áˆ­ áŠ á‰¶ áŠ áˆ…áˆ˜á‹µ áˆºá‹´ áŠ¥áŠ•á‹°áŒˆáˆˆáŒ¹á‰µ áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‹¨á‰¥á‹áˆ€áŠá‰µ áˆ€áŒˆáˆ­ áˆ˜áˆ†áŠ—áŠ• áŠ áˆ˜áˆáŠ­á‰°á‹ á‰ á‹¨áŠ áˆ˜á‰± á‹¨áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‰¥áˆ”áˆ­á£ á‰¥áˆ”áˆ¨áˆ°á‰¦á‰½áŠ“ áˆ…á‹á‰¦á‰½ á‰€áŠ• áˆ˜áŠ¨á‰ áˆ© á‰ áˆ€áŒˆáˆªá‰± áˆ…á‹á‰¦á‰½ áˆ˜áŠ«áŠ«áˆ áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹«á‹Š á‹ˆáŠ•á‹µáˆ›áˆ›á‰½áŠá‰µáŠ“ áŠ¥áˆ…á‰µáˆ˜áˆ›á‰½áŠá‰µáŠ• áˆ›áŒáˆá‰ á‰±áŠ• áŠ áˆµáˆ¨á‹µá‰°á‹‹áˆá¡á¡
áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« á‹¨á‰¥á‹áˆ€áŠá‰µ áŠ áŒˆáˆ­ áŠ¥áŠ•á‹°áˆ˜áˆ†áŠ— áˆ²á‰ªáˆ áˆ°áˆ­á‰ªáˆ±áˆ áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹«áŠ• á‰ áˆšáˆ˜áˆµáˆ áˆ˜áˆáŠ© á‰¥á‹áˆ€áŠá‰µáŠ•áŠ“ áŠ áŠ«á‰³á‰½áŠá‰µáŠ• á‹«áˆ¨áŒ‹áŒˆáŒ  áˆŠáˆ†áŠ• áŠ¥áŠ•á‹°áˆšáŒˆá‰£áŠ“ á‹´áˆáŠ­áˆ«áˆ²áŠ• á‰£áˆ…áˆ á‰ áˆ›á‹µáˆ¨áŒ áŒá‹°áˆ«áˆ‹á‹Š áˆ…á‰¥áˆ¨ á‰¥áˆ„áˆ«á‹ŠáŠá‰³á‰½áŠ•áŠ“ áŠ áŠ•á‹µáŠá‰³á‰½áŠ•áŠ• áˆ›áŒ áŠ“áŠ¨áˆ­ á‹­áŒ á‰ á‰…á‰¥áŠ“áˆ á‰¥áˆˆá‹‹áˆá¡á¡
á‰ á‰ áŠ áˆ áŠ áŠ¨á‰£á‰£áˆ© áˆ‹á‹­ á‹´áˆáŠ­áˆ«áˆ²áŠ“ áŒá‹´áˆ«áˆ‹á‹Š áˆ¥áˆ­áŠ á‰µ á‰ áŠ¢á‰µá‹®áŒµá‹« - á‰°áˆµá‹á‹á‰¹áŠ“ á‰°áŒá‹³áˆ®á‰¶á‰¹ áŠ¥áŠ•á‹²áˆáˆ á‰¥á‹áˆ€áŠá‰µáŠ•áŠ“ áŠ áŠ«á‰³á‰½áŠá‰µáŠ• á‹«áˆ¨áŒ‹áŒ‹áŒ  á‹¨áˆ²á‰ªáˆ áˆ°áˆ­á‰ªáˆµ áŒáŠ•á‰£á‰³ á‰ áˆšáˆ‰ áˆ­áŠ¥áˆ¶á‰½ áŒ¥áŠ“á‰¶á‰½ á‰€áˆ­á‰ á‹ á‰ á‰°áˆ³á‰³áŠá‹á‰½ áˆ°áŠ á‹á‹­á‹­á‰µ á‰°á‹°áˆ­áŒá‰£á‰¸á‹‹áˆá¡á¡

### 95
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/09/26/the-united-nations-at-a-critical-juncture-africas-time-to-take-active-role
TITLE: The United Nations at a Critical Juncture: Africaâ€™s Time to Take Active Role â€“ IFA

It was eighty years ago that the United Nations (UN) was established by the founding member states in 1945 to maintain international peace and security, foster friendly relations among the community of nations, and to attain international cooperation. It was the manifestation of determination to â€œsave the succeeding generations from the scourge of war, which twice in our lifetime has brought untold sorrow to humankind.â€
[1]
The establishment of the UN was raising hopes for peace and tranquility after five years of devastation that claimed millions of lives. Since then, the UN has gone through ups and downs to meet the spirit of the founding document,
the Charter that serves as the bedrock of a â€œmore peaceful, prosperous, and just world.â€
Different challenges that have emerged from the institutional setup, the paucity of transparency and accountability, the lack of commitment of the member states to reform the organization, geopolitical tensions, and major power competitions have caused the UN system to become â€œbureaucratic, costly, cumbersome, lacking in oversight, and often incapable of fulfilling the responsibilities placed upon it.â€
[2]
In response to persistent challenges confronting the organization, various reform initiatives have been proposed. Among these were An Agenda for Peace (1992) [3] and An Agenda for Development (1994)
[4]
, the UN Millennium Declarations, High-Level Panels, and the 2005 UN Summit Outcome Document.
[5]
The foregoing and subsequent reforms aim to capacitate the organization to deal with the present economic and political realities.
At the time of commemorating its eightieth anniversary, the United Nations has faced formidable challenges that could compromise its responsibilities. Cognizant of the multifaceted crisis the UN is currently facing, the current Secretary General of the organization, Antonio Guterres, remarked that â€œwe cannot solve 21st century problems with 20th century tools. We need a UN 2.0â€
[6]
at the opening of the UN 2.0 in April 2024. Again, on 22 September 2024 at the Summit of the Future, global leaders adopted the Pact for the Future and its annexes, including the Global Digital Compact and the Declaration on Future Generations.
[7]
The agreement is the testimony of a commitment demonstrated by the member states to address the global challenges humanity is facing and prepare the generation for future challenges. The Pact for the Future addresses the lingering global issues as to peace and security (the Security Council reform, nuclear disarmament, space governance, and regulating emerging technologies); sustainable development and climate action (sustainable development goals, financial reform, climate finance, and rethinking progress); digital cooperation; youth and future generations; transforming global governance; and human rights and gender equality.
[8]
Banking on previous reforms, the UN80 initiative has been launched since March 2025 by Secretary-General Antonio Guterres to make the organization â€œmore agile, integrated, and equipped to respond to todayâ€™s complex global challenges amid tightening resources.â€
[9]
Since 22 September 2025, leaders have attended the UN General Assembly. This meeting has been held amidst the rising of uncertainty, the erosion of multilateralism and the weakening of the collective security system, the rising of unilateralism, deteriorating relations between major powers, crises in the Middle East and in some parts of Africa, challenges accompanying the future of the peacekeeping operations in Africa, poverty, terrorism, pandemics, environmental challenges, migration and refugees, transnational crimes, human rights violations, and humanitarian crises. Furthermore, artificial intelligence and mounting biological risks are increasingly posing threats.
[10]
The multilateral response to the crises is severely affected by the lingering divisions among the members of the Security Council, â€œa divided international community and a divided membership.â€
[11]
In response to the multifaceted crisis the UN is facing, representing 54 states, the African Group (AG) needs to continue to demonstrate a common position and voice together with like-minded states and groups that could address the divisions and the paralysis afflicting the organization, particularly the Security Council during the 80
th
Session of the UN General Assembly that is held under the theme
â€œBetter together: 80 years and more for peace, development, and human rightsâ€ since 9 September 2025.
[12]
African states should further advance the historic agreement of the Pact for the Future and its annexes that call for enhanced international cooperation to address climate change, poverty, and health problems.
[13]
In line with the commitments, African states, including Ethiopia are also keeping on championing the reform of the UNSC by calling for the overturning of the historical underrepresentation of AfricaÂ , strengthening the Economic and Social Council, strengthening the United Nations System, more investment on regional security infrastructure, reforming the international financial architecture and sustainable financing, nuclear disarmament, preventing arms race in space, maritime security and safety and secure support for the realization of Â sustainable development goals. Indeed, the African Union, in this regard, can play a pivotal role by bringing the continentâ€™s voices to the front stage as recently the chairperson of the AU Commission, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf, engaged in demonstrating a commitment to â€œjoin Africaâ€™s heads of states and government to highlight Africaâ€™s leadership and agency in addressing peace and security challengesâ€
[14]
and reach out to global partners to â€œpromote investment and trade opportunities that can accelerate Africaâ€™s development and advance the AUâ€™s Agenda 2063.â€
[15]
Thus, African states will continue to demonstrate their commitment to the UNâ€™s multilateral framework as â€œthe most viable path to achieving global peace and sustainable development.â€
[16]
This will in turn help the goals of the present initiative to have a global institution that is efficient, effective, people-centered, accountable, and proactive in addressing global challenges amidst the shifting international order.

Navigating Ethiopiaâ€™s Debt Landscape: Strategies for Sustainable Economic Resilience

### 96
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/11/saudi-pakistan-defense-pact-a-new-security-frontier
TITLE: Saudi-Pakistan Defense Pact: A New Security Frontier â€“ IFA

Introduction
The September 9, 2025, Israeli attack targeting exiled Hamas leaders in Qatar shocked not only the Arabs but also the whole Muslim world. Countries from super and sub identities gathered in solidarity in Doha, where they condemned the Israeli attack as barbaric and provocative. Arab and Muslim leaders in the conference and in their side talks discussed the next steps to defend countries in the region from any future regional threats. Participants of the summit proposed many alternative measures to tackle future threats, including the formation of a Muslim/Arab NATO style security alliance, banning Israel from the United Nations General Assembly, and cutting diplomatic and economic ties with Israel.
The reverberation of the Doha conference culminated in the historic Saudi-Pakistan Defense Pact, signed on 17 September 2025, a pact typically signed when two friendly nations reach the zenith of their diplomatic relationship. The agreement was signed between Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Saudi Arabia and Pakistan are the most powerful nations in the Muslim world, Pakistan being the only nuclear nation in the Muslim world, while Saudi Arabia is the ideological and economic hub.
According to the Pakistani Prime Minister,
This agreement, which reflects the shared commitment of both nations to enhance their security and to achieving security and peace in the region and the world, aims to develop aspects of defense cooperation between the two countries and strengthen joint deterrence against any aggression. The agreement states that any aggression against either country shall be considered an aggression against both.
The Prime Ministerâ€™s speech indicated that the scope of the pact extends beyond regional commitment, potentially enabling the two countries to engage in broader global peace and security initiatives. The remarks also alluded to the potential exchange of the latest military technologies, such as nuclear warheads and the latest fighter jets. Most significantly, the Prime Minister unequivocally underscored that any attack on Saudi Arabia is considered an attack on Pakistan, and vice versa.
Saudi officials, meanwhile, dismissed the unfounded narrative linking the pact to regional events or adversaries. This is best captured in the saying of one Saudi official: â€œ
This agreement is a culmination of years of discussions. This is not a response to specific countries or specific events but an institutionalization of longstanding and deep cooperation between our two countries
.â€ However, scholars and analysts have already begun to debate the scope, limitations, and implications of the Saudi-Iran Defense Pact. As this backdrop, this policy brief will examine the context, commitments, and potential scenarios of the pact vis-Ã -vis Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic interest in Saudi Arabia.
Strategic Context
The Saudi-Pakistani relations began right after the independence of the latter from British colonialism in 1947. The relation is characterized by consistency with a high level of trust from both sides. This is due to the fact that Pakistan believed in Saudi Arabiaâ€™s de facto leadership of Islam and portrayed itself as the guardian of Saudi Arabia. The level of trust can be evidenced by the presence of Pakistani soldiers (1500-2000) stationed in Saudi Arabia for decades as protectors of the kingdom, advisor, and trainer of the Saudi Armed forces. So far, Pakistan has reported having trained over 8000 Saudi military personnel. Beyond these, the kingdom frequently summoned additional Pakistani military forces whenever Saudi Arabia was threatened by external threats. The Al-Wadiah War between Saudi Arabia and Yemen in 1969, and the deployment of 20,000 Pakistani Soldiers in Saudi Arabia during the Iraq-Iran War in the 1970s and 1980s were cases in point. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia has also been a major importer of Pakistani arms, purchasing $81 million worth in 2016 alone. Although the relations between the two states at the strategic level have been harmonious, Pakistanâ€™s rejection of contributing troops to the Saudi-led intervention against Houthiss remained exceptional (Rabia, 2025; Anwar et al, 2025).
Theoretical Framework: Understanding the Saudi-Pakistan Defense Pact
The Saudi Pakistani Defense pact seems to be best explained by alliance theory. Two distinct theories are very important to explain this Pact. The first is
balance of threat theory
which was developed by Walt (1987) while the second one was
alliance dependency theory
which was developed by Snyder (1997).
The
balance of threat theory
contends that states primarily form alliance for balancing threat but it is determined by the level of threat perception. Walt identified four sources of threat: aggregate power of a rival state (population, economy and military capability), geographical proximity (neighboring states are more threatening than distant states), offensive capability of a rival state (power projection and advanced weapon) and perceived intentions of a rival state (aggressiveness and hostility). All these determinants changes the behavior of states on why and how to form alliance. Most states form alliance against the strongest threat to protect themselves while others align with a threatening power. Â Alliance are flexible depending on the threat perception. This is to mean that credibility of alliance rests on shared threat perceptionâ€”alliance strengthened if perception converges (Walt, 1987).
The alliance dependency theory, on the other hand, argues that alliance is formed for mutual dependency, but this dependency is often asymmetrical. This determines the bargaining power, influence, and durability of the alliance. The state that is less dependent on the alliance will have more bargaining power. This imbalance creates opportunities for exploitation in which the stronger power urges more concessions, while the weaker power fears abandonment. States manage alliance dependency paradox through assuring credibility, adjusting commitments, and striking a balance between autonomy and alliance cohesion (Snyder, 1997).
The Pact: Cause and Commitments
Causes of the Alliance
Although the triggering factor for the signing of the Defense pact between Saudi and Pakistan is Israeli aggression of Qatar on 9 September 2025, the balance threat theory seems to explain why the alliance is formed. On the side of Saudi Arabia, the geographical proximity of the Houthis, Iranâ€™s growing regional influence, and the United Statesâ€™ failure to provide a reliable security guarantee were the main driving factors behind the alliance (Rabia, 2025). The Houthis has been the most formidable threat for Saudi Arabia, the geographical proximity of the threat just in its immediate neighborhood seem to have forced Saudi Arabia to form alliance with a nuclear state of Pakistan. The level of the threat can be evidenced by the 2018 Houthis rocket and drone attack on the Saudi cities and oil infrastructures. It should be noted that Saudi Arabia fought bloodiest war with Houthis between the years 2014 and 2023. Although peace agreement was signed in 2023, Houthis and Iran are still the primary security concern in comparison to Israel. The alliance with nuclear-armed Pakistan enhances Saudi Arabiaâ€™s deterrence posture. It signals that aggression from the Houthisâ€”or indirectly from Iranâ€”will be met with a strengthened security guarantee. The pact therefore serves both as an immediate hedge against local threats and a broader balancing mechanism against Iranâ€™s regional influence (Al-Madhaji, 2016). The Saudi-Pakistan defense pact reflects a strategic choice to balance threats rather than merely respond to crises. By deepening its alliance with Pakistan, Saudi Arabia seeks to deter hostile actors like Houthis, Iran and Israel hoping an aggregate outcome of greater regional stability.
On the other hand, Pakistan is the closest non-Arab ally to Saudi Arabia. Although Pakistan is the only nuclear state in the Muslim world, it is the most politically unstable and economically impoverished state. Since 1949 Pakistan has been struck by military coups, no civil government completed five year of terms. The military regularly intervened in the civilian politics notably using military coup, judicial rulings and presidential decrees. For example, the military directly took over power three times in 1958, 1977 and 1999. Â Economically, Pakistan frequently suffered from chronic inflation, currency depreciation, low productivity and export. In addressing these, the country is highly dependent on foreign loans and financial support especially from Saudi Arabia and IMF. Saudi Arabia is the main economic backer when Pakistan faced macroeconomic instability. The kingdom often supported Pakistan in terms of grants, loans and provision of oil in credits. For instance, it is worth mentioning Saudiâ€™s $ 6 billion financial support to stabilize the Pakistani financial crisis in 2018(Ibid). It is fair to conclude that Pakistan signed the Defense Pact primarily driven by economic aspirations particularly aiming at increasing the cash inflow and steady oil supply from Saudi Arabia.
Commitments of the Pact
When countries signed a defense pact, there are certain
commitments
that need to be observed. However, commitments differ depending on the scope and depth of the agreement. Saudi and Pakistan signed a historical defense pact on 17 September 2025. According to the statement of the agreement, both countries pledged a â€œjoint deterrence against aggressionâ€. Â Although the details of commitment is not clear whether it Â will follow a NATO style Article-5 framework or not, it is crystal clear that both countries declare that any attack on Saudi is an attack on Pakistan, and the vice versa. Although Pakistan involved in training and advising the Saudi Armed forces for decades, formalizing strategic cooperation in terms of Defense Pact potentially enhance all military assistance including the provision of a â€œnuclear umbrellaâ€ to the kingdom (Rabia, 2025). Beyond these, joint military exercise, sharing of intelligence and defense technology, supply and sales of weaponry are some of the commitments which are expected from both nations, particularly from Pakistan.
Since the two powers have asymmetrical independence in their commitment, their relation will be more of symbiotic. Saudi Arabia is economically the most prosperous nation in the Muslim world while Pakistan is among the poorest. Riyadh is expected to provide financial support in terms of loans, grants, credit facilities. Saudi Arabia is also expected to expand its oil supply on preferential terms. Beyond these, the kingdom is anticipated to invest in Pakistani military industrial complex particularly in â€œProject Azemâ€, a research and development program aimed at building a fifth-generation stealth fighter air craft. Saudi Arabiaâ€™s strong economic and financial leverage increases Pakistanâ€™s dependence on Saudi Arabia. On the contrary, Pakistan holds the most powerful military, and the only nuclear state in the Muslim world. This provides a more bargaining power for Pakistan to influence the new Defense Pact, while Saudi Arabia remains dependent on Pakistani military capability. Given Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic interest (remittance, hundreds thousands of immigrant workers, Red Sea security and energy security) rests more in the stability of Saudi Arabia, the next section will assess scenarios whether the pact will provide effective protection to the latter.
Scenarios: Will the Pact Defend Saudi Arabia?
The Saudiâ€“Pakistan Defense Pact could provide Saudi Arabia with enhanced security, but the extent of its effectiveness depends on how both sides operationalize their commitments. Given the long-standing diplomatic relations between the two states, three possible scenarios can be developed whether the pact will effectively defend Saudi Arabia.
Scenario 1: Partial or Symbolic Defense
The pact will most likely have partial or symbolic defense for the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. There are many reasons for this scenario to happen. Firstly, the ambiguity of terms in the agreement, whether it could provide a NATO-style Article 5 guarantee for Saudi Arabia. Secondly, Saudi Arabiaâ€™s dependency syndrome on the US security protection. It is unlikely for the Saudi leaders to break the security alliance with the US. Although there were a few cases of security impasse, the kingdom has not been totally detached from the US security enclave for the last many decades. The signing of the pact with Pakistan seems an act of Saudi Arabiaâ€™s tactical move to bring the US back to its traditional service. Thirdly, Saudi Arabiaâ€™s complete withdrawal from the US Middle East security architecture might expose the kingdom to strategic vulnerability. In response to the pact, the US might shift its alliance with the traditional enemies of the kingdom, such as Iran, the Houthis, and Israel. Beyond this, the US might undermine the role of Pakistan in Saudi Arabia through economic sanctions and a strategic alliance with its traditional enemy, India. Lastly, Pakistanâ€™s technological incapability to sufficiently deter threats to Saudi Arabia. How far is Pakistan potentially capable of defending against Houthi, Iranian, or Israeli missiles, drones, and aerial attacks? These are some of the puzzles that need to be addressed in relation to the effectiveness of the defense pact. In such a case, the pact would act more as a political signal of solidarity than a binding operational defense arrangement. While Saudi Arabia would gain some reassurance, its hard security would continue to depend on U.S. military systems and Western partnerships.
Scenario 2: Effective Defense of Saudi Arabia
The pact will likely serve as an effective Defense mechanism for Saudi Arabia. There are some reasons for this to happen. Firstly, the pact most importantly might provide a â€œnuclear umbrellaâ€ to Saudi Arabia, which is a powerful deterrence for the threats coming from the region and beyond. Secondly, excessive petro-dollar inflow from the kingdom will keep Pakistan committed and stable. Lastly, Pakistan is anticipated to provide more military manpower and advanced training to the Saudi armed forces. All these provisions could reduce dependency on the US for hard power and boost protection of vital infrastructure such as oil fields, ports, cities, and borders.
Scenario 3: Ineffective Defense of Saudi Arabia
The pact will unlikely provide meaningful defense for Saudi Arabia. Some of the reasons for this scenario to occur are: Firstly, the entrenched political instability between civilian politics and the military might undermine Pakistanâ€™s capability to project power abroad. Secondly, the incompatible threat perception might hamper cooperation between the two signatories. Saudi Arabia might prioritize Iran (a neighbor to Pakistan), Houthis, and Israel, while Pakistan might prioritize India. Thirdly, Pakistan might hesitate to intervene militarily in times of real crisis if Iran/Houthis attack or an Israeli strike occurs. All these factors might have led the kingdom to abandon the pact and be forced to fall back on the US security arrangement.
Conclusion
Saudi Arabia and Pakistan signed the defense pact, aiming at balancing threats. The former joined the pact primarily threatened by Iran, the Houthis, the expansionist policy of Israel, and the US failure to provide a security guarantee.Â  The latter was primarily motivated to ensure economic and political stability through securing economic assistance from Saudi Arabia. Although many writers portrayed Saudi Arabiaâ€™s confrontation with the Houthis and Pakistanâ€™s Indian-centric nuclear doctrine as potential challenges, the two nations are supposed to set balancing mechanisms to align their national interests. The defense pact seems to have shown that there is asymmetrical commitment in which Pakistan, with higher bargaining power, is entrusted to provide military assistance such as advisory, training, arms supply, including the provision of â€œnuclear umbrellaâ€, while Saudi Arabia with strong economic commitment is anticipated to provide loans, grants, credit facilities and investment for Pakistani military industrial complex. However, the presence of mutual dependency between the two nations strengthens the durability of the defense pact, as it reduces the risk of entrapment and abandonment. Given that Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic interest rests more in the stability of Saudi Arabia, the effective protection of the latter either through this defense pact or the US security arrangement will ensure the uninterrupted flow of remittance, communal security of hundreds of thousands of Ethiopian immigrant workers, stability of the Red sea region, and safeguard energy security.
References

Ethiopiaâ€™s Sea Access Strategy: From Geopolitical Challenge to Economic Necessity
The Initiative of Pulse of Africa: A Digital Media Platform to Rectify Africaâ€™s Narratives in Post-Truth Public Diplomacy

### 97
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/29/the-seventh-africa-eu-summit-priorities-and-divergences
TITLE: The Seventh Africa-EU Summit: Priorities and Divergences? â€“ IFA

Summary
The seventh summit between the two sides of the Mediterranean Sea will set priorities to strengthen future relations, learning from the past.Â  The possibility of cooperation anchored in mutual benefits, common values, and shared interests could benefit the two continents as long as they move toward actionable solutions. Nevertheless, the drifting away from supporting the African Solutions to African Problems, domestic security uncertainties in the continent, some African statesâ€™ turned their back on their European counterparts in the aftermath of military coup, demonstrated piecemeal move to reform the existing international institutions, the war between Moscow and Kyiv, and the emerging alternative economic and security arrangement seem to cloud the coming summit and hence remain the significant sources of divergences between the African Union and the European Union in the future relationship.
The Previous Summits
Africa has built bilateral and trilateral partnerships with major global actors. As part of addressing both continental and global challenges, the African Union, representing its member states, has been forging ties with its counterpart, the European Union, for the last twenty-five years. Since 2000, the AU-EU summit has been held in the selected capital cities of member states of the African Union and the European Union. Since the start of the partnership, the areas of cooperation between the two sides have focused on peace and security, migration, democracy, good governance and human rights, trade, health, development, multilateralism, global and emerging issues. The first meeting between the two sides of the Mediterranean Sea took place in Cairo, Egypt, on 3 and 4 April 2000 under the theme of â€˜A New Dimension to Our Global Partnership for the Twenty-First Centuryâ€™.
[1]
After a seven-year interval, the second summit was held in Lisbon, Portugal, in 2007 that culminated in the adoption of the Africa-EU Joint Strategy and its Action Plan
[2]
and the establishment of an institutional setup and funding mechanisms to support AUâ€™s activities.
The third and fourth summits were held in Tripoli on November 29 and 30, 2010, and Brussels, Belgium, on 2 and 3 April 2014, respectively. During the Tripoli Summit, the Tripoli Declaration and a Joint Declaration on Climate Change were adopted.
[3]
The roadmap for EU-Africa relations (2014-2017) was adopted during the Brussels Summit.
[4]
In Abidjan, CÃ´te dâ€™Ivoire, the fifth AU-EU Summit was held on 29-30 November 2017. The Abidjan summit gave due recognition to the UNâ€™s 2030 Agenda on sustainable development, the Paris Agreement on climate change, and Africaâ€™s Agenda 2063.
[5]
The sixth EU-AU Summit took place in Brussels on 17 and 18 February 2022. During this summit, the leaders of both institutions agreed on a joint vision for a renewed partnership.
[6]
The Joint AU-EU Vision for 2030, among others, aims to augment AU peace support operations, support for the UN assessed contributions, support for the implementation of the Women, Peace and Security (WPS), Youth, Peace and Security and deepen cooperation on security. Luandaâ€™s summit, scheduled for 24 and 25 November 2025, will be more than a symbolic celebration of the 25th anniversary of their cooperation. It will set the priorities and demonstrate the divergent positions both sides have vis-Ã -vis regional and global issues.
The Seventh AU-EU Summit: Priorities and Dark Clouds
The seventh summit between the two sides marks a quarter-century partnership between the EU and the AU.
[7]
The coming summit will give due attention to regional economic integration, trade, peace and security, climate financing, AI, the erosion of multilateralism, the Global Gateway Initiative, and the unfolding conflict between Russia and Ukraine. On the side of Africa, Agenda 2063, the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA), Sustainable Global Development 2030, reforming the global financial and security architectures, particularly the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the United Nations Security Council, and financing the peacekeeping operations (UNSC 2719) will seize the center stage.
Both the AU and the EU share common priorities, albeit with concern about the prevailing misalignment evident in the two-decades-plus partnership. Indeed, both sides are also showing a commitment to shared values and to maintaining multilateral arrangements amid the unfolding challenges. Despite ties between the two sides, challenges remain in fostering deeper cooperation. This concern is indeed reflected during the third AU-EU ministerial meeting.
[8]
Among the challenges the upcoming summit is facing is whether the EU remains a major partner in financing African peace and security infrastructure, as it was witnessed in various peace operations on the continent. The EUâ€™s decreasing interest in backing the continentâ€™s peace and security efforts has been observed in its â€œshifting from supporting AfSol towards framing EU foreign and security policies with a direct link between African stability and European security (and economic) interestsâ€
[9]
could be mentioned. Leaders in the EU and major member states are paying closer attention to Europeâ€™s peace and security, especially after the 2022 war between Moscow and Kyiv. Furthermore, the emergence of right-wing groups in Europe has led to a decline in interest in African affairs. These instances are among the major factors that cast a shadow on the trajectory of the partnership between the two sides.
Another area of divergence between the two sides is military coups in the Sahel, which have caused diplomatic friction among regional states and with some European states. In an effort to fill the security vacuum left by European powers, extra-regional geopolitical actors and rivals are vying to forge new allies. Sahel states may not participate at a higher level at the upcoming summit due to increasingly precarious diplomatic relations with some European Union member states. Besides, the current geopolitical reality that shows alternative security and economic arrangement like that of BRICS Plus and its members inroads to Africa to build a closer ties with African states in tandem of the admission of Ethiopia and Egypt into the organization tend to compel the EU to refrain from â€œclaiming Africaâ€™s unique partner.â€
[10]
Hence, there is a possibility of not giving weight to the coming summit as equal as its predecessors.
Currently, the global south is calling for reform of the international institutions established in the wake of the end of World War II. Even from the global north, particularly the EU, there is interest in backing the AU in its call for the democratization of international institutions to address the embedded unfairness and unrepresentativeness in the changing geopolitical and geo-economic order. Notwithstanding its commitments in joint declarations and summits, the EU is still criticized for failing to translate them into reality. Such a trajectory, according to a recent report by ECDPM, will incentivize â€œAfrica and the wider Global South to continue to develop alternative institutions or gravitate towards non-Western power blocs such as the BRICS.â€
[11]
Another challenge that could affect the partnership between the AU and the EU is related to the model of the partnership between the two sides that has changed from what it was twenty-five years ago. Development aid, migration, and financing the peacekeeping operations were previously the major pillars of cooperation. Currently, however, investment, the fight against irregular migration, energy security, and access to strategic minerals has come to the forefront of the discussion table. It seems that a â€œtransactional approachâ€
[12]
tends to highly affect the relationship between the two sides in the coming years or decades. As a result, the predominant mantra of â€œsolidarity with the global south [Africa]â€ could be sidelined in future engagements. Rather, interests will dominate the discussion amid rising security uncertainties across different pockets of the continent. Furthermore, the third Russia-Africa summit that is scheduled to convene in one of the capitals of Africa by next year may cloud the condition of the coming summit and its subsequent effort to translate the declaration into reality.
Conclusions
In retrospect, the prior summits between the AU and the EU envisaged to build a deepening partnership anchored on â€œcommon values, equality, mutual respect, and cooperation.â€ Looking after twenty-five years of cooperation, there are still shortcomings in building political, economic and cultural ties that are reciprocated by mutual benefits while looking at the foregoing determinants stand between the two sides. Notwithstanding the challenges and uncertainties the international community has witnessed, the AU and the EU member states need to bolster their shared commitment to address global and continental challenges more than ever. Otherwise, foregoing trends will cast a shadow not just to the coming summit, but also the future partnership.

Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Survival: Economic Drivers for Sea Access
The Battle for Africaâ€™s Strategic Wealth: Leveraging Resource Power in the Era of Critical Mineral Geopolitics

### 98
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/17/unleashing-atomic-potential-why-is-ethiopia-turning-to-nuclear-energy-now
TITLE: Unleashing Atomic Potential: Why Is Ethiopia Turning to Nuclear Energy Now? â€“ IFA

Executive Summary
Ethiopia is a strategic inflection point in its energy policy. The High-Level Ministerial Roundtable on Ethiopia Nuclear Power Programme held recently in Addis Ababa with the help of International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is a step forward in replacing plans with action. The nuclear energy is currently positioned as a fundamental national development tool, geared towards mitigating structural energy deficiencies, industrialization, and energy sovereignty on national level. A nuclear programme, which is well regulated, peaceful, internationally supervised is a strategic need. Ethiopia is experiencing acute climatic vulnerability, increasing energy needs, and geopolitical dangers of over-exploiting scarce resources. Non-diversification at this point threatens to bring economic stagnation in the long, hydrological fragility, and underdeveloped industry. Gradual, safety-first nuclear, coupled with renewable energy, will offer predictable, low-carbon energy, technological innovation, and increase the resilience of Ethiopia and its independence.
Context and Rationale: The Imperative for Energy Diversification
The energy system in Ethiopia exhibits great success but it is extremely susceptible. More than 90 percent of the installed generation capacity is hydropower, which makes Ethiopia a leader in renewable in the region (Trade.gov, 2025; Survey.amu.edu.et, 2025). However, this reliance puts the nation at the risk of drought, seasonal fluctuations, and cross-border political risks (MDPI, 2024; ABJOL.org.et, 2024). Untapped potential energy sourcesâ€”such as solar, wind, geothermal, and biomassâ€”limit the countryâ€™s energy access and adaptability (Trade.gov, 2025). Diversification of energy is not an option anymore, it is a strategy that is needed. Increasing the energy mix improves the resilience of the system, creates a fair access point, attracts investment, and deals with climate risks and geopolitical risks (ClimateChangeNews, 2025). Nuclear energy is used to supplement hydropower and renewables and gives the economy a solid, dense and weather-independent base-load.
Rising Energy Demand and Hydrological Vulnerability
Electricity demand is rapidly growing with population growth, urbanization and industrial expansion. With large-scale investments in hydropower, the rural population is left underrepresented, and frequent outages of power limit the productivity and investment (MDPI, 2024; Academic.oup.com, 2025). Peak demand is usually greater than the supply, so there is a need to resort to expensive and polluting back-up sources. These problems are complicated by climate variability. The extended droughts lower the level of reservoirs, initiate the process of load-shedding throughout the nation, and complicate the energy security and the upstream-downstream geopolitics. Nuclear power is predictable and a constant energy source that does not depend on weather and other external forces.
Ethiopia is pursuing nuclear power to address a critical gap between its rapidly growing electricity demand and its over-reliance on hydropower, which currently accounts for 90% of its energy.
While projects like the GERD have increased capacity, the nation remains highly vulnerable to climate-induced droughts and seasonal rainfall variability. By integrating nuclear energy, Ethiopia aims to create a more stable, low-carbon power grid that can support its expanding industrial economy and 120 million citizens regardless of weather conditions.
Strategic Energy Security and Sovereignty
Ethiopiaâ€™s decision to pursue nuclear energy is essentially a strategic one to protect the national energy security and enforce sovereignty. Energy security is not just being able to have access to power, but a diversified portfolio against systemic weaknesses. An excessive dependence on hydropower puts the nation at a climatic and geopolitical risk. Seasonal droughts lower the level of the reservoirs which results in the load shedding in the whole country leading to interruption in the production of industries, commerce, and services delivered to people (MDPI, 2024). Further, the dependency on the Nile basin interconnects national energy security with upstream and downstream politics and it is a potential point of vulnerability to exogenous forces. To overcome these weaknesses, nuclear energy offers the country a constant predictable and weather-free supply of electricity that will enable the nation to supply the base-load power demand irrespective of climatic changes.
In addition to resilience, nuclear energy reinforces Ethiopiaâ€™s strategic independence. By generating a considerable amount of electricity domestically, the country can decrease its reliance on energy imports from neighboring nations. This strengthens Ethiopiaâ€™s bargaining power in the regional arena and ensures a more autonomous energy policy.Â  The nuclear programme is also part of the industrialization agenda of Ethiopia and some of the high-tech industries, manufacturing clusters, and the emerging infrastructure projects will have uninterrupted power supply. In this respect, nuclear energy will act as a buffer against exterior shocks and a mechanism of long-term economic and technological independence, which will be the foundation of a stronger, independent country.
Policy Arguments: Why Nuclear Energy Is a Strategic Necessity
Nuclear power is not a luxury, but a strategic investment in Ethiopiaâ€™s future development. The economic impacts of failure to diversify the energy source are significant: chronic power outages, limited industrialization and further dependence of imported fossil fuels or local energy systems. As a reliable, large-scale, and low-carbon base-load source, nuclear power helps stabilize the energy system by providing a grid anchor; this allows variable renewable sources, such as solar and wind, to be integrated into the system more effectively (Trade.gov, 2025; ClimateChangeNews, 2025).
Although the initial capital outlay is significant, it should be viewed as a strategic investment that fosters industrial strength, energy security, and long-term development resilient to climate change.
Moreover, nuclear energy is an effective engine for industrialization and the creation of high-skilled jobs. The Ethiopian governmentâ€™s programme for green steel, fertilizer production, and electric mobility rely on an assured power supply. Thousands of high-tech jobs for engineers, researchers, and technical service providers will be created during the construction, operation, and regulation of nuclear facilities. In addition to direct employment, the program encourages a domestic supply chain for high-level components and promotes technological innovation in fields such as materials science, medicine, and agriculture. (Academic.oup.com, 2025). This forms a virtuous cycle where energy security, industrial development and human capital development strengthen other ones.
The international supervision is equally important in enhancing the safety and credibility. The IAEA cooperation with Ethiopia helps to guarantee the compliance with international standards of nuclear safety, security, and waste disposal to reduce political and operation risks. Quite on the contrary, this kind of supervision boosts public trust and international confidence that offers a good ground to domestic and regional acceptance. Diversifying energy sources by adopting nuclear power does not only ensure stable electricity supply but also a high level of strategic sovereignty, less susceptibility to hydrological and geopolitical shocks and leadership of the region, as a technologically prospective state.
Challenges and Risk Mitigation
Nuclear energy has transformative advantages; however, it is a complex entity that needs financial, technical, regulatory, and social risks to be managed. There are also major problems of financial and technical constraints because nuclear plants demand large initial investments, lengthy construction periods, and technical skills and expertise. In order to avoid these challenges, Ethiopia ought to consider adopting a gradual approach to investment, by initially undertaking small scale projects like Small Modular Reactors (SMRs), which have relatively small scale, are inherently safe and can be used in off-grid or industrial settings. Enhanced financing systems such as the support of the international development banks, public-private associations etc. can also be used to lower the fiscal load as well as help to meet climate and development goals (Trade.gov, 2025).
Another important factor lies in regulatory and institutional capacity. The Ethiopian Nuclear Energy Commission (ENEC) should be an independent body that is strong and technologically competent to control licensing, safety checks, and response to emergencies. Enhancing the ENEC needs to have sufficient legal power, long-term financing and strategic human resource growth. It needs twinned arrangement with other experienced nuclear regulators, intense training programmes, and compliance with the principles of the IAEA safety culture in order to be confident that the operations are performed on the highest standards on the planet and people are still confident.
Lastly, social license and public communication are the key to long-term success. The issue of safety, management of radioactive wastes, and location of the facility will have to be resolved by conducting open, long-term and participatory engagement programs. Public confidence may be strengthened by showing the practical benefits of the nuclear energy such as the creation of local employment, the enhancement of infrastructure, its use in medicine, agriculture and research. Technical rigor with proactive community activity can support Ethiopia in the development of the social license that can guarantee the support of the population and the sustainability of the long-term program (ClimateChangeNews, 2025; MDPI, 2024).
Policy Recommendations
To navigate the technical and financial complexities of nuclear integration while ensuring the highest standards of safety and public trust, the Government of Ethiopia should adopt the following strategic policy measures:
1
. Hasten Regulatory Frameworks: Enact all inclusive safety, liability, licensing and emergency response legislation according to IAEA specifications.
2. Focus on Human Capital Development: Introduce national scholarships, professional training, and cooperation with international nuclear education institutions.
3. Embraced Staged Deployment: The implementation of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) should be used as a small step into industrial sectors and remote locations.
4. Enhance International Cooperation: Maintain IAEA control and diversify technology partners so that there is flexibility and maximum transfer of knowledge.
5. Make Transparency Institutional: Publicize milestones, safety reviews and audits to gain confidence inside and out.
Conclusion
Ethiopiaâ€™s entry into the nuclear power sector marks a historic turning point, transitioning the nation from energy vulnerability toward technological sovereignty. With rigorous regulation, strategic alliances, and active stakeholder engagement, nuclear energy has the potential to revolutionize Ethiopiaâ€™s energy landscape. More than just a power source, it serves as a catalyst for industrialization, resilience, and sustainable national prosperity. By embracing this path, Ethiopia secures its position in a sustainable, independent, and technologically advanced future.

Ethiopia Today on the Global Climate Stage : Insights from COP30 and G20

### 99
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/04/17/ethiopias-quest-for-sea-access-navigating-peaceful-diplomatic-strategies
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Sea Access: Navigating Peaceful Diplomatic Strategies â€“ IFA

As one of the few civilizational states, Ethiopia has had contacts with ancient civilizations through caravan and long-distance commercial activities using the Red Sea coastal access points. It was one of those states engaging in the Red Sea region for a number of strategic reason such as security, commerce and international relations. Due to various domestic, regional and international ruptures, however, Ethiopiaâ€™s sovereign access and control of the Red Sea region faded away over the years. Ethiopia has, at least four times, lost and regained access to the Red Sea region. The rise of Islam in the Middle East in the 7
th
C AD and its subsequent expansion to the Red Sea region, the expansion of the Ottoman Empire and control of the Red Sea in the 17
th
C. AD, the Italian colonial establishment in Northern Ethiopia, present day Eritrea (1896-1942), and independence of Eritrea in 1993 were some of the factors that left Ethiopia landlocked. Time and again, Ethiopia lost and regained control of the Red Sea illustrates Ethiopiaâ€™s past and present undying zeal and ambition to get access to the Red Sea.
While being an economic and military power in the Red Sea region, Ethiopia has been affected by being landlocked. It is one of the fastest growing economies in the world. However, most of the economic dividends are paid to the countries providing access for the transit of goods and services to and from the international market. Currently, over 85% of the nationâ€™s import-export trade activities are dependent on the Djibouti port which in turn demands the payment of rents in cash â€“ one of the highest transit costs in the world. This is keeping other factors such as misappropriation, delayance, constant inspections and monitoring, and mishandling constant. Also, due to lack of storage capacity, Ethiopia is often forced to prioritize import-export items of goods and services. Much of the goods to be exported to the external markets are primary products and seasonal â€“ making the prioritization of goods highly inconsistent. This affects economic development.
Aside from economic development perspectives, there are also strategic reasons related to national security vulnerabilities that the country has suffered from by being landlocked. The Red Sea is one of the most dynamic regions in the world characterized by interstate and intrastate conflicts, hot-bed for external powers rivalries, proxy conflicts and cross-border crimes, piracy and armed robberies and international terrorism. Since Ethiopia is few miles away from the Red Sea coasts, these security developments are highly concerning. Gaining access, therefore, helps identify the national security vulnerabilities and define the types of responses to be taken.
The last loss of Ethiopiaâ€™s sovereign access to the Red Sea region was following the independence of Eritrea in 1993. However, the quest of getting access to the sea has been securitized for decades that followed. Discussing or raising issues related to Ethiopiaâ€™s access to the sea used to cause mortal danger until the 2018 reforms. The question of getting access to the sea that has been simmering in the background and became public, especially following Prime-Minister Abiy Ahmedâ€™s (PhD) parliamentary speech in October 2023 stating that â€œEthiopia needs access to the Red Sea coasts.â€ This was followed by the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding for port development with the
de facto
state of Somaliland in January 2024 in return for considering the recognition of Somaliland â€“ which has irritated the surrounding littoral states.
There are several mechanisms in which landlocked states can secure either direct or diversified access to the open sea. These includes, bilateral agreements signed with transit states, building of ports through concessions or land lease with full management and operation rights for a prescribed period, constructing canals or artificial waterways, and connecting all ports and infrastructures through regional corridor projects involving both littoral and non-littoral states. Situated at the center of the Red Sea and the Horn of African growing economies, Ethiopia can ensure possession of reliable sea access through all possible mechanisms discussed above with the exception of canals which are currently unavailable in the region. Most importantly, the ongoing plan to connect the region through the LAPPSET corridor presents one alternative to meet Ethiopiaâ€™s demand for diversified sea access. This is in addition to the port development agreement signed with the
de facto
state of Somaliland through concessions â€“ which serves as an additional access point within the interconnected LAPPSET corridor.
Ethiopiaâ€™s recent quest for access to the sea has significant national and geopolitical implications. Nationally, it has reignited long-suppressed public aspirations for maritime access. Gaining access to the sea contributes to alleviating the economic challenges the country has been exposed to including but not limited to high transit costs and other issues stemming from being the largest landlocked country in the world. From a strategic perspective, the pursuit of sea access also aims to address security vulnerabilities arising from the Red Sea region, including piracy, armed robbery, cross-border crimes, and terrorism. Given Ethiopiaâ€™s status as a regional economic powerhouse with one of the strongest militaries in Africa, it could play a crucial role in fostering robust regional economic and security cooperation, thereby reducing the interventionist agendas of proliferating global and regional powers in the area. However, this does not come without costs. It has also some adverse geopolitical implications resulting in heightened interstate tensions, formation of unhealthy regional alliances against Ethiopia, and, if not carefully managed, has the risk of proxy conflicts involving global and regional powers. The recent Ethiopia-Somalia tension and the formation of the Asmara-Cairo-Mogadishu axis can be significant manifestation.
Recommendations
The following can be policy alternatives that need to be carefully pursued to balance Ethiopiaâ€™s renewed interest in the Red Sea region and the subsequent geopolitical tensions;
Heighten negotiating/bargaining power â€“ Landlocked states have the right to negotiate for a direct or diversified access to access the sea. As a landlocked country, Ethiopia needs to maximize its ability to bargain with the neighboring coastal nations. It offers various consumer goods to littoral states in the region, including foodstuffs, freshwater, and electricity throughout the year. These goods can serve as leverages to secure either direct or diversified access to the sea or, at the very least, to obtain reduced costs for the transit of goods and services.
Focus on diversifying access through corridor projects â€“ Relying solely on one direct or transit access route is insufficient for Ethiopia, considering its rapidly growing economy and population. Currently, corridor projects are emerging as vital tools for overcoming geographic trade barriers. They are transforming traditional interstate trade and commercial ties by connecting various networks and infrastructures. Securing diversified access for Ethiopia is a top priority, as it leads to lower transit costs and enables the exchange of a wider range of goods to and from the international markets. This diversification enhances competitiveness of transit costs among transit providers and reduces customs-related expenses, making Ethiopia more attractive to potential transit or access providers.
Promote regional economic and security cooperation â€“ The Red Sea region has experienced challenges in economic and security cooperation, likely due to the lack of institutional and material capacity among its littoral states to foster regional economic integration and establish robust security partnerships. As a significant economic and military power in the region, Ethiopia possesses the necessary capability to enhance economic cooperation and address regional security vulnerabilities. Therefore, it is vital to align Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of sea access with broader objectives of regional economic cooperation and security alliance in the Red Sea region.
Avoid unhealthy regional grouping/alliances â€“ Gaining direct or diversified access to the sea for a landlocked state heavily relies on the political will and mutual benefits. Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of sea access has unsettling effect on littoral neighbors, who perceive it as a â€œthreatâ€. This situation has led to short term interstate tensions and the formation of unhealthy regional groupings. However, prioritizing peaceful and regional solutions could provide Ethiopia with the strategic advantages in navigating these tensions. This context allows Ethiopia to gauge the reactions of its neighbors and work to prevent unhealthy alliances mushrooming the region.
Reinstitute naval power â€“ As one of the landlocked nations with merchant fleets operating in international trade, Ethiopia needs a strong naval presence in the Red Sea region due to the increasing maritime threats. A plot of land in either the western or eastern half of the Red Sea is essential to serve as docking point to responding to growing maritime threats. Currently, there are over 14 foreign naval bases and military facilities in the western half of the Red Sea and along the Indian Ocean coasts. Responding to maritime threats from inland is costly and naturally challenging. Therefore, a naval presence is crucial for addressing threats to Ethiopiaâ€™s merchant fleets operating in international waters and for maintaining a healthy flow of goods to and from the global market.
Careful oversight of Red Sea regional security platforms â€“ In response to regional maritime threats such as piracy and armed robberies, several platforms have been established that involve both littoral and non-littoral states. Some of these platforms include Ethiopia, while others do not. As a nearby non-littoral state in the Red Sea seeking direct or diversified access, it is essential to examine the intentions and objectives of these platforms particularly that exclude Ethiopia from membership. By closely monitoring these platforms, the country can better understand ongoing developments in the region and ensure that its national interests are safeguarded.
About the Author
Amare K. Aweke (PhD),  Middle East
Affairs Research Director General at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA).

Beyond the Fray: Africaâ€™s Agency Amidst a Contentious Global Trade Order

### 100
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/20/de-securitizing-the-nile-a-lesson-egypt-should-take-from-iraq-turkiyes-water-cooperation-deal
TITLE: ğƒğ-ğ¬ğğœğ®ğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ¢ğ³ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ­ğ¡ğ ğğ¢ğ¥ğ: ğ–ğ¡ğ² ğ„ğ ğ²ğ©ğ­ ğŒğ®ğ¬ğ­ ğ“ğšğ¤ğ ğš ğ‹ğğ¬ğ¬ğ¨ğ§ ğŸğ«ğ¨ğ¦ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ“ğ®ğ«ğ¤ğ¢ğ²ğ-ğˆğ«ğšğª ğ–ğšğ­ğğ« ğ‚ğ¨ğ¨ğ©ğğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ ğƒğğšğ¥ â€“ IFA

Last year, in late April 2024, Iraq and TÃ¼rkiye signed
several agreements
and memoranda of understanding, where a framework agreement on water policy cooperation was particularly worth to be mentioned. This original framework marked a new phase of better relations between the two neighboring countries after years of strained ties. More recently, in line with the framework, a few days ago, the two countries signed a landmark deal based on the principle of â€œgive and takeâ€, putting oil and water on the transaction table. Â In this perspective, Baghdad and Ankara agreed on the â€œ
oil-for-water
â€ deal, containing several details and specific mechanisms on the
implementation o
f water cooperation framework between the two countries. Among others, these mechanisms include channeling oil-based petro-dollars from Iraq to Turkiye, which in turn, serves as a means to execute water related projects in Iraq. The agreement also gives opportunity for Turkish companies to build Iraqâ€™s water infrastructure.
During the signing ceremony, representing the downstream country, Iraqi Foreign Minister Fuad Hussen
praised the deal
, describing it as the â€œfirst-of-its-kind cooperation on water managementâ€ between neighboring countries. This reflects the potential of the deal to be served as a bench-mark for other countries, seeking the same suit. Similarly, his Turkish counterpart, Hakan Fidan said: â€œAfter long years, Turkiye and Iraq are cooperating on water.â€ Beyond the signatory countries, several countries including the
United States of America
congratulated Baghdad and Ankara on their success â€“ reaching an agreement.
In light of the prevailing context, we firmly believe that no recent agreement has contributed more to effective water management than the cooperation framework introduced by Iraq and TÃ¼rkiye. Undoubtedly, it stands as a timely and pragmatic model of regional water cooperation, allowing the flow of Trans-boundary water resources, Euphrates and Tigris, in a manner that benefits both the upper and downstream countries. In this connection, the Nile River presents no obstacle to the implementation of the same path the Iraqi-TÃ¼rkiye Modelâ€”except for Egyptâ€™s excessive self-interest, which is heavily dependent on outdated colonial agreements. It is, therefore, vitally important for Egypt to draw constructive lessons from the Model, thereby prioritizing cooperative framework to the GERD dispute. As Ethiopia repeatedly reiterated, Egyptâ€™s long-term water security will be best achieved through a win-win approach rooted in genuine water diplomacy, not through conspiracy or meddling in the internal affairs of riparian states, especially Ethiopia. Egyptâ€™s traditional reliance on intimidations and subversive tactics has proved nothing more than the reality that such attempts have no habitat in todayâ€™s geopolitical landscape. Otherwise, Egypt will remain a downstream country forever and cannot have more rights than Ethiopia with respect to the Nile River â€“ strikingly, this is a divine fate, not decided by Ethiopia or other upper riparian countries.
Possible Scenarios for Egypt
Despite the realities outlined above, it remains challenging to predict whether Egypt will take a lesson from the Turkeyâ€“Iraq water cooperation deal. The outcome, however, hinges on whether Egypt de-securitizes the Nile, its long-serving position. The following are probable scenarios that can be discerned from the existing dynamics.
De-securitization of the Nile â€“ the Most Highly-unlikely Scenario
Egypt has long â€œsecuritizedâ€ negotiations regarding the Nile waters, embedding this issue in the
Constitution
of the Arab Republic of Egypt as part of its national security priorities. The preamble, for instance, states,
Egypt is the gift of the Nile and the gift of Egyptians to humanity
.
Article 44
which is devoted entirely to the Nile, guarantees every citizenâ€™s right to
enjoy the River Nile
and prohibits encroachment on the riverbank reserve or harm to the riverine environment, implicitly recognizing the Nile as Egyptâ€™s primary water source
. The
article further
asserts that the Nile is
a historic right of Egypt
. Given these constitutional principles, it is highly unlikely that Egypt would engage in negotiable deals with any of the riparian states, particularly Ethiopia, regarding Nile waters. De-securitizing the Nile would require removing certain principles embedded in the Constitution, a prospect that seems improbable due to Egyptâ€™s recent internal political instability and fears of public backlash. Consequently, it appears impossible for Egypt to pursue negotiable agreements concerning the Nile in the foreseeable future, which explains its frequent withdrawal from successive dialogues and formal discussions centered on the equitable share and reasonable utilization of the Nile waters.
Enhanced Security Cooperation in the Red Sea region â€“ the Best Scenario
If Egypt were to de-securitize the Nile and open negotiations, though this is highly unlikely due to constitutional and legal constraints, it could facilitate security cooperation between Egypt and Ethiopia in the Red Sea region. Such cooperation would serve the interests of both Ethiopia and Egypt in relation to the Nile and the Red Sea. Egypt has repeatedly made unfounded claims that Ethiopia has violated international watercourse regulations and jeopardized Egyptâ€™s historical rights by constructing development projects on the Nile, such as the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD). Meanwhile, Ethiopia has asserted that Egypt incessantly employed diplomatic maneuvers to isolate it from accessing the Red Sea and has excluded it from any Red Sea related security cooperation, notably the â€œRed Sea Council,â€ by skillfully establishing exclusionary criteria. Therefore, Egyptâ€™s de-securitization could have benefited both nations and the entire region offering enhanced security cooperation.
Continue with the Status quo â€“ the Most-likely Scenario
De-securitizing the Nile in Egyptâ€™s national security and foreign policy could increase public pressure against the faltering regime. Therefore, it seems likely that Egypt will maintain the status quo, continuing to frame the Nile as a critical national security priority. In this context, Egypt will portray its traditional diplomatic stance, arguing that any negotiations regarding the Nile waters will benefit neither the staggering regime nor the Egyptian public. This is the most plausible scenario for Egypt, which is unlikely to accept any deal regarding the Nile waters. Securitizing transnational resources, however, lacks international legal grounds and fails to produce constructive outcomes. Consequently, if no agreement is reached, Egypt will remain a downstream country indefinitely, unable to claim more rights than Ethiopia regarding the Nile â€“ an outcome determined not by Ethiopia or other upstream nations, but by an inherent reality.
Concluding Remarks
The bilateral agreement initiated by Turkiye and Iraq based on the principle of â€œ
oil for water
â€ could have served as a pivotal example for managing similar transnational water resources, such as the Nile. This could potentially ease the intransigent position that Egypt has historically maintained regarding Nile waters and foster greater security cooperation in both the Nile and Red Sea regions. However, since issues concerning the Nile waters have long been â€œsecuritizedâ€ by Egypt and backed by national normative grounds, it is highly unlikely that Egypt will adopt a similar approach regarding Nile-related issues in the foreseeable future.
