### 101
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2024/11/19/ethiopias-quest-for-sea-access-balancing-between-escalation-and-d-escalation
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Quest for Sea Access: Balancing Between Escalation and D- Escalation â€“ IFA

By Gizachew Asrat, Ph.D. and Gashaw Ayferam, Ph.D.
Ethiopiaâ€™s quest for sovereign access to the sea is not merely a geographical ambition; it is a profound struggle for identity and belonging in a world that has often relegated it to the margins. As Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed revitalizes this long-held aspiration through the recent Memorandum of Understanding with Somaliland, the stakes rise beyond trade routes and economic growthâ€”this journey symbolizes Ethiopiaâ€™s fight against historical isolation and its desire to reclaim its rightful place within the global community.
Following the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between Ethiopia and Somaliland in January 2024, which will grant Ethiopia access to the sea, the federal government of Somalia responded in a different manner. While Mogadishu has chosen to securitize the MoU, portraying it as a threat to its sovereignty, Ethiopia has long regarded access to a permanent seaport as an existential necessity. As a result of Somaliaâ€™s securitization, the issue has been escalated, with Somalia linking it to other issues such as the Post-ATMIS transition and inviting other actors, including Egypt and Eritrea, who have an adversarial mentality and perception towards Ethiopia. This has led to the entanglement of bilateral issues, including the MoU, Post-ATMIS transition, and the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD), resulting in a sort of trilateral alliance. This piece examines Ethiopiaâ€™s journey towards accessing a permanent sea port, its policy choices, and the responses of Somalia and other regional actors.
For centuries, Ethiopiaâ€™s quest for access to the sea has been a tumultuous journey marked by periods of progress and setbacks, as well as unwavering perseverance and resilience. While the physical geography of the sea and the countryâ€™s physical security are undoubtedly crucial aspects of this journey, the story of Ethiopiaâ€™s pursuit of the sea is ultimately rooted in a deeper need: the need to maintain a sense of biographical continuity that includes the narratives that have shaped the countryâ€™s identity and its relationship with the world.
For Ethiopia, except during the EPRDF era, accessing the sea was considered an existential matter. However, the Red Sea-centered foreign policy orientation was tactically silenced following Eritreaâ€™s independence in 1991, de facto, and in 1993, de jure. This marked a significant departure from the pre-existing narrative, as the government (EPRDF period 1991-2018) voluntarily abandoned Ethiopiaâ€™s claim to the sea and politicized the issue, characterizing those who raised it as expansionists and
war-monger
.
Although Ethiopiaâ€™s loss of sea access was caused by a combination of historical, geopolitical, and international factors including the 16th-century Portugal-Ottoman Empires rivalry and the 19
th
and late 20 century British-Italian-French rivalry it was primarily the policy orientation of the EPRDF that transformed Ethiopia into a landlocked country and
ended the struggle for permanent sea access
. This EPRDFâ€™s siloed worldview curtailed the generations-long quest for a permanent seaport, aligning with the intended policy objectives pursued by Ottoman Empire, European colonial powers, and post-independent Egypt. It was not the aspirations of the people that were realized, but rather those of
Egypt
, a country that supported insurgents and secessionists, including the EPLF and TPLF, from the beginning. Under the EPRDFâ€™s siloed worldview, the narratives that regarded access to the sea as an existential matter were reduced to viewing ports as mere tradable
commodities
.
The regime also delinked access to the sea from its existential necessity for development and national security, believing that it had no strong causal link. This was further legitimized by the double-digit economic growth of the time. As the late PM Meles Zenawi stated: â€œIf we donâ€™t use the two ports [Misewa and Aseba],
we lose nothing
â€¦. Being landlocked does not make us poorâ€¦. We cannot and should not suffer from being a landlocked nationâ€¦In terms of development and growth, Ethiopia experienced its quickest results everâ€. However, this view overlooks the reality that the countryâ€™s economic growth and strategic interests have been constrained by its lack of direct access to the sea, creating a dependency on a single sea outlet.
Ramification of being landlocked
Landlocked developing countries like Ethiopia engage in 30% less trade, on average, compared to their coastal counterparts, leading to slower economic growthâ€”about 1.5%
lower
due to their landlocked status.This situation has resulted in higher import prices and decreased export revenues, with transportation costs being a major challenge. Ethiopia heavily depends on Djibouti for nearly 80-90% of its imports and exports, which has driven up transport expenses. In 2023, the country faces an enormous annual cost of
$1.6 billion
in port fees due to its lack of direct sea access.Additionally, the port of Djibouti struggles to keep up with Ethiopiaâ€™s rising trade demands and its rapidly expanding economy. Issues such as lengthy transit times (averaging around 50 days), high logistics costs for imports, inconsistent customs practices, and delays at the port all contribute to Ethiopiaâ€™s
elevated logistics expenses
for bulk imports.
In addition to the economic ramifications of being landlocked, Ethiopiaâ€™s geographical status positions it as a passive observer in the geopolitical dynamics of the Red Sea Theater, where major and regional powers actively engage. This landlocked condition exacerbates Ethiopiaâ€™s security vulnerabilities, as it becomes increasingly reliant on the maritime strategies and decisions of its neighboring coastal states, thereby diminishing its own strategic autonomy.
Furthermore, the countryâ€™s lack of direct access to the sea significantly constrains its military capabilities, limiting it to land and air power. This geographical limitation hampers its ability to project power and influence maritime security in the region. As a result, Ethiopia is compelled to rely on land and air power, which may not adequately address evolving security challenges from non-state actors like terrorists and pirates.
Hence, Ethiopiaâ€™s quest for sovereign, permanent access to a seaport emerges as a panacea for the strategic and economic challenges that constrain its physical and ontological security. This pursuit is not merely about enhancing trade routes or gaining a physical advantage; it represents a fundamental effort to reclaim a sense of belonging in the global community that has been eroded by geographical isolation. Ethiopiaâ€™s lack of coastline has historically fostered feelings of disconnection from the strategic dynamics of the Red Sea region, intensifying the countryâ€™s sense of vulnerability.
In the wake of the post-2018 reforms, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has rejuvenated these longstanding aspirations, framing access to the sea as not only a national priority but also a
matter of survival
. This strategic rebranding has shifted the discourse from questioning the importance of maritime access for development to a widely accepted understanding that it is an existential imperative for Ethiopia.
This sovereign access to the sea has been driven by a complex interplay of domestic, regional, and international factors, including economic, demographic, and strategic considerations. The country sought a more diversified sea access, taking into account the countryâ€™s rapidly expanding economy, growing population, and desire for regional integration. Regionally, while the physical distance between Ethiopia and the Red Sea coast is relatively short, in reality, Ethiopia has become a distant observer of the Red Sea Theater, as the region has hosted several military bases of major and middle powers from distant regions. Furthermore, neither relying on Djibouti nor port diversification, which comes as a policy choice for Ethiopiaâ€™s dependency on Djibouti, has met Ethiopiaâ€™s import-export demands. Furthermore, the lack of a permanent seaport has impacted the countryâ€™s strategic and political interests.
One outcome of this policy choice is the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed between Ethiopia and Somaliland on January 2024. The MoU follows Prime Minister Abiy Ahmedâ€™s statement on Ethiopiaâ€™s peaceful access to the sea, which marks a significant shift after 27 years of voluntary abandonment of Ethiopiaâ€™s claim to a permanent seaport. The agreement, according to the statement made by the Foreign Minister of Somaliland, grants landlocked Ethiopia
access to the sea
, and in return, Ethiopia reciprocates by recognizing Somaliland as an independent state. Under the terms of the agreement, Ethiopia will secure less expensive and more reliable access to the sea, leasing a 20-kilometer stretch of coastline for 50 years. The agreement also allows Ethiopia to build a naval base and develop a commercial port on the strategic Gulf of Aden.
However, the MoU paradoxically has become entangled with the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD), reconfiguring the interstate relations in the region. Mogadishu has interpreted the MoU as an existential threat to its territorial integrity and sovereignty. In response, it has opted for the securitization of the MoU and alliance formation as deterrence. Egypt and Eritrea have also joined the securitization of the MoU aimed at countering Ethiopiaâ€™s sovereign access to the sea. The Cairo-led alliance escalated its subversive activities in the region following the recent entry into force of the Nile River Cooperative Framework Agreement.
The new geopolitical developments in the region seem to have offered Cairo a new geopolitical opportunity to initiate a tripartite coalition of Cairo, Asmara, and Mogadishu. The formation of a tripartite alliance to counter Ethiopia is a continuation of Cairoâ€™s long-term strategy to undermine the position of Ethiopia in the region. While Cairo-Asmara-Mogadishuâ€™s path has been one of securitization, Addis Ababa has taken a de-escalatory approach, employing tactical de-escalation and strategic de-securitization. Ethiopia has emphasized that its sovereign access to the sea is achieved through peaceful and diplomatic means based on give and take. Ethiopiaâ€™s strategy focuses on regional cooperation and economic integration, aiming to establish stability and mutual benefit in the Horn of Africa. Ethiopiaâ€™s emphasis on peaceful and diplomatic means contrasts with Cairo-Asmara-Mogadishuâ€™s tripartite coalitionâ€™s more aggressive tactics, highlighting a fundamental difference in approach to regional issues. By prioritizing cooperation and integration, Ethiopia seeks to foster long-term stability and prosperity in the Horn of Africa.
In this connection, Ethiopia has offered its sovereign projects, including the GERD, Ethiopian Airlines, and Ethio-telecom as a concessions. Speaking to the parliament on October 31, 2024, PM Abiy Ahmed also outlined Ethiopiaâ€™s strategy, which is a win-win approach with the states of the Horn of Africa.
..Peaceful neighborliness is Ethiopiaâ€™s sole realistic approach to its neighbors, whether they are Somalia, Kenya, Eritrea, or others. Together, we must develop the give-and-take mentality. We are committed to helping any country establish a friendly and cooperative foundation. Peace with Eritrea is necessary. For Somalia to remain a state, thousands of Ethiopians have been sacrificed. Ethiopia will make greater efforts than before to promote peace, development, and the common good in the
Horn of Africaâ€¦â€
Ethiopiaâ€™s de-securitization approach aimed to deescalate tensions, but the government in Mogadishu has linked the MoU to several unrelated issues, including the GERD, the post-ATMIS transition, and broader regional peace and security concerns. This has not only complicated the situation but has also drawn external actors with malign intentions into the region, potentially jeopardizing peace in inter-state relations in the Horn.
The Mogadishu government is facing a constitutional crisis. The Hassen Shieke administration has been leaning towards a more centralizing and unitary approach in relations between the federal government and regional states in Somalia, taking lessons from Eritrea while ignoring the importance of de-centralization and federalism as the best options for stability in Somalia. Itâ€™s unlikely that Egypt will take a leading role in the fight against Al-Shabab; rather, Egypt has an interest in encircling Ethiopia rather than in helping to alleviate the security burden of fighting the Al-Shabab and bringing stability and peace to the Somali people.
Furthermore, the Mogadishu governmentsâ€™ securitization methods failed to achieve their stated purpose of terminating the MOU. Mogadishuâ€™s efforts to tie the MOU and complicate Ethiopiaâ€™s desire for a sea outlet appear to have failed, as it has failed to rally regional governments and significant donors to oppose Ethiopia. Despite Mogadishuâ€™s attempts to garner support against Ethiopia, many regional governments and donors have chosen to remain neutral or support Ethiopiaâ€™s position.
Ethiopiaâ€™s access to the sea has the potential to boost regional connectivity and trade. Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomatic de-escalation andÂ strategy to de-securitize should be analyzed in the context of state behavior and the motivations, strengths, and interests of regional actors.Â It is essential to adapt to shifting dynamics while pursuing diplomatic avenues to realize Ethiopiaâ€™s dream of openÂ access to the sea.
About the Authors
Gizachew Asrat (PhD), African Affairs Research Director General at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA).
Gashaw Ayferam (PhD), Senior Researcher of African Affairs at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA).

Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Positioning Amidst Possible Rise in US-China Rivalry Following Trumpâ€™s Second Term.

### 102
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2024/11/19/walking-the-talk-green-modelling-ethiopia-in-africa-and-beyond
TITLE: Walking the Talk: Green Modelling Ethiopia in Africa and Beyond â€“ IFA

By: Solomon Tekalign(PhD)
Ethiopia accounts for less than 0.1 percent of emissions, yet it is already experiencing the adverse effects of climate change. Particularly, in the last five years, it experienced severe drought as well as flooding together with landslides that resulted in loss and damage to large communities.
Despite this fact, Ethiopia has made landmark climate action from planning through resource mobilization to transformative climate actions in agriculture, Green Legacy, E-mobility, Corridor Development in cities, Eco-tourism, etc. which undoubtedly have great potential to attract partners for support.
Some of the major climate actions include but are not limited to wheat production initiative, climate-smart practices, the Bouncy of the Basket (Yelemat Tirufat), the Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, and a range of projects suitable for Green Bond financing, including Renewable energy generation (solar, wind, and hydropower), sustainable agriculture initiatives, Climate-resilient infrastructure development, etc.
Regarding the GLI, which was initiated by PM Abiy Ahmed in 2019, Ethiopia was able to plant 40 billion tree seedlings that enhance its forest coverage to 23.6 percent with a potential carbon sink of over 10 billion tons. The government earmarked about 1 percent of its annual budget for the GLI and Land Restoration Fund.
Similarly, the heat-resistant wheat production project came up with an output of 107 million quintals of wheat in the last three years. This contributed much towards a sustainable food system by having carbon-negative and climate-resilient crops.
In addition, Ethiopia has now become among the few countries in the world to pass a law banning fuel automobiles as part of reducing the impact of greenhouse gas emissions. Ethiopia, through its corridor development program, prioritizes a people-centered and climate-smart approach to reverse this alarming trend. In this context, Addis Ababa is a testament to this success while the exemplary practices are being replicated in regional and provincial cities to enhance the greening effects. Likewise, there are rural green initiatives and rural electrification effects that is designed not only to enhance carbon-free energy to the largest community but also to secure food security at the household level too via its Yelemat Tirufat (the Bouncy of the Basket) Project.
Moreover, Ethiopia has adopted its subsequent Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), long-term low-emission government, and national adaptation plan that guide the collective commitment to significantly lessen the impacts of climate change.
This can be scaled up further by having global support for such endeavors. So, Ethiopia aspires and hopes to translate its Paris Agreement Commitment into tangible actions. This will contribute to the collective reverse of humanityâ€™s trajectory of destruction and do justice to the victims of climate change impacts, particularly for developing countries like Ethiopia and beyond.
Together with this, the message of PM Abiy Ahmed (PhD) upon COP 29 disclosed that Ethiopia will fulfill the Paris Conference Agreement and COP 28 responsibilities. The main aspects of the agreement include increasingly ambitious climate actions towards zero carbon solutions. While of COP 28 was to speed up theÂ transition away from fossil fuelsÂ to renewables such as wind and solar power in their next round of climate commitments. Similarly, Ethiopia is ambitiously determined to meet the Paris Conference Agreement and of the COP 28 commitments.
Conversely, the debate on climate finance has become overly complex and painstakingly slow-paced. It underscores the imperative to simplify the process and come up with practical and pragmatic solutions. In this regard, Ethiopia hence pragmatically focused and emphasized the need to finalize the new collective quantified goal on climate finance and make it operational. Ethiopia wants to share its experiences with Africa and beyond which can be enhanced through the green finance that is expected to be agreed at COP 29. It is finally calling the global community to come together to create an enabling zero-carbon sustainable environment for the coming future.
About the Author
Solomon Tekalign (PhD), Chief Trainer and Policy Consultant at the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA).

Ethiopiaâ€™s Strategic Positioning Amidst Possible Rise in US-China Rivalry Following Trumpâ€™s Second Term.
ADDIS ABABAâ€™S WORLD WITHOUT HUNGER CONFERENCE: EXPECTATIONS AND OUTCOMES

### 103
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/13/ethiopias-imf-program-the-crucial-insights-from-the-fourth-review
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s IMF Program: The Crucial Insights from the Fourth Review â€“ IFA

Ethiopia has reached a notable milestone in its ongoing economic reform agenda following a staff-level agreement between the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Ethiopian authorities on the fourth review of the countryâ€™s Extended Credit Facility (ECF) arrangement. Subject to approval by IMF management and the Executive Board in the coming weeks, the agreement is expected to unlock approximately USD 261 million in new financing. This would bring total IMF disbursements under the program to about USD 2.13 billion, out of the USD 3.4 billion facility approved in July 2024 to support Ethiopiaâ€™s Homegrown Economic Reform (HGER) agenda. While the immediate financial injection offers short-term relief, the broader significance of the review lies in Ethiopiaâ€™s ability to sustain one of Africaâ€™s most determined economic reform programs amid debt restructuring pressures, post-conflict recovery, and far-reaching monetary and fiscal adjustments.
According to the IMF staff team, led by Alvaro Piris, implementation of the ECF-supported program has delivered favorable macroeconomic outcomes. Economic growth has accelerated, inflation has declined, and the value of goods exports has more than doubled within a year. These outcomes reflect a relatively strong reform momentum, with the programâ€™s disbursement rate now standing at roughly 62.5 percent. A central driver has been the liberalization of the foreign exchange regime in July 2024, which effectively eliminated the parallel market premium and improved price discovery and transparency. This shift, combined with tighter monetary policy, has helped stabilize expectations despite an initial depreciation of the birr.
Export performance has been further strengthened by increased gold production, partly due to the formalization of previously informal supply channels, as well as a rebound in agricultural exports. These gains have improved external balances and enhanced Ethiopiaâ€™s capacity to finance essential imports and meet external obligations. At the same time, the export base remains concentrated in a limited range of commodities, leaving the economy exposed to price volatility and external shocks. Inflation dynamics nonetheless suggest growing policy credibility, as price pressures have moderated in spite of currency adjustment, reflecting improved supply conditions and disciplined macroeconomic management. The IMF has underscored the importance of continuing efforts to deepen foreign exchange market liquidity and develop risk-hedging instruments to support private sector activity and investor confidence.
Debt restructuring remains a pivotal, yet unresolved, component of Ethiopiaâ€™s stabilization strategy. The program is anchored in the G20 Common Framework, under which Ethiopia reached a memorandum of understanding with its Official Creditor Committee in July 2025. This step represents meaningful procedural progress, but the process is incomplete, as bilateral agreementsâ€”particularly with major creditors such as Chinaâ€”have yet to be finalized. Until these negotiations are concluded, a portion of IMF financing will continue to be absorbed by debt servicing rather than redirected toward growth-enhancing public investment. Restoring full debt sustainability is therefore essential, not only to regain fiscal space but also to rebuild market confidence and attract private capital.
Economic growth has gathered pace since mid-2024, driven by sector-specific developments. Gold exports have emerged as a major contributor to foreign exchange earnings, although part of this increase may reflect statistical reclassification rather than purely organic expansion. Energy generation from the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) has strengthened domestic power supply and enhanced Ethiopiaâ€™s potential as a regional electricity exporter, even as the project remains entangled in sensitive geopolitical dynamics with downstream riparian states, notably Egypt. Agriculture has also shown signs of recovery, supported by favorable weather conditions and targeted policy incentives, though productivity gains remain vulnerable to climate variability and logistical constraints.
These positive trends should be interpreted with caution. Much of the observed acceleration reflects recovery from a low base following years of conflict, pandemic disruptions, and macroeconomic imbalances. Sustaining growth at higher levels will require deeper structural transformation, including diversification away from primary commodities, expanded infrastructure investment, and sustained improvements in human capital. Without these shifts, current gains may prove difficult to maintain over the medium term.
The reform agenda also carries significant political and institutional implications. Currency depreciation, subsidy rationalization, and fiscal tightening have imposed tangible costs on urban households and the middle class, raising concerns about social tolerance for continued adjustment. Ethiopiaâ€™s federal structure, combined with regional disparities and post-conflict sensitivities, complicates the consistent implementation of reforms across the country. While the IMF has emphasized inclusive consultations with financial institutions, the private sector, and development partners, maintaining a broad domestic consensus remains a delicate task.
Prime Minister Abiy Ahmedâ€™s administration has thus far managed to balance reform ambition with political realities, but more demanding phases lie ahead. Planned measures such as civil service reform, state-owned enterprise restructuring, and deeper financial sector reforms could test institutional capacity and political cohesion. Experience from other reform episodes suggests that reform fatigue can emerge once distributional effects become more pronounced, making sustained political commitment a critical variable in the programâ€™s success.
Looking ahead, Ethiopia has already implemented several high-impact reforms, including exchange rate liberalization and initial fiscal consolidation. Future reviews will focus on more entrenched and politically sensitive measures, such as subsidy phase-outs and banking sector recapitalization, which may expose underlying vulnerabilities and provoke resistance from vested interests. External risksâ€”including global commodity price swings, regional instability, and tighter international financial conditionsâ€”could further complicate the adjustment path. Domestically, deepening foreign exchange markets and completing debt restructuring will be essential benchmarks for long-term macroeconomic viability.
Beyond its national implications, Ethiopiaâ€™s experience under the ECF carries broader relevance for the African continent. As Africaâ€™s second-most populous country and host of the African Union, Ethiopiaâ€™s reform trajectory serves as a test case for the effectiveness of the G20 Common Framework in delivering timely and meaningful debt relief. Its approach to exchange rate liberalization offers lessons on managing currency transitions without triggering runaway inflation, while its gradual shift from a state-led to a more market-oriented development model may inform similar efforts elsewhere, provided political contexts allow for adaptation.
In conclusion, the fourth review of Ethiopiaâ€™s IMF program affirms tangible progress in stabilizing the economy, with notable gains in exports, inflation control, and growth. Yet the durability of these achievements will depend on resolving outstanding debt negotiations, deepening structural reforms, and cushioning the economy against external shocks. The outcome of this program will not only shape Ethiopiaâ€™s economic destiny but also influence debt-distressed peers across the continent, highlighting the interplay of policy resolve and global cooperation in fostering sustainable development.
By
Zahra Abdulhakim,Â  an independent researcher

Asmaraâ€™s Isolation Doctrine: Why Eritrea Rejects Prosperity in a Changing Horn

### 104
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/10/asmaras-isolation-doctrine-why-eritrea-rejects-prosperity-in-a-changing-horn
TITLE: Asmaraâ€™s Isolation Doctrine: Why Eritrea Rejects Prosperity in a Changing Horn â€“ IFA

The relationship between Ethiopia and Eritrea extends far beyond formal diplomacy. The two nations share intertwined histories, cultures, languages, and social foundations that long predate their modern political separation. Since Eritreaâ€™s 1993 independence, they have remained linked by more than 1,000 kilometers of border and deeply interdependent political and socioeconomic trajectories.
In the decades that followed, relations oscillated between moments of cooperation and phases of tensionâ€”from early optimism to devastating war, proxy hostilities, cold peace, and eventual normalization in 2018 after Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed (PhD) came to power. Yet even after peace resumed, Eritreaâ€™s internal political crisis continued to drive hundreds of thousands of Eritreans into Ethiopia, particularly Addis Abeba, seeking safety and dignity. Their migration reflects both the social closeness of the two peoples and the harsh conditions under Eritreaâ€™s authoritarian rule. Few show any desire to return under current circumstances.
Drawing from years of study and close observation, I argue in this article that the blessings and burdens shared by Ethiopia and Eritrea are rooted in a common past, shaped by the present, and decisive for the regionâ€™s future. This article examines how Eritreaâ€™s one-man dictatorship has undermined its own national prospects and obstructed peace and stability across the Horn of Africa.
Eritrea After Independence: Promises kept or sacrifices let down?
Thirty and a half years after independence, Eritrea should have been one of Africaâ€™s rising statesâ€”blessed with prime geography and a coastline along one of the worldâ€™s most strategic waterways. Instead, it remains among the continentâ€™s most closed, militarized, and impoverished nations.
This stagnation is no historical accident. It is a deliberate political choice. President Isaias Afwerki has engineered a system in which prosperity is treated as a threat, regional cooperation as vulnerability, and isolation as a strategy for regime survival. Eritreaâ€™s tragedy is not simply underdevelopmentâ€”it is the purposeful construction of poverty, weaponized to preserve undeserved political power.
This brings to my mind a point made by Gedion Thimotewos (PhD), Ethiopiaâ€™s Minister of Foreign Affairs, during the Foreign Policy Forum held last month about the Eritrean regimeâ€™s miscalculations. He described what he called â€œIsaiasâ€™ doctrineâ€â€”the idea that President Isaias takes pride in achieving Eritreaâ€™s political independence while simultaneously believing that Eritrea can rely on Ethiopia for everything it needs for its socioeconomic well-being, even after Eritreaâ€™s secession.
Peace without freedom, stability without growth
Most nations seek peace as a platform for institution-building and economic progress. Isaiasâ€™Eritrea seeks peace to immobilize society.
For nearly thirty and a half years, the Eritrean leadership has viewed peace not as a tool for transformation but as a minimal condition: no open conflict and no meaningful socioeconomic change. After three decades, Eritrea still has no implemented constitution, no democratic elections, no independent media, no dynamic private sector capable of innovation, and no open borders that allow the flow of commerce, ideas, or information.
Instead of creating positive peaceâ€”peace that expands opportunity and nurtures social well-beingâ€”the government offers only the absence of open conflict. It uses this absence of war as justification for the absence of progress.
Poverty as policy, conflict as governance
Where most authoritarian states use economic benefits to secure loyalty, Isaiasâ€™Eritrea relies on scarcity to enforce obedience.
The indefinite national service program has immobilized an entire generation, ensuring that poverty remains engineered rather than accidental. Hunger becomes a political tool, and exhaustion becomes a form of control.
The indefinite national service program has immobilized an entire generation, ensuring that poverty remains engineered rather than accidental.â€
Externally, the regime sustains and inflates tensions with neighboring states to legitimize permanent militarization. For Asmara, conflict is not a diplomatic failure; it is a governing strategy.
The ruling elite believes that a society trapped in daily survival is easier to dominate than a society empowered by economic opportunity. In Eritrea, this calculation has allowed one-man rule to endure for decades.
While Isaiasâ€™Eritrea exports instability across the Horn of Africa, it shows little interest in improving the lives of farmers, workers, or urban residents inside the country.
In effect, the regime competes not with neighboring states but with the well-being and future of its own people, using public policy to deepen poverty so that political control remains unchallenged.
The coastline that was never allowed to prosper
Eritrea possesses one of Africaâ€™s most valuable coastlines. The ports of Massawa and Assab could have evolved into thriving logistics hubs along the Red Sea, integrated with booming Gulf economies and positioned along one of the worldâ€™s busiest shipping lanes.
However, the regime views openness as a threat and isolation as a form of security. Prosperity would empower citizens; poverty keeps them dependent and controllable.
While Eritrea closes itself off, landlocked Ethiopiaâ€”ambitious and outward-lookingâ€”is rapidly expanding its maritime partnerships through Djibouti, Somalia, and Kenya. Ethiopiaâ€™s economic growth could have been Eritreaâ€™s greatest opportunity, yet Asmara regards Ethiopiaâ€™s dynamism as a threat to its internal political structure.
Five rationales behind Ethiopiaâ€™s quest for sea access
Ethiopiaâ€™s determination to secure diversified and reliable sea access is often misunderstood. The countryâ€™s approach is shaped by historical realities, geographic necessity, international law, developmental logic, and diplomatic principles.
First, Ethiopiaâ€™s position is supported by historical precedent: from the Aksumite era until the 1990s, the country maintained access to the Red Sea, and its loss was the outcome of decisions made by unelected guerrilla leaders rather than democratic processes.
Second, Ethiopiaâ€™s geographyâ€”as the worldâ€™s most populous landlocked country with more than 120 million peopleâ€”makes permanent reliance on a single port corridor unsustainable.
Third, international law, including the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, affirms the rights of landlocked states to secure access to the sea through negotiated agreements, which aligns with Ethiopiaâ€™s current approach.
Fourth, Ethiopia argues that maritime cooperation benefits the entire region. Countries such as Eritrea, Djibouti, Somalia, Somaliland, and Kenya can all gain from Ethiopiaâ€™s massive market, growing trade volume, and advanced infrastructure. Prime Minister Abiy has repeatedly expressed Ethiopiaâ€™s readiness to share the advantages of its major national institutionsâ€”such as Ethiopian Airlines, the expanding telecom sector, and even the benefits of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD)â€”as part of mutually beneficial agreements.
Fifth, Ethiopiaâ€™s strategy emphasizes peaceful, negotiated solutions. The government insists that any arrangement must be rooted in dialogue, consensus, and broader regional security considerations, recognizing that maritime stability is inseparable from peace in the Horn of Africa.
Together, these five principles form what Ethiopian officials call â€œthe golden pathways to the sea.â€
A future bigger than one manâ€™s fear
Eritrea stands at a historic crossroads. It can continue functioning as a hyper-securitized, inward-looking state whose most tragic export is its youthâ€”or it can unlock the prosperity that its geography and people naturally promise.
The world must acknowledge that Eritreaâ€™s stagnation is not an accident. It is a system of institutionalized poverty designed to preserve authoritarian rule.
But no government can permanently suppress the aspirations of its people. Nor can Eritrea isolate itself from the transformations reshaping the Horn of Africa. Ultimately, the countryâ€™s future will be determined not by the fears of a single ruler but by the resilience of a population that has endured immense hardshipâ€”and still preserved hope.
About the Author
: Miessa Elema Robe, PhD, is a political science and international relations analyst specializing in Ethiopiaâ€“Eritrea relations. He currently serves as Head of Democratic Culture Building at the Addis Ababa City Administration.

Flowing Uphill: How Ethiopia is Reversing the Power Dynamics of the Nile
Ethiopiaâ€™s IMF Program: The Crucial Insights from the Fourth Review

### 105
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/05/flowing-uphill-how-ethiopia-is-reversing-the-power-dynamics-of-the-nile
TITLE: Flowing Uphill: How Ethiopia is Reversing the Power Dynamics of the Nile â€“ IFA

GERD is more than a hydropower project; itâ€™s a geopolitical pivot. This analysis explores how the dam is shattering a century-old status quo and redefining power in Northeast Africa.
In the unforgiving arena of geopolitics, nations are driven by one primal instinct: survival. For too long, the narrative surrounding the Nile has been dictated by downstream powers, framing the river as their historical right and Ethiopiaâ€™s development as a threat. This era is over.
The completion of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) is more than an infrastructure project; it is a profound geopolitical pivot. It is the moment Ethiopia moved from a nation pleading its case to a nation projecting its power, transforming its geography from a constraint into a commanding strategic asset.
As noted in a previous analysis on
Abren
,
â€œFrom the River to the Sea: Ethiopiaâ€™s Geopolitical Destinyâ€
, Ethiopiaâ€™s historical sovereignty over the source of the Blue Nile has rarely translated into leverage. For centuries, the nation was caught between its own needs and the demands of downstream capitals. The GERD has shattered that paradigm.
The dam is not merely a source of electricity; it is a source of national pride and unassailable negotiating strength. It is Ethiopiaâ€™s ultimate bargaining chip in a world governed not by morality, but by the ruthless law of the fittest. To remain relevant and secure, a nation must command respect, and the GERD does exactly that.
The corridors of power in Cairo now echo with alarmist rhetoric, a testament to this shifted balance. They claim simultaneously that the GERD causes both water shortages and floodingâ€”an impossible contradiction that reveals their true anxiety. It is not about the Nileâ€™s flow, which technical assessments consistently confirm remains unaffected for downstream nations. The real contest is for leverage and regional dominance. Egyptâ€™s growing unease stems from Ethiopiaâ€™s undeniable emergence as an economic and geopolitical force in the Horn of Africa.
Egyptâ€™s persistent demand for a â€œbinding agreementâ€ is, in essence, a coded attempt to control GERD from within Ethiopiaâ€™s borders. But let us pose an honest question: if the roles were reversed, would Cairo ever allow Addis Ababa to dictate terms over the Aswan High Dam? The answer is self-evident. In fact, Egypt explicitly excluded Ethiopiaâ€™s involvement in the construction of its own Aswan high dam. Emperor Haile Selassieâ€™s request on information was rebuffed in the 1950s. Ethiopia was systematically excluded from any meaningful dialogue or data-sharing regarding the Nile throughout the 1950s.
This demand for veto power is a historical anomaly. When TÃ¼rkiye built 22 dams on the Euphrates and Tigris, no downstream nation was granted control. When China erected massive dams on the Yarlung Tsangpo (Brahmaputra) or when the U.S. built the Hoover Dam, neither India nor Mexico sought binding oversight. Why, then, should Ethiopia be held to a different standard? The language of â€œhistoric rightsâ€ is a language of the weak; the language of sovereign development is the language of the strong.
This dynamic is not unique to the Nile. Across the globe, the same pattern endures: power respects power, while weakness invites interference. In the Gulf, Saudi Arabia and the UAE cooperate when interests align but compete fiercely for dominance. In Asia, the rivalry between China and India mirrors their relentless pursuit of global stature.
Ethiopia, with the GERD, has entered this arena not as a supplicant, but as a peer. It has demonstrated the strategic wisdom to build a project that commands respect, forcing the world to acknowledge its right to utilize its own resources for the prosperity of its people.
Yet, true survival in geopolitics requires more than raw might. It demands the strategic wisdom to negotiate, to cooperate, and to build partnerships without surrendering sovereignty. The future will not belong merely to the strong, but to the wise.
Ethiopiaâ€™s path is clear. It must continue to champion equitable and reasonable utilization, as enshrined in international water law. It must engage with Sudan and Egypt, not from a position of weakness, but from the solid foundation of its operational dam and its unwavering national resolve. The goal is not to beggar thy neighbor, but to turn a zero-sum rivalry into a collective opportunity for progress, stability, and shared energy security in the region.
The GERD is the embodiment of a new Ethiopian destinyâ€”one where it is no longer defined by the river, but defines the riverâ€™s future. The arena is unforgiving, but for the first time in a long time, Ethiopia is not just a participant; it is a power.
By
Yohannes Temesgen
,

### 107
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/01/23/h-e-jafar-bedru-confers-with-ambassador-hamid-asghar-khan-additional-secretary-of-ministry-of-foreign-affairs-of-pakistan-and-mr-atif-sharif-mian-pakistans-ambassador-to-ethiopia

Both parties explored a range of opportunities for partnership, focusing on joint research initiatives, co-hosting events, and capacity-building programs. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) to formalize their partnership is expected to be signed soon.

IFA, FLJI Hold Workshop on Hague Apostle Convention and Ethiopiaâ€™s Ratification

### 109
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/20/ifa-flji-hold-workshop-on-hague-apostle-convention-and-ethiopias-ratification
TITLE: IFA, FLJI Hold Workshop on Hague Apostle Convention and Ethiopiaâ€™s Ratification â€“ IFA

High-level officials and legal experts gathered at the Pyramid Hotel in Bishoftu today, December 20, 2025, for a national consultative workshop co-organized by the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA) and the Federal Justice and Law Institute (FLJI).
The forum examined the legal framework and strategic implications of Ethiopiaâ€™s potential ratification of the Hague Apostle Convention, signaling a significant move toward modernizing the nationâ€™s document authentication system and streamlining international trade and legal cooperation.
The workshop focused on a comprehensive research report titled
â€œThe Legal Framework and Implementation System of the Hague Apostle Convention: Significance and Implications of its Ratification in Ethiopia.â€
Joining the convention would eliminate the often-cumbersome, multi-layered â€œlegalizationâ€ process for public documents, replacing it with a single â€œApostleâ€ certificate recognized by all member states.
H.E. Jafar Bedru, Executive Director of the IFA, emphasized that the convention is a â€œprimary international legal instrumentâ€ central to Ethiopiaâ€™s diplomatic and economic interests.
â€œIt has become essential to examine its benefits and implications for our country in depth,â€ H.E. Jafar noted. â€œIt is believed that ratifying this Convention will play a significant role in streamlining the document authentication system in a way that supports Ethiopiaâ€™s development and growth.â€
The Director General of the Institute of Law and Justice, Honorable Ambassador Degfe Bula, underscored that the move toward ratification is not merely administrative but a pillar of the nationâ€™s broader economic diplomacy. He highlighted the necessity of ensuring that such transitions are â€œgrounded in knowledge and evidence.â€
â€œThese platforms allow for research-based policy options to be developed,â€ Ambassador Degfe stated. â€œThey provide an opportunity to weigh the pros and cons of complex policy alternatives in a clear, scientific, and evidence-based mannerâ€¦ rather than deciding in isolation.â€
While the opportunities for increased efficiency are clear, the Q&A sessions revealed a cautious approach. Officials acknowledged that while Ethiopiaâ€™s existing digital and physical infrastructure is â€œin good shape,â€ challenges and potential threats to national interests remain.
The consensus among leadership was that the ratification process must be handled with precision. H.E. Mitiku Mada, Deputy Director of the FLJI, emphasized that the current study is still being refined to address identified gaps before a final policy is launched.
â€œThe Apostle Convention is crucial for Ethiopia but should be joined with due caution,â€ H.E. Mitiku remarked during the closing session. â€œWe should focus on the national interest of Ethiopia before we delve into adopting the convention.â€
The findings of this workshop are expected to serve as a â€œvital baseline inputâ€ for Ethiopiaâ€™s high-level leadership. The final policy recommendation will aim to balance the ease of international business with the protection of national legal standards.
The event saw attendance from senior leadership, including Honorable Ambassador Fitsum Arega, Director General of the Ethiopian Diaspora Service, alongside a wide array of diplomats, legal researchers, and stakeholders from across the justice and foreign relations sectors.

ğğ¯ğğ« ğŸ•ğŸğŸ ğ†ğ¥ğ¨ğ›ğšğ¥ ğˆğ§ğ¯ğğ¬ğ­ğ¨ğ«ğ¬ ğ„ğ±ğ©ğğœğ­ğğ ğšğ­ ğ…ğ¨ğ®ğ«ğ­ğ¡ â€œğˆğ§ğ¯ğğ¬ğ­ ğ¢ğ§ ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğšâ€ ğ…ğ¨ğ«ğ®ğ¦ ğ¢ğ§ ğ€ğğğ¢ğ¬ ğ€ğ›ğšğ›ğš

### 110
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/11/addis-ababa-launches-landmark-space-diplomacy-forum-positioning-africa-for-a-unified-future-in-space
TITLE: Addis Ababa Launches Landmark Space Diplomacy Forum, Positioning Africa for a Unified Future in Space â€“ IFA

The Addis Space Diplomacy Forum Inauguration 2025 took place today, 11 December 2025, at the Elilly Hotel in Addis Ababa under the theme
â€œStrengthening Continental Partnership for Space, Development and Shared Prosperity.â€
Organized by the Space Science and Geospatial Institute (SSGI) in collaboration with the Institute of Foreign Affairs (IFA) and the Africa Space Leadership Institute (ASLI), the forum marks a major milestone in Africaâ€™s pursuit of a coordinated and forward-looking space agenda.
The event convened African space experts, policymakers, and international partners to craft a shared vision for the continentâ€™s future in space.
Opening the forum, ASLI Co-founder Etim Offiong called for a single African passport and visa-free mobility to accelerate integration, noting ASLIâ€™s work to align future strategies with Agenda 2063 and position Addis Ababa as Africaâ€™s emerging space diplomacy hub.
Dr. Gizachew Asrat, Chief of Staff and Senior Researcher at IFA, highlighted Africaâ€™s growing space ambitions and the need for stronger continental cooperation to leverage space science for peace, development, and shared prosperity. â€œAddis Ababa is poised to become Africaâ€™s hub for space diplomacy,â€ he said, aligning national and continental agendas with IFAâ€™s mission to elevate African agency in global governance.
Dr. Abdi Zenebe, Deputy Executive Director of IFA, emphasized Ethiopiaâ€™s recent milestonesâ€”including the PTRS-1 satellite launch and the establishment of SSGIâ€”describing partnerships as vital pathways for development, peace, and collaboration.
UNECAâ€™s H.E. AndrÃ© Nonguierma praised Ethiopiaâ€™s advancements and stressed the urgency of forging a unified African voice in global space governance.
SSGI Deputy Director-General Dr. Yeshurun Alemayehu called the forum a historic step toward Africaâ€™s strategic autonomy in space, underscoring the need to strengthen the continentâ€™s data and space infrastructure.
Melaku Mulualem, IFAâ€™s Director General for Training, outlined Africaâ€™s three strategic prioritiesâ€”Human Capital, Institutional Frameworks, and Infrastructureâ€”reminding participants that â€œspace is not merely technology; it is diplomacy.â€
Speakers urged unified policies, greater investment, and sustained capacity-building to accelerate Africaâ€™s global role in space diplomacy.
Participants concluded with a shared commitment to deepen collaboration among governments, institutions, and development partners to advance space diplomacy, unlock socio-economic gains, and secure a permanent and influential African presence in the global space arena.

ğ…ğ¨ğœğ®ğ¬ ğ¨ğ§ ğ‹ğ¨ğœğšğ¥ ğğ°ğ§ğğ«ğ¬ğ¡ğ¢ğ© ğŠğğ² ğ­ğ¨ ğğğšğœğğ¤ğğğ©ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ’ğ®ğœğœğğ¬ğ¬, ğğšğ¤ğ°ğğ¬ğğ ğ¡ğš ğ“ğğ¥ğ¥ğ¬ ğ‡ğ¨ğ«ğ§ ğƒğ¢ğšğ¥ğ¨ğ ğ®ğ
IFA, FLJI Hold Workshop on Hague Apostle Convention and Ethiopiaâ€™s Ratification

### 111
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/09/11/%F0%9D%90%87%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A7-%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%9F-%F0%9D%90%80%F0%9D%90%9F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%8B%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9D
TITLE: ğ‡ğ¨ğ«ğ§ ğ¨ğŸ ğ€ğŸğ«ğ¢ğœğš ğ‹ğğšğğğ«ğ¬ ğ”ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ ğšğ­ ğ†ğ„ğ‘ğƒ ğˆğ§ğšğ®ğ ğ®ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§, ğ’ğ¢ğ ğ§ğšğ¥ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ‘ğğ ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ ğ’ğ¨ğ¥ğ¢ğğšğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ² ğšğ§ğ ğ‚ğ¨ğ®ğ§ğ­ğğ«ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ„ğ ğ²ğ©ğ­â€™ğ¬ ğğ¢ğ¥ğ ğğšğ«ğ«ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¯ğ â€“ IFA

The attendance of neighboring heads of state during the inauguration of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) demonstrates a moment of Horn of Africa solidarity, countering narratives that GERD is solely Ethiopiaâ€™s concern.
Since its inception in 2011, Ethiopia has consistently called on the lower riparian countries, Sudan and Egypt, for fair and equitable utilization of the Abbay River [Nile]. However, Egypt has persistently cast doubt on Ethiopiaâ€™s legitimate call, clinging to colonial-era treaties that completely excluded Ethiopia, the source of more than 85% of the Nileâ€™s waters.
Egypt has attempted to frame the GERD as a source of tension, instigating Sudan and using proxy measures against Ethiopia through neighboring countries. The presence of the heads of state of Somalia, Djibouti, and Kenyaâ€”all from the Horn of Africaâ€”during the GERD inauguration marks a landmark diplomatic shift in favor of Ethiopia and the wider Horn, projecting GERD not only as a national project but also as a regional one benefiting the entire region.
Despite Somaliaâ€™s growing alignment with Egypt (particularly regarding Red Sea and Nile politics), President Hassan Sheikh Mohamudâ€™s presence at the inauguration is significant. During his remarks, he acknowledged the GERDâ€™s importance as an anchor symbolizing the common wealth of the Horn of Africa. He emphasized Somaliaâ€™s commitment to unwavering regional peace and integration, recognizing that GERD benefits not only Ethiopia but also Somalia and the region at large. His presence signals a diplomatic gesture that could bolster the Ankara Declaration with Ethiopiaâ€”an agreement granting Ethiopia sea access via Somalia. It may also represent a balancing act: supporting Somaliaâ€™s historically, socially, and economically tied neighbor Ethiopia, while maintaining strategic ties with Egypt.
Djibouti, another strategic Horn of Africa state, also endorsed the GERD through its president, IsmaÃ¯l Omar Guelleh, who called the inauguration a historic day and described the GERD as an African project. Djibouti, host to multiple foreign military basesâ€”including those of the U.S., China, France, and Gulf Statesâ€”sent a message of neutrality and interest in regional stability by attending the event. President Guellehâ€™s framing of the GERD as an African project, rather than merely an Ethiopian one, reinforces this stance. Ethiopia has already begun exporting electricity to Djibouti, and President Guellehâ€™s speech suggests Djiboutiâ€™s interest in strengthening electricity interconnections and economic cooperation.
President William Rutoâ€™s presence further reflects Kenyaâ€™s support for Ethiopiaâ€™s development sovereignty and its role in promoting cooperative regional infrastructure. In his keynote speech, he described the day as a moment of monumental historical significanceâ€”both a feat of engineering and a bold affirmation of Africaâ€™s capacity to shape its own destiny. Kenya, which has positioned itself as a diplomatic hub in the Horn through efforts such as the Nairobi Process, Somalia peace talks, and regional mediation, views the GERD as a building block of trust and regional integration. Since Kenya has already begun accessing GERD electricity, the dam serves as a foundation for cooperation and shared destiny in the Horn.
The GERDâ€™s inauguration is also a diplomatic asset showcasing African leadership. The attendance of regional leaders strengthens Ethiopiaâ€™s stance against Egyptâ€™s claims of â€œhistorical rightsâ€ based on colonial-era treaties that excluded Ethiopia. While Egypt has consistently countered Ethiopiaâ€™s position by aligning with Sudan, Gulf States, and occasionally Horn states, Ethiopia has stood firm, asserting its legitimate right to use the Nile while calling for cooperation guided by the principle of Limited Territorial Sovereigntyâ€”ensuring equitable utilization of trans-boundary rivers. The GERD inauguration can be read as Ethiopia consolidating neighborly support to counter Egyptian influence.
Moreover, the GERD inauguration marks a cornerstone in energy diplomacy and regional integration. The presence of Horn leaders reflects the projectâ€™s practical benefits. Kenya, Djibouti, and Somalia all face energy shortagesâ€”Ethiopia already exports electricity to Djibouti and Kenya, and Somalia could also benefit. This positions the GERD as an economic driver of regional integration, reducing dependence on external powers.
Ultimately, the attendance of Horn leaders underscores that the GERD is an African matter. Ethiopia has consistently adhered to the principle of â€œAfrican solutions to African problems,â€ framing the dam as a matter of African cooperation rather than external intervention. The event highlights Ethiopiaâ€™s unwavering commitment to regional integration and demonstrates that Egypt must reconsider its refusal to embrace Ethiopiaâ€™s call for shared development.

One Voice Against Climate Change: Embracing Africaâ€™s Homegrown Solutions
ğˆğ¬ğ§â€™ğ­ ğˆğ­ ğ“ğ¢ğ¦ğ ğŸğ¨ğ« ğ€ğŸğ«ğ¢ğœğš ğ­ğ¨ ğ’ğ©ğğšğ¤ ğ–ğ¢ğ­ğ¡ ğğ§ğ ğ•ğ¨ğ¢ğœğ ğ¨ğ§ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ–ğ¨ğ«ğ¥ğ ğ’ğ­ğšğ ğ?

### 112
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/09/the-golden-jubilee-of-diplomatic-relationships-50-years-of-ethio-cuba-friendship
TITLE: The Golden Jubilee of Diplomatic Relationships: 50 Years of Ethio-Cuba Friendship â€“ IFA

This year marks the Golden Jubilee of the formal diplomatic relationship between Ethiopia and Cuba, a bond established in 1975. This half-century milestone is not merely a diplomatic anniversary; it is a commemoration of a profound, blood-sealed solidarity that helped preserve a nationâ€™s sovereignty.
The foundation of this unique relationship was laid during the brutal Ogaden War. On 13 July 1977, Somalia, under President Ziad Barre, invaded eastern Ethiopia to fulfill its irredentist ambition of creating a â€œGreater Somalia.â€ The Somali soldiers advanced rapidly, seizing control of significant territory in the Ogaden region. Ethiopia, simultaneously grappling with internal conflicts against groups like the EPLF (Shabia) the TPLF and EPRP, that led to an existential threat to its territorial integrity.
It was at this critical juncture that Cuba, under the steadfast leadership of President Fidel Castro, answered the call. In a stunning act of international solidarity, Cuba dispatched 15,000 soldiers to fight alongside the Ethiopian forces. At one time Fiedel Castro was asked by a Western journalists how many military advisors and soldiers of Cuba are working in Ethiopia. He responded saying â€œWhy you ask details, I cannot work for CIAâ€.
The support of Ethiopia was not an isolated act but part of Cubaâ€™s broader commitment to African liberation, having supported freedom fighters in Algeria, Angola, Mozambique, against apartheid in South Africa and the like. As the late President Nelson Mandela once stated, â€œCubans are in the hearts of Africa.â€
The war was bloody, resulting in massive casualties and displacement. About 163 Cuban soldiers made the ultimate sacrifice, with others taken as prisoners of war in Somalia. Their contribution was decisive. The turning point came at the Battle of Karamara, where the joint Ethio-Cuban forces secured a victory that ultimately chased out the invaders and guaranteed Ethiopiaâ€™s sovereignty. By the support of Cuba and other allies, Ethiopia won the war, while Somaliaâ€™s ambition lay in ruins. After the death of Ziad Bare Somalia faced state collapse and remained so for decades.
This shared history of struggle created an unbreakable bond. As the saying goes, â€œA friend in need is a friend indeed.â€ For Ethiopia and Africa at large, Cuba paid a selfless sacrificeâ€”a policy of â€œgiveâ€ rather than â€œgive and take.â€ The relationship was, as many veterans from both nations who still remember each otherâ€™s friendship would attest, cemented by blood.
The diplomatic and personal exchanges further solidified ties. Fidel Castro visited Ethiopia in 1978, attending a military parade in Meskel Square sitting on the Tribune where the former office of the Institute of Foreign Affairs located. President Castro had also travelled to Jigjiga to celebrate the victory. Similarly, President Mengistu Hailemariam visited Cuba in March 1978. During this time it was Castro himself who was driving the car to show his solidarity. These gestures underscored a partnership based on shared values and mutual respect.
In the heart of Addis Ababa stands the Ethiopia-Cuba Friendship Memorial Park. The Park was inaugurated in 1984 during the Mengistu regimeâ€™s ten years national celebration. Its 50-meter-high monument, decorated with sculptures of intertwined Ethiopian-Cuban soldiers, is a solemn tribute to the Cuban soldiers and military advisors who fell on Ethiopian soil. In this Park, there are photos of Cubans who lost their life in the Ogaden War. This park has become a living symbol of gratitude, where Ethiopians gathered in 2016 to mourn the passing of Fidel Castro, a man the African Union praised as â€œa freedom fighter who supported Africaâ€™s struggles.â€ The then President Mulatu Teshome of Ethiopia attended the funeral service on December 3, 2016 in Santiago de Cuba.
Beyond the battlefield, Cubaâ€™s support extended to nurturing Ethiopiaâ€™s future. In a compassionate post-war gesture, about 5,000 Ethiopian children who had lost parents in the conflict received scholarships to study in Cuba. This generation returned as doctors, engineers, and professionals. Today, many Ethiopian graduates from Cuban universities work in vital sectors, while cultural intermingling continues. These opportunities created continuing people-to-people links, including intermarriages and Cuban expatriate communities in Ethiopia. The cooperation also touched on social campaigns. Cuba supported Ethiopiaâ€™s national literacy drive, helping adults learn to read and write. And in a lighter, yet enduring cultural exchange, the Cuban love song â€œGuantanameraâ€ became, and remains, a popular melody in Ethiopiaâ€”a tune that symbolizes the warm, people-centered nature of the bond.
As Ethiopia and Cuba celebrate this Golden Jubilee, the relationship rests on a solid historical foundation but is dynamically oriented toward the future. Both nations maintain embassies in each otherâ€™s capitals and are actively working to mark a new chapter within the framework of South-South Cooperation.
The current partnership is being expanded through various Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs), exploring renewed collaboration in economics, health, education, and technology. The need to explore more areas of cooperation is clear, building on the unparalleled political goodwill that exists.
This relationship is historically unique, rooted in a shared struggle for sovereignty and justice. It is deepened by the African ancestry of many Cubansâ€”a connection forged through the tragic history of the Atlantic Slave Trade and the role of Afro-descendants in Cubaâ€™s own liberation from Spanish colonialism. This creates a historical and blood relationship between Africa and Cuba that transcends diplomacy.
The durable lesson of the past fifty years is that true partnership is built on principles, not just interests. Cubaâ€™s decisive intervention was a testament to its commitment to African independence and justice. Ethiopiaâ€™s enduring gratitude is evident in its remembrance and continued friendship.
As both nations look ahead, the deep-rooted tiesâ€”nurtured by veterans, alumni, artists, and diplomatsâ€”provide a resilient framework. The Golden Jubilee is not just a milestone to reflect on a heroic past, but a launching pad for a future where the spirit of Karamara evolves into shared victories in development, innovation, and mutual prosperity. The friend in need has proven to be a friend indeed.
About the author
Melaku Mulualem K.,
Director General for Training
Institute of Foreign Affairs

Ethiopia and BRICS: from membership to strategic economic partnership

### 113
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/23/partnership-or-patronage-the-fine-line-in-the-new-u-s-ethiopia-alliance
TITLE: The 2025 U.S. National Security Strategy: Implications for U.S.-Ethiopia Strategic Cooperation â€“ IFA

The newly released National Security Strategy signals a
marked reorientation
in U.S. engagement in Africa â€” moving away from an â€œaid-first, liberal-democracy promotionâ€ model toward a more selective, partnership-based approach built around trade, investment, and conflict prevention.
Under this framework, Ethiopia â€” with its strategic location in the Horn of Africa, its history as a U.S. partner in counterterrorism, and its current legitimate calls for sea-accessâ€” emerges as a natural candidate for deeper U.S. cooperation. Several key factors explain why.
Firstly, Ethiopia has long contributed to regional efforts to counter militant Islamist movements such as Al-Shabaab. In the most recent
high-level visit
by the U.S., U.S. Africa Command (AFRICOM) Commander Dagvin R. M. Anderson met with Ethiopiaâ€™s leadership to emphasize shared threats from Islamic extremist groups. During the discussion, where Field Marshal Berhanu Jula was the top representative of Ethiopia, it was disclosed that General Anderson
praised
Ethiopiaâ€™s ongoing contribution to regional peace and security and confirmed U.S. support for Ethiopiaâ€™s efforts to counter terrorism.
The Generalâ€™s visit to Ethiopia and the subsequent high-level discussion could be a primitive that Washington had taken the importance of strengthen counter-terrorism in the horn of Africa where Ethiopia is a potential long-standing partner. The new Strategy explicitly highlights the resurgence of Islamist terrorism in parts of Africa as a core concern â€” and underscores the need to cooperate with â€œcapable, reliable statesâ€ rather than rely on prolonged large-scale deployments.
Secondly, Ethiopia sits at the crossroads of the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea / Bab el-Mandeb corridor, and the complex web of states and conflicts that stretch from the Horn to the Sahel and central Africa. The November 2025 Strategy names the Horn as a priority region for preventive diplomacy, given persistent tensions involving Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Somalia.
Importantly, Ethiopiaâ€™s legitimate trajectory to regain access to the sea â€” either through Djibouti, a leased port, or maritime access via neighboring coastal zones â€” now resonates more directly with U.S. strategic goals.
Recent reporting
notes that U.S. backing could lend diplomatic legitimacy to Addis Ababaâ€™s maritime ambitions, as maritime access for Ethiopia â€œis inseparable from national growth and sovereignty.â€
Moreover, U.S. support for Ethiopiaâ€™s peaceful pursuit of sea access
was explicitly affirmed
by General Anderson during his 2025 visit. During this visit, he publicly expressed U.S. support for Ethiopiaâ€™s peaceful maritime ambitions and indicated he would brief Washington on Ethiopiaâ€™s priorities. While holding discussions with H.E. Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, he said the U.S. would work with Ethiopia to explore cooperation that helps stabilize the Horn and open new economic and security opportunities.
The new U.S. strategy of shifting from an aid-centric relationship with African states to one oriented toward trade, investment, and mutual economic benefit is the third pillar where Ethiopia could position itself to benefit from it.
For Ethiopia, this could reopen a window of opportunity. The new strategy could potentially reform frameworks like the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA).
Ethiopia, with its large population, youthful workforce and promising industrialization efforts, could become a key beneficiary of renewed U.S. trade and investment flows â€” especially in sectors such as energy, critical minerals, infrastructure, and manufacturing. This dovetails with long-standing Ethiopian ambitions to industrialize, expand export capacity, and reduce reliance on aid by diversifying its economy.
By combining its internal reforms and economic ambitions with U.S. investment, Ethiopia could anchor a new â€œinvestment and growth paradigmâ€ â€” one that aligns with both American strategic objectives and Ethiopiaâ€™s development goals.
Moreover, the new Strategy foregrounds preventive diplomacy: the U.S. signals readiness to support negotiated settlements in existing conflicts (e.g., DRCâ€“Rwanda, Sudan) and to prevent emergent ones â€” including potential flashpoints in the Horn (Ethiopiaâ€“Eritrea, Ethiopiaâ€“Somalia).
In this context, Ethiopia could play a pivotal role. As a relatively large, regionally influential state in the Horn, Addis Ababa could help broker or lend legitimacy to peace processes, especially if paired with U.S. diplomatic backing. Its renewed outreach to Eritrea over sea-access negotiations as Ethiopian high-level leaders including H.E. PM Abiy Ahmed have indicated, could be a test case â€” and an opportunity for Washington to deploy preventive diplomacy rather than reactive conflict management. During his November 2025 visit, General Anderson was
briefed
on a constructive exchange on regional security and opportunities for enhanced cooperation
That said, the alignment between U.S. strategic interests and Ethiopiaâ€™s ambitions is not without tension or risk. The main challenges involve resolving internal instability, which the government is working on; addressing neighboring statesâ€™ misconceptions (particularly Eritreaâ€™s) regarding Ethiopiaâ€™s sea access move, which requires careful navigation; and, following its success with the Food Independency Initiative, ensuring the government sticks to the new investment and growth paradigm by avoiding reversion to an aid-dependent mindset.
Overall, the November 2025 U.S. National Security Strategy for Africa marks a turning point. By prioritizing conflict prevention, counterterrorism, investment, and trade â€” and by signaling selectivity rather than blanket engagement â€” Washington is opening a window for deeper, more strategic cooperation with states that can deliver. Ethiopia, because of its history, geography, ambitions, and potential, is among the strongest candidates to be such a partner.
The recent visit of General Dagvin Anderson underscores Washingtonâ€™s serious intent: Ethiopia is no longer just part of a regional portfolio, but a focal point. By coupling diplomatic initiatives (such as sea access), internal stabilization, and economic reforms with its long-standing historical engagement, Addis Ababa could anchor a new modelâ€”one where the U.S.-Ethiopia relationship shifts from aid dependency toward shared security, mutual economic growth, and strategic cooperation.
Despite its rhetorical shift from aid to investment, the 2025 U.S. National Security Strategy reveals a narrow and instrumental reading of Africaâ€™s strategic importanceâ€”one that risks reproducing extractive and quasi-colonial patterns of engagement. The Strategy explicitly prioritizes Africaâ€™s â€œabundant natural resources and latent economic potentialâ€ and identifies â€œthe energy sector and critical mineral developmentâ€ as areas offering â€œa good return on investmentâ€ for the United States, including nuclear energy, liquefied natural gas, and mineral extraction (U.S. National Security Strategy, 2025). While framed as mutually beneficial, this emphasis sidelines Africaâ€™s structural governance, industrial, and institutional needs in favor of resource access and market opening for U.S. goods and services. By favoring â€œcapable, reliable states committed to opening their markets,â€ the Strategy risks reducing African partnerships to transactional arrangements that privilege external demand over endogenous development priorities, thereby reinforcing asymmetries long associated with colonial and post-colonial economic relations (U.S. National Security Strategy, 2025).
Moreover, although Washington has demonstrated constructive diplomatic engagementâ€”most notably by supporting negotiated de-escalation efforts between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congoâ€”the Strategy treats peace building largely as a means of stabilizing environments for investment rather than as an end rooted in African political agency. Conflict mediation is framed alongside preventing threats to U.S. interests and avoiding â€œany long-term American presence or commitments,â€ signaling a preference for low-cost stabilization over sustained institution-building (U.S. National Security Strategy, 2025). This selective engagement risks leaving the underlying drivers of conflictâ€”competition over resources, weak regional integration, and uneven developmentâ€”unaddressed. By foregrounding counterterrorism, conflict containment, and mineral security while downplaying Africaâ€™s role as a geopolitical, demographic, and normative actor in its own right, the Strategy may inadvertently perpetuate cycles of exploitation, instability, and external dependency, even as it claims to move beyond the aid paradigm (U.S. National Security Strategy, 2025).
By
Getahun Tsegaye
, IFA-associated researcher
