Regime Survival over Regional Cooperation: Eritreaâ€™s Disengagement from Multilateralism

### 114
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/17/regime-survival-over-regional-cooperation-eritreas-disengagement-from-multilateralism
TITLE: Regime Survival over Regional Cooperation: Eritreaâ€™s Disengagement from Multilateralism â€“ IFA

Since achieving de facto independence in 1991, Eritrea has maintained a highly centralised, oneâ€‘party political system dominated by President Isaias Afwerki and the Peopleâ€™s Front for Democracy and Justice (PFDJ). The regime operates without meaningful elections, a functioning legislature, or independent civil society oversight, and continues policies of indefinite national service and internal repression documented by the United Nations and human rights organisations. A UN Special Rapporteur has repeatedly reported grave human rights abuses, including arbitrary detention, enforced disappearances, and forced conscription, with no sign of democratic reform over decades of internal and external reporting. As of 2024 an estimated 17â€¯percent of Eritreaâ€™s population had sought asylum abroad, a reflection of persistent repression and limited political freedoms at home that also undermine the countryâ€™s standing in international forums. Most of them lived in East Africa. In 2023 2 percent of the country population flees the state.
The Map adopted from UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) 2024, cited in Migration Policy Institute, 2025.
Economically, Eritrea remains one of Africaâ€™s most fragile states. Less than six percent of Eritrean land is arable, recurrent droughts and militarised labour policies suppress productivity, and remittances from the diaspora constitute a significant share of GDP amid limited domestic economic diversification. State control extends over roughly 80â€¯percent of GDP, and most Eritreans live in poverty on less than USDâ€¯2â€¯per day, with remittances and resource extraction (e.g., the Bisha gold mine) chiefly sustaining the regime and its security apparatus rather than public welfare. These structural economic constraints leave Eritrea with limited financial and administrative capacity for sustained multilateral engagement, encouraging reliance on selective bilateral arrangements that demand less accountability and public transparency.
Eritreaâ€™s pattern of disengagement with multilateral organisations spans decades. After playing a role in early efforts to revitalise the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) in the early 1990s, Eritrea abruptly withdrew from IGAD in 2003, citing dissatisfaction with the organisationâ€™s processes and perceived bias, and remained outside the bloc for nearly two decades. Although Asmara rejoined IGAD in June 2023, it never participated meaningfully in its activities and formally withdrew again in December 2025, asserting that membership offered â€œno discernible strategic benefitâ€ and reflecting deep skepticism toward regional institutional frameworks. In response, IGAD expressed regret and noted Eritreaâ€™s nonâ€‘participation even while it attempted conflict mediation and regional cooperation initiatives. This cyclical engagement illustrates that Eritreaâ€™s relationship with regional multilateralism is characterised by absence and withdrawal rather than sustained cooperation.
Eritreaâ€™s interaction with continental and global institutions has been similarly constrained. In 2025, Eritrea sought to end the mandate of the UN Special Rapporteur on its internal human rights situation, submitting a proposal to the UN Human Rights Council to terminate the independent monitoring mechanism. This move marked an unprecedented attempt to weaken accountability mechanisms at the UN level and defensive resistance to scrutiny of its human rights record. Such behaviour underscores Eritreaâ€™s broader reticence to engage in multilateral processes that could expose internal policies to critique or demand compliance with international norms.
Eritrea as a Spoiler in Regional Conflicts: Sudan and Ethiopia
Despite its withdrawal from multilateral frameworks, Eritrea has pursued bilateral and proxy strategies in regional conflicts, notably in Sudan and Ethiopia, where it wields influence through military support and militia engagements rather than institutional cooperation.
In the Sudan conflict, Eritrea has politically and militarily aligned with the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), providing training, logistical support, and, according to various reports, even covert deployment of troops to strengthen SAF positions. Eritrean authorities have reportedly facilitated the creation and training of local militias from eastern Sudan including those drawing on eastern tribal networks using camps on Eritrean territory to shape local dynamics in ways favourable to SAF and Eritrean security interests. Observers also point to Eritreaâ€™s role in arms trafï¬cking networks that undermine arms embargoes, and to its strategic diplomacy focused on bilateral ties with Khartoum rather than inclusive, multilateral political solutions. This approach emphasises Asmaraâ€™s comfort with bilateral security cooperation over multilateral peace processes in Sudan, as it seeks to manage crossâ€‘border risks and extract strategic advantage in a fragmented regional environment.
Eritreaâ€™s role in the Ethiopian conflict further illustrates its preference for direct military involvement over institutional engagement. Eritrean Defence Forces (EDF) participated alongside Ethiopian federal forces during the law enforcement operation (2020â€“2022), providing essential manpower that allowed the Ethiopian army to sustain operations and exert control in contested areas. Eritrean troops committed systematic human rights violations, including documented incidences of sexual violence and war crimes actions that continued beyond formal hostilities and contributed to ongoing humanitarian crises in northern Ethiopia. Eritrean forces also reportedly exploited natural and cultural resources in Tigray region, extracting substantial commodities into unregulated markets, in a pattern interpreted as part of a strategic effort to degrade local economic and administrative capacity. These actions reflect Eritreaâ€™s utilitarian engagement in conflict zones, prioritising regime interests and security calculations without accountability to multilateral standards or human rights norms.
Eritreaâ€™s bilateral approach has had enduring consequences for regional stability. In both Sudan and Ethiopia, Eritreaâ€™s military and diplomatic conduct has deepened fragmentation and complicated international efforts aimed at conflict resolution. Its bilateral agreements with Sudanese leadership in 2025, which include security and economic cooperation on projects such as fisheries, mineral refineries, and infrastructure, further solidify ties with SAF while eschewing broader multilateral engagement that could integrate Sudan into regional frameworks. These agreements are pursued outside institutional platforms such as IGAD or African Union (AU) initiatives and signal Eritreaâ€™s strategy of leveraging direct stateâ€‘toâ€‘state cooperation to advance its interests.
Economic and Institutional Constraints on Effective Cooperation
Eritreaâ€™s disengagement from multilateralism is reinforced by profound economic and institutional limitations that curtail its capacity to participate effectively in shared governance or collective peacebuilding. The Eritrean economy, constrained by a command structure dominated by state and military interests, struggles with low productivity and widespread poverty; most citizens subsist on limited incomes with minimal social services or economic opportunity. The IMF and other assessments identify remittances as a critical component of the economy, and reports suggest that natural resource ventures such as gold mining are directed more toward regime preservation than public welfare. These economic fragilities reduce the stateâ€™s ability to contribute financially or administratively to regional organisations like IGAD or AU programs that require sustained investment and policy alignment.
Such economic constraints intersect with Eritreaâ€™s political culture: an absence of domestic accountability mechanisms, lack of democratic elections, and entrenched authoritarian governance discourage transparency and impede policy reform necessary for constructive participation in multilateral institutions. Without domestic pressure for reform or accountability, the regime has little incentive to align with international norms, instead doubling down on policies that emphasise internal control and bilateral manoeuvring in regional conflicts. This dynamic has contributed to the perception documented by external analysts that Eritrea is an outlier in regional cooperation forums, often acting defensively or disengagedly in contexts where neighbouring states seek collective action on security, economic integration, and political stability.
Eritreaâ€™s disengagement from multilateralism is rooted in a confluence of authoritarian governance, economic fragility, and strategic prioritisation of regime survival through bilateral security and conflict involvement. Its withdrawal from IGAD, resistance to UN human rights mechanisms, and preference for direct engagements in conflicts such as those in Sudan and Ethiopia all exemplify a foreign policy that eschews sustained institutional cooperation in favour of contingent, regimeâ€‘centred tactics. This pattern has weakened regional collective responses to shared crises, reduced the efficacy of continental frameworks like the African Union, and complicated international efforts to mitigate human suffering and foster peace. Meaningful change both to Eritreaâ€™s domestic governance and its international engagement would require fundamental reforms that increase transparency, accountability, and integration into cooperative regional mechanisms.
IGADâ€™s Role Beyond the Criticism
The Horn of Africa states, through the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), wielded significant influence over regional affairs. As a key regional organization, IGAD consistently shaped the policy positions of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) and later the African Union (AU) on Somalia, with its frameworks frequently informing United Nations approaches and strategies in the country. In practice, few stakeholders engaged on political or security matters in the Horn without consulting IGAD and the AU, reflecting IGADâ€™s status as a central voice in regional diplomacy and conflict management.
IGADâ€™s leadership extended beyond Somalia to encompass broader peace and security concerns in the region. Notably, the peaceful attainment of South Sudanese independence was largely underpinned by IGAD-led mediation efforts, supported by key member states such as Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, and Djibouti. These efforts ultimately contributed to the negotiation and implementation of the 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement, which laid the groundwork for South Sudanâ€™s secession. Following South Sudanâ€™s independence, renewed tensions emerged between Khartoum and Juba, particularly over the contested Abyei area. IGAD played a pivotal role in defusing this crisis, facilitating diplomatic engagement between the parties and contributing to discussions on the deployment of peacekeepers. In this context, both Sudan and South Sudan initially advocated for peacekeeping forces drawn from IGAD member states, with Ethiopia identified as a preferred contributor reflecting confidence in the regional organizationâ€™s capacity to manage sensitive security arrangements.
Across these engagements from mediating peace processes to shaping continental and international policy IGAD demonstrated its capacity to serve as both a regional convener and peacebroker in the Horn of Africa. Its contributions have been integral to constructing regional consensus, supporting formal peace agreements, and facilitating coordination between African and global actors on issues of peace and security.
IGAD ultimately reflects the commitment of its member states. Unless member states demonstrate genuine political will and undertake meaningful reforms both domestically and at the regional level, IGAD will continue to face significant challenges. After all, it is an institution created, owned, and sustained by the states of the region themselves.
About the author
Gizachew Asrat (PhD)
, Chief of Staff and Senior Researcher.

Ethiopiaâ€™s Enduring Commitment to Peacekeeping in Somalia: From Intervention to Cooperation
The 2025 U.S. National Security Strategy: Implications for U.S.-Ethiopia Strategic Cooperation

### 115
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/12/15/ethiopias-enduring-commitment-to-peacekeeping-in-somalia-from-intervention-to-cooperation
TITLE: Ethiopiaâ€™s Enduring Commitment to Peacekeeping in Somalia: From Intervention to Cooperation â€“ IFA

Introduction
The modern era of international peacekeeping began with the creation of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO) in May 1948. This first mission, which oversaw the ceasefire between Israel and neighboring Arab states, set the stage for multinational efforts to manage conflicts. In the years that followed, the need for these operations grew significantly, with Africa becoming the main focus for United Nations peacekeeping activities. Currently, half of all global UN peacekeeping missions are deployed across the continent, showing its ongoing challenges with instability and a complicated history.
In this context, Ethiopia has become a key pillar of both international and African peacekeeping. It ranks among the largest contributors of personnel to both the UN and the African Union. Ethiopia routinely sends over 12,000 military and police peacekeepers to crisis zones around the world, with a history of service ranging from Korea to Sudan. However, it is in its immediate region, the Horn of Africa, that Ethiopiaâ€™s commitment has been most apparent and sustained. This is especially true in Somalia, a country marked by government failure and ongoing warfare.
This analysis looks at the varied and changing role Ethiopia has taken in peacekeeping operations in Somalia since 1991. It charts the development of this involvement from initial humanitarian actions to ongoing stabilization efforts under the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) and its successor, the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS) and now AUSSOM missions. Through this examination, the article shows how a regional player uses peacekeeping not just as a diplomatic tool but as an important strategy for enhancing collective security, protecting its own national interests, and fulfilling a sense of regional responsibility.
To understand Ethiopiaâ€™s role, we first need to look at the unstable environment that created it: the Horn of Africa. This region is strategically important but suffers from ongoing instability, facing security threats like terrorism and piracy due to competition for resources. At the heart of this crisis is Somalia, where the government collapsed in 1991, leading to a long civil war, clan conflicts, and lawlessness. This breakdown caused severe humanitarian suffering and allowed militant groups, particularly Al-Shabaab, to grow. The resulting chaos crossed borders, leading to refugee movements, illegal arms trafficking, and increased regional insecurityâ€”threats felt acutely by neighboring Ethiopia. The international response initially focused on humanitarian aid during the 1992-1993 famine when militia blockades prompted the U.S.-led Operation Restore Hope. However, the missionâ€™s failure after the deadly 1993 ambush in Mogadishu led Western powers to withdraw, creating a security void. This withdrawal discouraged further large-scale international military intervention, leaving regional actors, especially Ethiopia, to take on more responsibility for stabilizing Somalia.
Ethiopiaâ€™s military involvement in Somalia has evolved through three definitive stages, transitioning from unilateral interventionist actions to a cornerstone role in multilateral peacekeeping, and now into a phase of complex geopolitical realignment. Initially, from 1996-2006, Ethiopia acted independently to neutralize direct security threats, culminating in its 2006 campaign against the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). While militarily successful, this intervention fueled local backlash and inadvertently strengthened Al-Shabaab, prompting a strategic recalibration. This led to the second stage, where Ethiopia formally integrated into the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) in 2014, becoming its most pivotal troop contributorâ€”bearing the primary combat burden, securing key sectors, and training Somali forces.
The current third stage, beginning in 2024, is defined by the post-ATMIS transition towards new frameworks like AUSSOM where Ethiopiaâ€™s primary role is as a
major troop-contributing country
involved in regional security and counter-insurgency efforts against the Al-Shabaab militant group, and helping strengthen Somaliaâ€™s governance and regional peace. The agreement for Ethiopiaâ€™s formal deployment within AUSSOM was a result of recent diplomatic efforts (specifically the Ankara Declaration and subsequent high-level talks in early 2025) which resolved previous political tensions and disagreements with the Federal Government of Somalia regarding Ethiopiaâ€™s involvement in the mission. Consequently, Ethiopia remains the indispensable security anchor against Al-Shabaab, a leading troop contributor within evolving AU missions, and the central geopolitical catalyst in a regional dispute navigating a fragile, externally-mediated resolutionâ€”all in service of its enduring objectives of border security, regional influence, economic access, and enhanced global partnerships.
Ethiopiaâ€™s critical role in Somali security is defined by a fundamental tension: it operates as the regionâ€™s most potent counterforce against Al-Shabaab, yet its effectiveness is hampered by a hybrid mandate that blurs peacekeeping with combat, eroding its perceived neutrality and escalating risks. This operational dilemma is compounded by Somaliaâ€™s internal divisions, which conscript Ethiopian forces into political mediation, and by the enduring legacy of the 2006 intervention, which militants weaponize to discredit the mission as an occupation. Underpinning these immediate obstacles are chronic systemic weaknessesâ€”shortages in manpower and materiel, erratic financing, and the precariousness of short-term mandatesâ€”that stifle long-term strategy. To break this costly cycle and convert Somalia from a persistent security liability into a collaborative partner, Ethiopia must champion a comprehensive strategic pivot. This begins with diligently fulfilling the Ankara Agreement, leveraging port access as a mutual economic opportunity to restore diplomatic trust. Concurrently, Ethiopia should recalibrate its security approach by leading within the AUSSOM framework toward a mission focused on Somali capacity-building and precision strikes, while fortifying its own border as a defensive shield against spillover. Diplomatically, it must proactively shape consensus within the AU and IGAD and navigate relations with global powers without firm allegiance. Through this integrated strategyâ€”balancing verified diplomacy, sustainable security, and inclusive economic statecraftâ€”Ethiopia can evolve from a reluctant intervener into the principal architect of regional stability, thereby securing its own frontiers and unleashing its national economic potential.
Conclusion: From Cornerstone to Catalystâ€”A Role in Flux
Ethiopiaâ€™s role in peacekeeping in Somalia since 1991 is not a straightforward tale of humanitarian goodwill; it is a complex mix of national interests, regional duty, and adaptive strategies. From the unilateral actions of the 2000s to its central position within the AUâ€™s mission, Ethiopia has been a crucial player in preventing Somaliaâ€™s total collapse and gradually reducing the threat of Al-Shabaab. Its contributions have come at a significant cost in lives and resources, reflecting a deep understanding that its own security is closely tied to Somaliaâ€™s stability. As AMISOM transitions to the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS) and later to AUSSOM, with a clearer focus on transferring security responsibilities to Somali forces, Ethiopiaâ€™s role has changed. It has shifted more towards training, mentoring, and providing strategic oversight while maintaining strong capabilities for counter-terrorism operations. The Somali case shows that in a region of ongoing conflict, lasting peace often relies not only on distant international organizations but also on committed regional stakeholders who have the most to lose from continued instability. Through its peacekeeping commitment, Ethiopia has positioned itself as such a stakeholder. The path to lasting peace in Somalia remains long and difficult, but it would be far more dangerous without its neighborâ€™s ongoing engagement. Understanding this role is crucial for analyzing not just Somaliaâ€™s future but also the changing nature of peacekeeping in an era where regional solutions are increasingly important.
Ethiopia, in collaboration with regional organizations such as IGAD and the AU, should strengthen capacity-building for Somali security forces, enhance regional diplomacy, and increase its focus on community-level stabilization by supporting local governance structures and reconciliation initiatives so that lasting stability can prevail.

Ethiopia and BRICS: from membership to strategic economic partnership
Regime Survival over Regional Cooperation: Eritreaâ€™s Disengagement from Multilateralism

### 116
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/11/03/beyond-desalination-can-ethiopia-be-a-sustainable-water-partner-for-the-arab-region
TITLE: Beyond Desalination: Can Ethiopia be a Sustainable Water Partner for the Arab Region? â€“ IFA

Introduction
Water scarcity is an escalating global problem, projected to intensify in the coming decades as the number of countries facing absolute scarcity has been witnessing a significant surge. The level of scarcity is also rising at an alarming rate owing to
multiple factors
across different geographical regions. The Arab region, in particular, faces the most acute water insecurity, with average per capita renewable water availability of 1,000 cubic meters annually. This is well below the internationally recognized minimum amount required per annum. In various Arab countries, this figure drops below 100 cubic meters per capita, placing the Arab region among the top water-stressed part of the planet. What makes the situation of this region more concerning is that water
consumption continues
alarmingly from time to time due to rapid economic growth, demographic expansion and accelerated urbanization.
Triggered by the aforementioned complexities, the Arab countries have taken different measures to ensure their water security. A case in point, in this regard, is the proliferation of desalination projects in the region since the 1970s. Recently, Qatar built the worldâ€™s
largest desalination
plant, delivering an extraordinary 600 million liters of drinking water per day. In one of the driest parts on earth â€“ the Arab region, the project is more than infrastructure â€“ it is a lifeline. However, the desalination industry by itself is problematic and may not solve the issue of water scarcity in a sustainable manner, demanding a long-term solution. Notably, desalination
by-products
can further exacerbate the already high salinity levels of water in the region â€“ Gulf and Red Sea. This alarms the need for establishing a cooperation framework between the Arab World and the nearby neighboring countries â€“ such as Ethiopia.
Ethiopiaâ€™s Pathways to Foster Cooperation with Arab Countries
The idea of strengthening bond between countries is neither new nor uncommon to maintain water security. Ethiopia is an exemplary country, as the Ethio-Djibouti potable water project echoed this reality, albeit from a distance. It is hoped that Ethiopia can play similar roles with neighboring Arab countries, especially whose water insecurity forced them to import water from other countries. For instance, Ethiopia and Saudi Arabia can work together on water (in) security as the later extremely rely on imported water. Evidently, Saudi Arabia
imports water
from Switzerland ($12,967.37K), Austria ($5,043.61K), United Arab Emirates ($3,829.40K) and other countries. Except Egypt, the reality of most countries in the Arab region is not fundamentally different from Saudi Arabia â€“ dependent on imported water. In this connection, despite I have no current updates,
Addis fortune news
reported that efforts of exporting water to Saudi Arabia underwent five years ago. According to the report one of the newest water bottler, Abebe Dinku Water & Non-Alcoholic Beverages, closed a 20-year deal with a Saudi Arabian company to export water.
Obviously, Ethiopia possesses abundant freshwater resources, especially from the Blue Nile Basin, Lake Tana, and highland rainfall. Being known as the â€˜Water Tower of Africaâ€™, it can be a potential candidate to contribute to the Arab world, leveraging its geographical proximity. The idea of supplying water to Arab countries via transnational pipelines has been under consideration for several decades. For instance, despite it was not realized, a similar project was drafted between Israel and Turkiye in 1998 to launch an undersea fresh-water pipeline from Turkey via northern Cyprus to Israel. Should Arab states fulfill their freshwater needs through Ethiopia, it would substantially elevate Ethiopiaâ€™s regional influence in the Horn of Africa, thereby strengthening its capacity to assert strategic autonomy.
Potential Challenges Facing Ethiopia
Despite Ethiopia is committed to work together with the Arab world in the area of water resources, challenges may arise from some of the Arab countries. Particularly, Egypt may try every avenue to create hassle as usual, very well demonstrated, during the construction of the GERD Project. Egyptians authorities often echo outdated colonial era agreements to silence Ethiopiaâ€™s just call for equitable utilization of trans-boundary water resources. Thus, Ethiopia and the Arab countries should jointly champion regional water-sharing mechanisms that meet the genuine interest of upstream and downstream countries. Above all, some esteemed readers may question the feasibility of the project â€“ supplying water to Arab countries â€“ citing Ethiopiaâ€™s landlocked status. Indeed, landlocked status cannot prevent the realization of such scheme. Several landlocked countries export water directly or indirectly to other countries. For instance, despite being a landlocked country, Switzerland
exported $1.75
Million dollars of water, making it the 65th largest exporter of water across the world.
Conclusion and Policy Recommendations
Ethiopia possesses abundant freshwater resources, while the Arab world has faced chronic water scarcity and relied heavily on desalination, making external freshwater sources an attractive long-term option. Consequently, Ethiopia can be a sustainable water partner for the Arab Worldthrough various mechanisms. Among others, these include increasing bottled water export, building joint trans-national pipeline project and enhancing virtual water trade. Ethiopia starts to export bottled-water to some Arab countries in small commercial volumes. The country needs to increase its export level and destinations in order to reach more countries. Supplying fresh water through pipelines is another alternative for Ethiopia, as its
experience with Djibouti
permits to do so. Expanding those lessons obtained from the ambitious trans-national water project, spanning 258 kilometers from underground wells in Ethiopiaâ€™s Somali region to Djibouti city is vitally important. Last but not least, Ethiopia has the potential to expand its virtual water trade with Arab countries. By increasing the export of water-intensive goods, such as fruits, vegetables, and livestock, Ethiopia can indirectly supply freshwater to Arab countries. The realization of these strategies hinges on fostering a constructive spirit. This sprit should encounter divisive narratives including the partisan notion that
erroneously asserts
the water security of the Republic of Sudan and Egypt is an integral part of Arab national security.

Ethiopiaâ€™s Nuclear Vision: Powering a Sustainable Future and Economic Growth
Does the Expansion of BRICS Catalyze the Shifting of the World Order?

### 117
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/13/%F0%9D%90%84%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9A-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9D%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%92
TITLE: ğ„ğ­ğ¡ğ¢ğ¨ğ©ğ¢ğš ğ‘ğğœğ¨ğ«ğğ¬ ğ’ğ­ğ«ğ¨ğ§ğ  ğŒğšğœğ«ğ¨ğğœğ¨ğ§ğ¨ğ¦ğ¢ğœ ğ†ğ«ğ¨ğ°ğ­ğ¡ ğ€ğ¦ğ¢ğ ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ©ğ«ğğ¡ğğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ¯ğ ğ‘ğğŸğ¨ğ«ğ¦ğ¬ â€“ IFA

Addis Ababa, October 6, 2025 â€” The Government of Ethiopia has
registered significant achievements through comprehensive macroeconomic reforms aimed at addressing structural imbalances and fostering sustainable economic growth, President Taye Atske Selassie highlighted during the joint session of the House of Peoplesâ€™ Representatives and the House of Federation.
In his address, President Taye underscored the governmentâ€™s strategic priorities for the current Ethiopian fiscal year, covering economic, political, and diplomatic initiatives. Reflecting on the concluded 2017 fiscal year, he noted positive outcomes across multiple sectors, emphasizing that the ongoing macroeconomic reforms have produced tangible results.
The President cited the inauguration of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) and the launch of the Ogaden Liquefied Natural Gas Project as landmark achievements demonstrating Ethiopiaâ€™s development progress.
He further noted that Ethiopiaâ€™s export sector has expanded, contributing to over 8 billion USD in revenue last fiscal year â€” the highest in the nationâ€™s economic history â€” and highlighting the countryâ€™s shift from a single-sector to a diversified development strategy.
President Taye concluded that the countryâ€™s economy is now showing strong signs of recovery and resilience following the implementation of wide-ranging economic reforms, setting a foundation for sustainable growth and inclusive prosperity.

### 118
URL: https://www.ifa.gov.et/2025/10/15/ethiopia-and-pakistan-deepen-cooperation-across-strategic-sectors
TITLE: Ethiopia and Pakistan Deepen Cooperation Across Strategic Sectors â€“ IFA

Ambassador Jemal Beker (@jemalbeker) met with H.E. Khawaja Asif, Federal Minister of Defence of Pakistan, at the National Assembly of Pakistan.
Discussions focused on strengthening bilateral and multilateral cooperation in peace and security, defence, aviation, climate change, trade and investment, tourism, and culture.
The Ambassador briefed His Excellency on the recent inauguration of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) â€” a symbol of Africaâ€™s self-reliance and commitment to equitable, mutually beneficial use of shared water resources, fostering regional development without harming any other country.
H.E. Ambassador Beker expressed gratitude for the Ministerâ€™s steadfast support over the past three years, reaffirming the commitment to deepen cooperation between the two brotherly nations.
Later, the Ambassador met with H.E. Chaudhry Salik Hussain, Pakistanâ€™s Federal Minister for Overseas Pakistanis and Human Resource Development. The discussion highlighted skills development, Ethiopiaâ€™s economic reforms, and investments in emerging technologies such as AI, blockchain, and coding to empower youth.
Ambassador Beker also proposed joint initiatives to upskill young people in both countries and briefed His Excellency on Ethiopiaâ€™s â€œBack to Originsâ€ initiative, encouraging diaspora engagement in national development.
Concluding the meetings, H.E. Ambassador Beker commended the Ministers for their remarkable contributions to strengthening Ethioâ€“Pakistan relations, underscoring the enduring friendship and mutual respect between the two nations.

GSEZ discussed with Ethiopian Investment Commission
admin
News
0
Gada Special Economic Zone (GSEZ) had a high-level discussion with the Ethiopian Investment Commission today at EIC Head Quarter, during which senior officials engaged in constructive discussions on a range of strategic issues aimed at enhancing a conducive working environment and jointly attracting experienced investors with strong capital from across the globe. ### 121
URL: https://www.gadasez.gov.et/gsez-digital-strategy
TITLE: GSEZ Digital Strategy - Gada Special Economic Zone

In a significant move toward enhancing the digital landscape of the Gada Special Economic Zone, key stakeholders from Adama City Administration, Harambe University, and ZTE convened in a collaborative meeting. The primary objective of this gathering was to lay the groundwork for a comprehensive digital strategy that will revolutionize the economic zoneâ€™s operations and growth.
The meeting provided a platform for open dialogue and the exchange of ideas, emphasizing the importance of a multifaceted approach to digital development. Stakeholders emphasized the need for a strategic plan that aligns with the economic zoneâ€™s unique requirements and the broader goals of the zone.
The attendees shared their expertise and insights, offering valuable perspectives on how to leverage digital technologies to enhance the Gada Special Economic Zoneâ€™s efficiency and competitiveness. By bringing together the administrative experience of Adama City, the educational prowess of Harambe University, and the technical know-how of ZTE, the collaboration is poised to harness the full potential of digitalization.
The development of a robust digital strategy is anticipated to create a significant impact on various facets of the Gada Special Economic Zone, from optimizing industrial operations and supply chain management to bolstering educational and research initiatives. Itâ€™s also expected to play a pivotal role in attracting businesses and investments to the region.

### 124
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/about-us/background-history.html
TITLE: Background History

Background History
Background & History of EPA
Background & History of EEPA
Ethiopia has issued various strategic and institutional frameworks to be applied in the effort to manage the environment. The regulatory framework ranges from the supreme law of the country, the constitution, to various specific environmental standards. Whereas the institutional arrangements extended from the federal to the local levels.
Ethiopiaâ€™s Constitution
Ethiopiaâ€™s Constitution incorporates a number of provisions relevant to the protection, sustainable use, and improvement of the countryâ€™s environment. Article 44 guarantees â€œthe right to a clean and healthy environment,â€ while Article 43 pledges â€œthe right . . . to sustainable development.â€ Additionally, Articles 89 and 92 require national policy and government activities to be compatible with environmental health. Article 89 further obliges the government to ensure sustainable development, work for the common benefit of the community, and promote the participation of the people, including women, in the creation of national development policies and programs. Moreover, according to Article 91, the government is duty-bound to protect and support cultures, traditions, natural endowments, and historical sites and objects. The incorporation of these important provisions into the supreme law of the land has raised environmental issues to the level of fundamental human rights.
The Ethiopian Environmental Protection Authority
The Ethiopian Environmental Protecion Authorty (EEPA) is the Federal institution for managing the Environment of Ethiopia. EEPA is responsible to ensure the realization of the environmental rights, goals, objectives and basic principles enshrined in the Constitution. As well as the Environment Policy of Ethiopia through coordinating appropriate measures, establishing systems, developing programs and mechanisms for the welfare of humans and the safety of the environment.
It is mandated to formulate or initiate and coordinate the formulation of strategies, policies, laws and standards as well as procedures and up on approval monitor and enforce their implementation. It is also responsible for the synergistic implementation and follow-up of international and regional environmental agreements. Including those pertaining to hazardous chemicals, industrial wastes and anthropogenic environmental hazards in which Ethiopia is a party. All MEAâ€™s are currently being coordinated and monitored by the Environment, Forest and climate Change Commission.
History of Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
Environmental Protection Authority (EPA)
To reach its current existence, the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has passed through different institutional restructuring and changes in its legal formation. The Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) , Ministry of Environment and Forest and Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change were key stepping institutions for the establishment of the Environment, Forest and Climate Change commission.
Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) was established as an autonomous government agency at the Federal level by Proclamation 9/1995 in 1995. The institution was accountable to the prime Minister. Along with EPA, the Environmental Protection Council was also established to oversee the tasks and activities of EPA as well as the activities of sartorial environmental agencies and units responsible for environmental management. The proclamation establishing EPA also stipulated the need for the establishment of environmental organs by regions.
Ministry of Environment and Forest
Following the need for better representation of environmental matters in the Council of Ministers, EPA upgraded to the Ministry of Environment and Forest showing the political will and increased momentum in managing the Environment. EPA was subsequently re-established as an autonomous body responsible to the Prime Minister by the Environmental Organs Establishment Proclamation No. 295/2002. The Ministry of Environment and Forest was established by the amended proclamation 803/2013. The proclamation mandated the Ministry, to Coordinate and ensure the environmental objectives stipulated in the 1995 constitution of Ethiopia and the basic environmental principles indicated in the 1997 environmental policy of Ethiopia. The Ministry took the following powers and duties vested to it by proclamation No 803/2013:
Coordinate and ensure the environmental objectives stipulated in the 1995 constitution of Ethiopia and the basic environmental principles indicated in the 1997 environmental policy of Ethiopia
Ensure that private, public and government projects do not inflict adverse social and environmental impacts. It also ensures that government social and economic development policies, strategies, laws and programs are in line with the constitution and other law of the lands and never induce adverse social and environmental impacts;
Prepare a mechanism that promotes social, economic and environmental justice and channel the major part of any benefit derived thereof to the affected communities to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases that would otherwise have resulted from deforestation and forest degradation;
Ensure the implementation of internationally agreed and ratified environmental and natural resource issues are rightly implemented through the preparation of different policies and strategies as well as establishment of implementing institution(s);
Propose incentives to encourage best practices or disincentives to discourage practices that may hamper the sustainable use of natural resource or the prevention of environmental degradation or pollution;
Promotes the sustainability of the environment and the conservation and use of forest as well as the equitable sharing of benefits accruing from them while creating opportunities for green jobs.
Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
In 2015, the Ministry of Environment and Forest was renamed and restructured to the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change by Promotion No 916/2015. The Ministry has, the following powers and duties:
Coordinate measures to ensure that the environment objectives provided under the constitution and the basic principles set out in the environmental policy of Ethiopia are realized.
Establish a system for environmental impact assessment of public and private projects, as well as social and economic development policies, strategies, laws and programs.
Prepare a mechanism that promotes social, economic and environmental justice and channel the major part of any benefit derived thereof to the affected communities to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases that would otherwise have resulted from deforestation and forest degradation.
Coordinate actions on soliciting the resources required for building a climate resilient green economy in all sectors and at all governance levels as well as provide capacity building support and advisory services.
Establish a system for the evaluation of the environmental impact assessment of investment projects submitted by their respective proponents, the concerned sartorial licensing organ or the concerned regional organ prior to granting permission in accordance with the Environmental Impact Assessment Proclamation.
Take part in the negotiations of international environmental agreements and, as appropriate, initiate a process of their ratification.
Establish an environmental information system that promotes efficiency in environmental data collection, management and use.
Promote and provide non-formal environmental education program and cooperate with competent organs with a view to integrating environmental concerns in the regular educational curricula.
Environment, Forest and Climate Change Commission
In 2018, the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change was renamed and restructured to the Environment and Forest and Climate Change CommissionÂ by Promotion No ----/2018. The Ministry has, the following powers and duties:
Ethiopian Environmental Protection Authority
In 2021, the Environment and Forest and Climate Change Commission was renamed and restructured to theÂ EthiopianÂ Environmental Protection Authority by Promotion No ----/2021. The Ministry has, the following powers and duties:

### 125
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/about-us/mission,-vision-and-values.html
TITLE: Mission, Vision and  Values

Mission, Vision and  Values
Mission Vision and Core Values
Mission, Vision,
Objectives
and Core Values
Mission
â€œPromote and ensure the protection and conservation of the environment as a valuable asset for the people of Ethiopia. To protect our people and the environment from harmful effects of Pollution, Climate change and Biodiversity loss.â€
Vision
All Ethiopian Society and sectors of development value and undertake sound environmental management to clean, healthy, safe, and protected environment that supports the national aspiration to be African bacon of prosperity by 2030.
Values
EPAÂ is guided by the following core values/principles:
To be a trusted, independent and authoritative advocate for the environment.
To provide our services in a manner that is competent, courteous and responsive.
To be innovative, adaptive and open to new and flexible ways of working.
To make objective decisions based on the best available scientific evidence and information.
To make a difference by working with others to build trust, networks and partnerships to deliver effective outcomes.
To strive continuously for improvement and excellence through learning and development.
To manage our resources effectively and efficiently to deliver value to the public,
To regulate in a fair, proportionate and transparent manner and target those who don't comply.

### 126
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/about-us/powers-and-duties.html
TITLE: Powers and Duties

Powers and Duties
Power and Duties
Power and Duties
The major duties and responsibilities of the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change as stated in the Proclamation No. 916/2015 are as follows:
Coordinate activities to ensure that the environmental objectives provided under the Constitution and the basic principles set out in the Environmental Policy of the Country are realized;
Establish a system and follow up implementation for undertaking environmental impact assessment or strategic environmental assessment on social and economic development polices, strategies, laws, programs and project set by the government or Privet;
Prepare a mechanism that promotes social, economic and environmental justice and channel the major part of benefit derived thereof to the affected communities to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases that would otherwise have resulted from deforestation and forest degradation;
Coordinate actions on soliciting the resources required for building a climate resilient green economy in all sectors and at all Regional levels; as well as provide capacity building support and advisory services;
Establish a system for evaluating and decision making, in accordance with the Environmental Impact Assessment Proclamation, the impacts of implementation of investment programs and projects on environment prior to approvals of their implementation by the concerned sectoral licensing organ or the concerned regional organ;
Prepare programmes and directives for the synergistic implementation and follow up of environmental agreements ratified by Ethiopia pertaining to the natural resources base, desertification, forests, hazardous chemicals, industrial wastes and anthropogenic environmental hazards with the objective of avoiding overlaps, wastage of resources and gaps during their implementation in all sectors and at all governance levels;
Take part in the negotiations of international environmental and climate change agreements and, as appropriate, initiate a process of their ratification; play key role in coordinating the nationwide responses to the agreements;
coordinate, and as may be appropriate, carry out research and technology transfer activities that promotes the sustainability of the environment and the conservation and use of forest as well as the equitable sharing of benefits accruing from them while creating opportunities for green jobs;
Establish a system for development and utilization of small and large scale forest including bamboo on private, communal and watershed areas, and ensure implementation of same;
Establish a system to rehabilitate degraded forest lands and ensure its implementation to enhance their environmental and economic benefits.

Message from His Excellency Dr. Belete Molla, Minister of Innovation and Technology
Dear followers of our website
The role of innovative technology capacity building is significant for the development and universal prosperity of a country. Therefore, it requires relentless efforts to adapt technology and innovation policies and plans to the current situation. In our country, since 1987, efforts have been made to bring about structural change by devising and implementing policies, strategies and plans to bring results in the field of science and technology.
It has been believed that it is important to empower the actors in order to reduce poverty by bringing social and economic development to the sector. As a result, efforts have been made to build a workforce that is capable of finding, providing,Â  adapting the technology that will be used for the proposed change based on the needs of the industry.
Our ministry has been reorganized in accordance with Decree No. 1097/11 to support the indigenous economic direction designed following the national change. The new organization has given it a new capacity to play its role in the national development by making a coherent policy and strategy in the field of technology. With this new capacity, the Ministry able to put into action a ten-year plan for the sector based on indigenous economic development agenda.
The use of digital technology has been identified as a critical capability for the success of the new development direction. Therefore, an inclusive digital transformation strategy has been prepared that is aligned from the indigenous economic perspective, that will achieve the ten-year plan and strengthen the sector. The Digital Ethiopia 2025 strategy is an angle that ensures inclusive national prosperity by achieving the indigenous economic development plan and takes our achievements so far to a new stage of development.
This was possible due to the arrival of information technology and a change leadership with a clear perspective in the field and being able to provide sufficient support. With the attention given, we are required to work by establishing new procedures to bring results of social change.
We are working on ICT and digital economy, research and innovation sector to create job opportunities, GDP contribution. I am sure; the website will be an important knowledge-sharing platform between our Ministry and public at large for creating science and Technology Community.
Belete Molla Getahun (PhD)
Minister, MinistryÂ  of Innovation and Technology
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Vision
Build a country that is conducive for job and wealth creation through technology and innovation.
Mission
The Miss
ion also to ensure the sustainability of the countryâ€™s development by creating an environment in which innovation systems are implemented.
Creating an environment for the digital economy of the country
Building the capacity to increase the competitiveness of the country's technology industry development
Our values
Decent conscience and good heart
An limitless thirst for learning
Love of work and dedication
Unlimited thought and imagination
A foundation for generations
Organizational Philosophy
Knowledge is wealth
We acknowledge new ideas
Diligence is the power of positive change
Technology and innovation is the language of the new generation
Encouraging innovation for the next generation
Modern digital economy is the basis of our development
History
Established in December 1975 by proclamation No.62/1975 as a Science and Technology commission.
Science and Technology Commission (1975 -1994 )
The Commission was re-established in March 1994 by Proclamation No.91/1994.
Furthermore, the commission went into its 3rd phase of re-institution on the 24th of August 1995 by Proclamation No.7/1995 as Science and Technology Agency
Science and Technology Agency (1994-2008)
4th phase of re-institution on September 29, 2008 by proclamation No.601/2001 as a Ministry.
After the year 2011 EC Â Ministry of Science and Technology changed into ministry of Innovation and Technology by combining the then Ministry of Science and Technology and Ministry of Communication and Information Technology.
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

Innovation

Digitalization

The Ministry of Innovation and Technology shall have the following powers and duties:
1. The Ministry of Innovation and Technology shall have the following powers and duties:
a)Â Â  initiate policies, strategies, laws and programs that sustainably ensure the developmentÂ Â  andÂ  Â competitiveness bio and emerging technology, geospatial, space, technology and digital economic development; prepare a detail program that is compatibleÂ  withÂ  theÂ  countryâ€™s overall development plan and implement the same upon approval;
b)Â Â  initiate policy, in collaboration with the concerned organs, for the enhancement of technology and innovation use culture; ensure, in collaboration with the concerned organs, the countryâ€™s educational curricula are designed in tune with innovation and technology development;
c) prepare and implement national innovation and technology research and development policies, strategies andÂ Â  programs;Â Â Â Â Â  identifyÂ Â Â Â Â  new innovationÂ  andÂ  technologyÂ  studies and researchÂ  areas pertinent toÂ  the national development; coordinate national research programs;
d)Â Â  establish a system that enhance the participation and role of the private sector in the development of innovation and technology sector; create conducive condition for implementationÂ  ofÂ  theÂ  same; establish and implement a system for the grant of awards and incentives to individuals and institutions contributing to the advancement of innovation and technological development works;
e)Â Â  set, in collaboration with concerned organs, standards to ensure the provision of quality, reliablity and security of information communication technology services; monitor the implementation of the same;
f) SupportÂ Â Â Â  capacityÂ Â Â Â  buildingÂ Â Â Â  of institutionsÂ  andÂ  professionals involved in innovation and technology activities; support and encourage professional associations and research and study institutions
g)Â Â  establish, in collaboration with the concernedÂ Â  organs,Â  Â aÂ  Â systemÂ  Â to identify technology demand, explore appropriate technologies and implement the same; follow up the implementation of the same;
h) Â support studies, researches and their dissemination, for the improvement, development and marketing of indigenous technologies; provide necessary support for practical application Â of Â such Â works;Â  cause them accessible to stakeholders and the community in the form of prototype; encourage and support individuals,Â Â  professional associations, study and research institutions that will make significant contribution for the development of innovations and technologies;
i)Â  registerÂ  informationÂ  about technologies from different fields; coordinate works for their compilation and preservation; cause them to be used for future works;
i) design programs that enable the expansion of innovation and technology in particular digital infrastructures; ensure for critical systems and services in public sector are supported by appropriate technology and positioned to better provide services to the public; in general, works and provide support public services be supported by technology and efficient;
j)Â Â  organize innovation and technology data base, compile information, set national standards for information management;
k)Â Â  in collaboration with relevant bodies, support the development, and coordination of information systems; provide support for the deployment secured information network within federal and regional government institutions;
l)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  provide support for the promotion of domestic innovation skills through establishing internationally standardized laboratories, workshops and informationÂ Â Â Â  communication technology parks for selected innovation and technology research works;Â  facilitateÂ  forÂ  the establishment of start-up fund for the the same;
m)Â  follow up the implementation of the system regulating the utilization and disposal of radiation and radiation producing items;
n) provide professional and technical support to regional innovation and technology institutions; identify and cause common understanding on innovation and technology development activities to be undertaken by the regions: follow implementation ofÂ  the same;
o) follow up the effectiveness of the transformation of innovative ideas in to values role for national prosperity by supporting creativity and innovation;
2/Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The powers and duties entrustedÂ  to the Ministry of Innovation and Technology underÂ  otherÂ  lawsÂ  thatÂ  areÂ  currentlyÂ  in force are hereby vested in the Ministry of InnovationÂ  andÂ  TechnologyÂ  established by this Proclamation.
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

Innovation Development
Coordinate, promote and lead the national Business, tech and Research based Innovation and Startup Ecosystem development.
In particular, the unit operates to meet ministryâ€™s goal to enable the Ethiopiaâ€™s startup ecosystem reaching the fourth stage of its life cycle, which would enable Ethiopiaâ€™s startup ecosystem to finally integrate with the global fabrics of knowledge, produce a global business model, and achieve high global market reach in the long run. In the near future, the unit places its priority on the first cycle, which is the activation ecosystem life cycle, which is stifled by challenges such as limited ecosystem experience, challenges of resource leakages to later-stage ecosystems that inhibit growth, and also activation cycle success indicators such as triggering the globalization ecosystem life cycle through multiple startups with 100 million+ USD exits and through national resource attraction in some of our regions, such as Kenyaâ€™s and Nigeriaâ€™s startup ecosystems Among many other activities, the unit technically coordinates Startup Designation Provision Services based on legal and regulatory frameworks.

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Technology Development and Transfer
Technology Development and Transfer CEO under the FDRE Ministry of Innovation and Technology (MInT), is dedicated to cultivating a thriving ecosystem for the advancement and exchange of cutting-edge technologies within the nation. The CEO, operates three distinct Desks, each serving a crucial role in this mission. The Technology Transfer and Linkage Desk focuses on fostering partnerships and collaborations to facilitate the transfer of innovative technologies into Ethiopia. The Indigenous innovation and Technology Development Desk is responsible for nurturing homegrown talent and ideas, supporting the development of indigenous technologies that can compete on a global scale. Lastly, the Innovation and Technology Data Development and Management Desk plays a vital role in collecting and analyzing data to drive informed decision-making and strategy development in the tech sector. Together, these three Desks work harmoniously to propel Ethiopia towards a future defined by innovative and technological excellence.
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

National Electronic Government Development
Leads programs and projects designed based on national strategies and plans.
Aligns the requirements for doing architecture-related work with the national digital strategy.
Develops enterprise architecture policies, standards, guidelines and procedures.
Analyzes national interoperability and enterprise architecture guidelines and standards.
Conducts Feasibility Study & Impact Analysis of E-Government Systems projects.
Monitors, supports and evaluates the functionality of electronic services;
Conducts Researches on Modern and up-to-date digital platforms; implementation tools; Database technologies; mobile platforms and service delivery channels.
Ensures Business Continuity by promptly resolving problems in the event of cyber-attack.
Conducts research and development for the development of new technologies in the data development sector.
studies, and analyzes inconsistencies or unusual data that may distort analytical results. Predicts the future using machine-learning algorithms
Prepares guidelines for data use and management by the government, submit them to the higher authority for approval and prepares operating guidelines; Monitors implementation.
Ensures that the computer networks and applications in use are integrated and interoperable.
Participates in the preparation of standard information communication technology policy, as well as supervises, coordinates and monitors the ICT policy making process.
Design Implementation strategies to make data technology infrastructures with national coverage accessible to all government institutions.
Develops and coordinates data development within federal and regional governmental institutions in cooperation with relevant institutions; Supports the implementation of secure data operations;
provides the necessary professional and technical support for the innovation and technology bureaus of regional and city administrations to build capacity on data development;
3. Objectives
Coordinate national digital transformation efforts through development of Fast, Reliable and Secure Digital Government Services ensuring the provision of dependable government services and improving ease of doing business.
Coordinate the development of national digital plans, strategies and implementation tools that guide the development and implementation of digital government services and national digital infrastructures.
Coordinate and support the development of national data interoperability, digital data asset administration and open data policies and support their implementation and use in job creation and national development endeavors.
4. Duties and responsibilities
Develop, administer and upgrade digital government services
Provide technical support and capacity building related to development and administration of digital government services
Develop policies, strategies and programs for national ICT services
Establish and monitor standards for quality, security and reliability of development of ICT services
Ensure data quality, security and reliability by establishing reliable national data development ecosystem and supporting frameworks
Develop and upgrade national data infrastructures
Support government data development services and activities
5. Projects and programs if any
Upgrade, Implementation, Support and Maintenance of Ethiopian eServices Platform and eServices for MINT
Upgrading and Expansion of Existing NBP, ODE and eCompliant platforms to Diredawa, Bahir Dar and Adama City Administrations.
Development of E-Gov Strategy and Government Enterprise Architecture for Ethiopia.
Implementation of Ethiopian National Data Warehouse
Development of Online Transaction System for Ministries
Document Digitization Service for Federal Supreme Court, DARA and MoJ.
Development of Government Office Modernization Roadmap
Establishment of E-Gov Training Center
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

Digital Economy Development
Our primary responsibility is to build a national digital system that will promote the development of the country's digital economy. We are doing to ensure the practical implementation of digital economy. We are also doing to establish a system that allows them to be fair actors in the digital economy. Ensuring the healthy growth of the digital economy by developing and implementing standards and regulatory frameworks that foster the growth of the digital economy. The role of the community in the development of the digital economy and ensure its benefits. Creating favorable conditions for private sector participation in the digital industry.

Ensuring the healthy growth of the digital economy by developing and implementing standards and regulatory frameworks that foster the growth of the digital economy

Announcement for training opportunity beneficiaries
Ethiopian ecosystem
English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
CALL FOR CONCEPT NOTES
Ministry of Innovation and Technology (MinT) pleased to announceÂ  annual Indigenous award and recognition which is held in Addis Ababa at national levelÂ  to recognize outstanding individuals, association and institution for those who have made significant contributions that have influenced positive change in the field of indigenous innovation and technology.
The aim of the recognition is to honor indigenous technologies driving significant economic growth in line with the country's development plans. The recognition involves evaluating the impact that the indigenous knowledge and technologies (IKT) has brought in contribution to the 2nd development and transformation plan by the government of Ethiopia.
We encourage interested applicants who meet the specified criteria to submit a concept note detailing the prototype, technology, or product they have for consideration
Priority Areas of the Indigenous Technology (IK)
: When assessing the concepts, priority is placed on the following areas of the IK
Indigenous Agriculture.
Indigenous Medicine
Handcraft
Cottage Industry
Construction
Indigenous food and beverage technologies,
Indigenous writing technologies
Eligibility
The following selection criterion will be strictly followed. The indigenous knowledge technology/ innovation / product submitted for evaluation should:
Be original or existed knowledge in Ethiopia
Candidates must be citizens of Ethiopia.
Have significant contribution to scientific, social and economic transformation of the country
Address the local area or nationwide problems in Ethiopia
Have acquired IP /Utility Model/applied for IPR/ rights (this criterion is optional but those products having the IPR/ UM/ applied for will have priority from other products)
Submission guidelines
The concept note should
Be as per the Concept Note submission guideline/format
The file must be submitted in PDF format (not in Word).
Be submitted
from
Nov 26/2017 to Dec 26/2017 E.C
Guideline for Concept Notes
Apply for CALL FOR CONCEPT NOTES
The government merged the former Ministry of Science and Technology and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology to form the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in 2019.

17th BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro, Prime Minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed
Attending the 17th BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro and during the opening session on peace and security and global governance, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed focused his remarks on the urgent need for international institutions that can foster mutual trust and enable effective cooperation. He also reiterated the call for comprehensive reforms in the decision-making structures of international financial institutions and global norms towards promoting collective security and shared prosperity.
Ethiopia officially joined the BRICS bloc in 2023, standing shoulder to shoulder with nations committed not only to building an economic alliance but also to advancing a just, equitable, and multipolar world order. As a BRICS member, Ethiopia aims to actively contribute to these efforts, particularly by supporting the expanded representation of emerging markets and developing countries in global decision-making forums.
In his remarks, Prime Minister Abiy highlighted the blocâ€™s growing influence, stating: â€œBRICS has grown from a bold idea into a dynamic force for global transformation. With the addition of new members, our collective voice grows stronger, our shared purpose becomes clearer, and our potential expands.â€
#PMOEthiopia

áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
41st Regular Council of Ministers Meeting Resolutions The council of ministers discussed and passed a decision on various issues at the 41st regular meeting today.
41st Regular Council of Ministers Meeting Resolutions
The council of ministers discussed and passed a decision on various issues at the 41st regular meeting today.
1. The parliament discussed in advance with the Ethiopian government with the International Development Association for the implementation of the modern government service improvement project of 53,300,000.00 S. .. R and the financial sector strengthening project implementation of 525,700,000 s. .. R is on 2 bills that are proposed to approve financial aid and loan agreements. Both loans are interest free, 0.75% service charge and are payable in 38 years including a 6 year term term period. The House should pass the bills to the House of Representatives ensuring that the loans are in line with our country's credit policy. He decided unanimously.
2. Next, the house discussed on the regulation to amend the investment incentive regulation. Investment incentive regulation number 517/2014 is being implemented but companies in different sectors are facing performance problems before and after the regulation. The amendment was made to make the rules clear. After the discussion on the amendment regulations, the Federal Negarit was added resources by the Federal Negarith. It has been decided unanimously to implement the newspaper from the day it was published.
3. The draft regulation that was proposed to dismantle the ownership and administration of governmental development organizations is another agenda that the parliament discussed. In order to enable the privatization of governmental development companies to be transferred to debt and asset management corporation, the regulation is submitted to the parliament because it is necessary to dismantle governmental development organizations' property and administration and transfer its rights and obligations to the corporation. Advice After extensive discussion on the elaborate rules, the house has decided unanimously to add resources and put it into action from the day it was published in Negarit newspaper.
//

5 Million Coders Professional Training
Register here to benefit from free online training opportunities through the Five Million Ethiopian Coders Initiative to develop basic coding skills in the areas of web-programming, Android development, data science and artificial intelligence.
https://ethiocoders.et/
Qualified trainees who complete the online training within the allotted 8 weeks will be awarded an internationally recognized certificate. By taking out your gift; Let's change tomorrow!!!

5 million Ethiopian coders
The "5 million Ethiopian coders" initiative is a program that will help our youth to have the appropriate digital skills and create jobs and wealth to fuel theÂ  digital economy.
=======
Ethiopian coders initiative where five million citizens will benefit from digital technology training It was announced today by the Honorable Prime Minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed.
Speaking at the program, Dr. Belete Molla of the Ministry of Innovation and Technology said that the "5 Million Ethiopian Coders" initiative is a program that will help our youth to have the appropriate digital skills and create jobs and wealth to fuel the construction of a digital economy on a large scale.
The minister said that today, we have reached a new era where technology is not only a work tool but also a change agent.
The Minister also mentioned that the Ethio Coders program will equip young Ethiopians with the skills and knowledge to actively participate in the digital ecosystem, create new opportunities for them and open the door for our country to move forward in the field of technology.
He said that the Ethiocoders program shows the commitment of the government to empower our youth, develop creativity and use the huge potential of the digital age.
He said that one of the important foundations to ensure a digital Ethiopia is building the digital ecosystem and digital skills are an important starting point to use the economy and provide services in the construction of a digital economy.
"Coding is not just about writing lines of code. Coding is about problem solving, critical thinking and creativity." The minister said, "When we equip our youth with coding skills, they can confidently join the wider digital world and use applications created by others, but they can also benefit the country and make people's lives easier." He said that it is important to realize that the way is being facilitated for them to be able to develop many applications on their own.

### 163
URL: http://www.mint.gov.et/web/guest/w/780-thousand-citizens-are-undergoing-five-million-ethio-coders-training-h.e-minister-dr.-belete-molla
TITLE: 780 thousand citizens are undergoing five million Ethio Coders training â€“H.E Minister  Dr. Belete Molla - MINT

+251118132191

áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
780 thousand citizens are undergoing five million Ethio Coders training â€“H.E Minister Dr. Belete Molla
Minister of Innovation and Technology Belete Molla (Dr) stated that in the 5 million Ethiopians coders initiative, 780 thousand citizens are taking coders training.
The minister who mentioned that about 280 thousand of them graduated and got their certificates; also pointed out that this certificate is international.
This program is a three year program and in these years 5 million to 7 million youth are expected to benefit from this program.
The minister who said the world is entering into digital technology system has stated that the initiative is important for the citizens to be qualified and productive in building the digital economy.
The minister added that different strategies have been implemented to achieve digital economy transition in Ethiopia.
The minister said that in order to achieve the digital economy transition in Ethiopia, different resources and jobs are expected; one of the main things is to expand infrastructure.
The minister who stated that the government and the private society should work together to make this change that Ethiopia has started a reality. He pointed out that many changes have been recorded in this way.
By increasing the number of internet and mobile users, they have realized that developing resources that are helpful for the construction of the digital economy is the main goal of the transition of digital economy.
The minister explained that to build the digital capacity of citizens, we need to work on human resources development.

Ğ£Ğ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ² Ğ´Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½ĞµĞ¹ÑˆĞµĞ¼ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¸ ÑĞ¾Ñ‚Ñ€ÑƒĞ´Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ° Ğ² Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğµ Â«Ğ¦ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°Ñ ĞĞ·Ğ¸Ñ â€“ Ğ Ğ¾ÑÑĞ¸ÑÂ» Ğ¸ Ğ² Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ°Ñ… Ğ¡Ğ¾Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ¶ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ° ĞĞµĞ·Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ¼Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ“Ğ¾ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ñ€ÑÑ‚Ğ², ÑƒĞºÑ€ĞµĞ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ°ĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ´ĞµĞ¹ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ ÑĞ¾ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸, ÑĞ²Ğ»ÑÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ ĞµÑÑ‚ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ½ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸
