æ¥æºï¼šæ’’å“ˆæ‹‰è§†é‡ã€€å‘å¸ƒï¼š2026-01-01 23:09
2025å¹´ï¼Œä¸­éåˆä½œè®ºå›æ­¥å…¥æˆç«‹25å‘¨å¹´çš„å†å²æ€§æ—¶åˆ»ã€‚ä»å…±å»ºâ€œä¸€å¸¦ä¸€è·¯â€çš„å®ä¼Ÿæ“˜ç”»ï¼Œåˆ°çœŸå®äº²è¯šç†å¿µçš„æ·±å…¥äººå¿ƒï¼Œä»æ°‘ç›¸äº²ã€å¿ƒç›¸é€šçš„æ·±åšæƒ…è°Šï¼Œåˆ°å…±é€ç°ä»£åŒ–çš„åšå®šæ­¥å±¥ï¼Œä¸­éåˆä½œä¹‹è·¯æ—¥ç›Šå®½å¹¿ã€‚åœ¨å¹¿è¢¤çš„éæ´²ï¼Œè®°è€…æ·±åˆ‡æ„Ÿå—åˆ°ï¼Œåˆä½œèµ‹èƒ½æ­£è®©è¿™ç‰‡å¤è€çš„å¤§é™†æ¶ŒåŠ¨å‡ºæ›´å¤§ç”Ÿæœºã€‚
ä¸€æ ªâ€œå¹¸ç¦è‰â€ï¼Œç‚¹ç»¿è’æ¼ ï¼Œæ¸©æ¶¦äººå¿ƒã€‚
ä»Šå¹´æ˜¯ä¸­å›½ä¸æ¯›é‡Œå¡”å°¼äºšå»ºäº¤60å‘¨å¹´ã€‚2025å¹´6æœˆï¼Œè®°è€…æ¥åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªâ€œæ²™æ¼ ä¹‹å›½â€ï¼Œè®°å½•ä¸­å›½èŒè‰æŠ€æœ¯å¦‚ä½•åœ¨æ­¤è½åœ°ç”Ÿæ ¹ã€é€ ç¦ä¸€æ–¹ã€‚ç›®ä¹‹æ‰€åŠï¼ŒèŒè‰ç”°éƒéƒè‘±è‘±ã€‚èŒè‰æ—¢æˆä¸ºå½“åœ°é‡è¦çš„é¥²è‰æ¥æºï¼Œä¹Ÿæ„ç­‘èµ·é˜²é£å›ºæ²™çš„ç”Ÿæ€å±éšœã€‚
è¿™æ˜¯1æœˆ18æ—¥åœ¨æ¯›é‡Œå¡”å°¼äºšä¼Šè¿ªå°¼æ‘çš„ä¸­å›½æ´æ¯›é‡Œå¡”å°¼äºšç•œç‰§ä¸šæŠ€æœ¯ç¤ºèŒƒä¸­å¿ƒæ‹æ‘„çš„èŒè‰è¯•éªŒç”°ä¸€éš…ã€‚æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€… å¸æºæ‘„
å–œæ‚¦ï¼ŒçœŸåˆ‡å†™åœ¨äººä»¬è„¸ä¸Šã€‚ç‰§æ°‘é˜¿ç±³å°”Â·é˜¿åœæœçš„ç¾Šç¾¤ä»ç˜¦éª¨å¶™å³‹å˜å¾—è†˜è‚¥ä½“å£®ã€‚â€œå¤šäºä¸­å›½ä¸“å®¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç»ˆäºèƒ½å–‚å…»å¥½ç‰²ç•œï¼Œæ—¥å­æœ‰äº†ç›¼å¤´ï¼â€
åœ¨æ¯›é‡Œå¡”å°¼äºšé¦–éƒ½åŠªç“¦å…‹è‚–ç‰¹å‘¨è¾¹ï¼Œä¸€ä½å¸¸æ¥æ¢æœ›èŒè‰å›­çš„è€äººè¯´ï¼Œå¥¹è‡ªå¹¼æœªè§è¿‡æ²™æ¼ ä¹‹å¤–çš„ä¸–ç•Œï¼Œè¿™ç‰‡æ„å¤–ç”Ÿé•¿çš„ç»¿æ„ï¼Œå®›å¦‚æ¢¦ä¸­çš„å›­åœƒã€‚
åœ¨â€œåƒä¸˜ä¹‹å›½â€å¢æ—ºè¾¾ï¼ŒèŒè‰æŠ€æœ¯æ­£æ‚„ç„¶æ”¹å˜æˆåƒä¸Šä¸‡å®¶åº­çš„ç”Ÿæ´»ã€‚å½“åœ°é’å¹´è±æ˜‚å°¼è¾¾æ–¯è‡ªç¦å»ºå†œæ—å¤§å­¦å­¦æˆå½’å›½åï¼Œå¸¦é¢†å›¢é˜Ÿåˆ©ç”¨èŒè‰åŸ¹è‚²è˜‘è‡ï¼Œä¾›åº”å¸‚åœºã€‚çœ‹åˆ°å½“åœ°å­©å­ä»¬å¼€å¿ƒé£Ÿç”¨è˜‘è‡è¥å…»é¤ï¼Œè®°è€…æ›´æ·±åˆ‡ä½“ä¼šåˆ°â€œå¹¸ç¦è‰â€æ‰€æ‰¿è½½çš„æœŸå¾…ã€‚
ä¸€åº§ä½“è‚²åœºï¼Œç­‘æ¢¦åŸºçŸ³ï¼Œç…§äº®å‰ç¨‹ã€‚

è¿™æ˜¯3æœˆ18æ—¥åœ¨è‚¯å°¼äºšé¦–éƒ½å†…ç½—æ¯•æ‹æ‘„çš„å¡”å…°å¡”ä½“è‚²åŸé¡¹ç›®æ–½å·¥ç°åœºã€‚æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€… éŸ©æ—­ æ‘„
è¿™åº§ç”±ä¸­å›½ä¼ä¸šæ‰¿å»ºã€å°†ä½œä¸º2027å¹´éæ´²æ¯ä¸»èµ›åœºä¹‹ä¸€çš„ç°ä»£åŒ–ä½“è‚²ç»¼åˆä½“ï¼Œè‡ªå¥ åŸºä¹‹æ—¥ä¾¿æ‰¿è½½åšæœ›ã€‚è‚¯å°¼äºšæ€»ç»Ÿé²æ‰˜åœ¨è§†å¯Ÿå¼€å·¥ç°åœºæ—¶è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå°†å´›èµ·ä¸€åº§ä¸–ç•Œçº§ä½“è‚²æ®¿å ‚ã€‚
å¡”å…°å¡”ä½“è‚²åŸå»ºè®¾æ•…äº‹ç³»åˆ—çŸ­è§†é¢‘åœ¨ç¤¾äº¤å¹³å°å‘å¸ƒåï¼Œç½‘å‹ç•™è¨€ï¼šâ€œä¸­å›½å§‹ç»ˆä»¥å®é™…è¡ŒåŠ¨åŠ©åŠ›éæ´²å»ºè®¾â€â€œæ„Ÿè°¢ä¸­å›½ï¼ŒæœŸå¾…æ›´å¤šåˆä½œä½³éŸ³â€ã€‚
å¡”å…°å¡”ä½“è‚²åŸæ˜¯ä¸­éåˆä½œçš„ä¸€å¸§ç¼©å½±ã€‚2025å¹´4æœˆï¼Œé²æ‰˜åœ¨è®¿åå‰å¤•æ¥å—æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€…é‡‡è®¿æ—¶è¯´ï¼Œè’™å†…é“è·¯ã€æ‹‰ç©†æ¸¯ç­‰é‡å¤§åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½åˆä½œé¡¹ç›®ä¸ä»…æ”¹å–„äº†è‚¯å°¼äºšå›½å†…çš„äº’è”äº’é€šï¼Œä¹Ÿä¿ƒè¿›äº†ä¸œéåœ°åŒºçš„åŒºåŸŸä¸€ä½“åŒ–å’Œç»æµå‘å±•ã€‚
ä¸€åœºè®ºå›ä¼šï¼Œå¿ƒå£°å…±é¸£ï¼Œæ–°ç¨‹åŒå¯ã€‚

æ¥æºï¼šäººæ°‘æ—¥æŠ¥ã€€å‘å¸ƒï¼š2025-12-30 00:55
ä»Šå¹´æ˜¯ä¸­å›½å’Œé©¬é‡Œå»ºäº¤65å‘¨å¹´ã€‚ä¸­å›½å’Œé©¬é‡Œéƒ½æ‹¥æœ‰æ‚ ä¹…å†å²å’Œç¿çƒ‚æ–‡åŒ–ã€‚è¿‘ä»£ä»¥æ¥ï¼Œä¸¤å›½äººæ°‘ç»è¿‡è‰°è‹¦æ–—äº‰ï¼Œå„è‡ªèµ¢å¾—æ°‘æ—ç‹¬ç«‹å’Œäººæ°‘è§£æ”¾ã€‚1960å¹´é©¬é‡Œç‹¬ç«‹ä¸ä¹…å³åŒä¸­å›½å»ºç«‹äº†å¤–äº¤å…³ç³»ï¼Œæ˜¯æ’’å“ˆæ‹‰ä»¥å—éæ´²æœ€æ—©åŒä¸­å›½å»ºäº¤çš„å›½å®¶ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚2024å¹´9æœˆ2æ—¥ï¼Œä¹ è¿‘å¹³ä¸»å¸­åœ¨åŒ—äº¬äººæ°‘å¤§ä¼šå ‚ä¼šè§æ¥åå‡ºå¸­ä¸­éåˆä½œè®ºå›åŒ—äº¬å³°ä¼šçš„é©¬é‡Œæ€»ç»Ÿæˆˆä¼Šå¡”ã€‚ä¸¤å›½å…ƒé¦–å®£å¸ƒï¼Œå°†ä¸­é©¬å…³ç³»æå‡ä¸ºæˆ˜ç•¥ä¼™ä¼´å…³ç³»ï¼Œæ¨åŠ¨ä¸­é©¬å…³ç³»å‘å±•è¿ˆä¸Šæ–°å°é˜¶ã€‚å»ºäº¤65å¹´æ¥ï¼Œä¸­é©¬äººæ°‘åšå®šæ”¯æŒå½¼æ­¤èµ°ç‹¬ç«‹è‡ªä¸»çš„å‘å±•é“è·¯ï¼Œé«˜æ•ˆå¼€å±•ç»æµç¤¾ä¼šé¢†åŸŸåˆä½œï¼Œå¹¶è‚©ä¿ƒè¿›å…¨çƒå—æ–¹å›¢ç»“å‘å±•ï¼Œæ˜¯çœŸè¯šå‹å¥½ã€æ‚£éš¾ä¸å…±çš„å…„å¼Ÿå’Œä¼™ä¼´ã€‚
ä¸­é©¬æ”¿æ²»äº’ä¿¡å†ä¹…å¼¥åšã€‚ä¸¤å›½åœ¨æ¶‰åŠå½¼æ­¤æ ¸å¿ƒåˆ©ç›Šå’Œé‡å¤§å…³åˆ‡çš„é—®é¢˜ä¸Šç›¸äº’æ”¯æŒï¼Œå…±åŒç»´æŠ¤å¤šè¾¹ä¸»ä¹‰å’Œå›½é™…å…¬å¹³æ­£ä¹‰ã€‚é©¬é‡Œæ”¿åºœé•¿æœŸæªå®ˆä¸€ä¸ªä¸­å›½åŸåˆ™ï¼Œä¸ºæ¢å¤ä¸­åäººæ°‘å…±å’Œå›½åœ¨è”åˆå›½çš„åˆæ³•å¸­ä½ä½œå‡ºé‡è¦è´¡çŒ®ï¼Œåšå®šæ”¯æŒä¸­æ–¹ç»´æŠ¤å›½å®¶ä¸»æƒå’Œé¢†åœŸå®Œæ•´çš„åŠªåŠ›ã€‚ä¸­æ–¹ä»¥å®é™…è¡ŒåŠ¨æ”¯æŒé©¬æ–¹åœ¨ä¸»æƒã€å®‰å…¨ã€å‘å±•æ–¹é¢çš„åˆç†è¯‰æ±‚ï¼Œæ”¯æŒé©¬é‡Œäººæ°‘è‡´åŠ›äºå›½å®¶ç»Ÿä¸€ã€æ°‘æ—æŒ¯å…´çš„æ­£ä¹‰äº‹ä¸šã€‚
ä¸­é©¬åŠ¡å®åˆä½œç¡•æœç´¯ç´¯ã€‚åœ¨é©¬é‡Œç‹¬ç«‹åˆæœŸï¼Œä¸­å›½å…‹æœå›°éš¾ä¸ºé©¬é‡Œæ´å»ºäº†çººç»‡å‚ã€ç³–å‚ã€çš®é©å‚ã€åˆ¶è¯å‚ç­‰å·¥ä¸šå’Œæ°‘ç”Ÿé¡¹ç›®ï¼Œä¸ºé©¬é‡Œç»æµå‘å±•å’Œå·¥ä¸šä½“ç³»å¥ å®šè‰¯å¥½åŸºç¡€ã€‚ä¸­å›½æ´å»ºçš„å·´é©¬ç§‘å›½é™…ä¼šè®®ä¸­å¿ƒã€å·´é©¬ç§‘ç¬¬ä¸‰å¤§æ¡¥ã€é©¬é‡ŒåŒ»é™¢ã€å¡å·´æ‹‰å¤§å­¦åŸã€3Â·26ä½“è‚²åœºç­‰é¡¹ç›®åœ¨é©¬é‡Œç»æµç¤¾ä¼šå‘å±•ä¸­å‘æŒ¥ç€é‡è¦ä½œç”¨ï¼Œæ˜¯é©¬é‡Œäººæ°‘å¿ƒä¸­çš„æ˜æ˜Ÿå·¥ç¨‹ã€‚åŒè¾¹è´¸æ˜“ç¨³æ­¥æå‡ï¼Œ2024å¹´ä¸¤å›½è´¸æ˜“é¢çªç ´10äº¿ç¾å…ƒï¼ŒåŒæ¯”å¢é•¿23%ã€‚ä¸­éåˆä½œè®ºå›åŒ—äº¬å³°ä¼šæå‡ºçš„â€œåå¤§ä¼™ä¼´è¡ŒåŠ¨â€ç›¸å…³é¡¹ç›®åœ¨é©¬é‡Œæœ‰åºå±•å¼€ï¼Œè¨ç¦å…‰ä¼å‚¨èƒ½ç”µç«™ã€â€œæ•°å­—é©¬é‡Œâ€ç­‰é¡¹ç›®æŒç»­æ·±åŒ–ä¸­é©¬åŠ¡å®åˆä½œã€‚ä¸­æ–¹å¼€å±•çš„ä¿®ç¼®å°å­¦ã€æ‰“äº•ç­‰æ°‘ç”Ÿé¡¹ç›®éåŠé©¬é‡Œå„åœ°ï¼Œèµ¢å¾—å½“åœ°æ°‘ä¼—å¹¿æ³›èµèª‰ã€‚
ä¸­é©¬æ°‘é—´å‹å¥½è–ªç«ç›¸ä¼ ã€‚è‡ª1968å¹´ä»¥æ¥ï¼Œä¸­å›½ç´¯è®¡å‘é©¬é‡Œæ´¾é£30æ‰¹åŒ»ç–—é˜Ÿã€åŒ»ç–—äººå‘˜900å¤šäººæ¬¡ï¼Œä¸ºå½“åœ°æ‚£è€…æä¾›åŒ»ç–—æœåŠ¡è¶…è¿‡700ä¸‡äººæ¬¡ï¼Œè¢«é©¬é‡Œæ°‘ä¼—èª‰ä¸ºâ€œä¸œæ–¹ç™½è¡£å¤©ä½¿â€ã€‚å­”å­å­¦é™¢å’Œå­”å­è¯¾å ‚åœ¨é©¬é‡Œæ€èµ·äº†å­¦ä¹ ä¸­æ–‡ã€äº†è§£ä¸­å›½æ–‡åŒ–çš„çƒ­æ½®ã€‚ä¸­æ–¹é€šè¿‡æä¾›æ”¿åºœå¥–å­¦é‡‘ã€ä¸¾åŠåŸ¹è®­ç­ç­‰æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä¸ºé©¬é‡Œå„ç•Œäººå£«å’Œé’å¹´åˆ›é€ èµ´åå­¦ä¹ äº¤æµæœºä¼šï¼Œä¸ºèµ“ç»­ä¸¤å›½ä¼ ç»Ÿå‹è°ŠåŸ¹å…»ç”ŸåŠ›å†›ã€‚
åƒå·æ±Ÿæµ·é˜”ï¼Œé£å¥½æ­£æ‰¬å¸†ã€‚ä¸­éåˆä½œè®ºå›åŒ—äº¬å³°ä¼šä¸ºä¸­éå…³ç³»å‘å±•æŒ‡æ˜äº†æ–¹å‘ã€‚ä¸ä¹…å‰ï¼Œä¸­å›½å…±äº§å…šäºŒåå±Šå››ä¸­å…¨ä¼šæˆåŠŸå¬å¼€ï¼Œä¼šè®®é€šè¿‡äº†â€œåäº”äº”â€è§„åˆ’å»ºè®®ï¼Œæ“˜ç”»äº†ä¸­å›½å¼ç°ä»£åŒ–çš„å…‰æ˜å‰æ™¯ï¼Œå¿…å°†ä¸ºä¸­éå…±é€ç°ä»£åŒ–ä¹‹æ¢¦æ³¨å…¥æ–°åŠ¨èƒ½ã€‚ä¸­æ–¹æ„¿åŒé©¬æ–¹æºæ‰‹åŠªåŠ›ï¼Œè½å®ä¸¤å›½å…ƒé¦–è¾¾æˆçš„é‡è¦å…±è¯†ï¼Œè¿›ä¸€æ­¥æ·±åŒ–æ”¿æ²»äº’ä¿¡ã€å……å®åŠ¡å®åˆä½œã€ä¸°å¯Œäººæ–‡äº¤æµï¼Œåœ¨æ„å»ºæ–°æ—¶ä»£å…¨å¤©å€™ä¸­éå‘½è¿å…±åŒä½“çš„è¿›ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œç»­å†™ä¸­é©¬å‹å¥½æ–°ç¯‡ç« ã€‚ï¼ˆæ¥æºï¼šã€Šäººæ°‘æ—¥æŠ¥ã€‹ï¼Œä½œè€…ä¸ºä¸­å›½é©»é©¬é‡Œå¤§ä½¿æå“ï¼‰

600å¤šå¹´å‰ï¼Œä¸­å›½æ˜ä»£èˆªæµ·å®¶éƒ‘å’Œç‡èˆ¹é˜Ÿä¸ƒä¸‹è¥¿æ´‹ï¼Œè¶³è¿¹æœ€è¿œè‡³éæ´²ä¸œå²¸å’Œçº¢æµ·æ²¿å²¸ï¼Œè°±å†™äº†ä¸­éæ–‡æ˜ä¹ƒè‡³ä¸–ç•Œæ–‡æ˜äº¤æµäº’é‰´çš„å£®ä¸½ç¯‡ç« ã€‚å¦‚ä»Šï¼Œâ€œéƒ‘å’Œå®èˆ¹â€æ‰€æ‰¿è½½çš„æ–‡æ˜äº¤æµå¯¹è¯ä»å†å²èµ°å‘ç°å®ã€‚åœ¨å¹³ç­‰ã€äº’é‰´ã€å¯¹è¯ã€åŒ…å®¹çš„æ–‡æ˜è§‚æŒ‡å¼•ä¸‹ï¼Œä¸­éæºæ‰‹æ‰§ç¬”ï¼Œç»§ç»­ä¹¦å†™â€œæ–‡æ˜å› äº¤æµè€Œå¤šå½©ï¼Œæ–‡æ˜å› äº’é‰´è€Œä¸°å¯Œâ€çš„åŠ¨äººæ–°ç¯‡ã€‚

â€œä¸­å›½å€¡å¯¼çš„â€˜å’Œè€Œä¸åŒâ€™ç†å¿µï¼Œé“å‡ºæ–‡æ˜åŒ…å®¹å…±å­˜çš„å…³é”®ã€‚ä¸­å›½æ‹¥æœ‰æ‚ ä¹…å†å²å’Œæ·±åšæ–‡åŒ–åº•è•´ï¼Œè¿˜ä»¥å¼€æ”¾å¿ƒæ€ä¸ä¸–ç•Œåˆ†äº«ï¼Œä¿ƒè¿›å„å›½ç›¸äº’ç†è§£ã€‚â€å·´ç‰¹å‹’-å¸•è€¶ç‰¹è¯´ã€‚
è¿™æ˜¯2024å¹´5æœˆ14æ—¥åœ¨åŒ—äº¬ä¸­å¤®ç¤¼å“æ–‡ç‰©ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒå±•å…æ‹æ‘„çš„å¡èˆŒå°”å‰æ€»ç»Ÿè©¹å§†æ–¯Â·ç±³æ­‡å°”èµ é€çš„â€œéƒ‘å’Œå®èˆ¹â€æ¨¡å‹ã€‚æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€…æ¨å…‰æ‘„
åœ¨ä¸å¡èˆŒå°”ä¸€æµ·ä¹‹éš”çš„è‚¯å°¼äºšå’Œå¦æ¡‘å°¼äºšï¼Œäººä»¬å‘ç°äº†æ›´åŠ ä¹…è¿œçš„éä¸­æ–‡æ˜å¯¹è¯å°è®°ã€‚æ®æ¹–å—çœé•¿æ²™é“œå®˜çª‘åšç‰©é¦†äººå‘˜è€ƒæ®ï¼Œè¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªéæ´²å›½å®¶æ²¿æµ·åœ°åŒºå‡ºåœŸäº†ä¸­å›½å”ä»£çš„é•¿æ²™çª‘é‡‰å½©ç“·ç‰‡ï¼Œæ¯”éƒ‘å’Œä¸‹è¥¿æ´‹çš„å†å²é˜¶æ®µè¿˜æ—©æ•°ç™¾å¹´ã€‚
ä½äºè¾¾ç´¯æ–¯è¨æ‹‰å§†å¸‚çš„å¦æ¡‘å°¼äºšå›½å®¶åšç‰©é¦†ï¼Œå±•æœ‰å¤šæšä¸­å›½ç“·ç‰‡å’Œå¤šä»½èˆªæµ·å²æ–™å›¾ã€‚åšç‰©é¦†å†å²åˆ†é¦†é¦†é•¿è‚–é©¬é‡ŒÂ·æ‹‰è´¾å¸ƒÂ·è‚–é©¬é‡Œè¯´ï¼Œéƒ‘å’Œèˆ¹é˜Ÿæ¥åˆ°éæ´²ï¼Œä¸ä»…å¸¦æ¥ä¸ç»¸ã€ç“·å™¨å’ŒèŒ¶å¶ç­‰å•†å“ï¼Œæ›´ä¿ƒè¿›äº†æ–‡åŒ–äº¤æµã€‚â€œè¿™ä¸€å£®ä¸¾å¯¹éä¸­æ–‡æ˜äº’é‰´æ„ä¹‰é‡å¤§ï¼Œå°è¯äº†æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç´§å¯†è”ç³»æ—©å·²æ·±æ¤äºæ•°ç™¾å¹´çš„å†å²ä¸­ã€‚â€
â€œè®¸å¤šä¸­å›½æ¸¸å®¢æ…•åè€Œæ¥ï¼Œåªä¸ºäº²çœ¼è§è¯è¿™äº›è·¨è¶Šæ•°ä¸ªä¸–çºªçš„å†å²ä¿¡ç‰©ã€‚å®ƒä»¬ä¸ä»…æ˜¯éä¸­å‹è°Šçš„è§è¯ï¼Œæ›´æ‰¿è½½ç€ä¸¤ä¸ªæ–‡æ˜å¯¹è¯çš„æ°¸æ’è®°å¿†ã€‚â€è‚–é©¬é‡Œè¯´ã€‚

2025å¹´6æœˆ10æ—¥ï¼Œä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°ä¸¾åŠä¸°å¯Œå¤šå½©çš„æ´»åŠ¨ï¼Œåº†ç¥é¦–ä¸ªè”åˆå›½â€œæ–‡æ˜å¯¹è¯å›½é™…æ—¥â€ã€‚è”åˆå›½å†…ç½—æ¯•åŠäº‹å¤„æ€»å¹²äº‹ç­å¤æ‹‰åœ¨çºªå¿µæ´»åŠ¨ä¸­å‘¼åå“åº”é¦–ä¸ªå›½é™…æ—¥å·å¬ï¼Œå¼ºè°ƒå¯¹è¯æ˜¯é€šå¾€å’Œå¹³ä¹‹è·¯ã€‚
å¦æ¡‘å°¼äºšè¾¾ç´¯æ–¯è¨æ‹‰å§†å¤§å­¦ä¸­å›½ç ”ç©¶ä¸­å¿ƒä¸»ä»»æ±‰å¼—è±Â·è«å¸Œè¯´ï¼Œæ¯ç§æ–‡åŒ–éƒ½æœ‰å…¶ç‹¬ç‰¹ä»·å€¼ï¼Œåº”è¯¥ç›¸äº’å°Šé‡ã€äº’å­¦äº’é‰´ã€‚ä¸­å›½æå‡ºçš„ç†å¿µç¬¦åˆå½“ä»Šå›½é™…ç¤¾ä¼šæ¨åŠ¨å¤šå…ƒå…±å­˜ã€åŒ…å®¹å‘å±•çš„æ™®éå…±è¯†ã€‚

â€œå½“ä»Šä¸–ç•Œæ ¼å±€å·²ä¸åŒå¾€æ˜”ï¼Œå„å›½éƒ½åœ¨æ¢ç´¢ç¬¦åˆè‡ªèº«å›½æƒ…çš„ç°ä»£åŒ–é“è·¯ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åº”æ‘’å¼ƒæ–‡æ˜å†²çªè®ºï¼Œæ”¯æŒæ–‡æ˜åŒ…å®¹äº’é‰´ä¸å…±åŒå‘å±•ã€‚â€å¡èˆŒå°”å‰ç¤¾ä¼šå‘å±•å’Œæ–‡åŒ–éƒ¨éƒ¨é•¿è´å°”çº³Â·æ²™å§†æ‹‰è€¶è¯´ã€‚
2025å¹´11æœˆï¼Œâ€œå…¨çƒå—æ–¹â€åª’ä½“æ™ºåº“é«˜ç«¯è®ºå›ä¸­éä¼™ä¼´å¤§ä¼šå…¨ä½“ä¼šè®®åœ¨å—éçº¦ç¿°å†…æ–¯å ¡ä¸¾è¡Œã€‚ä¹Œå¹²è¾¾å‘å±•è§‚å¯Ÿä¸­å¿ƒæ‰§è¡Œä¸»ä»»é˜¿æ‹‰ç»´Â·å¡æ›¼è¾¾åœ¨å‘è¨€ä¸­è¯´ï¼Œéƒ‘å’Œç‡èˆ¹é˜Ÿåˆ°è®¿éæ´²æ—¶ï¼Œå…¶ç›®çš„å¹¶éæ®–æ°‘æˆ–æ å¤ºï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å¼€å±•è´¸æ˜“ä¸å‹å¥½äº¤å¾€ã€‚è¿™ä¸€å†å²äº‹å®å……åˆ†ä½“ç°äº†éä¸­å…³ç³»å§‹ç»ˆå»ºç«‹åœ¨äº’æƒ ä¸åˆä½œåŸºç¡€ä¹‹ä¸Šã€‚
å¡æ›¼è¾¾è¯´ï¼Œåœ¨å›é¡¾å†å²çš„åŒæ—¶ï¼Œæ›´åº”ç€çœ¼æœªæ¥ï¼Œå¯»æ‰¾è¿›ä¸€æ­¥åŠ å¼ºæ–‡æ˜äº’é‰´ä¸æ–‡åŒ–äº¤æµçš„æœºé‡ã€‚ä»–ç‰¹åˆ«æåˆ°ï¼Œå³å°†åˆ°æ¥çš„éä¸­äººæ–‡äº¤æµå¹´å°†ä¸ºåŒæ–¹æ·±åŒ–æ•°å­—ã€åª’ä½“ä¸æ–‡åŒ–åˆä½œæä¾›æ–°å¥‘æœºã€‚
åœ¨å¡èˆŒå°”æ¸”ä¸šå’Œè“è‰²ç»æµéƒ¨éƒ¨é•¿è®©-å¼—æœ—ç´¢ç“¦Â·è´¹æ‹‰é‡Œçš„åŠå…¬å®¤ï¼Œä¸€å¼ éƒ‘å’Œèˆªæµ·è·¯çº¿å›¾æ‘†åœ¨ä¹¦æ¶ä¸Šã€‚èˆªæµ·å›¾ä¸Šæ ‡æ³¨çš„â€œæ…¢å·´æ’’â€â€œéº»æ—åœ°â€ç­‰éæ´²ä¸œæµ·å²¸å¤åœ°åä¸ã€Šæ˜å²Â·éƒ‘å’Œä¼ ã€‹ç›¸äº’å°è¯ï¼Œå‹¾å‹’å‡ºæµ·ä¸Šä¸ç»¸ä¹‹è·¯æ·±åšè€Œæ‚ è¿œçš„æ–‡åŒ–è„‰ç»œã€‚
è¿™æ˜¯2025å¹´3æœˆ17æ—¥åœ¨å¡èˆŒå°”é¦–éƒ½ç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšå¡èˆŒå°”æ¸”ä¸šå’Œè“è‰²ç»æµéƒ¨éƒ¨é•¿è®©-å¼—æœ—ç´¢ç“¦Â·è´¹æ‹‰é‡ŒåŠå…¬å®¤æ‹æ‘„çš„éƒ‘å’Œèˆªæµ·å›¾ã€‚æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€…è‘£æ±Ÿè¾‰æ‘„

è¿‘æ—¥ï¼Œä¸­ä¼æ‰¿å»ºçš„åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰é¦–éƒ½é‡‘æ²™è¨ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯é¡¹ç›®ç´¯è®¡å®Œæˆç¢çŸ³åº•åŸºå±‚æ–½å·¥60å…¬é‡Œï¼Œæ ‡å¿—ç€è¿™ä¸€é‡è¦æ°‘ç”Ÿå·¥ç¨‹å»ºè®¾è¿›å…¥å…¨é¢åŠ é€Ÿé˜¶æ®µã€‚è¿™æ¡æ–°å»ºçš„ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯å…¨é•¿çº¦72å…¬é‡Œï¼Œè®¾è®¡åŒå‘å››è½¦é“ï¼Œå»ºæˆåå°†æå¤§ç¼“è§£é‡‘æ²™è¨äº¤é€šæ‹¥å µï¼Œä¸ºå½“åœ°å±…æ°‘å‡ºè¡Œå¸¦æ¥ä¾¿åˆ©ã€‚

é‡‘æ²™è¨äººå£è¶…è¿‡1700ä¸‡ã€‚ä½œä¸ºå…¨å¸‚è·¨åŒºäº¤é€šçš„â€œä¸»åŠ¨è„‰â€ï¼Œç©¿åŸè€Œè¿‡çš„N1å›½é“ä»…ä¸ºåŒå‘ä¸¤è½¦é“ï¼Œå´æ‰¿æ‹…äº†70%çš„åŸå¸‚äº¤é€šå‹åŠ›ã€‚é«˜å³°æ—¶æ®µï¼ŒåŸæœ¬10åˆ†é’Ÿçš„è½¦ç¨‹ç»å¸¸è¦è€—è´¹1ä¸ªå¤šå°æ—¶ã€‚å½“åœ°ä¸€å®¶ç‰©æµå…¬å¸è´Ÿè´£äººåšè¥¿æ— å¥ˆåœ°è¯´ï¼šâ€œä»å¸‚ä¸­å¿ƒåˆ°éƒŠåŒºä»…22å…¬é‡Œçš„è·¯ç¨‹ï¼Œæ—¥å¸¸é€šè¡Œéœ€è¦3ä¸ªå¤šå°æ—¶ï¼Œè·¯ä¸Šæ‹¥å µå¯¼è‡´ç”Ÿé²œè´§ç‰©æŸè€—ç‡è‡³å°‘å¢åŠ 15%ã€‚â€
2024å¹´6æœˆ22æ—¥ï¼Œåœ¨åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰æ€»ç»Ÿé½å¡å…‹è¿ªå’Œæ€»ç†å›¾å¢å¡å…±åŒè§è¯ä¸‹ï¼Œé‡‘æ²™è¨ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯é¡¹ç›®æ­£å¼å¯åŠ¨ã€‚é¡¹ç›®åˆ†ä¸ºè¥¿å—ç¯çº¿ä¸ä¸œå—ç¯çº¿ä¸¤æ®µï¼Œä¸²è”èµ·é‡‘æ²™è¨å¸‚åŒºä¸å§†å¯Œè’‚ã€å¢å½“å¾·é‡Œç­‰å‘¨è¾¹æ•°åä¸ªæ‘é•‡ï¼Œå…¨çº¿åŒ…å«å¤šåº§æ¡¥æ¢ã€æ¶µæ´åŠé“è·¯å‘¨è¾¹æ²»ç†å·¥ç¨‹ã€‚è¯¥é¡¹ç›®ç”±ååˆšçŸ¿ä¸šè‚¡ä»½æœ‰é™å…¬å¸å‡ºèµ„ï¼Œä¸­åˆšåŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å»ºè®¾è‚¡ä»½æœ‰é™å…¬å¸è´Ÿè´£ç»„ç»‡å®æ–½ï¼Œä¸­é“å…«å±€ç­‰ä¸­èµ„ä¼ä¸šæ‰¿å»ºã€‚
åœ¨é‡‘æ²™è¨è¥¿å—éƒŠåŒºçš„å§†å¯Œè’‚æ‘ï¼Œæ‘æ°‘é©¬è´è±è¯´ï¼šâ€œä»¥å‰ï¼Œä»æˆ‘ä»¬æ‘å»å¸‚åŒºåªæœ‰ä¸€æ¡å‘æ´¼ä¸å¹³çš„åœŸè·¯ï¼Œä¸‹é›¨æ—¶é“è·¯æ³¥æ³ï¼Œå‡ºè¶Ÿé—¨å¾ˆä¸æ–¹ä¾¿ã€‚ç°åœ¨ï¼Œè¿™æ¡åœŸè·¯å› ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯ä¿®å»ºå°†å‡çº§ä¸ºåŒå‘å››è½¦é“çš„å¤§è·¯ã€‚â€å•†è´©ç›–ç‰¹ç±³Â·æ©ä¸œå·´ä¹Ÿæ·±æœ‰ä½“ä¼šï¼šâ€œä»¥å‰å»æ‰¹å‘å¸‚åœºè¿›è´§ï¼Œä»…åœ¨è·¯ä¸Šå°±è¦è€—æ‰å¤§åŠå¤©ï¼Œç”Ÿæ„å¾ˆéš¾åšã€‚ç°åœ¨éƒ¨åˆ†è·¯æ®µä¿®å¥½äº†ï¼Œç”Ÿæ„ä¹Ÿå˜å¥½äº†ã€‚â€
ä½œä¸ºä¸­åˆšâ€œä¸€æ½å­â€åˆä½œæ¡†æ¶ä¸‹çš„é‡ç‚¹åŸºå»ºé¡¹ç›®ï¼Œè¯¥é¡¹ç›®ä¸»è¦é€šè¿‡æŠ€æœ¯è½¬ç§»å’Œäº§ä¸šè”åŠ¨ï¼Œæå‡å½“åœ°å‘å±•èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚ä¸­åˆšåŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å»ºè®¾è‚¡ä»½æœ‰é™å…¬å¸è‘£äº‹é•¿åºé¾™è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯å»ºæˆåï¼Œå°†æå¤§æ”¹å–„é‡‘æ²™è¨äº¤é€šæ‹¥å µçŠ¶å†µï¼Œæå‡åŸå¸‚äº¤é€šè¿è¡Œæ•ˆç‡ã€‚
â€œç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯å»ºæˆåå°†å½»åº•æ‰“ç ´åŸå¸‚å‘å±•åªä¾èµ–ä¸­å¿ƒåŸåŒºçš„æ ¼å±€ã€‚â€åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰å›½å®¶å¤§å‹å·¥ç¨‹å±€å±€é•¿å°¼ç§‘Â·æ©æ‰ä¹ŒÂ·æ©æ‰ä¹Œè¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œè¯¥é¡¹ç›®æ˜¯æ”¿åºœæ”¹å–„æ°‘ç”Ÿã€ä¿ƒè¿›ç»æµå‘å±•çš„æˆ˜ç•¥æ€§å·¥ç¨‹ï¼Œé€šè½¦åé¢„è®¡èƒ½åˆ†æµä¸‰æˆé‡‘æ²™è¨çš„äº¤é€šæµé‡ï¼Œæœ‰æ•ˆç¼“è§£é¦–éƒ½ä¸»åŸåŒºäº¤é€šæ‹¥å µçŠ¶å†µï¼Œé™ä½è¿è¾“æˆæœ¬ï¼Œæå‡é‡‘æ²™è¨ä¸å‘¨è¾¹çœåŒºäº’è”äº’é€šæ°´å¹³ã€‚
å› åœ°åˆ¶å®œï¼Œæ‰“é€ å“è´¨å·¥ç¨‹
æ–½å·¥ä¸­ï¼Œä¸­æ–¹å›¢é˜Ÿå…‹æœå›°éš¾ï¼Œå› åœ°åˆ¶å®œæ”¹è¿›æ–½å·¥å·¥è‰ºï¼Œç¡®ä¿å·¥ç¨‹é«˜è´¨é‡æ¨è¿›ï¼Œä¸­ä¼çš„ä¸“ä¸šæ°´å‡†å’Œæ•¬ä¸šç²¾ç¥èµ¢å¾—åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰å„ç•Œäººå£«çš„ä¸€è‡´å¥½è¯„ã€‚
ä¸­é“å…«å±€é‡‘æ²™è¨é¡¹ç›®éƒ¨è´Ÿè´£äººå¼ å‰‘æ³¢è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œä¸­æ–¹å»ºè®¾å›¢é˜Ÿä»ä¸€å¼€å§‹å°±æ ‘ç«‹ç›®æ ‡â€”â€”æ‰“é€ ä¸€æ¡å¹³æ•´è€ç”¨ã€é€‚é…å½“åœ°æ°”å€™ç‰¹æ€§ã€çœŸæ­£ç»å¾—èµ·æ—¶é—´æ£€éªŒçš„é«˜å“è´¨ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯ã€‚æ–½å·¥æœŸé—´ï¼Œä¸­æ–¹å›¢é˜Ÿå…‹æœçƒ­å¸¦é«˜æ¸©ã€é›¨å­£æ´ªæ°´ç­‰æŒ‘æˆ˜ï¼Œâ€œä»ææ–™é€‰æ‹©åˆ°æ–½å·¥å·¥è‰ºï¼Œä¸­ä¼å…¨åŠ›ä»¥èµ´ç¡®ä¿å·¥ç¨‹è´¨é‡ã€‚â€å¼ å‰‘æ³¢è¯´ã€‚
ä¸ºåº”å¯¹é‡‘æ²™è¨å¸¸å¹´é«˜æ¸©çš„æ°”å€™ç‰¹ç‚¹ï¼Œä¸­æ–¹å›¢é˜Ÿç ”å‘å‡ºé€‚åº”é«˜æ¸©çš„æ²¥é’é…æ–¹ï¼›é’ˆå¯¹å½“åœ°ç²‰æ²™åœŸè¿‡äºæ¾è½¯çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œæ–½å·¥å›¢é˜Ÿåœ¨æ˜“æ¾åŠ¨çš„è¾¹å¡åœ°å¸¦æ¶èµ·è±å½¢éª¨æ¶å½“â€œè„Šæ¢â€ï¼Œå†é“ºè®¾å…­æ£±å—åšâ€œæŠ¤ç”²æ¿â€ï¼Œä»¥â€œåŒä¿é™©â€é™ä½æ»‘å¡éšæ‚£ã€‚
åœ¨ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯K12æ®µçš„å§†å¯Œè’‚æ¡¥å»ºè®¾ä¸­ï¼Œ18æ ¹ç›´å¾„1.5ç±³çš„æ¡©åŸºéœ€è¦é’»ç©¿4ç§ä¸åŒæ€§è´¨çš„å²©å±‚ã€‚â€œéš¾åº¦å¥½æ¯”åœ¨åƒå±‚é…¥é‡Œæ‰“æ¡©ã€‚â€ä¸­é“å…«å±€é‡‘æ²™è¨é¡¹ç›®æ€»å·¥ç¨‹å¸ˆè°­æ¡¥è¯´ï¼Œæ—¢è¦é¢å¯¹ç»†ç ‚å±‚ææ˜“æºƒæ•£çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œåˆè¦ç¨³ç¨³é’»å¼€åšç¡¬å²©å±‚ï¼Œå›¢é˜Ÿé‡‡ç”¨çš„å†²å‡»é’»æˆå­”æŠ€æœ¯æ–¹æ¡ˆæœ€ç»ˆä¸å¤æ‚åœ°è´¨æ¡ä»¶ç²¾å‡†é€‚é…ã€‚ä¸­æ–¹è¿˜å¼•å…¥é€‚é…å½“åœ°ç¯å¢ƒçš„80å¨é—¨å¼èµ·é‡æœºåŠä¸“ç”¨æ¶æ¡¥æœºç­‰ä¸­å›½è£…å¤‡ï¼Œè¿™äº›å¤§å‹è®¾å¤‡çš„åº”ç”¨å¼€åˆ›äº†åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰å¢ƒå†…æ¡¥æ¢å»ºè®¾å·¥è‰ºçš„å…ˆæ²³ã€‚
â€œé¡¹ç›®å……åˆ†å±•ç°äº†ä¸­å›½ä¼ä¸šçš„æŠ€æœ¯å®åŠ›å’Œè´£ä»»æ‹…å½“ã€‚â€åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰å…¬å…±å·¥ç¨‹éƒ¨å®˜å‘˜å¢å¤šç»´å…‹è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œâ€œç›¸ä¿¡è¿™äº›é“è·¯å’Œæ¡¥æ¢ä¼šåƒé‡‘æ²™è¨çš„æ£•æ¦ˆæ ‘ä¸€æ ·ç¨³ç¨³æ‰æ ¹ã€‚â€
æ°‘ç”Ÿâ€œç—›ç‚¹â€ï¼Œå˜æˆå¹¸ç¦â€œæ”¯ç‚¹â€
é‡‘æ²™è¨ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯é¡¹ç›®çš„ç¨³æ­¥æ¨è¿›ï¼Œæ­£åœ¨è§£å†³æ›¾ç»å›°æ‰°å½“åœ°æ°‘ä¼—çš„å‡ºè¡Œéš¾ã€å°±ä¸šéš¾ç­‰ç”Ÿæ´»â€œç—›ç‚¹â€ï¼Œä¸ºæ°‘ç”Ÿæ”¹å–„æä¾›åšå®â€œæ”¯ç‚¹â€ã€‚
é¡¹ç›®æ–½å·¥ä¸­ï¼Œä¸­æ–¹å»ºè®¾å›¢é˜Ÿåœ¨ä¿è¯å·¥ç¨‹è¿›åº¦ä¸è´¨é‡çš„åŒæ—¶ï¼Œè®¤çœŸå±¥è¡Œç¤¾ä¼šè´£ä»»ï¼ŒæŒ‰ç…§â€œä¸­æ–¹æŠ€æœ¯+æœ¬åœ°äººåŠ›â€æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œåœ¨æ–½å·¥è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å……åˆ†å¸çº³å½“åœ°æ°‘ä¼—å°±ä¸šï¼Œå¼€å±•æŠ€èƒ½åŸ¹è®­ï¼ŒåŸ¹å…»ç®¡é“å·¥ã€é’¢ç­‹å·¥ã€ç”µå·¥ã€ç„Šå·¥ã€æœºæ¢°ç»´ä¿®å·¥ç­‰å½“åœ°æŠ€æœ¯äººæ‰ï¼Œç•™ä¸‹äº†â€œå¸¦ä¸èµ°çš„å‘å±•èƒ½åŠ›â€ã€‚
ä¸­åˆšåŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å»ºè®¾è‚¡ä»½æœ‰é™å…¬å¸æ€»ç»ç†ä½•ä¿®ä¹‰ä»‹ç»ï¼Œæˆªè‡³ç›®å‰ï¼Œè¯¥é¡¹ç›®å·²ç´¯è®¡å¸¦åŠ¨å½“åœ°3000ä½™äººå°±ä¸šï¼ŒåŸ¹å…»å‡º10å¤šä¸ªå·¥ç§400ä½™åæŠ€æœ¯äººæ‰ã€‚â€œæ˜¯ä¸­å›½ä¼ä¸šæ•™ç»™æˆ‘ä»¬ä¿®è·¯æŠ€èƒ½ï¼Œç»™äº†æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨å®¶é—¨å£å°±ä¸šçš„æœºä¼šã€‚â€å½“åœ°å‘˜å·¥å¡ç¼ªå°”è¯´ï¼Œä»–å·²èƒ½ç†Ÿç»ƒæ“ä½œæ‘Šé“ºæœºã€‚
ç›®å‰ï¼Œéƒ¨åˆ†è·¯æ®µå·²æŠ•å…¥ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œæ”¹å–„äº†å½“åœ°å±…æ°‘çš„å‡ºè¡Œæ¡ä»¶ï¼Œæœ‰æ•ˆèŠ‚çœäº†é€šå‹¤æ—¶é—´ã€‚â€œæ–°é“è·¯å¸¦æ¥æ–°ç”Ÿæ´»ã€‚â€åœ¨ç±³è…¾è¿ªé•‡æ–°è½æˆçš„å»ºæå¸‚åœºé‡Œï¼Œåº—ä¸»éœ²è¥¿å‘Šè¯‰è®°è€…ï¼Œå¥¹çš„ç“·ç –ç”Ÿæ„æ¯”å»å¹´å¢é•¿äº†3å€ï¼Œâ€œè¿‡å»å®¢æˆ·æ€»æŠ±æ€¨è¿è¾“æˆæœ¬å¤ªé«˜ï¼Œç°åœ¨æ‰¹å‘å•†ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡ç¯çº¿å…¬è·¯é€è´§ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„å”®ä»·ä¸‹é™äº†15%ã€‚â€
æèµ·æ–°è·¯å¸¦æ¥çš„å˜åŒ–ï¼Œå½“åœ°ä¸€æ‰€å­¦æ ¡çš„å­¦ç”Ÿç›åˆ©äºšå…´å¥‹ä¸å·²ï¼šâ€œä»¥å‰ä¸Šå­¦è·¯ä¸Šæ€»ä¼šç²˜ä¸€è„šæ³¥ï¼Œè‡ªä»ä¿®äº†è¿™æ¡å…¬è·¯ï¼Œæˆ‘åˆ°å­¦æ ¡æ—¶é‹å­è¿˜å¹²å¹²å‡€å‡€ã€‚â€è¯¥æ ¡æ ¡é•¿æ¯”å®‰å¼—å°¼Â·å¢å…‹å·´è¯´ï¼šâ€œå­¦æ ¡æœ‰çº¦300åå°å­¦ç”Ÿå’Œ250åä¸­å­¦ç”Ÿï¼Œç°æœ‰çš„7é—´æ•™å®¤æ ¹æœ¬ä¸å¤Ÿç”¨ã€‚ä¸­å›½ä¼ä¸šæ­£ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬å»ºé€ 10é—´æ–°çš„æ•™å®¤ã€‚â€

åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰å›½åŠ¡éƒ¨é•¿å…¼èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­éƒ¨é•¿é©¬å…‹Â·åŸƒåŸºæ‹‰Â·åˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥æ—¥å‰åœ¨åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰é¦–éƒ½é‡‘æ²™è¨æ¥å—æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€…ä¸“è®¿æ—¶è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œåˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰åŒä¸­å›½çš„åˆä½œå·²ä»ä¼ ç»ŸåŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å’Œé¡¹ç›®å»ºè®¾ï¼Œæ‹“å±•è‡³èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­å’Œé’å¹´å°±ä¸šé¢†åŸŸï¼Œè¿ˆå‘æ›´åŠ æ³¨é‡æŠ€èƒ½åŸ¹è‚²ä¸å°±ä¸šå¯¹æ¥çš„æ–°é˜¶æ®µã€‚
åˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥æ—¥å‰å‡ºå¸­äº†ä¸­å›½â€”åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰èŒä¸šæŠ€æœ¯æ•™è‚²åŸ¹è®­å¤§ä¼šã€‚ä»–åœ¨ä¼šå‰å¯¹æ–°åç¤¾è®°è€…è¯´ï¼Œå½“å‰åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰æ­£åŠ å¿«æ¨è¿›çŸ¿ä¸šã€åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å’ŒåŸå¸‚å»ºè®¾ç­‰ä¸€ç³»åˆ—é‡ç‚¹é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œå¯¹æŠ€æœ¯å·¥äººå’Œä¸“ä¸šæŠ€èƒ½äººæ‰çš„éœ€æ±‚æ—¥ç›Šè¿«åˆ‡ã€‚ä¸€é¡¹åˆæ ¼çš„åŸ¹è®­ã€ä¸€ç§è·å¾—è®¤å¯çš„æŠ€èƒ½ï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿä¸ºé’å¹´æ‰“å¼€å°±ä¸šä¹‹é—¨ã€‚
åˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥è¿‘æ—¥èµ°è®¿äº†ä¸ŠåŠ ä¸¹åŠ çœå’Œå¢é˜¿æ‹‰å·´çœçš„å¤šå®¶ä¸­èµ„ä¼ä¸šï¼Œä»–å‘ç°è¿™äº›ä¼ä¸šå¤§å¤šè®¾æœ‰æ¡ä»¶å®Œå–„ã€æ°´å¹³è¾ƒé«˜çš„åŸ¹è®­ä¸­å¿ƒã€‚â€œå…¶ä¸­ä¸€äº›åŸ¹è®­ä¸­å¿ƒåŸæœ¬é¢å‘ä¼ä¸šå†…éƒ¨å‘˜å·¥ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å·²ä¸è¿™äº›ä¼ä¸šè¾¾æˆå…±è¯†ï¼Œä»æ˜å¹´å¼€å§‹ï¼Œä¸€äº›åŸ¹è®­é¡¹ç›®å°†é€æ­¥é¢å‘åˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰ç¤¾ä¼šã€‚â€
åˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥è¯´ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å¤šåˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰é’å¹´å°†æœ‰æœºä¼šè¿›å…¥é«˜æ°´å¹³çš„åŸ¹è®­ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œæ¥å—ä¼˜è´¨å¸ˆèµ„çš„æŒ‡å¯¼ï¼Œå¹¶ç›´æ¥å¯¹æ¥å°±ä¸šå²—ä½ã€‚â€œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„é’å¹´å°†å› æ­¤çœŸæ­£ä»åŸ¹è®­ä¸­è·ç›Šï¼Œå¹¶è·å¾—å·¥ä½œæœºä¼šã€‚â€
åˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œåˆšæœï¼ˆé‡‘ï¼‰ä¸ä¸­å›½åœ¨èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­é¢†åŸŸçš„åˆä½œå¹¶éä¸´æ—¶å®‰æ’ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å»ºç«‹åœ¨é•¿æœŸäº¤æµçš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šã€‚æ—©åœ¨2016å¹´ï¼Œä»–å°±æ›¾èµ´åæ¥å—æ”¿ç­–è§„åˆ’å’Œå®è§‚ç»æµé¢†åŸŸçš„åŸ¹è®­ï¼Œä»–å¯¹ä¸­å›½åœ¨å‘å±•è§„åˆ’å’Œç»æµæ²»ç†æ–¹é¢çš„ç»éªŒæœ‰äº†æ›´ç›´è§‚è®¤è¯†ã€‚
2024å¹´ï¼Œåˆ©å­”æ¯”å¥¥èµ´åå‡ºå¸­ä¸–ç•ŒèŒä¸šæŠ€æœ¯æ•™è‚²å‘å±•å¤§ä¼šï¼Œå¹¶å®åœ°è€ƒå¯Ÿä¸­å›½èŒä¸šæ•™è‚²ä½“ç³»ä¸äº§ä¸šå‘å±•ï¼Œå°±èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­ã€æŠ€èƒ½å¯¹æ¥å’Œé’å¹´å°±ä¸šç­‰è®®é¢˜ä¸ä¸­æ–¹æ·±å…¥äº¤æµã€‚ä»–è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œè¿™äº›äº¤æµä¸ºä¸¤å›½åœ¨èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­é¢†åŸŸå¼€å±•åŠ¡å®åˆä½œå¥ å®šäº†åŸºç¡€ï¼Œç›¸å…³åˆä½œæœºåˆ¶æ­£ä»ä¹¦é¢åè®®é€æ­¥è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºå…·ä½“æˆæœã€‚

éæ´²ä»ä¸­è·å¾—çš„å…³é”®å¯ç¤ºåœ¨äºï¼ŒåŸ¹å…»ç±»ä¼¼çš„æˆ˜ç•¥å®šåŠ›ã€‚é€šè¿‡å¯¹ç ”ç©¶æœºæ„ã€å…ˆè¿›æŠ€æœ¯ã€èŒä¸šåŸ¹è®­åŠæ•°å­—åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½è¿›è¡Œæœ‰ç›®çš„çš„é•¿æœŸæŠ•å…¥ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åŸ¹è‚²å¯Œæœ‰æ´»åŠ›çš„ç”Ÿæ€ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ŒåŠ©åŠ›æœ¬åœŸä¼ä¸šæå‡åˆ›æ–°èƒ½åŠ›ã€å¢åŠ é™„åŠ å€¼å¹¶èå…¥å…¨çƒä»·å€¼é“¾ã€‚
çœŸæ­£çš„å‘å±•å¿…é¡»åšæŒä»¥äººæ°‘ä¸ºä¸­å¿ƒã€‚ä¸­å›½çš„å‘å±•æ¨¡å¼æ—¥ç›Šæ³¨é‡æ•™è‚²å…¬å¹³ä¸è´¨é‡ã€ç¤¾ä¼šå®‰å…¨ç½‘çš„æ‰©å±•ã€åŒ»ç–—æœåŠ¡çš„å¯åŠæ€§ä»¥åŠç¼©å°åœ°åŒºå·®è·çš„é’ˆå¯¹æ€§æªæ–½ã€‚è¿™å¯¹éæ´²å›½å®¶çš„å¯ç¤ºååˆ†æ˜ç¡®ï¼šç»æµå¢é•¿è‹¥ä¸èƒ½åˆ‡å®ã€å¹¿æ³›åœ°æ”¹å–„å›½æ°‘ç”Ÿæ´»æ°´å¹³ã€å®‰å…¨ä¿éšœä¸å‘å±•æœºä¼šï¼Œç»ˆå°†æ˜¯ä¸å¯æŒç»­çš„ã€‚

è¿™å°±æ˜¯åæ¥é—»åä¸–ç•Œçš„å¦èµé“è·¯ã€‚å°¼é›·å°”æ›¾æ„ŸåŠ¨åœ°è¯´ï¼šâ€œå†å²ä¸Šå¤–å›½äººåœ¨éæ´²ä¿®å»ºé“è·¯ï¼Œéƒ½æ˜¯ä¸ºæ å¤ºéæ´²çš„è´¢å¯Œã€‚è€Œä¸­å›½äººç›¸åï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å¸®åŠ©æˆ‘ä»¬å‘å±•æ°‘æ—ç»æµã€‚â€
å¡ç¿è¾¾ä¹Ÿå›å¿†è¯´ï¼šâ€œæˆ‘å’Œå°¼é›·å°”æ€»ç»Ÿä¸€åŒå»è¥¿æ–¹å›½å®¶ï¼Œå‘Šè¯‰ä»–ä»¬èµæ¯”äºšå’Œå¦æ¡‘å°¼äºšéœ€è¦è¿™æ¡é“è·¯ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œè¥¿æ–¹å›½å®¶æ‹’ç»äº†æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼Œå‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸è¦æœŸæœ›æœ‰è¿™æ ·ä¸€æ¡é“è·¯ã€‚ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬å»åŒ—äº¬è§äº†æ¯›æ³½ä¸œå’Œå‘¨æ©æ¥ã€‚ä»–ä»¬åšå®šåœ°è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œâ€˜æˆ‘ä»¬å’Œä½ ä»¬ä¸€åŒå»ºè¿™æ¡é“è·¯ã€‚â€™äºæ˜¯ï¼Œä¸­å›½å…„å¼Ÿå§å¦¹ä»¬æ¥äº†ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€åŒæ‹¼æã€‚ä½ çœ‹ï¼Œè¿™ç§å‹è°Šå¤šä¹ˆå•çº¯ã€‚å½“å…¶ä»–äººéƒ½è®¤ä¸ºä¸å¯èƒ½çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å»ºæˆäº†è¿™æ¡é“è·¯ã€‚è¿˜æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆèƒ½è¶…è¿‡è¿™ç§å‹è°Šå‘¢ï¼Ÿâ€
æ˜¯å•Šï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆèƒ½è¶…è¿‡è¿™ç§å‹è°Šå‘¢ï¼Ÿ
ä¹Ÿæ­£æ˜¯è¿™æ¬¡è®¿é—®ä¸­å›½å›å›½åï¼Œå¡ç¿è¾¾ä¾¿åˆ›é€ æ€§æå‡ºâ€œå…¨å¤©å€™æœ‹å‹â€è¿™ä¸ªåè¯ã€‚ä»æ­¤ï¼Œâ€œå…¨å¤©å€™æœ‹å‹â€ï¼Œè¢«å¤šæ¬¡åœ¨ä¸åŒåœºåˆç”¨æ¥å½¢å®¹ä¸­èµã€ä¸­éå…³ç³»ã€‚çœ‹æ–°åç¤¾çš„æŠ¥é“ï¼Œåœ¨å¡ç¿è¾¾çš„å®¶ä¸­ï¼Œä¸€ç›´æ‘†æ”¾ç€ä»–ä¸æ¯›æ³½ä¸œä¸»å¸­ä¼šè§æ—¶çš„åˆå½±ã€‚
æ–°åç¤¾çš„ä¸€ç¯‡æŠ¥é“ï¼Œè¿˜æåˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªç»†èŠ‚ï¼š
æ¯æœ‰ä¸­å›½æœ‹å‹åˆ°è®¿èµæ¯”äºšï¼Œåªè¦èº«ä½“æ¡ä»¶å…è®¸ï¼Œå¡ç¿è¾¾éƒ½ä¼šçƒ­æƒ…æ¥å¾…ã€‚ä»–ä¼šç”¨æ ‡å¿—æ€§é¥°ç‰©ç™½æ‰‹å¸•æŠšæ‘¸æ¯ä½åˆ°è®¿æœ‹å‹çš„é¢å¤´ï¼Œé€ä¸Šç¥ç¦ï¼Œå’Œä¸­å›½æœ‹å‹ç•…è°ˆèµä¸­å‹è°Šçš„å†å²å’Œä»Šå¤©ã€‚
æœ‰æ—¶ï¼Œä»–è¿˜ä¼šä¸ºå¤§å®¶å¼¹èµ·å‰ä»–æˆ–è€…é’¢ç´ï¼Œé«˜å”±ç”±ä»–å¡«è¯çš„æ­Œæ›²ã€Šå›¢ç»“ä¸€å¿ƒã€‹ï¼Œå…±åŒç¥æ„¿ä¸¤å›½å…³ç³»ä¸æ–­å‘å±•ã€‚è¯åˆ«æ—¶ï¼Œä»–ä¼šåšæŒé€åˆ°é—¨å¤–ï¼Œå‘æ¯ä¸€ä½ä¸­å›½æœ‹å‹æŒ¥èˆç™½æ‰‹å¸•ï¼Œç›®é€å¤§å®¶è¿œå»â€¦â€¦ä½œä¸ºèµæ¯”äºšçš„å›½çˆ¶ï¼Œå¡ç¿è¾¾å°¤å…¶è®©äººå°Šæ•¬çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œ1991å¹´é€‰ä¸¾é­é‡æŒ«è´¥åï¼Œä»–æ²¡æœ‰æ‹æ ˆï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æ¯…ç„¶äº¤å‡ºäº†æƒåŠ›ã€‚å°½ç®¡ä»–åæ¥ä¹Ÿé­é‡è¿‡æ”¿æ²»è¿«å®³ï¼Œä½†ä¸€ç›´å¦ç„¶ä»¥å¯¹â€¦â€¦
ä»–ç¦»å¼€äº†æ”¿æ²»èˆå°ä¸­å¤®ï¼Œä½†å´èµ¢å¾—äº†æ›´å¤šäººçš„å°Šé‡ã€‚ç½‘ç»œä¸Šè¿˜æœ‰ä¸å°‘çŸ­è§†é¢‘ï¼Œå¹´äº‹å·²é«˜çš„å¡ç¿è¾¾ï¼Œæ‹„ç€æ‹æ–ï¼Œåœ¨äººä»¬çš„å–å½©å£°ä¸­ï¼Œè·³èµ·æ¬¢å¿«çš„éæ´²èˆè¹ˆâ€¦â€¦

President ofÂ Russia
TheÂ President ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation is theÂ head ofÂ state andÂ guarantor ofÂ theÂ Constitution andÂ ofÂ human andÂ civil rights andÂ freedoms.
TheÂ President is elected forÂ aÂ 6-year term byÂ theÂ Russian Federationâ€™s
citizens onÂ theÂ basis ofÂ universal, equal andÂ direct suffrage byÂ secret
ballot.
Vladimir Putin.
Oath ofÂ theÂ President ofÂ Russia
â€œInÂ performing myÂ duties asÂ theÂ President ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation, IÂ pledge toÂ respect andÂ protect theÂ rights andÂ liberties ofÂ every citizen; toÂ observe andÂ protect theÂ Constitution ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation; toÂ protect theÂ sovereignty andÂ independence, security andÂ integrity ofÂ theÂ state andÂ toÂ serve theÂ people faithfully.â€
President's Authority andÂ Duties
TheÂ status ofÂ theÂ President ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation is defined inÂ Chapter Four ofÂ theÂ Constitution.
TheÂ President shall be theÂ head ofÂ state andÂ theÂ guarantor ofÂ theÂ Constitution andÂ ofÂ civil andÂ human rights andÂ liberties. He shall take measures toÂ protect theÂ sovereignty ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation, its independence andÂ integrity andÂ toÂ ensure theÂ concerted functioning andÂ interaction ofÂ all bodies ofÂ state power.
TheÂ President shall define theÂ basic domestic policy guidelines ofÂ theÂ state.
TheÂ President shall define theÂ basic foreign policy guidelines ofÂ theÂ state.
TheÂ President shall be theÂ Supreme Commander-in-Chief ofÂ theÂ Armed Forces.
TheÂ President shall resolve issues ofÂ citizenship ofÂ theÂ Russian Federation, award state decorations andÂ grant pardons.

Vladimir Putin

AtÂ this moment, asÂ we stand onÂ theÂ threshold ofÂ theÂ New Year, we all feel theÂ passage ofÂ time.
Before us lies theÂ future, andÂ what it holds largely depends onÂ us.
We draw strength from
within ourselves andÂ from those who stand beside usÂ â€“ those who are dear andÂ close toÂ our heartsÂ â€“ andÂ we are always ready toÂ lend our shoulder inÂ return. This
mutual support gives us confidence that all our aspirations, hopes, andÂ plans
will definitely be realised.
Naturally, each ofÂ us has personal, unique dreams, very special inÂ their own way. Yet they are
inseparable from theÂ destiny ofÂ our Motherland andÂ from theÂ sincere desire toÂ be
ofÂ service toÂ it.
ForÂ we are unitedÂ â€“
theÂ people ofÂ Russia. TheÂ labour, achievements, andÂ successes ofÂ each ofÂ us add
new chapters toÂ its thousand-year history, while theÂ strength ofÂ our unity
determines theÂ sovereignty andÂ security ofÂ our Fatherland, its development, andÂ its future.
TheÂ New Year is,
above all, aÂ time when we hope forÂ theÂ best, forÂ goodness andÂ good luck. It is
aÂ special andÂ magical holiday, when we open our hearts toÂ love, friendship, andÂ compassion, toÂ sympathy andÂ generosity.
We strive toÂ bring

You have taken upon

OnÂ this New Yearâ€™s Eve, millions ofÂ people across Russia, IÂ assure you, are

is aÂ strong indicator ofÂ confidence andÂ trust onÂ theÂ part ofÂ our beneficiaries.
What are our areas ofÂ focus andÂ our

benefits, offering free legal assistance, andÂ arranging medical care, including
health resort treatment when needed. Special care is provided forÂ those who are
injured, severely wounded, orÂ disabled. They receive modern prostheticsÂ â€“
including devices not listed onÂ theÂ federal programmeÂ â€“ or, if necessary, we
pay anÂ additional fee toÂ theÂ Social Fund toÂ secure aÂ certificate, allowing theÂ individual
toÂ obtain prosthetics that restore asÂ much functionality asÂ possible.
This marks aÂ major advancement inÂ theÂ prosthetic field, which has evolved considerably over theÂ past year andÂ aÂ half asÂ we established aÂ standard forÂ prosthetic care. We are now funding not
just theÂ prosthesis itself, but aÂ full spectrum ofÂ services, including
rehabilitation, pre-fitting preparation, fitting, andÂ training inÂ prosthetic
use. Thanks toÂ this comprehensive approach, our heroes can now genuinely lead

During theÂ prosthetic industry
exhibition atÂ theÂ Federation Council, Valentina Matviyenko andÂ IÂ were touring
theÂ displays when we met some ofÂ our service members who, despite serious
injuries, had chosen toÂ continue serving inÂ theÂ Ministry ofÂ Defence. They
shared how they had run aÂ half marathonÂ â€“ nearly 22 kilometresÂ â€“ andÂ were
training forÂ aÂ full marathon. Ms Matviyenko rightly remarked, â€œWhat kind ofÂ disabled persons are they? Few ofÂ those here could perform theÂ work these guys
do.â€ AndÂ she was absolutely right. Therefore, reviewing regulations, including
legislative ones, has now become aÂ routine part ofÂ our work becauseâ€¦
Vladimir Putin
: Any revisions must not, under any
circumstances, infringe theÂ rights ofÂ our guys.
Anna Tsivileva
: OfÂ course.
Vladimir Putin
: These changes should serve only toÂ improve andÂ stabilise their situation, never toÂ make it worse.
Anna Tsivileva
: Exactly. Our initiatives are
driven entirely byÂ theÂ veteransâ€™ own requests; they do not infringe their
rights but instead provide them with additional opportunities. We often receive
inquiries onÂ key issues such asÂ acquiring new skills, retraining, andÂ further
education. This also extends toÂ employment andÂ resocialisation, aiming forÂ theÂ full integration ofÂ individuals into society, regardless ofÂ their disabilities.
InÂ other words, we have
fundamentally reshaped societyâ€™s perception ofÂ people with disabilities. They
are no longer seen merely asÂ individuals inÂ need ofÂ help, but asÂ people with
theÂ opportunity toÂ lead active lives, benefit theÂ state, andÂ fully pursue their
goals andÂ aspirations. This represents anÂ entirely new mindset, one inspired byÂ theÂ veterans themselves through their proactive approach toÂ life andÂ their
determination toÂ continue serving theÂ state, even inÂ civilian roles.
This [presentation] briefly covers our spheres
ofÂ activity inÂ figures. One ofÂ them is medical assistance. We consider it
important toÂ conduct aÂ medical examination ofÂ those who return [from theÂ special military operation] because medical support they will receive from
healthcare facilities depends onÂ theÂ state ofÂ their health. Based onÂ theÂ results ofÂ medical examination ofÂ 65,000 such people, we have identified health
issues inÂ 55,000 cases andÂ new medical conditions inÂ 12,000 cases. Checking up
onÂ your health is really very important, especially since our heroes do not pay
much attention toÂ their health. Like other people, they sometimes have latent health
issues. If left unattended, they can eventually reactivate, whereas
comprehensive health screening helps young people take care ofÂ their health,
improving their health orÂ dealing with medical problems that got worse during
theÂ hostilities.
TheÂ family factor is extremely important.
According toÂ statistics, rehabilitation is much more effective when you have aÂ close relative byÂ your side. We encourage families toÂ accompany our heroes
during rehabilitation programmes andÂ even cover theÂ cost ofÂ these trips.
Other issues have toÂ do with providing
technical means ofÂ rehabilitation. It is also important that we help improve
living conditions inÂ houses andÂ flats where people with disabilities live. This
is very important; it makes everyday life more comfortable forÂ them andÂ their
families. This includes specialised kitchens, bathrooms, special openings, andÂ smart home equipment. If they decide toÂ work from home, which some ofÂ them do,
especially those who are wheelchair-bound orÂ have lost their eyesight, we
provide theÂ necessary equipment so that they can work from home andÂ also
receive new competencies, forÂ example, online.
We have aÂ wonderful programme used atÂ School
21, Sberbankâ€™s school ofÂ digital technology, where IT professionals, including
those who were seriously wounded orÂ have lost their eyesight, are trained
remotely.
Speaking about prosthetic devices, our men are
good athletes seriously engaged inÂ sports.
AsÂ forÂ retraining andÂ employment, it is anÂ extremely important sphere, asÂ IÂ have pointed out. Moreover, it is very
important forÂ us toÂ help our veterans expand their horizons. InÂ this photo you
can see our veteran, aÂ long-haul driver. We travelled with him inÂ his KAMAZ
truck. TheÂ KAMAZ manufacturer has started making hand-controlled trucks andÂ buses, including public transport, which we have seen atÂ theÂ Abilympics
competition inÂ Kazan, so that our veterans can use prosthetic legs andÂ arms toÂ resume their profession.
OfÂ course, there is great demand forÂ our
programme ofÂ providing vehicles toÂ double amputees. Our men not only gladly use
them toÂ work andÂ spend time with their families but also willingly take part inÂ rallies andÂ even take extreme driving courses.
Certainly, we engage our veterans inÂ sporting
andÂ cultural events. Sports play aÂ vital role forÂ them. We have individuals
with prosthetics who go mountaineering. There was anÂ instance this year ofÂ them
climbing Mount Elbrus. We have aÂ team that plays rugby andÂ goes skiing, having
mastered these sports while using prosthetics. They also take part inÂ snowboarding. Indeed, theÂ demand forÂ active sports is very high
This serves not only asÂ aÂ means ofÂ improving
health, but also asÂ aÂ tool forÂ resocialisation, asÂ it transforms aÂ combat
brotherhood into aÂ sporting one. They come together, share experience, support
each other, feel much more atÂ ease andÂ confident, and, ofÂ course, challenge one

actively.
Regional governors also provide active support,
andÂ we regularly hold Defenders ofÂ theÂ Fatherland Cup competitions.
AÂ particularly important area is our veteransâ€™
participation inÂ theÂ patriotic education ofÂ young people andÂ inÂ preserving theÂ memory ofÂ our heroes, their comrades-in-arms. Memorial plaques are being established,
andÂ various projects are being developed that truthfully convey theÂ story ofÂ aÂ comradeâ€™s feat. We have already published anÂ entire trilogyÂ â€“ three books

Anna Tsivileva
: Yes, they are theÂ authors.
These books have now been eagerly taken up byÂ our film directors andÂ producers, with plays being staged inÂ theÂ regions based

IÂ would also like toÂ note that we have actively

This is particularly important work, andÂ it

Through theÂ Defenders ofÂ theÂ Fatherland

That is our objective here.
Furthermore, forÂ those who continue toÂ serve

This is very important.
Another project we have implemented with you is

Many ofÂ theÂ women who have themselves lost

AÂ particularly sensitive issue has also been

Pursuant toÂ theÂ Ministerâ€™s instruction, we are
actively digitalising theÂ Defence Ministryâ€™s operations, specifically social
support mechanisms. AÂ key example is theÂ certificate ofÂ participation inÂ theÂ special
military operation. Previously, obtaining this document involved months ofÂ bureaucratic procedures. Now, it is accessible almost instantly with aÂ single

Furthermore, we are developing aÂ unified data

We would also like toÂ make aÂ proposal.

Vladimir Putin:

Anna Tsivileva:

AsÂ forÂ theÂ first group, this is

IÂ would like toÂ thank you andÂ everyone working atÂ theÂ foundation, not only forÂ theÂ results you have achieved,

Director General ofÂ theÂ Znaniye (Knowledge)
Society Maxim Dreval presented theÂ results ofÂ theÂ Rodnaya Igrushka (Native Toy)
nationwide competition, aimed atÂ developing games andÂ toys rooted inÂ traditional Russian spiritual andÂ moral values. This year, around 150,000 such

forÂ preschool institutions. Maxim Dreval also spoke about continued efforts toÂ promote theÂ mobile game Say It inÂ Russian, which aims toÂ popularise theÂ Russian
language among young people andÂ reduce theÂ use ofÂ Anglicisms.
TheÂ meeting participants also

byÂ MarchÂ 1, 2026; preparations forÂ theÂ first International Forum ofÂ School
Librarians, scheduled toÂ take place inÂ Moscow inÂ December 2025; measures toÂ improve theÂ quality ofÂ training forÂ primary school teachers; theÂ opening ofÂ aÂ cultural andÂ educational interactive space forÂ theÂ promotion ofÂ theÂ Russian

Events
Meeting ofÂ theÂ Commission forÂ Veteran Affairs
Deputy Prime Minister
Tatyana Golikova held aÂ regular meeting ofÂ theÂ Presidential Commission onÂ Veteransâ€™ Affairs. TheÂ discussion focused onÂ theÂ provision ofÂ medical care toÂ veterans ofÂ theÂ Great Patriotic War andÂ participants inÂ theÂ special military
operation.
November 14, 2025
11:20
InÂ Russia, theÂ provision ofÂ medical
care toÂ veterans ofÂ theÂ Great Patriotic War andÂ equivalent categories ofÂ citizens is under ongoing monitoring. AsÂ ofÂ OctoberÂ 1, routine medical
examinations have been conducted forÂ more than 124,000 veterans ofÂ theÂ Great
Patriotic War, including 67,700 who received home visits. Subsequently, based
onÂ theÂ results ofÂ these examinations, medical care was provided toÂ 107,000
veterans, with 66,000 receiving treatment inÂ their homes.
Special attention is also given toÂ those who defended theÂ country during theÂ special military operation. AÂ new
section, Procedure forÂ Providing Medical Care toÂ Combat Veterans, has been
incorporated into theÂ state programme forÂ guaranteeing free medical care toÂ citizens forÂ 2025â€“2027. This procedure grants combat veterans priority access
toÂ all types ofÂ medical care.
Key provisions also include access
toÂ spa treatment, theÂ right toÂ choose aÂ convenient primary healthcare facility
with aÂ designated personal coordinator, theÂ right toÂ consultation with aÂ medical psychologist atÂ all stages ofÂ care, andÂ various aspects related toÂ routine
medical examinations andÂ follow-up forÂ veterans.
Following theÂ meeting, aÂ number ofÂ instructions were issued toÂ theÂ Ministry ofÂ Health toÂ be implemented inÂ coordination with theÂ regions.

TITLE: Meeting ofÂ theÂ Council forÂ theÂ Implementation ofÂ State Demographic andÂ Family Policy â€¢ President ofÂ Russia

Events
Meeting ofÂ theÂ Council forÂ theÂ Implementation ofÂ State Demographic andÂ Family Policy
TheÂ President attended
theÂ first meeting ofÂ theÂ Council forÂ theÂ Implementation ofÂ State
Demographic andÂ Family Policy.
October 23, 2025
14:40
TheÂ Kremlin, Moscow
TheÂ agenda includes regional experience, measures toÂ support student
families, theÂ introduction ofÂ corporate demographic standards, theÂ protection
ofÂ reproductive health, andÂ proposals onÂ addressing housing problems ofÂ families with children.
* * *
President ofÂ Russia Vladimir Putin:
Colleagues,
Today, we are holding theÂ first meeting ofÂ the
Council
forÂ theÂ Implementation ofÂ State Demographic andÂ Family Policy. We will evaluate what
has been accomplished, andÂ outline further steps inÂ our joint work.
IÂ want toÂ emphasise right away that supporting families andÂ creating
conditions that enable theÂ birth ofÂ asÂ many children asÂ possible inÂ Russia is aÂ crucial and, effectively, aÂ cross-cutting trend ofÂ all our national projects andÂ strategic development plans. It permeates practically all spheres ofÂ life andÂ encompasses everything that is needed andÂ important forÂ our people.
This is anÂ absolute priority because it concerns theÂ future ofÂ our
country. InÂ this regard, it is particularly important forÂ theÂ state, theÂ business community, civil society, andÂ leaders ofÂ our traditional religions toÂ coordinate
andÂ consolidate their efforts. Additionally, we all need support from theÂ media,
asÂ well asÂ well-aligned actions atÂ all levels andÂ inÂ all areas, actions based
onÂ aÂ single line ofÂ logic.
TheÂ Councilâ€™s compositionÂ â€“ andÂ it includes representatives ofÂ federal
andÂ regional authorities, public andÂ non-profit organisations, scientific andÂ entrepreneurial communitiesÂ â€“ undoubtedly reflects theÂ commitment toÂ aÂ comprehensive, system-wide approach toÂ addressing theÂ tasks we face. IÂ hope
that today we will discuss specific proposals aimed atÂ making our policy onÂ demographic
development andÂ support forÂ families more effective andÂ robust.
Colleagues,
Falling birth
rates have become aÂ global trend andÂ aÂ global challenge inÂ theÂ modern world. While
not inÂ all countries are affected equally, many, particularly economically developed
nations, face this issue, andÂ Russia is unfortunately no exception. Additionally,
asÂ you know, we suffer from theÂ effects ofÂ two demographic pitfalls, asÂ we call
them: theÂ tragic losses ofÂ WWII, theÂ Great Patriotic War, andÂ theÂ crisis ofÂ theÂ 1990s, which took place just after theÂ collapse ofÂ theÂ Soviet Union.
Different countries
respond toÂ this demographic challenge inÂ various ways, including theÂ encouragement
ofÂ uncontrolled, andÂ even chaotic migration toÂ replace theÂ native population, often
sacrificing their identity andÂ culture, and, importantly, their internal political
stability.
Our choice is
unequivocal: we support theÂ family asÂ theÂ fundamental basis ofÂ Russian society
andÂ aim toÂ protect andÂ preserve genuine family values andÂ traditions, which have
united andÂ strengthened our country forÂ centuries.
It is myÂ deep
conviction that we can only address theÂ demographic challenge byÂ developing our
own demographic potential, byÂ preserving andÂ increasing theÂ number ofÂ all native
peoples inÂ Russia, supporting large family traditions, andÂ implementing programmes
toÂ bring home our compatriots, Russian andÂ Russian-speaking people who form theÂ core ofÂ our society.
This approach
guarantees our future, preserves theÂ ethno-cultural balance inÂ Russian society
andÂ strengthens our sovereignty.
IÂ have said
onÂ many occasions that families with three orÂ more children should be seen asÂ aÂ standard andÂ natural way ofÂ life inÂ our country. InÂ this regard, internal
guidelines, people's beliefs, andÂ their priorities hold immense, sometimes
decisive, importance.
According toÂ sociologists, anÂ increasing number ofÂ our citizens express aÂ desire toÂ have
large families.
InÂ 2005, our citizens
believed that aÂ family should have 2.4 children (this is statistical dataÂ â€“ theÂ figure may sound strange forÂ theÂ media representatives present here, but
statisticians consider this normal) andÂ now this figure is over three children,
andÂ this trend is very important.
AndÂ one more thing. IÂ believe that you will, most likely, discuss this issue today. Ms Valentina
Matviyenko andÂ IÂ have agreed that IÂ will speak andÂ then will leave you toÂ attend toÂ myÂ routine matters, andÂ you will continue working inÂ these wonderful
Kremlin interiors under theÂ supervision ofÂ Ms Matviyenko. But this is what IÂ would like toÂ say. Ms Tatyana Golikova is focusing onÂ this issue all theÂ time
when communicating with her colleagues inÂ theÂ Government, andÂ she persistently
revisits this issue when engaging with meÂ â€“ how toÂ provide financial
support forÂ families. This is absolutely correct. It is very hard toÂ address
demographic issues without this.
But,
ofÂ course, inner moral values, attitudes andÂ principles are much stronger andÂ more important. Did Russian peasant households earn average European-style
incomes? No, they did not, but each peasant family had seven toÂ ten
children. Their values andÂ attitudes
were different. This is what underlies demographic policy, andÂ this should lie
atÂ its foundation.
It
is now very important (IÂ believe this is
also one ofÂ theÂ Councilâ€™s objectives) toÂ promote andÂ uphold theÂ internal attitude that IÂ have mentioned, that tendency ofÂ theÂ internal attitude that IÂ just spoke about, so that theÂ desire toÂ create aÂ family, toÂ marry andÂ toÂ have many children becomes prevalent inÂ theÂ public mentality.
Certainly,
no pressure should be exerted inÂ this sphere. AÂ decision toÂ have aÂ child is,
certainly, aÂ private andÂ personal matter ofÂ any person, any family. However, we
should work jointly andÂ make sure that people (young people, inÂ theÂ first
place) would sincerely aspire toÂ aÂ happy motherhood, would aim toÂ effectively
raise their children, andÂ that they would feel confident that theÂ state will
support them whenever necessary, lend them aÂ helping hand, andÂ that it will do
everything possible toÂ prevent living standards from deteriorating following
theÂ birth ofÂ children but would, rather, raise theÂ family status.
You know, we have already
created anÂ entire range ofÂ essential tools forÂ providing this support. IÂ am
talking about maternity capital, flat-rate benefits forÂ low-income families andÂ low-interest mortgages. IÂ would also like toÂ recall that, from 2025, regions
whose birth rates fell short ofÂ average Russian levels inÂ 2023 received
additional funding forÂ implementing birth rate expansion programmes. InÂ 2025â€“2030, 41 regions will receive about 75 billion
rubles. TheÂ family taxation initiative will be launched inÂ early 2026; it will
reduce income tax levels toÂ six percent forÂ low-income families raising two
children andÂ more.
When
formulating support measures, we base them onÂ theÂ real needs ofÂ families. What
would IÂ like toÂ highlight inÂ this regard? It is clear that large families,
whose expenses are always significant, find it more difficult toÂ purchase aÂ larger flat orÂ house onÂ their own. Support measure is therefore available,
including aÂ payment ofÂ 450,000 roubles from theÂ state toÂ help repay mortgages.
InÂ several
regions, local authorities are actively addressing theÂ housing needs ofÂ large
families. Overall, IÂ would like toÂ reiterate that tackling demographic
challenges andÂ supporting families is aÂ shared responsibility, one that
involves all levels ofÂ government, from federal toÂ municipal. It is essential forÂ regions toÂ take aÂ proactive approach andÂ develop their own solutions. AsÂ anÂ example ofÂ effective regional policy inÂ this area, IÂ would like toÂ highlight
theÂ work being done inÂ theÂ Nizhny Novgorod Region. TheÂ governor described this
toÂ me inÂ detail during myÂ working visit there. TheÂ regionâ€™s initiatives include
several significant support measures, foremost among them regional family
capital, which provides monthly payments toÂ families forÂ three years following
theÂ birth ofÂ aÂ childÂ â€“ whether it is theÂ first, second, third, orÂ subsequent
child. Moreover, every family, regardless ofÂ income level, receives support
upon theÂ birth ofÂ aÂ child.
What else
do IÂ think is important toÂ highlight? Young people todayÂ â€“ not only inÂ RussiaÂ â€“
often postpone having children, believing they should first focus onÂ other
goals. But asÂ time passes, it can turn out that theÂ best years forÂ starting aÂ family have been irretrievably lost. Our task is toÂ help young people
understand that they do not have toÂ choose one path over another but can
successfully combine parenthood with studying orÂ building aÂ career. Yes, it may
be challenging, but it is possible, andÂ it is important toÂ balance these
responsibilities with raising aÂ child.
OfÂ course,
this requires significant effort andÂ hard work, but theÂ state stands ready toÂ provide assistance andÂ support. We must continue toÂ remind people ofÂ something
that may seem obvious but still needs toÂ be said aloud: fatherhood andÂ motherhood are aÂ source ofÂ joy, andÂ there is no need toÂ postpone happiness.
That is what truly matters. AtÂ theÂ same time, it is also essential that we help
young people andÂ families navigate this important stage ofÂ their lives.
Several relevant decisions have recently been made.
Pregnancy andÂ childbirth benefits have been increased forÂ full-time
students. InÂ some regions, lump sum payments have been approved forÂ pregnant
students. Universities are opening baby care rooms andÂ part-day child care
groups. We should certainly encourage everything that is being done inÂ this
sphere, primarily inÂ theÂ system ofÂ higher education but also atÂ secondary

IÂ know that theÂ Federation Council helped organise aÂ Festival ofÂ Student
Families inÂ July, asÂ Ms Matviyenko has told us. IÂ believe it was held atÂ Bauman
University.

We have
prepared aÂ number ofÂ proposals. We hope toÂ formalise them asÂ aÂ list ofÂ your
instructions, should you agree, so that we receive your instructions toÂ implement following todayâ€™s discussion.
TheÂ key issue is well known: housing. TheÂ family mortgage programme. OfÂ course, thanks
toÂ this initiative, millions ofÂ families have been able toÂ acquire housing ofÂ their own. However, upon closer examination, Mr President, it turns out that
family mortgages are increasingly becoming aÂ metropolitan mortgage, asÂ more
than half ofÂ theÂ preferential loans intended toÂ boost theÂ birth rate are being
issued inÂ Moscow, St Petersburg, andÂ theÂ Moscow andÂ Leningrad regions. We
believe it would be appropriate toÂ refine this tool. It is necessary toÂ create
conditions that allow families with children toÂ improve their housing conditions
inÂ theÂ areas where they actually live, onÂ their native land. This would, inÂ turn, give aÂ powerful boost forÂ housing construction across theÂ regions ofÂ theÂ Federation, including smaller towns, andÂ would promote planned territorial
development.
Given theÂ particular focus onÂ large families,
we also propose differentiating theÂ family mortgage rate according toÂ theÂ number ofÂ children: theÂ more children aÂ family has, theÂ lower theÂ rate should
be.
AÂ model ofÂ preferential, affordable rental
housing forÂ families with children, asÂ you have also mentioned, requires
further development. DOM.RF has already prepared specific proposals inÂ this
regard, which Mr Mutko will present inÂ more detail today.
You know, Mr President, dreams are inspiring.
Imagine, forÂ example, if aÂ third orÂ fourth child were born into aÂ family andÂ theÂ state were toÂ grant them anÂ apartment orÂ aÂ home ofÂ their own. This would,
ofÂ course, stimulate theÂ development ofÂ individual andÂ wooden housing
construction. We have vast forest resources forÂ that. It is every familyâ€™s
dream, andÂ such aÂ measure would certainly serve asÂ aÂ strong incentive toÂ have
more children.
We also believe that theÂ time has come toÂ improve theÂ maternity capital
programme. It should now be reoriented towards supporting large familiesÂ â€“ theÂ birth ofÂ aÂ third andÂ subsequent children. AtÂ present, maternity capital forÂ aÂ second orÂ third child is significantly lower than forÂ theÂ first child. We
believed aÂ similar approach should be applied toÂ regional maternity capital
payments.
Overall, there should, inÂ myÂ view, be aÂ unified philosophy: all
additional support measures, both federal andÂ regional, should be directed
primarily towards encouraging theÂ birth ofÂ third, fourth, andÂ subsequent
children.
Infrastructure. You are, ofÂ course,
absolutely right toÂ note that theÂ state must provide theÂ necessary
infrastructure: schools, educational facilities, clubs, andÂ so forth. Yet this
family-centred approach must be applied inÂ all areas: modern playgrounds,
barrier-free environments forÂ strollers, andÂ mother-and-child rooms inÂ public
institutions. Among theÂ proposals we have received from theÂ regions andÂ public
organisations are: theÂ creation ofÂ designated parking spaces forÂ large
families; exemption ofÂ childrenâ€™s fares inÂ taxis; andÂ separate check-inÂ counters forÂ families with small children atÂ airports, among others.
Our society has aÂ strong,
long-standing tradition ofÂ special care forÂ expectant mothers andÂ children.
Undeniably, this deeply-held value must be translated into practical, everyday
benefits forÂ families with children, which does not necessarily require
significant budget expenditures. We are ready (andÂ are already acting) toÂ prepare corresponding recommendations forÂ businesses, regions, andÂ federal
agencies.
Furthermore, it is crucial that
employers actively engage with demographic objectives. AsÂ this is aÂ national
priority, businesses must also demonstrate their social responsibility byÂ contributing. Progress is already underway: we are collecting information from
theÂ regions, andÂ aÂ new national GOST corporate demographic standard has
recently been approved. While its application is currently voluntary, we
believe companies that implement high standards ofÂ demographic support should
be encouraged andÂ incentivised and, all other things being equal, be entitled
toÂ certain state preferences. This is only fair.
We must also streamline theÂ system
ofÂ state support, asÂ there are no trivial details inÂ this endeavour. ForÂ instance, if aÂ new mother receives aÂ substantial one-time payment from her
employer forÂ theÂ birth ofÂ aÂ child, this amount is currently counted asÂ income.
AsÂ aÂ result, she can lose her right toÂ receive aÂ flat-rate child care benefit.
We have submitted proposals toÂ theÂ Government, andÂ aÂ resolution is already
being prepared toÂ exclude such employer payments from theÂ calculation ofÂ average per capita family income. InÂ our view, it would be logical toÂ extend
this approach toÂ other demographic support payments, regardless ofÂ their
source.
Our Council has also uncovered
startling situations, such asÂ aÂ working woman receiving no maternity benefits
atÂ all. This can occur if her company is undergoing bankruptcy when she goes onÂ maternity leave, leaving no source forÂ theÂ payment. We have rectified this byÂ submitting new legislation, which has since been adopted; inÂ such cases, payments
are now made byÂ theÂ Social Fund.
Here is another critical example. AÂ woman may be de facto employed byÂ aÂ company but is formally registered asÂ self-employedÂ â€“ anÂ arrangement some businesses find economically efficient. TheÂ consequence is that when she becomes pregnant, she is not entitled toÂ paid
maternity leave andÂ is essentially thrust into financial limbo, with no
benefits orÂ guarantees. While these issues might seem minor toÂ some, they are
inÂ fact vital, critical even, andÂ we are committed toÂ addressing them
thoroughly.
Finally, IÂ would like toÂ thank theÂ Ministry ofÂ Labour andÂ Minister Anton Kotyakov forÂ supporting theÂ law that increases
maternity benefits forÂ new mothers who are university students. These benefits
have been raised almost tenfold, Mr President, representing truly significant
support.
You
mentioned theÂ necessity ofÂ placing special emphasis onÂ student families.
Considerable efforts have also been made inÂ this regard. AÂ non-reducible
standard ofÂ support forÂ student families has been established. Specific
measures are being implemented byÂ theÂ Ministry ofÂ Science andÂ Higher Education,
with university rectors andÂ Minister ofÂ Science andÂ Higher Education Valery
Falkov actively engaged inÂ this agendaÂ â€“ many thanks toÂ him forÂ his commitment.
We are
currently preparing legislative amendments that will enable priority placement
inÂ nurseries andÂ kindergartens near universities forÂ children from student
families.
Moreover,
Mr President, this is aÂ highly significant issueÂ â€“ it is widely discussed. We
propose considering aÂ more proactive development ofÂ nursery networks, both inÂ residential areas andÂ atÂ universities, asÂ well asÂ atÂ large enterprises.
Nurseries are absolutely essential forÂ women toÂ balance studies, work, andÂ motherhood. Nearly all regions have fulfilled your instructions regarding
kindergarten construction. TheÂ programme has been implemented, andÂ there is
virtually no shortage; however, nurseries remain inadequate. Women fear being
out ofÂ work forÂ three years, thereby losing professional skills, andÂ if they
have aÂ second orÂ third child, this period extends toÂ six orÂ nine years. Support
is needed forÂ these three years before kindergarten. IÂ believe we should
implement aÂ nursery construction programme, including private ones, possibly byÂ simplifying requirements forÂ establishing such institutions, naturally without
compromising child safety.
We would
like toÂ request that you instruct theÂ Presidential Plenipotentiary Envoys toÂ theÂ Federal Districts toÂ personally oversee demographic policy inÂ theÂ regions.
IÂ would
like toÂ cite anÂ exampleÂ â€“ Igor ShchegolevÂ â€“ today, he can truly be called theÂ Plenipotentiary Envoy forÂ Demography, not just aÂ Presidential Plenipotentiary
Envoy.
Special
thanks must be extended toÂ theÂ governors. They have genuinely excelled, fully
embracing their responsibilities. Demographic programmes have been adopted inÂ all regions. IÂ am confident they will begin toÂ yield results.
It is also
crucial forÂ theÂ demographic agenda toÂ receive adequate andÂ appropriate media
coverage. Several years ago, Alexei Gromov andÂ IÂ convened aÂ meeting with
leaders ofÂ all media communities: television, film, radio, internet, online andÂ offline cinemas, andÂ so on. We encountered absolute mutual understanding andÂ agreed onÂ many points. There are robust, substantive plans inÂ place. Council
member Oleg Dobrodeyev will elaborate onÂ this today.
IÂ think IÂ should conclude here.
Accurate statistics andÂ population
surveys reflecting theÂ realities are needed forÂ correct managerial decisions.
Our Council has already delved deeply into theÂ topic. It concerns, among other
things, measurements ofÂ demographic attitudes andÂ reproductive plans ofÂ our
citizens.
However, we
have toÂ exercise utter caution regarding various sociological studies that are
unprofessional, unscientific andÂ incorrect. Sociology is aÂ very complicated
science.
Objectives
studies are currently conducted byÂ Rosstat (Federal State Statistics Service),
but regrettably, once every five years, while we need more updated information.
This is obviously not enough.
IÂ have laid
out just some proposals, myÂ colleagues will add up toÂ them.
We keep analysing family support measures currently inÂ effect, andÂ identifying andÂ scaling-up theÂ most effective ofÂ them.
Mr President, we are about toÂ mark theÂ wonderful holidayÂ â€“National Unity Day. IÂ would like toÂ remind theÂ words ofÂ great Russian scientist Dmitry Mendeleyev, who was aÂ great Russian patriotÂ â€“ theÂ power ofÂ Russia is inÂ its unity, inÂ theÂ military andÂ theÂ graceful family spirit that
multiplies theÂ growth ofÂ theÂ nation. Thatâ€™s what we stand for. We shall do our best forÂ our Fatherland toÂ be strong, independent, sovereign, and, ofÂ course, with many large families.
Thank you
once again forÂ your participation.
Vladimir
Putin
: Thank you,
Ms Matviyenko.
Once IÂ have stayed here, let me say just aÂ couple ofÂ words
toÂ comment onÂ your remarks.
You are obviously aware that theÂ Government is
trying toÂ preserve all kinds ofÂ mortgage loan tools. What has remained ofÂ theÂ preferential
mortgage is intended toÂ support basically families with children, both theÂ six-percent family mortgage, theÂ two-percent mortgage inÂ some regions ofÂ Russia
that require our special attention andÂ support forÂ families with children, andÂ so on.
We will definitely
keep improving everything, including private housing construction which last year andÂ theÂ year before ensured
aÂ good growth ofÂ housing construction. This should evidently be also supported.
We indeed have aÂ lot ofÂ forests, andÂ you have
rightly said that some people like andÂ will gladly live inÂ theÂ forest but not
everyone. Therefore, apart from forests, we need relevant infrastructure.
Valentina Matviyenko
: Mr President, IÂ didnâ€™t mean that. IÂ meant that we have aÂ lot ofÂ timber andÂ we can step

Vladimir
Putin
: IÂ see your

But this is

DOM.RF General Director
Vitaly Mutko
Mutko Vitaly
General Director of DOM.RF

Vladimir
Putin

Now, regarding maternity capital. You know,
this idea first came toÂ me andÂ myÂ colleagues inÂ theÂ Government atÂ that time, andÂ it turned out toÂ be aÂ very successful one. OfÂ course, we must now think onÂ how
toÂ improve this tool. We are making every effort toÂ support it andÂ toÂ ensure it
is regularly adjusted forÂ inflation.
But IÂ would ask you toÂ bear one thing inÂ mind.
There is aÂ constant temptation toÂ use maternity capital toÂ resolve various

endless. Yet theÂ most important thing is not toÂ allow these funds toÂ be spent
onÂ things that are secondary orÂ insignificant.
Valentina Matviyenko:
Thatâ€™s right.
Vladimir Putin:
People are different; they have different

happens, interests ofÂ children andÂ women are above all. Although theÂ term
â€œfamily capitalâ€ is sometimes used, IÂ deliberately called it maternity capitalÂ â€“ andÂ forÂ good reason. We must prioritise theÂ protection ofÂ women andÂ children.
Therefore, IÂ ask you toÂ approach this matter with great care. Families have
fundamental needs, andÂ that is theÂ principle we must uphold.
Now, asÂ forÂ material support inÂ generalÂ â€“ ofÂ course, it is absolutely necessary. All our actions are aimed atÂ providing it.
But IÂ have already spoken about theÂ ideological aspect ofÂ this issue. IÂ think
you will all agree with me that demographic challenges appeared inÂ many Western
European countries long before they emerged here, even back inÂ Soviet times,
despite theÂ much higher standard ofÂ living enjoyed byÂ citizens inÂ those
countries. Other problems have since arisen. IÂ will not repeat them, but
demographers understand this well. Factors such asÂ getting education,
post-university education, building aÂ career, other ambitions, andÂ theÂ postponement ofÂ theÂ birth ofÂ theÂ first child, along with urbanisation andÂ theÂ broader effects ofÂ aÂ post-industrial society, have all contributed. Peopleâ€™s
consciousness has changed, their priorities have shifted, their values andÂ life
orientations have evolved. InÂ general, this is not aÂ bad thingÂ â€“indeed, it is aÂ sign ofÂ developmentÂ â€“ but it is important that theÂ fundamental values
associated with theÂ continuation ofÂ life, with theÂ joy ofÂ childhood, andÂ with
theÂ happiness ofÂ motherhood andÂ fatherhood, are preserved. These are things
that no amount ofÂ money can buy.
OfÂ course, it is essential toÂ create theÂ right
conditions. AsÂ theÂ saying goes, â€œwe must not breed povertyâ€Â â€“ andÂ that is
entirely true. But one cannot replace theÂ other. Value-based orientations are
important, andÂ forÂ that, joint andÂ concerted efforts are crucial.
And, asÂ IÂ said atÂ theÂ beginning, we must
support peopleâ€™s natural aspirations toÂ have more children. This is absolutely
clear. We must do so through consistent, practical
actions, both inÂ theÂ material sphere andÂ inÂ social policy.
Ms Matviyenko mentioned baby nurseries. IÂ absolutely agree onÂ this point. Some regions have failed toÂ resolve theÂ kindergarten issues completely but theÂ governors are attending toÂ these matters,
andÂ IÂ am sure all theÂ outstanding issues will soon be resolved. Basically,
everything has been completed, theÂ programme has been completed. However, you are
right about baby nurseries toÂ make sure that aÂ woman does not drop out ofÂ aÂ production process andÂ does not lose her professional skills, which means aÂ lot inÂ theÂ modern world asÂ theÂ situation is changing rapidly, theÂ pace ofÂ changes is enormous, especially inÂ production. It is crucial inÂ this regard that aÂ woman should have anÂ opportunity toÂ return toÂ her job without losing qualification.
You are
certainly absolutely right, we have toÂ address this issue. Ms Golikova, we have
repeatedly discussed this matter, andÂ we must give it another thought, but certainly
without slacking safety requirements forÂ these child care institutions. TheÂ requirements
may be changed, they must be up-to-date toÂ embrace modern capabilities andÂ materials,
equipment andÂ everything else. Modern technologies allow forÂ resolving many
issues ofÂ childrenâ€™s facilities safety inÂ aÂ modern way, andÂ thatâ€™s what we must
do. Therefore, theÂ requirements must not be slackened but changed inÂ accordance
with modern capabilities.
IÂ would like
toÂ finish with what IÂ began with andÂ what IÂ repeatedly addressedÂ â€“ theÂ inner motivation, theÂ ideological beliefs ofÂ our society andÂ what Ms Matviyenko referred toÂ asÂ respect forÂ theÂ very notion ofÂ childhood, fatherhood andÂ motherhood.
Regarding motherhoodÂ â€“ IÂ think everyone is perfectly aware ofÂ thatÂ â€“ yet IÂ will say it again. All peoples ofÂ Russia
(we have many peoples, theÂ Russian nation embraces over 100 ethnicities, toÂ be
more exact,192 ethnicities living here, andÂ we have been communicating with
each other forÂ asÂ many asÂ aÂ thousand years) have some beliefs common forÂ all. IÂ mean anÂ attitude toÂ mummy, toÂ mother, which has aÂ special sacred significance forÂ all ofÂ us. Even our major traditional religions have theÂ image ofÂ mother onÂ icons asÂ theÂ central image. Just look atÂ our basic religious values. What do they look like? AÂ Madonna with theÂ baby, she prevails. InÂ other cultures, forÂ example, inÂ Europe, theÂ main image is that ofÂ theÂ Saviour. InÂ our country, you know what is depicted onÂ theÂ icons. Do you get it? This is theÂ first point.
Second, regarding patriotic educationÂ â€“ one word is being passed over from generation toÂ generation, which is natural forÂ usÂ â€“ Motherland. InÂ fact, mother andÂ homeland are blended inÂ our consciousness asÂ one general image.
We must definitely
support these fundamental value-based attitudes inÂ aÂ talented, vivid andÂ masterful way, including andÂ above all with theÂ active engagement ofÂ cultural figures andÂ mass media representatives.
IÂ want toÂ wish you all theÂ best inÂ your todayâ€™s work.
Thank you
very much.

FORUMARCTICA.RU

### 504
URL: https://mofa.go.ug/node/155
TITLE: Consular Services |  The Republic of Uganda

DEPARTMENT OF CONSULAR SERVICES
The Consular Services Department provides consular services at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs headquarters and abroad through Uganda's Embassies and Missions.
The key functions of the Department are:
Strengthening the policy and regulatory framework for the provision of consular services.
Coordinating the establishment of Uganda Consular Missions abroad.
Coordinating the provision of consular services by Ugandan Embassies and Missions abroad.
Providing consular services at Headquarters to Ugandans, Diplomatic Missions and other foreign entities and nationals resident in Uganda.
Managing consular relations between Uganda and other countries.
Establishing national and international networks for the provision of consular services.
Consular Services provided by the Department include:
General information on consular protection and assistance.
Next of kin notifications in cases of death, illness, arrest and other emergency situations involving Ugandans abroad.
Repatriation guidelines in emergency situations abroad.
Coordination of visa application processes for Government Officials travelling abroad for official work.
Authentication of academic documents issued by Ugandan academic institutions.
Coordination of the issuance and renewal of Uganda Diplomatic passports for Ugandans carrying out diplomatic assignments abroad.
Coordination of consular visits to foreign nationals detained in Uganda.
HEAD CONSULAR SERVICES DEPARTMENT:
MR. KAYEMBA BENON
[emailÂ protected]

### 505
URL: https://mofa.go.ug/node/161
TITLE: Diaspora |  The Republic of Uganda

THE DIASPORA DEPARTMENT
The Department for the Diaspora handles issues related to the mobilization of the Uganda Diaspora for national development (i.e. transfer of resources/specialist knowledge; skills and technologies for development; and promoting gainful employment of Ugandans abroad; etc.).
The key functions of the Diaspora Department are:
Strengthening engagement with the Diaspora with a view to encouraging Ugandans abroad to support national development.
Promoting and strengthening appropriate structures and regulatory regimes that ease investment, financial and commercial transactions by the Diaspora.
Negotiating, in cooperation with key stakeholders, appropriate legal framework on the bilateral export and / or exchange of labour abroad.
Promoting incentives to encourage Diaspora skills and knowledge transfer home.
Providing services as the One-stop centre and channel of information and communication for the Uganda Diaspora community.
Establish and maintain a data base on the identity, location and skills of the Ugandan Diaspora. The key functions of the Department are:
The key functions of Diaspora Department Contâ€™d:
Strengthening engagement with the Diaspora with a view to encouraging Ugandans abroad to support national development.
Promoting and strengthening appropriate structures and regulatory regimes that ease investment, financial and commercial transactions by the Diaspora.
Negotiating, in cooperation with key stakeholders, appropriate legal framework on the bilateral export and / or exchange of labour abroad.
Promoting incentives to encourage Diaspora skills and knowledge transfer home.
Providing services as the One-stop centre and channel of information and communication for the Uganda Diaspora community.
Establish and maintain a data base on the identity, location and skills of the Ugandan Diaspora.
HEAD DIASPORA DEPARTMENT :
AMBASSADOR JOHNNY MUTHAHI MUHINDO
[emailÂ protected]
