### 596
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/sectors/environmental-regulatory/pcb-management-in-ethiopia-project.html
TITLE: PCB Management in Ethiopia Project

Environmental Regulatory
PCB Management in Ethiopia Project
PCB Management in Ethiopia Project
1. Background
Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) are a group of man-madeÂ Â  organic compounds that are resistant to environmental degradation through Chemical, Biological, and Photolytic processes. For this reason, they remain intact in the environment for a long time; become widely distributed throughout the environment; accumulate in fatty tissue of living organisms; and are toxic to humans and wildlife. The Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) counts Polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) among the most toxic and persistent chemicals listed in the convention to be eliminated worldwide by 2025. Although PCBs were mostly used in closed systems, like transformers and capacitors, very often such equipment is recycled at the end of their operational life and the PCB oil contained therein can be either directly wasted in the environment, recycled, or even sold as fuel oil. Aware of the adverse human health and environmental impacts of POPs, both at the national and global levels and the need for concerted action to address such impacts, Ethiopia is among one of the countries who took the commitment Stockholm in the convention.
Prior to the onset of the PCB project, the result of the preliminary PCB inventory in Ethiopia indicates that a comprehensive inventory will need to be conducted on all potentially PCB-containing electrical equipment in the Ethiopian electric power and electric utility system. Due to absence of data either on the nameplate or equipment manual, PCB concentrations have not been determined or characterized. Therefore, the lack of adequate national data on PCBs, the potential for significant PCB releases from their use, stockpiles and wastes, and the need to phase out and dispose of PCBs and equipment are major problems that have been prioritized for action.
This GEF-funded PCB management project in Ethiopia to meet the 2025 Stockholm Convention deadline is one of the key responses to the NIP by the Ethiopian government. In collaboration with UNDP, an implementing agency of the GEF, the project intends to provide Ethiopia with the necessary technical and financial support required to ensure that all the PCBs in the country are identified and disposed of. The identification and disposal of PCBs will result in health risk reduction associated with PCBs. This will lead to improved health and well-being of the people and contribute to sustainable development.
As the then (preparation of the project) inventory from the National Implementation Plan (NIP) was not sufficiently detailed to plan a full-size project, the project is designed to either confirm the lower bracket in terms of amount of PCBs in the country, and fully address the PCB issue in Ethiopia as part of this Phase 1 project; or identify additional PCBs thus justifying a phase 2 follow-up PCB project. The present project will include the identification and disposal of 150 t of PCB-contaminated equipment and waste.
2.
Project Objective
Overall objective
: strengthening capacity of national stakeholders to manage PCB as well as to achieve its elimination.
Specific objective
: identification and disposal of 150 t of PCB-contaminated equipment and waste
3. Project Budget
Total budget USD 1,990,000 plus USD 150K UNDP- core funding.
4. Project Duration
The project has four years + 1 year no cost extension
5. Partnerships:-
The project will be implemented in partnership with the relevant institutional and industrial partners, i.e. Environmental Protection Authority, Ethiopian Electric Power, Ethiopian Electric Utility, Ethio-engineering Group, Ethiopian Conformity Assessment Enterprise (ECAE) other potential holders of PCB equipment, and other interested and affected stakeholders. Each one of these partners will play a specific role in ensuring that the changes needed for the project implementation are achieved.
6. Project Component
Component 1
:
Strengthening of legal frameworks, administrative processes and technical preparedness for the sound management of P
CBs
in Ethiopia
This component will support Ethiopia to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the national and institutional legal framework, key stakeholders, and gaps and overlaps, and to prioritize needs. After the comprehensive review and assessment, a decision will be made to draft new legislation specifically on PCBs or to strengthen the existing ones with inclusion of PCB-specific provisions. The assessment will also address institutional capacity and arrangements for the management of PCB, and gaps and overlaps will be identified and addressed through consultation and coordination processes. In addition to the legal instruments to be put in place for PCB management and disposal, a national PCB tracking system to prevent illegal importation of equipment likely to contain PCBs will be developed. This will involve periodic technical visits to the PCB holders, which will provide technical support and advice to purchase PCB-free transformers, capacitors, and related equipment; and preventing exports of suspected PCB-containing transformers. As part of the actions to prevent PCB-related accidents, the current chemical response procedures and mechanisms will be strengthened and piloted.
Internal guidelines and procedures targeted for utility companies and step-by-step approaches for those working with equipment and oil likely to contain PCBs will be developed and training provided for all the affected workers. The utility companies will be requested to sign off on these guidelines and procedures to confirm their commitment.
Component 2: Review and strengthening of national capacity for PCB management throughout the lifecycle
This component will support Ethiopia to review and strengthen data collection and management capacity, as well as to develop detailed PCB management plans at the facility level. A comprehensive PCB training programme will take place, covering PCB inventories, analysis, prioritization, and development of management plans.
The inventory database will also provide a platform for characterisation of PCB waste streams. This characterization will then facilitate a feasibility study of using cost effective, technologically robust, and available technologies to promote environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs. About 33,000 pieces of transformers and capacitors will be inventoried covering all 10 regions of Ethiopia. The outcomes of the feasibility study will form a basis for the development of PCB management plans.
Furthermore, this component will result in improved generation/collection of data, information, and monitoring of PCBs providing solid support to sound decision-making and planning process for ESM of PCBs. Comprehensive guidance on operation and maintenance of PCB-contaminated equipment, identification and labelling procedures, handling, transportation, temporary storage, and disposal will be developed.
Additionally, a national PCB management plan will be developed and tested at the national and facility levels. The national PCB tracking system will also be tested. Training will be provided at the beginning of the implementation of each activity.
Under this component, an awareness raising strategy will also be developed, awareness materials such as brochures, project cards, meeting banners and posters, for different target groups, will be developed and disseminated at the different levels â€“ communities, technicians and policy-makers. Media briefing events both at mid-level managers (facility managers) and high-level (ministers, members of parliament and chief executives) will be planned and executed. Furthermore, local communities will have access to awareness raising materials in their own local languages and trainings for the community leaders will be organized. All these efforts will be geared towards ensuring that there is better understanding of the problem and ensure protection of the population and the environment from adverse effects of PCBs. The awareness raising will also contribute to generating political support for the project.
Component 3
:
ESM of PCBs liquids and equipment in use or out of service
This component will minimize and to a greater degree eliminate the risk of adverse effects of PCBs in the population and the environment. The database information will provide the required information to characterize the PCB waste streams and concentrations in the various matrices where PCBs are found. PCB-containing transformers and capacitors will be collected and transported to four central temporary storage facilities. Based on waste characterization outcomes, management and disposal options will be evaluated. The project will establish priorities according to the conditions of the PCB stocks and to the location. In that sense, the PCB management plans, developed in the previous project component, will guide facilities in their maintenance and disposal operations. The evaluation of disposal options will take into account the levels of PCB concentrations and the condition of the equipment. To reduce costs, a dechlorination approach will be explored. For example, the treatment or disposal of contaminated transformers which are relatively new and in good working order might only require a dechlorination approach â€“ whereas old, defective and highly contaminated transformers in low- or high-risk areas might require a different approach. These types of transformers and capacitors will be considered for dismantling at licensed facilities and will be incinerated with PCB oil at an incineration facility meeting international standards as defined by the Stockholm Convention. More importantly, the national PCB management team will decide on the PCB thresholds using internationally acceptable approaches and characterize the risk categories. The final decisions for treatment or disposal include several options. For example, a joint de-chlorination venture with Kenya for PCB-contaminated oil (the feasibility of which would depend on coinciding project timeframes and logistics, and cost-effectiveness), incineration in cement kilns (if practical), or export for destruction. The process for evaluating these options will be robust and will include considerations such as: condition of the equipment, convention requirements, PCB concentrations in the waste streams, and local conditions.
Furthermore, under this component, selected locations designated to serve as sites for PCB temporary storage facilities will be environmentally- and human-risk assessed. Management plans including emergency response plans for each temporary facility will be developed and implemented for each site. 150 metric tonnes of PCB oil transformer carcasses, capacitors, and contaminated soils are expected to be shipped out of the country and disposed of through high temperature incineration (standards, licensing scheme, and licensed facilities to incinerate PCBs are currently not available in Ethiopia.). The estimation of 150 metric tonnes of PCB oil transformer carcasses, capacitors and contaminated soils is based on the preliminary NIP data, the 33,000 transformers in the country, and the trends from other countries of similar nature, based on the experience of UNITAR in other countries. The precise figure will be confirmed during project implementation.
Based on other experiences from the region, the total cost of PCB disposal including transportation is in the range of USD 3,500-4,500 per ton. Factors that impact the cost include location of the port of exit, composition of PCB waste, inland transportation, and distance from the origin of PCB waste (Ethiopia) to the final destination. Djibouti will be the port of exit for the Ethiopian PCB materials; Djibouti has been a point of transit for other hazardous waste exports for disposal operations in the past. This possibility was confirmed by a representative of Djibouti, provided that necessary support documentation as per the Basel and Stockholm Conventions are provided to the competent authority in Djibouti.
Training (both theoretical and practical) will be conducted before the commencement of each activity planned under this component.
Considering the training required and the potential additional costs linked to the fact that Ethiopia is a landlocked country, which can make the operations more complex and costly, a total cost of USD 900,000 for 150 tonnes has been estimated for this component, which corresponds to USD 6,000 per tonne. This is a reasonable estimate of the expected overall costs for this disposal operation and the required necessary preparation for it. Moreover, as the project will enable the development of a comprehensive foundation for PCB management (which can also be applied to other POPs and chemicals management), subsequent projects, such as a phase 2 PCB project (which will not require foundational activities), will be implementable at greatly reduced costs compared to other PCB projects.
Component 4
:
Monitoring, evaluation and replication
Under this component, an internal project monitoring and evaluation (M&E) team will be constituted. The M&E team will regularly provide quarterly reports on project performance, stakeholdersâ€™ views on project impacts, and recommendations for improvements. Yearly lessons-learned reports will be prepared and disseminated. Lessons learnt and case study reports for each demonstration project (e.g. upgrading temporary storage sites) will be prepared for each project milestone, endorsed by national stakeholders, and shared internally and externally with other project countries such as Kenya and others, where similar projects are envisaged, and generally with countries implementing PCB management projects. Best practices for introduction of ESM will be identified, documented, and disseminated to participants, other stakeholders and Parties of the Stockholm Convention. The national project website will be developed for engagement, sharing good practices, guidance/tools, and experience. End-of-project publications will be prepared and disseminated.
PCB Database System
pcb.epa.gov.et

### 598
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/sectors/environmental-regulatory/used-lead-acid-batteries-guidelines.html
TITLE: Used lead acid batteries Guidelines

Environmental Regulatory
Used lead acid batteries Guidelines

### 599
URL: https://www.epa.gov.et/sectors/environmental-system-establishment/p4g-partnership.html
TITLE: P4G Partnership

Environmental System Establishment
P4G Partnership
P4G Partnership Concept Note Form
Thank you for your interest in joining the P4G family of partnerships. P4G accelerates pioneering green, market-based partnerships to build sustainable and resilient economies. We invest in impact to deliver inclusive and tangible solutions to build back better and greener to drive economic growth and meet the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Climate Agreement.
How to apply:
Go to
p4gpartnerships.org
. Review the
Partnership Fund Guidelines
to make sure your partnership is eligible and to become familiar with the evaluation criteria.
Complete the
Eligibility Checklist
on the P4G website.
Download the Concept Note Form (this Word document) from the website.
Complete the Concept Note Form below. All fields are required except where indicated.
Navigate to the
Online Concept Note Form
.
Copy and paste
your answers from the form below into the Online Form and
upload
the business plan summary and diagram where indicated.
Click "Submit Application." You will see a message on your screen letting you know the application has been submitted. You will not receive a copy of the form after it has been submitted, so please save your answers in this document as a record of your submission.
If your concept note indicates strong potential for alignment with P4G priorities, P4G staff may contact you for more information.
Important Reminders:
P4G ONLY FUNDS HIGHLY TRANSFORMATIVE PARTNERSHIPS THAT MEET OUR CRITERIA. ALL OTHER CONCEPTS WILL BE REJECTED. Therefore, please carefully read the
Guidelines
on the
Call for Partnerships web page
and review partnership examples in â€œ
The P4G Approach: Pioneering Green Partnerships, Investing in Impact
â€ and on P4Gâ€™s
website
to see if your idea matches our partnership profile.
As outlined in the Guidelines, each concept note will first be screened against the eligibility criteria. Concept notes that meet all six eligibility criteria will then be scored against evaluation criteria one through five. Only the highest scoring partnerships will advance.
Optional business plan guidance is available
here
.
Applications that are incomplete or that exceed the word limit/page limit in any section will not be considered. Use the Word Count feature to ensure you do not exceed the limits.
The submitted online application will be considered the full and final version of the application. P4G will not review any applications submitted by email or other formats.
Concept Note
Title of the Partnership/Concept.
(Fewer than 60 characters recommended.)
Summary of the partnershipâ€™s objectives.
Please give an overview of what the partnership aims to achieve, where, and by when. Describe the commercially viable business model you seek to start or to scale, and the end goals and outcomes of your venture (Max. 90 words).
Impact Goals
. (Max. 90 words) The specific planned goals, measurable impacts, and timeline (
SMART goals
) in the:
Short term (within the P4G funding period)
Medium term (within the scope of the initial targeted business model)
Long term (assuming scaling or replication catalyzed by the partnership)
Innovation
. The unique value proposition and innovativeness of this concept (Max. 90 words).
Business Model
Provide a diagram or schematic of your business model (no more than one page).
[A button to
attach your Business Model document
will appear here in the online form.]
Business Plan Summary
In no more than 2 pages, please summarize a business plan that indicates how your partnership is on the pathway to commercialization. Please ensure, at a minimum, that the following topics are addressed; feel free to add additional information and to format all information in this document to be as readable and succinct as possible. Applicants may wish to refer to the business plan guidance available
here
, for example, or other business plan resources.
The market opportunity / gap / need
The progress and quantified impact of the partnership to date, including all funding received to date
Financial sustainability plan: how the business will become commercially viable (with financial projections if available). Distinguish between the one- to two-year P4G funding window and the medium- to longer-term (5-10 years).
The implementation plan, go to market and growth strategies
Any regulatory or policy barriers that will need to be addressed, and the plan to address them
Track record and previous experience of the partners with similar ventures
[A button to
attach your Business Plan Summary document
will appear here in the online form.]
Primary SDG focus
:
Choose an item.
The focus of the partnership must be one of P4G's five
SDG
focus areas: SDG 2 food and agriculture; SDG 6 clean water and sanitation;Â  SDG 7 clean and affordable energy; SDG 11 sustainable cities; and SDG 12 responsible production and consumption (circular economy).
Alignment with P4Gâ€™s themes:
Theme
: Click or tap here to enter text.
Focus Area within Theme:
Click or tap here to enter text.
(P4G has identified clusters of P4G Partnerships working within these thematic areas. These themes align with P4Gâ€™s Communities of Learning and allow partnerships to benefit from synergies to magnify focused impact. Does your partnership fit into one of P4G's existing partnership themes? If not, select None of the Above. Note that alignment with one of these themes is not a requirement.) See
Guidelines
for list of Focus Areas within each theme.
Food and Agricultural Value Chain
Zero Waste Green Industry
Energy Transition
Digital Solutions for Water
None of the Above
[Once one of the above is selected, a new field will pop up to select one of the focus areas within that portfolio.]
P4G Partner Country or Countries
: Click or tap here to enter text.
(Please note which of P4G's 12 partner countries this partnership involves. Partnership activities must take place in one or more of the eight P4G partner countries eligible for P4G-funded projects
: Bangladesh, Colombia, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Kenya, Mexico, South Africa, and Vietnam
. Partnerships directly involving partners based in
Chile, Denmark, the Netherlands, or the Republic of
Korea
should indicate this here as well.)
Commercial Partners:
(Describe each core commercial partner's focus, location, and role in the partnership. Only include partners intending to be actively engaged members of the partnership.)
Civil Society/NGO Partners
:
(Describe each core NGO partner's focus, location, and role in the partnership. Only include partners intending to be actively engaged members of the partnership. Note which partner intends to serve as the Administrative Partner (contractual recipient of P4G funds); Refer to the table in the
Guidelines
to confirm administrative partner eligibility.)
Other Partners:
List any other core partners, including government agencies, academic institutions, etc. Briefly describe each partner's focus, type of organization, location, and role in the partnership. Only include partners intending to be actively engaged members of the partnership.
Partnersâ€™ Websites.
Please list the relevant web addresses (URLs) of each partner and of the partnership, if available. Click or tap here to enter text.
Estimated Budget.
Projected P4G budget request Click or tap here to enter text.
Projected co-financing (P4G funds no more than 50% - 75% of a partnership proposalâ€™s total budget, depending on the size of the award.) This should align with the business plan. Click or tap here to enter text.
P4G Network Connections
Please describe any collaboration or direct conversations you have had with
network
members to date, including P4G partner country national platforms, Board member organizations, or existing partnerships. Note that concept notes may be shared with relevant network members. (Max. 90 words.)
P4G Added Value
What other support beyond funding could P4G provide that would maximize your chances of success? (Max. 90 words)
Prior Recipients of P4G Funding
Has this partnership (with the same combination of partners) previously been awarded P4G funding? Check if yes. â˜
If your partnership previously received P4G funding, please summarize the results achieved using P4G funds to date and explain how additional P4G funds in this new funding cycle can help the partnership reach the next level, and why the timing is appropriate for additional funding. (Max. 125 words)

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
The Ministry briefing bout Â«Digital Ethiopia 2030Â».
H.E Dr. Belete Molla, Minister of Innovation and Technology, has given an explanation to questions raised by journalists about Â«Digital Ethiopia 2030Â».
The successful completion of Â«Digital Ethiopia 2025Â» strategy has laid the foundation for Â«Digital Ethiopia 2030Â», and explained in detail the works that are being done for the development of the country's digital economy and inclusively for all Ethiopian citizens to benefit from Â«Digital 2030Â».
The minister explained that Â«Digital Ethiopia 2030Â» strategy is a holistic way to create an Ethiopia that maintains its digital sovereignty, based on innovation and technology.
The minister who stated that strengthening citizens' digital skills is crucial for the digital economy transition, pointed out that skill development works will continue.
The minister who stated that the Â«Digital Ethiopia 2030Â» strategy is a big national plan aimed at changing the development direction of the country based on technology, pointed out that the main principle of the strategy is to actively involve all stakeholders.
They mentioned that one of the key points of the strategy is ensuring the sovereignty of citizens' information, and to achieve this, they stated that they are working on strengthening the capacity of institutions and protecting national information locally.
The Startup Declaration has a strong foundation to make Ethiopia a startup center in Africa, encourage innovation and increase the participation of the private sector.
Stating that one of the important issues for startups in the past few years is the creation of digital skills, he said that the number of startups and citizens who have developed and utilized digital technologies for the success of the Â«Digital 2030Â» strategy is expected to see a high number of people who have developed digital skills by developing and using digital technologies.

### 604
URL: http://www.mint.gov.et/w/ethiopia-and-india-discussed-on-the-issue-that-can-enable-them-to-work-together-on-digital-ethiopia-2030-strategy.?redirect=%2Fhome1
TITLE: Ethiopia and India discussed on the issue that can enable them to work together on Digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy. - MINT

+251118132191
contact@mint.gov.et

Ethiopian ecosystem
English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Ethiopia and India discussed on the issue that can enable them to work together on Digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy.
Minister of Innovation Technology H.E Dr. Belete Molla has welcomed Ambassador of India and African Union Permanent Representative Hon. Anil Kumar Rai in his office and advised us to work together on Digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy.
Minister Dr. Belete Molla on behalf of Ambassador Anil Kumar Rai received a gift sent by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and thanked them for the gifts and conveyed a message to the followers of Indian Christmas and upcoming foreign New Year.
Minister Dr. Belete Molla has noted that Ethiopia is focusing on working with partners on Digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy to achieve better results than the achievements of Digital Ethiopia 2025.
The minister said that Ethiopia and India are countries with a long-standing cultural relationship. If our country has vast experience and capacity in digital technology, he wants to work with India so his cooperation is crucial to create new opportunities.
Ambassador Anil Kumar Rai pointed out that Ethiopia's digital transformation journey will not only be successful but also be a great experience for Africa.
The Indian government and investors are interested in working together on Digital Ethiopia 2030 and will continue the partnership in space, biotechnology, nuclear, ICT and other sectors.
H.E Dr. Belete Molla has been invited to attend the technology fair organized by India by advising on cooperation works.

TITLE: The Ministry of Innovation and Technology has been thanked for the leadership given in digital Ethiopia 2025 implementation process. - MINT

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
The Ministry of Innovation and Technology has been thanked for the leadership given in digital Ethiopia 2025 implementation process.
Digital Ethiopia 2025 has been completed by achieving the goal that it has been dreamed of, has been said by Honorable Prime Minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed.
His excellency prime minister has shared his deep and broad views on the day of digital Ethiopia 2030 with his excellency FDRE innovation and technology minister Dr. Belete Mola especially on what our country's digital transition journey looks like. On this day, the minister announced that digital Ethiopia 2030 has officially started and thanked the leadership given by the office.
The prime minister stated that the key basic dreams of the new 2030 Digital Ethiopia strategy are broadening access, creating equal opportunities for citizens and building trust between citizens and institutions.
To make these dreams come true, especially in expanding the digital infrastructure of the people, this digital technology will create a great potential to improve the lives of citizens by being human centered.
In general, the works that are done in digital Ethiopia are related to the goal of the integration government's bureaucracy to implement great strategies.
His excellency prime minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed, his excellency minister Dr. Belete Mola have officially thanked the government for their contribution as a country and for the competent leadership they have given in digital Ethiopia 2025.
His excellency minister Dr. Belete Mollam, for the success of a country's digital transition, skills development, policy formation and implementation of strategies, institution construction, infrastructure expansion, digital system development and implementation. As it is expected that all these are necessary, the leader himself has a passion and understanding towards technology, in concerns and While he has a great understanding of his opportunities, being a high fan of technology and a tech person himself, we have thanked the Prime Minister for the great teaching role he has played. "

Announcement for training opportunity beneficiaries
Ethiopian ecosystem
English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Ministry of Innovation and Technology played an important role for the success of Digital Ethiopia 2025 strategy.
The Ministry of Innovation and Technology has accelerated the country's digital transformation by focusing on policy, technology base and digital skills development in order to turn Ethiopia's "Digital 2025" vision into action.
Minister of Innovation and Technology Dr. Belete Mola has said that the measures taken on digital strategy has been taken to strengthen the partnership between government and private sector and expand digital services nationwide.
The minister noted that he has contributed to reducing the cost of government services by expanding e-government services, increasing the speed and transparency of services, increasing the trust of the people and reducing the cost of public services.
The works done in the field of technology infrastructure have laid the foundation to improve internet access and data service quality and to be able to afford the digital economy.
Manpower empowerment was the main agenda of the success of "Digital Ethiopia 2025", the minister said that the youth have been widely participated in training, coding and digital skills programs.
Digital Ethiopia 2025, by strengthening innovation centers and start-up programs, they have created a convenient curriculum that will be helpful to promote the development of new ideas and bring new technologies into the market.
The minister pointed out that he has done a great job to strengthen cooperation with international institutions and countries to expand the exchange of technology experience and to develop domestic skills.
The success of "Digital 2025" in practice has made a positive impact on the economy, education and service sectors and has enabled the creation of technology solutions.
In general, the work done by the ministry of innovation and technology under the leadership, cooperation and continuity of "digital 2025" has proved that it is possible to achieve a better result for digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy.

### 607
URL: http://www.mint.gov.et/w/digital-ethiopia-2025-successfully-completed-and-digital-ethiopia-2030-launching-program-was-held.?redirect=%2Fhome1
TITLE: Digital Ethiopia 2025 successfully completed and Digital Ethiopia 2030 launching program was held. - MINT

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Digital Ethiopia 2025 successfully completed and Digital Ethiopia 2030 launching program was held.
Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed (Dr) announced that the Digital Ethiopia 2025 strategy has been completed and the Digital Ethiopia 2030 strategy has been officially launched today.
It has been noted that the new strategy is to expand accessibility, create equal opportunities for citizens and boost trust between citizens and institutions as key fundamental goals and are based on technological improvement of public services.
It has been said that using technology to improve the lives of citizens to achieve their dreams especially in expanding digital infrastructure of the people and making it human centered will create great potential to improve the lives and livelihood of citizens.
It has been stated that the widespread implementation of digital technology in government services will contribute to strengthening transparent and smooth bureaucracy and also increasing the speed of service. It is said that this will help strengthen the trust between citizens and institutions.
It has been pointed out that the works that are done under the "Digital Ethiopia" strategy will continue in line with the goal of implementing the great strategies of the integration government through simple bureaucracy.

### 608

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Digital Ethiopia 2025 has been completed after achieving its intended goals to an almost full extent. As of today, we have officially launched Digital Ethiopia 2030.
Digital Ethiopia 2025 has been completed after achieving its intended goals to an almost full extent. As of today, we have officially launched Digital Ethiopia 2030. Expanding accessibility, creating equal opportunities for citizens, and strengthening trust between citizens and institutions are among the key foundational pillars of the strategy. To ensure these pillars are realized, significant efforts will be made, particularly in expanding public digital infrastructure. This will create strong capacity for digital technology, with a people-centered approach, to improve the lives of citizens. Overall, the initiatives being implemented under Digital Ethiopia are aligned with the goals of the Medemer State to realize major strategies through streamlined bureaucracy.

### 635
URL: http://www.mint.gov.et/web/guest/w/the-ministry-of-innovation-and-technology-in-collaboration-with-the-southern-cooperation-organization-in-the-coming-year-greater-southern-fair-for-endogenous-technology-gresfet-1
TITLE: The Ministry of Innovation and Technology in collaboration with the Southern Cooperation Organization in the coming year Greater southern fair for endogenous technology (GresFET) - MINT

+251118132191
contact@mint.gov.et
Font Awesome Icons
Attractive Full-Width Navbar
Home
About Us
Message from H.E Minister
Vision, mission & values
Organizational Structure
Power & duties
Contact us
Sectors
Research and Innovation sector
Innovation development
Research Development
Technology Development and Transfer
ICT and Digital Economy Sector
ICT Infrastructure Development and Administration
Electronic government development and Administration
Digital Economy Development and administration
Administration Sectors
Policy and programs
Resources
Policy, regulation and strategy
Guideline and strategy
Plan & reports
Media
News
Press release
Magazine
Gallery
Announcements
MInT Systems
Internal systems
External systems
Notices
Bids
Vacancy
CALL FOR CONCEPT NOTES
Announcement for training opportunity beneficiaries
Ethiopian ecosystem
English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
The Ministry of Innovation and Technology in collaboration with the Southern Cooperation Organization in the coming year Greater southern fair for endogenous technology (GresFET)
He gave an explanation to the ambassadors of the member countries about the fair.
=========
In his explanation, the Minister of Innovation and Technology, Dietta Dr. Baysa, said that the Greater Southern Fair for Endogenous Technology (GresFET) organized by the Southern Cooperation Organization and the Ministry of Innovation and Technology in Dada will be a platform for technology and innovation experts and researchers from different member countries to participate and exchange experience.
Secretary General of the Southern Cooperation Organization, Sheikh Mansoor Bin Musallam, said that in addition to technology buyers and users, we should be creators of the industrial revolution and technology producers by supporting indigenous technologies.
The fair will be held from September 18 to 24/2017 and it is a fair where selected endogenous technologies from 28 member countries including Ethiopia will be presented and promoted.
This endogenous technology exhibition is attended by more than 28 countries and affiliated organizations, where at least three (3) endogenous technology products from each member country will be presented and a total of more than 100 technologists will be on display.
Ministers and other senior government officials of the Southern Cooperation Organization member countries will be present at the event, and it is expected to create favorable conditions for research institutes, universities, private researchers and other communities to contribute to the development of their country.

Most Visited News
17th BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro, Prime Minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed
Attending the 17th BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro and during the opening session on peace and security and global governance, Prime Minister Abiy ...

Innovation Development
Innovation Development
Coordinate, promote and lead the national Business, tech and Research based Innovation and Startup Ecosystem development.
In particular, the unit operates to meet ministryâ€™s goal to enable the Ethiopiaâ€™s startup ecosystem reaching the fourth stage of its life cycle, which would enable Ethiopiaâ€™s startup ecosystem to finally integrate with the global fabrics of knowledge, produce a global business model, and achieve high global market reach in the long run. In the near future, the unit places its priority on the first cycle, which is the activation ecosystem life cycle, which is stifled by challenges such as limited ecosystem experience, challenges of resource leakages to later-stage ecosystems that inhibit growth, and also activation cycle success indicators such as triggering the globalization ecosystem life cycle through multiple startups with 100 million+ USD exits and through national resource attraction in some of our regions, such as Kenyaâ€™s and Nigeriaâ€™s startup ecosystems Among many other activities, the unit technically coordinates Startup Designation Provision Services based on legal and regulatory frameworks.
AtoÂ Selamyhun Adefris
CEO, Innovation Development

áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Technology Development and Transfer
â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
Technology Development and Transfer CEO under the FDRE Ministry of Innovation and Technology (MInT), is dedicated to cultivating a thriving ecosystem for the advancement and exchange of cutting-edge technologies within the nation. The CEO, operates three distinct Desks, each serving a crucial role in this mission. The Technology Transfer and Linkage Desk focuses on fostering partnerships and collaborations to facilitate the transfer of innovative technologies into Ethiopia. The Indigenous innovation and Technology Development Desk is responsible for nurturing homegrown talent and ideas, supporting the development of indigenous technologies that can compete on a global scale. Lastly, the Innovation and Technology Data Development and Management Desk plays a vital role in collecting and analyzing data to drive informed decision-making and strategy development in the tech sector. Together, these three Desks work harmoniously to propel Ethiopia towards a future defined by innovative and technological excellence.
Contact Us
Teklemariam tesema (PhD)
CEO, Technology Development and Transfer

Digital Economy Development
Our primarly responsibility is to build a national digital system that will promote the development of the country's digital economy. We are doing to ensure the practical implementation of digital economy. We are also doing to establish a system that allows them to be fair actors in the digital economy. Ensuring the healthy growth of the digital economy by developing and implementing standards and regulatory frameworks that foster the growth of the digital economy. The role of the community in the development of the digital economy and ensure its benefits. Creating favorable conditions for private sector participation in the digital industry.
Objectives
Ensuring the healthy growth of the digital economy by developing and implementing standards and regulatory frameworks that foster the growth of the digital economy

áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
Electronic Government Development
Developing and implementing an integrated national plan and strategy to transition government services to an integrated digital system at the national level is to ensure good governance. Reviews documents, strategic plans related to e-government, ICT and local governance. Provides guidance, information and feedback. Collects information, collaborates with relevant government agencies, assesses e-Government situation, including opportunities and challenges. Drafting and issuing e-government strategy based on the inputs.
Develops and coordinates data development within federal and regional governmental institutions in cooperation with relevant institutions; Supports the implementation of secure data operations. Provides the necessary professional and technical support for the innovation and technology bureaus of and city administrations to build capacity on data development.
2. Objectives
Coordinate national digital transformation efforts through development of Fast, Reliable and Secure Digital Government Services ensuring the provision of dependable government services and improving ease of doing business.
Coordinate the development of national digital plans, strategies and implementation tools that guide the development and implementation of digital government services and national digital infrastructures.
Coordinate and support the development of national data interoperability, digital data asset administration and open data policies and support their implementation and use in job creation and national development endeavors.
3. Projects and programs
Upgrade, Implementation, Support and Maintenance of Ethiopian eServices Platform.
Upgrading and Expansion of Existing NBP, ODE and eCompliant platforms to Diredawa, Bahir Dar and Adama City Administrations.
Development of E-Gov Strategy and Government Enterprise Architecture.
Implementation of Ethiopian National Data Warehouse
Development of Online Transaction System for Ministries
Document Digitization Service for Federal Supreme Court, DARA and MoJ.
Development of Government Office Modernization Roadmap
Establishment of E-Gov Training Center
4. Â Services requirements and steps to get the services

Official letter
Portal development and support (for Government organization)
Official letter
Government Call Center (Contact Center) services
Official letter
Government SMS Services
Official letter
Mobile App development and support
Official letter
Technical support for ICT development services
Official letter
Capacity Building Services
Need based
Admaswork Mamo Dima

### 641
URL: http://www.mint.gov.et/web/guest/w/the-great-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-project-is-a-demonstration-of-the-results-of-ethiopians-working-together
TITLE: The Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam Project is a demonstration of the results of Ethiopians working together - MINT

+251118132191
contact@mint.gov.et
Font Awesome Icons
Attractive Full-Width Navbar

English
áŠ áˆ›áˆ­áŠ›
The Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam Project is a demonstration of the results of Ethiopians working together
The leadership and staff of the Ministry of Innovation and Technology celebrated the 13th anniversary of the laying of the foundation stone of the Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam Project. They celebrated with the motto. At the event, the Minister of Innovation and Technology Daeta Kbur Baysa Bedada (Dr.) said that the Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam project is a demonstration of the results of Ethiopians working together. They mentioned that the dam is built with all of our money and will be used by all of us to unite Ethiopians, so it is a project that involves all Ethiopians and is seen as a child by all. The minister expressed his gratitude for the support of all Ethiopians at all levels over the years for the dam to become a reality. The minister said that we should bring the growth and prosperity of Ethiopia by applying the active participation and cooperation seen in the Renaissance Dam to other development sectors. At the event, Dr. Ateneh Tesfaye, Chief Executive Officer of the Ministry of Innovation and Technology, presented real-time information on the Renaissance Dam construction project and discussed it with the staff. The chief said that the dam is a mark of the citizens of this era and urged citizens of all levels to strengthen their mark by giving their final support to the dam. In the discussion, the Ministry's staff mentioned that the completion of the Renaissance Dam construction project is expected to be completed and said that the success is a victory of the common history of Africans across the country and it is a mark of this generation.
Anteneh Tesfaye (PhD)

5 million Ethiopian coders
The "5 million Ethiopian coders" initiative is a program that will help our youth to have the appropriate digital skills and create jobs and wealth to fuel the construction of a digital economy. Dr. Bele Mola
=======
Ethiopian coders initiative where fifty million citizens will benefit from digital technology training
It was announced today by the Honorable Prime Minister Dr. Abiy Ahmed.
Speaking at the program, Dr. Bele Mola of the Ministry of Innovation and Technology said that the "5 Million Ethiopian Coders" initiative is a program that will help our youth to have the appropriate digital skills and create jobs and wealth to fuel the construction of a digital economy on a large scale.
The minister said that today, we have reached a new era where technology is not only a work tool but also a change agent.
The Minister also mentioned that the Ethio Coders program will equip young Ethiopians with the skills and knowledge to actively participate in the digital ecosystem, create new opportunities for them and open the door for our country to move forward in the field of technology.
He said that the Ethiocoders program shows the commitment of the government to empower our youth, develop creativity and use the huge potential of the digital age.
He said that one of the important foundations to ensure a digital Ethiopia is building the digital ecosystem and digital skills are an important starting point to use the economy and provide services in the construction of a digital economy.
"Coding is not just about writing lines of code. Coding is about problem solving, critical thinking and creativity." The minister said, "When we equip our youth with coding skills, they can confidently join the wider digital world and use applications created by others, but they can also benefit the country and make people's lives easier." He said that it is important to realize that the way is being facilitated for them to be able to develop many applications on their own.
Send feedback

A delegation from Kagool,
A delegation from Kagool, a leading global data and analytics group, and Micro Tech London visited Ethiopia to assess opportunities in the Information Technology as well as Emerging Technologies sectors.
The delegation have had successful meetings with Minister of Innovation and Technology, Director Generals for Information Network Security Agency, and Artificial Intelligence Institute, CEO for ICT Park, Director General for Ethiopian Diaspora Agency, as well as representatives of Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs.
With the understanding of Ethiopias growing competitiveness and governmentâ€™s commitment to harness opportunities in the sector, the delegation has decided to continue partnership with Government in the sector.
The decision by Kagool to open its regional delivery center in Addis Ababa will bring the latest digital transformation and AI capabilities into Ethiopia and across Africa using Addis at its gateway.

ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò›Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò›Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ XIX Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ±ĞµĞ»Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ± Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞºĞµĞ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ´Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ ÑÑ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ±ĞµÑˆ Ñ‘ÑˆĞ´Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğº Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½, Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑÑ…ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½, Ğ±ĞµĞ²Ğ¾ÑĞ¸Ñ‚Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ³Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ° ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° 10 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸Ğ¼ ÑÑˆĞ°Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ÑĞ¸ ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¼ĞºĞ¸Ğ½. ĞĞ¹Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ ÑˆĞ°Ñ…Ñ ÑÑƒÑ€ÑƒĞ½ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ò› ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¼ĞºĞ¸Ğ½ ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ñ.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ ÑƒĞ¼ÑƒĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ¹, Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ğ³ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½-Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ² Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸ Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ· Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¹ÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ ĞµÑ‚Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸. ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±ĞµĞ»Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞ· Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ± Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ò› Ñ‚ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸, Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ´ĞµĞ¿ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸, Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ ÑˆÑƒÒ“ÑƒĞ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¼ĞºĞ¸Ğ½ ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ñ.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑˆĞ°Ñ…ÑĞ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ñ…Ğ»ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ·Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸:
1) Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑÑ€ĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¾Ñ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ÑÑƒĞ²ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµÑ‚Ğ¸, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑ…Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞºĞ°Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€, Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑĞ·Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ€ÑƒÑ€ Ñ‡Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°-Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ĞºÑÑ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
2) Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞºĞ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ½Ğ¾ÑĞ°Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸Ñˆ ĞºÑÑ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
3) Ğ¼ÑƒĞ·Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸, Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°, Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ±ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¾Ñ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸;
4) ÑĞ· Ò³ÑƒĞ·ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ°ĞºĞºÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ´Ğ°Ğ½ ÑÑ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‡ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‡Ğ°Ò›Ğ¸Ñ€ÑƒĞ² Ñ‘Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
5) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³ÑƒĞ·ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ò³Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
6) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞºĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆÒ›Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑĞ½Ğ³ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑĞ·Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼ÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ³Ğ°;
7) Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¾ ÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‚ÑƒĞ³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸, ÑˆÑƒ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ€ Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºĞµĞ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
8) Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
9) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ’Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ĞœĞ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ°ÑŠĞ·Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÒšĞ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑŠÒ›ÑƒĞ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞµĞ¹Ğ¸Ğ½ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
10) Ò›ÑĞ¼Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€, Ğ°Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ò³Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ° Ğ¼ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ¸Ò› Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
11) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ñˆ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ĞºÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ò²Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ± Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑŠÒ›ÑƒĞ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞµĞ¹Ğ¸Ğ½ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
12) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆÑƒĞ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞµĞ¹Ğ¸Ğ½ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ”Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
13) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑĞ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ¡ÑƒĞ´ÑŒÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€ĞºĞ¸Ğ±Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞœĞ°Ñ€ĞºĞ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ½ĞºĞ¸ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ°Ñ€ÑƒĞ²Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸, Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ñ€ÑƒĞ¿Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ñ€ÑˆĞ¸ ĞºÑƒÑ€Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ò³Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ñ€ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ò³Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
14) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ¡ÑƒĞ´ÑŒÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚ ÑˆĞ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ€ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸Ñ ÑÑ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ±Ğ¾ÑĞ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ò²Ğ°Ñ€Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
15) Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚ ÑˆĞ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸. ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑĞ½Ğ¸, Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑƒĞ·Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼ ÑˆĞ°ÑŠĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ´Ñ€-Ò›Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ò“ Ñ‚ÑƒÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ…Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ¸-Ò³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€ ÑÑ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ²Ğ° ÑˆĞ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞ· Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ¸;
16) Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¾ ÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò³ÑƒĞ¶Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑÑ…Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸, Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¾Ñ€ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸; ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ’Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ĞœĞ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğº Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ¸;
17) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑÑŠĞ»Ğ¾Ğ½ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸; Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ· ÑÑŠÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºÑ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ³Ğ° Ò›ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ¸;
18) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ò³ÑƒĞ¶ÑƒĞ¼ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ¾Ğ²ÑƒĞ·Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€-Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑĞ·Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ±ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ€ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒÒ“Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒÑ€ÑƒÑˆ Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸, ÑƒĞ¼ÑƒĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ Ò›Ğ¸ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½ ÑĞ°Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº ÑÑŠĞ»Ğ¾Ğ½ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ ĞºÑƒĞ½ Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
19) Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° (Ñ€ĞµĞ°Ğ» Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆÒ›Ğ¸ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„, Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ±ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ñ€, Ğ¹Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğº Ò³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ñ‚, Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚, ÑĞ¿Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ¼Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€) Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑĞ·Ğ»Ğ°Ğ±, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ±ÑƒÑ‚ÑƒĞ½ Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ¶Ğ¾Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ²Ò›ÑƒĞ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¶Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ ĞºÑƒĞ½ Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸. Ğ¤Ğ°Ğ²Ò›ÑƒĞ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¶Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±ĞµĞ»Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
20) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ÒšÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸ ĞšÑƒÑ‡Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ñˆ Ò›ÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸, ÒšÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸ ĞšÑƒÑ‡Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ò›ÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸, Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ò³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑƒĞ½Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
21) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸, Ğ¼ĞµĞ´Ğ°Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‘Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼ÑƒĞºĞ¾Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ñ…Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑƒĞ½Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
22) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¿Ğ°Ğ½Ğ° Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ´ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
23) Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ò³ÑƒĞ¶Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³Ğ°Ò›Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ò³ÑƒĞºĞ¼ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ÑˆĞ°Ñ…ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ñ„Ğ² ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
24) ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ò³ÑƒĞ·ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¥Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒĞ½Ğ³Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸, ÑĞ· Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò›ÑĞ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞĞ´Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ò³ÑƒĞ·ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚-ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑˆĞ°ĞºĞ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸;
25) ÑƒÑˆĞ±Ñƒ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸Ñ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ğ½Ğ°Ğ·Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞ· Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½ÑĞ°Ğ±Ğ´Ğ¾Ñ€ ÑˆĞ°Ñ…ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¿ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ñ.
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑĞ³Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ± Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¾ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑĞ·Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ±ÑƒÑ‚ÑƒĞ½ Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ±ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ³Ğ° Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€, Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¹Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
ÒšĞ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ñ‘ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€ĞºĞ¸Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ» Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ò³Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ´ ÑĞ¾Ğ»ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸Ñ…Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ÑĞ· Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‘Ñ…ÑƒĞ´ ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ½ĞµÑ‡Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ´ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ´Ğ°, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº ÒšĞ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚ ÑÑ€Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ» Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ò³Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ´ ÑĞ¾Ğ»ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ğ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸Ñ…Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ÑĞ· Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑĞ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑƒĞ´Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÒšĞ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸, Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ± ÑĞ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¼ĞºĞ¸Ğ½.

ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞĞ´Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞĞ´Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ 2018 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 26 Ğ°Ğ²Ğ³ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ "ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ĞĞ´Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°"Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¤Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ¸Ò› Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ±, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ñ…Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‚-Ñ‚Ğ°Ò³Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ½Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€.
ĞĞ´Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸:
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑĞ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸, ÑˆÑƒ Ğ¶ÑƒĞ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞºĞµĞ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ´Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ ÑÑ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ±ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞºÑĞ¼Ğ°ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ñˆ;
Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹-ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ò³Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ;
Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›-Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸, Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ› Ğ²Ğ° ÑÑ€ĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¾Ñ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ³Ğ° ĞºÑĞ¼Ğ°ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ñˆ, Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ·Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ¸Ò›Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ;
Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞºĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆÒ›Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¹ÑĞ½Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑˆĞ°ĞºĞ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, ÑÑƒĞ²ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ·Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ, ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑ…Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ±ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ»Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ± Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò›Ğ¸Ñˆ;
Ğ°Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò› Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ»Ğ¾Ò›Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò› Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğ»Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ¶Ğ¸ÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° ÑÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ğº ÑˆĞ°Ñ…ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸ Ñ€ÑÑ‘Ğ±Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚-ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ÑÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ;
Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ´ĞµĞ¼Ğ¾ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò› Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¿Ğ¾ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ÑˆĞ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑĞ·Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ;
ĞºĞ°Ğ´Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ´ ÑĞ³Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ° Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ;
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ, ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° ĞºÑĞ¼Ğ°ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ¸Ñˆ;
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ò³ÑƒĞ·ÑƒÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº, ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° ĞºÑĞ¼Ğ°ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ° ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ» ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ;

Ğ¨Ğ°Ğ²ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‡ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² 1957 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 24 Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ´Ğ° Ğ–Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ·Ğ°Ñ… Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ—Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑˆĞ¸Ñ„Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾Ñ€ Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‚ÑƒÒ“Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½. ĞœĞ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ â€“ ÑĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞº. ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑŠĞ»ÑƒĞ¼Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸, 1981 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ñ€Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾Ò› Ñ…ÑĞ¶Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½. ĞœÑƒÒ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ-Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¼ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ…Ğ°ÑÑĞ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ³Ğ°. Ğ¢ĞµÑ…Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸, Ğ´Ğ¾Ñ†ĞµĞ½Ñ‚.
ĞœĞµÒ³Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ 1981 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ñ€Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾Ò› Ñ…ÑĞ¶Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ±, ĞºĞ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼, ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ° ÑÒ›Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒĞ²Ñ‡Ğ¸, Ğ´Ğ¾Ñ†ĞµĞ½Ñ‚, ÑÒ›ÑƒĞ² Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ° Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€ĞµĞºÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
1990 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¡Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ´ĞµĞ¿ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ±, Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ°Ò›Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ° ĞœĞ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¸ÑĞ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ ĞºÑÑ€ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ¸.
1992 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚ ÑˆĞ°Ò³Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¾ Ğ£Ğ»ÑƒÒ“Ğ±ĞµĞº Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸. 1996-2001 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ğ–Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ·Ğ°Ñ… Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸, 2001-2003 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¡Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ±, Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ·ĞºÑƒÑ€ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ° Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑĞ° Ò›ÑÑˆĞ´Ğ¸.
Ğ˜Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¾ Ò³Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ° 1995-2003 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ´ĞµĞ¿ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ¸Ğ¹, Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ğ´ĞµĞ¼Ğ¾ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½ Ò³ÑƒĞ¶Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ± Ñ‡Ğ¸Ò›Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‘Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ» Ğ¸ÑˆÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğº ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ±, ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´Ğ¸.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² 2003 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ± Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑƒÑˆĞ±Ñƒ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ½Ğ° ÑƒÑ‡ Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ° â€“ 2005, 2010, 2015 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ò›Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ¼ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ° ÑÑ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸Ğ»Ğº Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ğ± ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ‘Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ˜ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ ĞšĞ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğº Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ±, ÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑÒ›Ğ¸Ğ½ ÑĞ°Ñ„Ğ´Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ò›Ğ´Ğ°.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ò²ÑƒĞºÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ¸Ò“Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³ ĞºÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ´ĞµÑ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° ÑĞ½Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ, Ğ¹Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ± Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¹Ğ¸Ò³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ò³Ğ°Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¶Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ñ…ÑƒÑÑƒÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ»ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ ÑƒÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ° ĞºĞ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğº Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ½ĞµÑ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ…ÑƒÑÑƒÑĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑƒĞ»ÑƒÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºĞµÑĞºĞ¸Ğ½ Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò³ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÒ›Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ò³Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ´Ğ° ÑĞ·Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğº ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¸Ñ€ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ò›Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ½ ÑÑ‚Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞœĞ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ´ÑƒÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ» Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑĞºÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‚ ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ°Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ€ ÑĞ¾Ò³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ±Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¸Ò›ÑĞ°, Ñ„ĞµÑ€Ğ¼ĞµÑ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ò³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ò›Ò›Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ò›Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾Ò› Ñ…ÑĞ¶Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò³ÑÑƒĞ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‡ÑƒÒ›ÑƒÑ€ Ò›Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ° Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñˆ, Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸Ò›-Ğ¾Ğ²Ò›Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ°Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºĞ°Ñ„Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ°Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò³ÑÑƒĞ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑƒÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° ÑÑŠÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ¸.
Ğ®Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‡Ğ° Ò³ÑƒĞ´ÑƒĞ´Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒĞ»ĞºĞ°Ğ½ Ğ±ÑƒĞ½Ñ‘Ğ´ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ°Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ¼ÑƒĞ½Ğ°Ğ» Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ ĞºÑÑ€ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ñ€ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑˆĞ°Ò³Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸, Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¸Ò›ÑĞ°, ÑƒĞ·Ğ¾Ò› Ò›Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾Ò› Ñ‚ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞºÑ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ°Ò³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ¼ÑƒÑˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼ĞµÒ³Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ±Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½ ÑÑ…ÑˆĞ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³ ĞºÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ´Ğ¸.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° ÑĞ¾Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ»-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¼, Ñ„Ğ°Ğ½, ÑĞ¾Ò“Ğ»Ğ¸Ò›Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ°ÑĞ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ñ‘ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ ÑĞ¾Ò“Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ» Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ± Ğ²Ğ¾ÑĞ³Ğ° ĞµÑ‚Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ½Ğ¾ÑĞ¸Ğ± ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚-ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ÑÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ, Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ·Ğ° Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñˆ ÑƒÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ° ÑĞ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¸Ğ¼ ÑÑ€Ğ¸Ğ½ ÑĞ³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.
ĞĞ·Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ·Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ± Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°Ò³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ½ÑƒÑ„ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº, Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ° Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ°Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ´ĞµĞ¼Ğ¾ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»Ğ± ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ´Ğ° ÑƒĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ²Ò›ĞµĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ, Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼Ğ°ÑŠĞ½Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ò›Ğ°Ğ´Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑÑŠĞ·Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ·Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ» Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑÒ›Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° ÑÑŠÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ¸.
ÒšĞ°Ğ¹Ğ´ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´Ğ°, Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ¶Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ´Ğ° Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€, ÑˆÑƒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³Ğ´ĞµĞº, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ò³Ğ°Ñ€ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ° ÑĞ·Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¾Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ñ„Ğ°Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ĞºĞµĞ»Ğ¸ÑˆÑƒĞ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ° ÑÑ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ÑˆĞ´Ğ° Ğ±ĞµĞ²Ğ¾ÑĞ¸Ñ‚Ğ° Ñ€Ğ°Ò³Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ´Ğ¸.
2016 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 8 ÑĞµĞ½Ñ‚ÑĞ±Ñ€ÑŒ ĞºÑƒĞ½Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ ĞœĞ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸ ÒšĞ¾Ğ½ÑƒĞ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¡ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò›ÑÑˆĞ¼Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ò›ÑÑˆĞ¼Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒĞ²Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ¸Ò› ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ° Ğ²Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ°Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ° ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑĞºĞ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸.
19 Ğ¾ĞºÑ‚ÑĞ±Ñ€ÑŒ ĞºÑƒĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ¢Ğ¾ÑˆĞºĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¢Ğ°Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸ÑˆĞ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ â€” ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ›Ğ¸Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ»-Ğ´ĞµĞ¼Ğ¾ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ VIII ÑÑŠĞµĞ·Ğ´Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ± ÑÑ‚Ğ´Ğ¸. Ğ£Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¨Ğ°Ğ²ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‡ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ° Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ´Ğ¸Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ñˆ Ñ‚ÑÒ“Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ğ±ÑƒĞ» Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸. 2016 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 4 Ğ´ĞµĞºĞ°Ğ±Ñ€ ĞºÑƒĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ± ÑÑ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚ ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸ ÑĞºÑƒĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ 88,61 Ñ„Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ± ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸. 2016 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 14 Ğ´ĞµĞºĞ°Ğ±Ñ€Ğ´Ğ° Ñ€Ğ°ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½ ÑĞ· Ğ²Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ„Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ´Ğ¸.
2021 Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ» 24 Ğ¾ĞºÑ‚ÑĞ±Ñ€ÑŒ ĞºÑƒĞ½Ğ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ¨Ğ°Ğ²ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ 80,1 Ñ„Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ğ±ĞµÑˆ Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ° Ò›Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ° ÑĞ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸, Ğ¸ĞºĞºĞ¸ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ·, Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ ÑÒ“Ğ»Ğ¸, Ğ¾Ğ»Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€. Ğ Ğ°Ñ„Ğ¸Ò›Ğ°ÑĞ¸ Ğ—.Ğœ. ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ²Ğ° â€“ Ğ¼ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ…Ğ°ÑÑĞ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ¹Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ° Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ñ‡Ğ¸.
Ğ¨.Ğœ.ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ² Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆÒ›Ğ°Ñ€ÑƒĞ² Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ ĞºÑĞ¿ Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµÒ³Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸, ÑÑ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ· Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°Ò›Ğ¸, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ· Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğ»Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° ÑƒĞ»ĞºĞ°Ğ½ Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑĞ° Ò›ÑÑˆĞ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Â«ĞœĞµÒ³Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚ ÑˆÑƒÒ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Â» Ğ²Ğ° Â«Ğ¤Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ° Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½Â» Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½.

Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‘Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ°, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò› Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ°, Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº ÑĞ°Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ Ò›Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ ÑƒĞ»ĞºĞ°Ğ½ Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Ğ¼ÑƒĞºĞ¾Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€.

Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑĞºÑĞ°Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ³Ğ°, Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ° Ò›ÑƒĞ´Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ…Ğ°Ğ²Ñ„ÑĞ¸Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑŠĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ³Ğ°, Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ´Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ°Ñ€Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸, Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¶Ğ¸Ò³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ³Ğ°, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò› Ñ„Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ³Ğ° ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ° Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑĞ° Ò›ÑÑˆĞ³Ğ°Ğ½, ÑĞ·Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ¸ÑÑ‚ĞµÑŠĞ´Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸, Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¶Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ’Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ· Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°Ò›Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ° Ğ±Ğ°Ñ…Ñˆ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ±, Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¹Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼ÑƒĞ½Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ĞºÑÑ€ÑĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ± ĞºĞµĞ»Ğ°Ñ‘Ñ‚Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½ Ñ„ÑƒÒ›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ…Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ¼ÑƒĞºĞ¾Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸.â€‹
ĞĞ·Ğ±ĞµĞºĞ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¸ ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¨Ğ°Ğ²ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ ĞœĞ¸Ñ€Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ‘ĞµĞ²
ĞºĞµĞ½Ğ³ ĞºÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑĞ¸Ñ‘ÑĞ¸Ğ¹-Ğ¸Ò›Ñ‚Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¸ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ò³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ³Ğ° Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ñ€Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸, Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ°Ò›Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° ÑÑ…ÑˆĞ¸ Ò›ÑÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¼ÑƒÒ³Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ²Ğ° Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ½Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ´Ğ° ĞµÑ‚Ğ°ĞºÑ‡Ğ¸ Ğ±ÑĞ»Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸, Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ ÑÑ€Ñ‚Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹-Ğ³ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾Ò›Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ°Ò³ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ»Ğ°ÑˆĞ³Ğ° ĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ° Ò³Ğ¸ÑÑĞ° Ò›ÑÑˆĞ³Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑƒÑ‡ÑƒĞ½ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€ Ò³Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ° Ñ…Ğ°Ğ»Ò›Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ°ÑˆĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ³ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€ Ò›Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´ĞµĞ½ Ğ²Ğ° Ñ„Ğ°Ñ…Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑƒĞ½Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ»Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½ Ğ¼ÑƒĞºĞ¾Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½.
